From:	Kathy Calvert <Kathyscalvert@bellsouth.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 12:23 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	FW: APD/Education System/IQ Testing

Dear Governor Bush,

I don't know if you had anything to do with this or not but, you can imagine
my surprise when I just opened up a certified letter from the Agency for
Persons with Disabilities that says that Kara has now been placed on the
waiting list for the Waiver Program.  I'm not sure what the change in
philosophy was but, if you had anything to do with it, thank you.  If you
didn't, then I just wanted to let you know that, somehow, that part of our
concern has been taken care of.

I have also learned, since I e-mailed you, that the "disability labels" are
being looked into as well as the IQ testing in Duval County.  I will
continue to share my concerns with those who need to hear them and can
effect change.

Sincerely,

Kathy Calvert

-----Original Message-----
From: Kathy Calvert [mailto:Kathyscalvert@bellsouth.net]
Sent: Wednesday, July 12, 2006 3:06 PM
To: jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Subject: APD/Education System/IQ Testing


Dear Governor Bush,

It was a pleasure meeting you at the Family Café a few weeks ago.  I was so
very impressed with the Conference, but most importantly, the willingness
from so many State officials to listen and respond to questions, sometimes
very difficult questions, from so many parents.  Thank you for the
opportunity given to us to attend the conference and also for the openness
of so many.

To give you a quick background of our situation, our daughter, Kara is 3 ½
years old and was born with Down syndrome.  She also had many medical issues
as she was in intensive care for 4 ½ months at birth (she contracted a
hospital-acquired super-bug infection which almost took her life).

As we began the process to transition from the Early Steps Program into the
school system, Kara was given an IQ test (at the age of 2½).  Now, I
questioned the validity and reliability of this test and was told that it
was just one of the measures that was used so we consented.  Lo and behold,
we are then told that our daughter is LABELED “Trainably Mentally
Handicapped” (what an archaic, demeaning term) and that she would be placed
in the TMH Program.  We negotiated for her to be placed in a Physically
Impaired Program instead and that is where she has been (we’re very pleased
with this program).  We were told, “That is fine but we still have to put
Trainably Mentally Handicapped as her primary label” (again, so demeaning).

We sent in an application a couple of months ago for the Waiver Program and
had our meeting right after the Family Café with the Human Service Program
Analyst.  Just recently, I received a letter stating that, “You have been
determined to be at high risk for a developmental disability as defined in
Section 393.063 (12), F.S. children with this diagnosis, however, are not
eligible for the DS/HCBS waiver program”.  I called and received a very
prompt return call.  The reason that I was told that Kara didn’t qualify for
the med waiver is due to the IQ testing that was done (the Agency for
Persons with Disabilities evidently doesn’t use the IQ testing until a child
reaches the age of five or six).  I was told that we could apply again when
she turns five and another IQ test is completed.  I don’t understand the
reasoning behind this.

My comment is:  “The State of Florida uses an IQ test to label and place
children into programs at the age of 2½ but then turn around and say that
this test is NOT valid/reliable to use to qualify for the Med Waiver”.
There is something wrong, in my opinion, with this apparent conflict between
two State agencies.  If one agency utilizes the testing and says it’s
“valid/reliable” but the other agency doesn’t use it…hmmmm????  Also, I
believe that children with Down syndrome should automatically qualify to be
put on the Med Waiver just as other children with varying diagnoses are.

Thank you for your time and consideration of this information.  Our daughter
has been through a lot and, as you can tell, we’re not one for “labeling”.
We believe, wholeheartedly, that we should help our daughter “reach for the
stars and accept the moon”.  Labels placed on her do not help her to achieve
that.

I can be reached at 904-731-9897 if needed.

Sincerely,

Kathy Calvert, M.Ed., Ed.S.
Kara Calvert’s Mom


From:	jennifer Dorning <jenniferdorning@yahoo.com>

Subject:	LOCAL SHELL FISH EPIDEMIC DECLARED BY LEE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT

More evidence of water problems in Lee County:
 
On Behalf Of City 
of
Sanibel
Sent: Tuesday, July 18, 2006 11:57 AM
To: Orv Curry
Subject: LOCAL SHELL FISH EPIDEMIC DECLARED BY LEE COUNTY HEALTH
DEPARTMENT

LOCAL SHELL FISH EPIDEMIC
DECLARED BY LEE COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT

Lee County Health Department
Epidemiology and Communicable Disease Control Services Illness of 
Public
Health Concern Tuesday, July 18, 2006 - Second Notice In July, 11 cases
of neurotoxic shellfish poisoning have been reported in Lee County Ten
on Sanibel Island and one at Fort Myers Beach All patients were 
visitors
who consumed shellfish that they harvested from the local waters Six
cases required hospital intervention This constitutes a local epidemic
of this illness The Health Department is requesting that all businesses
and real estate offices that rent to visitors post a warning DO NOT TO
COLLECT SHELLFISH IN LOCAL WATERS DUE TO NEUROTOXIC CONTAMINATION This
should warning should be placed in each unit that has a kitchen area
Symptoms of this illness include numbness, tingling in the extremities,
temperature reversal, GI symptoms, difficulty in speaking and walking.
People experiencing these symptoms after ingestion of self-harvested
shellfish should immediately seek medical care.
Health Department Contact:
J. Robert South, Ph.D., M.P.H., PA-C.
Biological Administrator / Epidemiologist Epidemiology and Communicable
Disease Control Service Lee County Health Department - 3920 Michigan
Avenue - Fort Myers, Florida 33916
Phone: (239) 332-9657 - SunCom: 743-1657 - Secure Fax: (239) 332-9553



Note: forwarded message attached. 


Jennifer Dorning
16580 S. Oleander Dr.
Fort Myers, FL 33908

From:	Tim Slocum <tslocum1@cox.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 11:42 AM
To:	Gainesville City Commission
Cc:	Gainesville City Manager
Subject:	[*] Gainesville Regional Utilities Rate Increases

I am writing to you in hopes that you will reject Gainesville Regional Utilities recent request for a record 13.4% increase in our utility rates. I've lived here 20 years with my family and every year our GRU bill has steadily increased. Now, it's getting to the point that paying this bill is getting more and more difficult. If this keeps up, we're going to be unable to afford to live in Gainesville. It does no good to conserve when our bill keeps going up with across the board rate increases each and every year, and now GRU is proposing a double digit rate increase this year and has already stated future rate increases are on the way. Where does this stop? We're not made of money. Together, me and my mom can barely afford to live here as it is. I suspect a lot of low income and poor people are going to be unable to pay their utility bills when this huge increase goes forward. I live on a low income so I know how they feel. I watched a lady stand before you at last week's commission meeting and pleaded with you to do something to address this, but it was apparent that most, if not all of you have already made up your minds and this excessive across the board rate increase is a done deal. You do have it in your power to reject their request for a rate increase and make them go back and look at their budget. I'm sure there are a lot of areas in GRU's budget where spending could be reduced and/or funding could be cut. It's better for them to make cuts to their budget than to have than make us pay double digit across the board rate increases each year. If you are unwilling or unable to say no to Gainesville Regional Utilities's request for rate increases each time they request across the board increases like this in their budget, then perhaps it's time our state officials become involved to address this situation. What ever happened to deregulation? I thought this concept was supposed to lower our utility bills, but it seems like all it has done is increase our bills more and more each year. And since GRU has a monopoly on our local utilities, they can charge whatever they want. I hope somewhere, someone can do something to stop these excessive rate increases, or a lot of lower income people are not going to be able to pay these bills. It's that simple. Maybe it's time our state officials look into local utilities like GRU and try to find out why they are charging excessive across the board rate increases and why they keep proposing future rate increases to the point that a lot of low income people and even some middle income people will be unable to pay these bills in the future.

State lawmakers are offering more than 500 bills this year targeting 
state-mandated services, illegal aliens and the employers who hire them, 
responding to a growing chorus of public opinion nationwide calling for 
stricter enforcement of immigration laws.
    Led by Georgia, where benefits for illegal aliens were cut and stiff 
sanctions placed on employers who hire illegals, and by Colorado, which 
banned nonemergency services to those in the country illegally, at least 39 
states have either proposed or passed similar legislation.
    Lawmakers have focused on constituency concerns regarding an estimated 
10 million to 12 million illegal aliens now in the country, resulting in 
rising costs for education and medical care, higher crime rates and 
exploitation by employers.
    Georgia lawmakers passed and Gov. Sonny Perdue, a Republican, signed 
legislation this year requiring adults seeking benefits to prove their U.S. 
citizenship, sanctioning employers who hire illegals and requiring companies 
with state contracts to check employees' legal status. The Georgia laws also 
require police to check the legal status of people they arrest.
    The bill's author, state Sen. Chip Rogers, called it "the strongest 
single bill in America dealing with illegal immigration -- bar none." He 
told The Washington Times that it was intended to send a message that "while 
the federal government is not enforcing its immigration laws, the state of 
Georgia takes those laws seriously."
    In Colorado, new legislation requires employers to show that new hires 
are in the country legally and makes it a felony for an illegal to vote. It 
also put two measures on the November ballot: one barring employers from 
receiving state tax assistance if they hire illegals and another allowing 
the state attorney general to sue the U.S. government to force compliance 
with immigration laws.
    "If they've been taking benefits illegally, that's wrong," said Gov. 
Bill Owens, a Republican who worked with House Speaker Andrew Romanoff and 
Senate President Joan Fitz-Gerald, both Democrats, to pass the legislation.
    With federal immigration reform stalled on Capitol Hill, several states 
are proposing their own laws. More than 500 bills have been introduced this 
year covering a variety of topics, including employment, access to public 
benefits and voting rights, according to the National Conference of State 
Legislatures.
    The conference said 57 bills were passed this year, while others were 
vetoed and several more are awaiting gubernatorial action.
    Other bills were passed in Arizona and Illinois, where U.S. citizenship 
or legal immigrant status is required to receive health benefits. Kansas 
will only provide unemployment benefits to citizens and those with legal 
immigration status, Wyoming bars noncitizens and nonlegal permanent 
residents from state scholarships, and New Hampshire requires proof of 
citizenship to register to vote.
    In Louisiana, a new law allows any state agency to investigate a 
contractor's hiring policies if the employment of illegal aliens is 
suspected and says prosecutors can issue an order to fire the illegals and 
fine those employers who do not comply.
    Other bills were passed in Pennsylvania, which prohibits illegal aliens 
on projects financed by grants or loans from the state; Tennessee, which 
bars companies from state contracts for a year after they hired illegal 
aliens; Missouri, which prohibits learner's permits, driver's licenses or 
renewal licenses to people illegally in the country; and Virginia, where 
students with temporary or student visa status are ineligible for in-state 
tuition.
    Several bills also were vetoed, including in Arizona, where lawmakers in 
the Republican-controlled Legislature sought to criminalize illegal entry 
and allow trespassers to be prosecuted. They were vetoed by Gov. Janet 
Napolitano, a Democrat.
    Federal law requires states to provide some services to illegal aliens, 
including education and emergency medical care, but not other services, 
including continued health care and unemployment benefits.

SATURDAY JULY 14,  2006
A PRESS RELEASE FOR THE RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF FLORIDA
 
 
Honors to go to Florida’s Parents of the Year 2006
 
Dr. Peter and Patricia Kuhlman
of  Ponte Vedra Beach
 

Florida Parents’ Day Council

The National Parents' Day Council is a project of the American Family Coalition Inc. 
MailScanner has detected a possible fraud attempt from "www.americanfamilycoalition.org" claiming to be www.americanfamilycoaliton.org 
 
Contact: Robert Ouellette, 4162 Saunders Drive  -  Middleburg, FL 32068  

Phone: (904) 874-0849 / Fax: (291)4620 (notify before  faxing)

robertouellette@bellsouth.net
 
 
Mothers have Mother’s Day and Fathers have Father’s Day, in spite of this Florida will also honor outstanding fathers and mothers working as a team when it observes National Parents’ Day this year.  While it's easy to focus on our country's problems, the fact is that our nation's parents are an enormous national resource to be appreciated and strengthened.
National Parents’ Day was established in 1994 by unanimous Joint Resolution (#236) of the United States Congress.  It is celebrated on the 4th Sunday of July each year, throughout the nation, to recognize and support the important role that parents play in providing for the health and well being of their children and society.
Candidates are selected by their example of love and commitment to their children, each other and by their involvement in their community. They are often nominated by their schools, churches, and organizations or just by people in the community who know them.  
This year’s couple chosen as Florida’s Parents of the year is Dr. Peter and Patricia Kuhlman of Ponte Vedra Beach. The Kuhlman’s were chosen for their outstanding parenting, community involvement and their love and compassion for all people. In fact the entire family gets involved in community service. Congratulations to the Kuhlman family
 
Florida Parents’ Day Coalition:
4162 Saunders Drive  -  Middleburg, FL 32068

Phone: (904) 874-0849 / Fax: (291)4620 (notify before  faxing)

robertouellette@bellsouth.net
 
 
Parents’ Day Celebrations – Join us in making Parents’ Day – the fourth Sunday of each July – a special day to uplift parenthood. Whether it is your city council, civic organization, or church congregation, make sure that your community taps into this important day of commemoration
 
For Immediate Release
Office of the Press Secretary
July 13, 2006 
 
 
Parents' Day, 2006 
A Proclamation by the President of the United States of America 
As a child's first teachers, mentors, and role models, parents shape the character of those who will help to build the future of our Nation. On Parents' Day, we pay tribute to the hard work and sacrifice of the millions of devoted parents who provide guidance, support, and unconditional love to their children. 
Mothers and fathers help kindle imaginations, inspire a love of learning, nurture the formation of young minds, and give children the courage and the drive to realize their dreams. By instilling in children the difference between right and wrong, parents guide their children toward developing into successful adults and responsible citizens who lead lives of purpose. In addition, the commitment of parents to the welfare of young people strengthens families and communities throughout our great country. 
My Administration supports grants and programs to promote healthy marriages and responsible fatherhood. The No Child Left Behind Act is helping us ensure that every child has the opportunity to learn, and recognizes that parental involvement is a vital part of the success of schools across America. Federal, State, and local programs, and faith-based and community groups provide additional resources to help parents as they work to raise children of conviction and character. 
On this special day, we express our deep gratitude to parents for their dedication to a bright and hopeful future for their children. We also pray for parents in the military who stand up for America, and we resolve that their sacrifice will always be honored by a grateful Nation. 
NOW, THEREFORE, I, GEORGE W. BUSH, President of the United States of America, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and laws of the United States and consistent with Public Law 103-362, as amended, do hereby proclaim Sunday, July 23, 2006, as Parents' Day. I call upon citizens, private organizations, and governmental bodies at all levels to engage in activities and educational efforts that recognize, support, and honor parents, and I encourage American sons and daughters to convey their love, respect, and appreciation to their parents. 
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand this twelfth day of July, in the year of our Lord two thousand six, and of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and thirty-first. 
GEORGE W. BUSH

From:	Andrea Lipinsky <andrea.lipinsky@teenchallenge.cc>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 10:32 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; andercrenshaw@mail.house.gov; john.mica@mail.house.gov; bill.mccollum@mail.house.gov; ask.adam@mail.house.gov; katherine.harris@mail.house.gov; mark.foley@mail.house.gov; 'alcee.'
Subject:	Access To Recovery

July 6, 2006

 

To Whom It May Concern: 

 

We are writing to urge you to support the inclusion of funding for one of the most important programs created to help individuals overcome drugs and alcohol addiction. We are concerned that it appears that funding for this program—called Access to Recovery---has been cut from the 2007 Appropriations bill by the House Subcommittee dealing with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) budget.  The HHS FY 2007 request for the Access to Recovery program was $70 million. 

 

The Access to Recovery Program is administered by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA). ATR was created to increase the nation’s capacity to address substance abuse by increasing the number and types of providers, including faith-based providers, who deliver clinical treatment and/or recovery support services, and to allow individual to pursue recovery through many different and personal pathways. Because it directly empowers consumers by using vouchers, it allows them to choose the secular or faith-based provider that meets their needs without creating issues of church/state relationships, and it does not favor one kind over another.

 

We urge you to vote to restore this funding, which will affect the lives of thousands of individuals addicted to drugs and alcohol!

 

Yours sincerely,

 
Andrea K. Lipinsky
ATR/TANF Administrator
Central Florida Teen Challenge
(407) 330-9600 Ext. 307
(407) 330-0407 Fax

From:	Patrick O'Neill PhD <patrickoneillphd@cox.net>

Subject:	Sex Education for Children

Dear ACLU,
Although I am gay, I strongly disagree with your stance regarding parental approval of sex education in schools, especially the current case in Massachusetts.
Parents know better than your organization, governmental agencies, attorneys and judges, etc., when the children in their families can understand sex, sexuality and the freedoms / responsibilities associated with such.
Children of each generation have newly regarded peer pressures to be concerned, not only the traditional values associated with sexual preference.  Parents of those children probably know them on a 24 / 7 basis, not only during hours of school attendance.
School officials should receive parental approval before introducing sex education into the school curriculum.
Thanking you in advance for your immediate attention to this matter,
I remain...
Patrick W. O'Neill, PhD

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Devitt Harrison 
To: 'Olson, Steve' 
Cc: 'Coto, Cindy' ; 'Orth, James C' ; 'Lewis, Marsha N.' ; 'Trudy' ; 'Bill Belleville' ; 'Missynlas' ; LegalSandy@aol.com ; lroberts@orlandosentinel.com ; 'Don Browning' ; captainron@aol.com ; FBruno@co.volusia.fl.us ; 'Florida Hometown Democracy' ; jeb.bush@myflorida.com ; 'Kelli McGee' ; lovebergs@comcast.net ; mgreeson@co.volusia.fl.us ; 'Richard A. Markle' ; 'Pat Northey' ; sospeoplesrights@earthlink.net ; tara.alford@fwc.state.fl.us ; wkvandam@aol.com 
Sent: Monday, July 17, 2006 9:22 PM
Subject: RE: Response to your airboat inquiry on web site


Thank you for your response.  I understand your opinion for I too once shared your sentiment (being a FL native) until I actually moved out on the St. Johns River and began witnessing first hand the destruction to our environment caused by airboats.  I used to think they were “cool” because they didn’t have props but now realize I was very naïve.  Comparing their footprint to that of a canoe is preposterous for their footprint is far greater than any other vessel on the water and their activities of poaching through scarce natural resources is devastating.  The db range they hit is not only damaging to the human ear, but seriously diminishes the enjoyment of the river for anyone else not wearing the hearing protection they do.

 

The use of exhaust pipes has just now been formalized in SB1958 and HB733 but enforcement is very difficult if not impossible for law enforcement lacks the tools necessary to measure the db’s and the muffler law is vague.  Please note that numerous counties have evolved legislation to protect their scarce natural resources and protect their citizens from hearing loss from inadvertent exposure.  You mentioned that they are legal to be on the waterways but I challenge you to look up our Florida Constitution on the issues of noise exposure and you will find that they do not qualify.  

 

The sad thing is there is nothing “Natural Choice” about airboats and on the contrary they are the means to an end of any natural beauty and the end of the Seminole slogan.  Many airboat operators are environmentally conscience and considerate citizens.  But like anything else, there are renegade elements that will ruin it for everyone.  I am hopeful that enforcement and laws that aren’t manipulated by the airboat lobbyists will be created that truly reflect the desire of the majority and good of all.  As far as history is concerned, the act of slavery was a part of our history as well but we don’t say that just because it was in our history that something barbaric like that should continue.  When I am on the river in my canoe or well muffled motorized vessel, I and other boaters are enslaved to the tremendous deafening sound which impedes our enjoyment of our hobby which also has a history.

 

All the environmental issues aside, I thought it really would have been a decent gesture to remove the airboat from the Seminole County website www.seminolecountyfl.gov  under the circumstances of the recent tragedy and their family.  Are you familiar with the Florida Atlantic University study?  

 

I again appreciate your response and copying County Manager Coto who I have already met with on the issue as well as law enforcement who I have already met with.  I am going to cc your response to the victims, the press, and the St. Johns River Keeper and Sierra Club so that they know your stance on the matter.  I am hopeful that you will reconsider your promotion of airboat activities in what is left of Seminole County natural resources for the safety, enjoyment, and preservation of all.  Especially out of respect for the parents who are bereaved!

 

Sincerely,

 

Devitt Harrison

 


  _____  


From: Olson, Steve [mailto:SOlson@seminolecountyfl.gov] 
Sent: Monday, July 17, 2006 5:56 PM
To: dharrison@stjohnsriverescape.com
Subject: Response to your airboat inquiry on web site

 

Dear Mr. Harrison, 
I am responding to your request(s). You are asking us to remove the airboat picture from our web site. 
First of all, let me say I agree with you that airboats can be noisy. If operators are not careful, the craft can be damaging to the environment and dangerous. The recent incident involving the little boy was unfortunate and tragic for all involved. 

However, airboats are legal to operate on our waterways, such as the St. Johns River. They are regulated by state laws and local ordinances, which are enforced by State Officers as well as Seminole and Volusia County Sheriffs' Offices. 

True, they do leave a larger environmental foot print than, let's say, a canoe. But, it could also be argued that any use of the river by humans, whether by airboat, canoe, or row boat has some impact. 

Thus, I am not going to recommend the removal of the airboat from our web site. Whether one agrees, or disagrees, it is part of the Florida outdoors and enjoys a history locally, statewide and throughout the South. The picture has as much standing on our web site as the canoe photo. 

I have cc'd this response to your question to our County Manager and to the two Deputy County Managers, as well as the acting Information Technologies Director 

I have also passed along your concerns to Lt. Brent Davison of the Seminole County Sheriff's Range and Water Unit. He says he has spoken with you about your concerns on prior occasions and is aware of the issues you have brought up. 

Thank you for your time and for your interest. 

Steve Olson 
Seminole County Government 
Community Information Department Director 
solson@seminolecountyfl.gov

>  WORDS ? 
> > A MESSAGE FROM AN APPALLED OBSERVER: 
> > 
> > Today I went to visit the new World War II
> Memorial in Washington, DC! 
> > I got an unexpected history lesson. Because I'm a
> baby boomer, I was one of the youngest in the crowd.
>   Most were the age of my parents, Veterans of "the
> greatest war," with their families.  It was a
> beautiful day, and people were smiling and happy to
> be there. Hundreds of us milled around the memorial,
> reading the inspiring words of Eisenhower and Truman
> that are engraved there. 
> > 
> > On the Pacific side of the memorial, a group of us
> gathered to read the words President Roosevelt used
> to announce the attack on Pearl Harbor: 
> > 
> > Yesterday, December 7, 1941-- a date which will
> live in infamy--the United States of America was
> suddenly and deliberately attacked. 
> > 
> > One elderly woman read the words aloud: 
> > 
> > With confidence in our armed forces, with the
> abounding determination of our people, we will gain
> the inevitable triumph. 
> > 
> > But as she read, she was suddenly turned angry. 
> "Wait a minute," she said, "they left out the end of
> the quote.   They left out the most important part. 
> Roosevelt ended 
> > the message with "so help us God."   
> > 
> > Her husband said, "You are probably right.  We're
> not supposed to say things like that now." 
> > 
> > "I know I'm right," she insisted.  "I remember the
> speech." The two looked dismayed, shook their heads
> sadly and walked away.   
> > 
> > Listening to their conversation, I thought to
> myself, well, it has been over 50 years she's
> probably forgotten." 
> > 
> > But she had not forgotten. She was right. 
> > 
> > I went home and pulled out the book my book club
> is reading --- "Flags of Our Fathers" by James
> Bradley.   It's all about the battle at Iwo Jima. I
> haven't gotten too far in the book.  It's tough to
> read because it's a graphic description of the WWII
> battles in the Pacific.   
> >   
> > But right there it was on page 58.  Roosevelt's
> speech to the nation ends in "so help us God." 
> > 
> > The people who edited out that part of the speech
> when they engraved it on the memorial could have
> fooled me.  I was born after the war.!   But they
> couldn't fool the people who were there. 
> Roosevelt's words are engraved on 
> > their hearts. 
> > 
> > Now I ask: "WHO GAVE THEM THE RIGHT TO CHANGE THE

From:	Trudy <true@atlantic.net>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 7:55 AM
To:	Devitt Harrison; 'Olson, Steve'
Cc:	'Coto, Cindy'; 'Orth, James C'; 'Lewis, Marsha N.'; 'Bill Belleville'; 'Missynlas'; LegalSandy@aol.com; lroberts@orlandosentinel.com; 'Don Browning'; captainron@aol.com; FBruno@co.volusia.fl.us; 'Florida Hometown Democracy'; Governor Jeb Bush; 'Kelli McGee'; lovebergs@comcast.net; mgreeson@co.volusia.fl.us; 'Richard A. Markle'; 'Pat Northey'; sospeoplesrights@earthlink.net; tara.alford@fwc.state.fl.us; wkvandam@aol.com
Subject:	Re: Response to your airboat inquiry on web site

It is my understanding that Don Browning seriously pressured for the establishment of the 90 dba at 50 ft. ordinance in Marion County. I have heard him state that it is working in Marion County and the airboat noise in Marion County has diminished considerably. Don-correct me if I am wrong!
 
I have witnessed the airboat corporation GTO--established in Marion County--on the Withlacoochee River in Sumter/Citrus Counties with an airboat that was obviously being tested.  I asked the operator if it had a muffling device-(at the ramp). He launched the airboat and laughed at me and said "no" then he revved the engine that at that moment exploded horrendous sounds at me--and laughingly exploded the airboat up the river and stopped it adjacent to my house---where he continued testing the airboat -stopping--going revving full throttle etc. --obviously testing the airboat for hours nonstop in one place.
 
Perhaps the Marion County Airboats are traveling to other counties and that is why the ordinance has been so successful in Marion County.
 
Consider this-----Any person who purchases an airboat and does not install a muffling device equivalent to the muffling of the hp of the engine on that airboat---and who does not equip that airboat with "silent props" that have been available for years-----is guilty of deliberately devaluing all life and placing his or her life above all others------in the same manner that a person who devalues the life of the fetus or baby in the womb and in a cruel manner aborts that inconvenience in order to " have fun--irresponsibly"! The renegade position is false---all airboaters must devalue life in order to operate those instruments. Only those who abide by the mandate to "Love Thy Neighbor"- by effectively muffling according to the hp level of the airboat in the same manner  as automobiles must and silent props are properly placed might be considered non-renegade status. When all airboaters who do not require hearing aides because of their deafness operate the airboats without any hearing protection-and when all hearing aides are turned on to normal hearing capability -I might consider them as following the constitution--and not before!!!! All airboaters who do not "effectively" muffle both engine exhaust and prop exhaust are renegades and have reached the same level in society as any person who aborts life from the womb.--in order to have irresponsible fun!!!!
 
----- Original Message ----- 

From: Devitt Harrison 
To: 'Olson, Steve' 
Cc: 'Coto, Cindy' ; 'Orth, James C' ; 'Lewis, Marsha N.' ; 'Trudy' ; 'Bill Belleville' ; 'Missynlas' ; LegalSandy@aol.com ; lroberts@orlandosentinel.com ; 'Don Browning' ; captainron@aol.com ; FBruno@co.volusia.fl.us ; 'Florida Hometown Democracy' ; jeb.bush@myflorida.com ; 'Kelli McGee' ; lovebergs@comcast.net ; mgreeson@co.volusia.fl.us ; 'Richard A. Markle' ; 'Pat Northey' ; sospeoplesrights@earthlink.net ; tara.alford@fwc.state.fl.us ; wkvandam@aol.com 
Sent: Monday, July 17, 2006 9:22 PM
Subject: RE: Response to your airboat inquiry on web site


Thank you for your response.  I understand your opinion for I too once shared your sentiment (being a FL native) until I actually moved out on the St. Johns River and began witnessing first hand the destruction to our environment caused by airboats.  I used to think they were “cool” because they didn’t have props but now realize I was very naïve.  Comparing their footprint to that of a canoe is preposterous for their footprint is far greater than any other vessel on the water and their activities of poaching through scarce natural resources is devastating.  The db range they hit is not only damaging to the human ear, but seriously diminishes the enjoyment of the river for anyone else not wearing the hearing protection they do.

 

The use of exhaust pipes has just now been formalized in SB1958 and HB733 but enforcement is very difficult if not impossible for law enforcement lacks the tools necessary to measure the db’s and the muffler law is vague.  Please note that numerous counties have evolved legislation to protect their scarce natural resources and protect their citizens from hearing loss from inadvertent exposure.  You mentioned that they are legal to be on the waterways but I challenge you to look up our Florida Constitution on the issues of noise exposure and you will find that they do not qualify.  

 

The sad thing is there is nothing “Natural Choice” about airboats and on the contrary they are the means to an end of any natural beauty and the end of the Seminole slogan.  Many airboat operators are environmentally conscience and considerate citizens.  But like anything else, there are renegade elements that will ruin it for everyone.  I am hopeful that enforcement and laws that aren’t manipulated by the airboat lobbyists will be created that truly reflect the desire of the majority and good of all.  As far as history is concerned, the act of slavery was a part of our history as well but we don’t say that just because it was in our history that something barbaric like that should continue.  When I am on the river in my canoe or well muffled motorized vessel, I and other boaters are enslaved to the tremendous deafening sound which impedes our enjoyment of our hobby which also has a history.

 

All the environmental issues aside, I thought it really would have been a decent gesture to remove the airboat from the Seminole County website www.seminolecountyfl.gov  under the circumstances of the recent tragedy and their family.  Are you familiar with the Florida Atlantic University study?  

 

I again appreciate your response and copying County Manager Coto who I have already met with on the issue as well as law enforcement who I have already met with.  I am going to cc your response to the victims, the press, and the St. Johns River Keeper and Sierra Club so that they know your stance on the matter.  I am hopeful that you will reconsider your promotion of airboat activities in what is left of Seminole County natural resources for the safety, enjoyment, and preservation of all.  Especially out of respect for the parents who are bereaved!

 

Sincerely,

 

Devitt Harrison

 


  _____  


From: Olson, Steve [mailto:SOlson@seminolecountyfl.gov] 
Sent: Monday, July 17, 2006 5:56 PM
To: dharrison@stjohnsriverescape.com
Subject: Response to your airboat inquiry on web site

 

Dear Mr. Harrison, 
I am responding to your request(s). You are asking us to remove the airboat picture from our web site. 
First of all, let me say I agree with you that airboats can be noisy. If operators are not careful, the craft can be damaging to the environment and dangerous. The recent incident involving the little boy was unfortunate and tragic for all involved. 

However, airboats are legal to operate on our waterways, such as the St. Johns River. They are regulated by state laws and local ordinances, which are enforced by State Officers as well as Seminole and Volusia County Sheriffs' Offices. 

True, they do leave a larger environmental foot print than, let's say, a canoe. But, it could also be argued that any use of the river by humans, whether by airboat, canoe, or row boat has some impact. 

Thus, I am not going to recommend the removal of the airboat from our web site. Whether one agrees, or disagrees, it is part of the Florida outdoors and enjoys a history locally, statewide and throughout the South. The picture has as much standing on our web site as the canoe photo. 

I have cc'd this response to your question to our County Manager and to the two Deputy County Managers, as well as the acting Information Technologies Director 

I have also passed along your concerns to Lt. Brent Davison of the Seminole County Sheriff's Range and Water Unit. He says he has spoken with you about your concerns on prior occasions and is aware of the issues you have brought up. 

Thank you for your time and for your interest. 

Steve Olson 
Seminole County Government 
Community Information Department Director 
solson@seminolecountyfl.gov

Many of us are watching for what the effects on earth of massive atmosphere piercing joy rides into space will be. 
Also, I have been concerned about the space shuttle problem of losing tiles. I think it could be the metal cracking beneath the tiles. The same problem that Embraer planes had in the early 80's when I worked as an international business specialist for one of their suppliers in Tampa.
Their little commuter planes suddenly started falling out of the sky puzzling engineers until they found that the metal on the planes was cracking from being exposed too many times to extreme pressure and temperature stress.  And the shuttle has exposure to 3000 degrees of heat every landing and  to cold temperatures from much higher than the Andes .
Please consider passing this on to the proper authorities on the board.
Thanks again (and thank your family) for serving in such a manner that we feel we are a part of our government.

Erlinda Britt Vale

But don't you understand that Florida is being destroyed by these so-called hard workers who come here to Florida to do jobs that me and other Americans won't do? Read on please:
 
Copyright (c) All rights reserved         16 July 2006
 
The Art of Rain – Wayne Cross LLM, MBA    
 
We have available to us the technology to produce rain in limited to virtual unlimited amounts. It operates under a clear blue sky and forms the rain clouds.
 
The system is not about rain seeding. It is the culmination of R & D over 40 years. The system is available for contracted only use by its agents / operators in Australia.
 
I act as the global marketing agent for use of the system which has been under wraps having proven itself several times.
 
Basically the system involves an apparatus installed in the field and another apparatus that triggers the system. Using the co-ordinates of the area to be filled both apparatuses can be some long distance away.
 
The other aspect is the legal implications of over producing rain. We would seek appropriate indemnities against any and all claims as the use of such equipment in producing rain is man engineered which could invite legal challenges not as in rain damage caused by an Act of God so to speak. Our intent is not to cause any rain damage but there is always that risk as in fireman lighting a fire break to ward off a pending larger fire.
    
The timing for the operation of the equipment is normally 7-24hours. The contract terms require a nominal set up fee (transport, accommodation, meals, and satellite phone & fax communications) say US $100,000 per site. Rain gauges are set in the catchment area and read at the highest reading to wit that calibration is used per millimeter. It is these readings which we make appropriate charges against to the client, payable within 48hours of the production thereof.
 
We are prepared as good citizens to do one private demonstration only  for the sum of US$50,000 payable up front with appropriate indemnities & privacy guarantees in place, without a added production charge, on any nominated dam or catchment site preferably the one that is isolated, alone and most in need. 
 
This offer is made to you on first rights of refusal for the next 14 days from the above date. 
 
The science of the technology can also be extended to repelling tornadoes  cyclones,hurricanes,etc. This would mean the installation on the Florida coast involving a series of apparatuses that would be maintained under contract to us. 
 
As we are about to leave for overseas shortly on assignment would you please signal your ideas in the matter sooner than later.
 
 
 
Kind regards
Wayne Cross LLM, MBA

Miami, Queensland, 4220,

Addendum: The writer is former owner, Chairman and CEO of a major UK Plc subsidiary involving tens of millions of dollars invested overseas, other than an a long time overseas entrepreneur. 
 
His life spans 31.5 years permanent residency offshore, including in his role as a Australian Commonwealth Magistrate, two stints as Ad Hoc Adviser to two PNG P.M’s, PNG's past Country’s Chairman to the World Bank (Washington) Visiting Mission on Forestry Matters, Official Recruiter appointed in 1991 by US Navy Admiral (R’td) Thunmann the Commandant of Valley Forge Military Academy (Wayne, P.a, USA) – my two sons John S. & Monni P  (Academy Year book to hand) Class of ’90, General Norman Swarzkoph (Operation Desert Storm) Class of ’54.Academy accredited to US Presidential White House. etc.
 
Current engagements: 1. the manufacturer overseas of a proven device to run a car/truck (250 old Chevy)  without fuel using a cell extending to and including a stationary engine block again with a cell, no water tank. The cell can run fuel less indefinitely. In reality a upgrading and enhancement of a last century patent.
 
2. As in 1 above the manufacture overseas of  a in line cell but set before the water pump on the suction hose that can take the salinity out of salt in sea water and or clean dirty river water producing pure drinking water. Beyond desalination!!  
 
As in the rain making device due Federal and or local laws and regulations these technologies are being sold offshore with sole agency country rights. 
 
In particular we don’t want to be bogged down in any State or Federal deeming fuel tax laws of running cars, trucks, stationery engines without petrol and or diesel now or in the future giving legislators time to catch up as in the recent birth of electrical cars, motorcycles (zero fuel tax) to find other more amendable taxation methods in line with new technologies. In reflection we are in times as in the Ameriacm Wright Bros / Australian Aviator Burt Hinkler’s aviator days as then of no Aviation laws.
 
Vehicles that can run off a cell, vis-à-vis no diesel will come sooner than later under current R & D.  The quest for oil will be shortened to mostly lubricants in line with known globally limited oil reserves. Thank you.  End

The timing for the operation of the equipment is normally 7-24hours. The contract terms require a nominal set up fee (transport, accommodation, meals, and satellite phone & fax communications) say US $100,000 per site. Rain gauges are set in the catchment area and read at the highest reading to wit that calibration is used per millimeter. It is these readings which we make appropriate charges against to the client, payable within 48hours of the production thereof.
 
We are prepared as good citizens to do one private demonstration only  for the sum of US$50,000 payable up front with appropriate indemnities & privacy guarantees in place, without a added production charge, on any nominated dam or catchment site preferably the one that is isolated, alone and most in need. 
 
This offer is made to you on first rights of refusal for the next 14 days from the above date. 
 
The science of the technology can also be extended to repelling tornadoes  cyclones,hurricanes,etc. This would mean the installation on the Florida coast involving a series of apparatuses that would be maintained under contract to us. 
 
As we are about to leave for overseas shortly on assignment would you please signal your ideas in the matter sooner than later.
 
 
 
Kind regards
Wayne Cross LLM, MBA
The Castle, 16A Brakes Cr, 
Miami, Queensland, 4220,
Australia
Tel:(61) [REDACTED] -24/7

The cell can run fuel less indefinitely. In reality a upgrading and enhancement of a last century patent.
 
2. As in 1 above the manufacture overseas of  a in line cell but set before the water pump on the suction hose that can take the salinity out of salt in sea water and or clean dirty river water producing pure drinking water. Beyond desalination!!  
 
As in the rain making device due Federal and or local laws and regulations these technologies are being sold offshore with sole agency country rights.

Sent:	Tuesday, July 18, 2006 1:48 AM
To:	comments@whitehouse.gov; vice.president@whitehouse.gov
Cc:	info@gop.com; Governor Jeb Bush; news@worldnetdaily.com; editor@renewamerica.us; special@foxnews.com; speaker@mail.house.gov; senator@shelby.senate.gov; rush@eibnet.com; editor@weeklystandard.com; hannity@foxnews.com; Ailes, Roger; alerts@conservativealerts.com; FNS@foxnews.com; comments@sbgi.net; Feedback@foxnews.com; bill_frist@frist.senate.gov; newswatch@CBN.com; bccatanzaro@peedeeworld.net
Subject:	 Illusions Continue

A 'cycle' on nonsense
By Thomas Sowell
Tuesday, July 18, 2006

 
Now that Israel has responded to rocket attacks and the abduction of its soldiers by terrorists by making military strikes into areas controlled by those terrorists, much of our media are deploring another "cycle of violence" in the Middle East. 

For reasons unknown, some people seem to regard verbal equivalence as moral equivalence -- and the latter as some kind of badge of broadmindedness, if not intellectual superiority. 

Therefore, when Palestinian terrorists ("militants" in politically correct Newspeak) attack Israel and then Israel responds with military force, that is just another "cycle of violence" in the Middle East to some people. 

The "cycle" notion suggests that each side is just responding to what the other side does. But just what had Israel done to set off these latest terrorist acts? It voluntarily pulled out of Gaza, after evacuating its own settlers, and left the land to the Palestinian authorities. 

Terrorists then used the newly acquired land to launch rockets into Israel and then seized an Israeli soldier. Other terrorists in Lebanon followed suit. The great mantra of the past, "trading land for peace," is now thoroughly discredited, or should be. 

But facts mean nothing to people who are determined to find equivalence, whether today in the Middle East or yesterday in the Cold War. 

Since all things are the same, except for the differences, and different except for the similarities, nothing is easier than to create verbal parallels and moral equivalence, though some people seem to pride themselves on their ability to do such verbal tricks. 

Centuries ago, Thomas Hobbes said that words are wise men's counters but that they are the money of fools. 

Regardless of fashionable rhetoric, there is no Middle East "peace process" any more than trading "land for peace" has been a viable option. Nor is a Palestinian "homeland" a key to peace. 

During all the years when Arab countries controlled the land now proposed for a Palestinian homeland, there was no talk about any such homeland. Only after Israel took control of that territory as a result of the 1967 war was it suddenly sacred as a Palestinian homeland. 

There is no concession that will bring lasting peace to the Middle East because the terrorists and their supporters are not going to be satisfied by concessions. The only thing that will satisfy them is the destruction of Israel. 

Pending that, they will inflict as much destruction and bloodshed on the Israelis as they can get away with at any given time. This brutal reality is not going to vanish through verbal sleight of hand. 

The terrorists have spoken in words and in deeds, including suicide bombers. They have what Churchill once described in the Nazis as "currents of hatred so intense as to sear the souls of those who swim upon them." 

We saw that on 9/11 -- or should have seen it. But many, especially among the intelligentsia, are determined not to see it. 

Of all the Western democracies, only two have no choice but to depend on their own military forces for their survival -- the United States and Israel. The rest have for more than half a century had the luxury of depending on American military forces in general and the American nuclear deterrent in particular. 

People who have long been sheltered from mortal dangers can indulge themselves in the belief that there are no mortal dangers. Nuclear weapons in the hands of Iran or North Korea -- and, through them, in the hands of hate-filled terrorists -- may be all that will finally wake up such people. But that may be tragically too late. 

Those who keep calling for an end to the "cycle of violence" are what make such violence more likely. "World opinion" in general and the United Nations in particular can always be counted on to counsel "restraint" in response to attacks and "negotiations" in response to lethal threats. 

What that means is that those who start trouble will have a lower price to pay than if those they attacked were free to go all out in their counter-attack. Lowering the price to be paid by aggressors virtually guarantees more aggression. 

--------------------------------------------------------------------

From:	David Berman <David@BermanConstruction.com>

To:	cfo@dfs.state.fl.us
Cc:	Workers.CompService@fldfs.com; underwriting@fwcjua.com; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Workers' Compensation

Mr. Gallagher,

I am writing you today to express my concern and outrage with regards to Workers’ Compensation Insurance. I am a small General Contractor that has held an Exemption Certificate on me since the inception of my company. I have been a consultant for the last few years and the only employees in my company are me and my wife, who performs clerical work for me.

I have decided to expand my operations and have found an assistant that I would like to hire as a Construction Supervisor. Being the law abiding citizen that I am I started checking into obtaining Workers Compensation for my company.

Much to my dismay I found out that it is impossible for me to find a private insurer that would write this policy for a company as small as mine and that would even consider classifying my new employee as a Construction Supervisor. I was told that I would have to obtain my insurance from the Florida Workers’ Compensation Joint Underwriting Association, Inc.  (FWCJUA) So, I found an insurance producer that could write such a policy only to be told that the new supervisor would have to be considered a carpenter under the State’s “Class Code” 5645. Based on the information I provided to the producer and the class code he obtained from the FWCJUA, he obtained an estimate of $35,896 for my annual policy premium.

This is outrageous. Number 1, why can’t my new employee be classified and I be charged for the position I employ him as, a supervisor (Class Code 5606)? This could quite possibly save my company a lot of money as the rate should be significantly different.

Number 2 – how can a small company like mine grow and survive being saddled with such a large premium with such large required deposits (50% down and the balance in three payments over 9 months)?

I am sure you have heard this same sob story over and over again. But this time it affects me and my company and its ability to grow and bring on new employees. 

What more favorable options do I have? Am I missing something? Did I go about this in the wrong way?

A prompt response would greatly be appreciated.

 

 

Sincerely,

David Berman
