										July 17, 2006

THE PRESIDENT
SENATORS OF THE UNITED STATES
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES


	I wanted to write you briefly on the subject of the Jews and the Arabs in 
Palestine.  I will be sending a Treatise on the subject in a couple of days; 
  However, I wanted all of you to know where I am leaning concerning the 
issues.  The four points below will express where my views are before I send 
the Treatise which will go into the subject in-depth looking for answers.  I 
believe there is an answer out there, we just need to find it.


1)   	 What earthly power are directly behind the creation of Islamic 
terrorists, which 	also allows the Islamic terrorists to continue to exist?


	Most all Islamic terrorist groups are supported and encouraged by a Arab 
President or Arab Prime Minister in a Middle Eastern Nation.  Without the 
power of a government leader behind them in some way, terrorists would not 
be able to operate within the borders of a Islamic Nation.  Some of these 
Presidents and Prime Ministers are right out in the open that they are 
supporting terrorists and terrorism, (Iran, Syria, Palestine) whereas other 
Arab President’s and Prime Ministers will ride both sides of the fence 
(Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, etc.).  On one side of the fence they are secretly 
and covertly supporting terrorists and terrorism, and on the other side of 
the fence they are telling the International community that they are against 
terrorism and that they want to cooperate with everyone else on the war on 
terrorism.  These “two fenced” leaders then by taking such an approach get 
access to “highly sensitive” and “security related” information from the 
United Nations and other world leaders, and they use this information to 
their advantage to keep the terrorist organizations alive and functional in 
the International community.   There is also one other category of Arab 
Leaders.  He is the one who at one time was actively supporting terrorism, 
but because of pressure from the International community he has quit 
supporting the terrorist groups that he once supported, but at the same time 
he now sits back and does nothing to police and incarcerate the terrorist 
groups operating within his nation to launch strikes against Israel and 
others (Possibly Egypt, Pakistan, U.A.E., etc.)  It is only in rare 
situations will you actually find an Arab President or Arab Prime Minister 
who is against all forms of Islamic Terrorism and will actually use his 
“police powers” to bring “Islamic terrorist groups” to an end that are 
residing within his Nation.







2)   	Why has Islamic terrorism came about in the world?


	The League of Nations turned the Middle East over to the U.K. to control 
and monitor through the British mandate.  When they pulled out, the Jewish 
people were basically defenseless to a certain degree.  Therefore the greedy 
Arabs who already owned the entire Middle East and the Northern parts of 
Africa decided they did not want any Jews occupying any territory close to 
them, even though those Jews had no where else to go, and Israel had been 
their home all though ancient history.  The leaders of the Arab Nations then 
attacked Israel from all sides and were miraculously repelled.  Then the 
United States felt Israel’s plight, and began to help them with military 
supplies.  But even in the beginning it was the un-democratic Leaders of the 
Arab Nations who were the causes of all the problems.  They encouraged and 
incited their citizens to war against the Jews.
	In summary Islamic terrorism came about because the Arab Leaders could not 
beat Israel on the battle field through conventional warfare.   The Arab 
Leaders therefore resorted to financing covert terrorist activities in all 
forms, and supplied financing and support for the creation of “terrorist 
groups” and “terrorist militias“.  And this type of activity started in the 
1950’s, and has continued with most Arab leaders to the present.
	Someone might ask would the Arabs have resulted to terrorism in the world, 
eventually, even if Israel had never existed?  I believe the answer is yes, 
that they would have, however, it would not have been as extreme and it 
would have started off slower than what it actually did.   Even if Israel 
had not existed, the Muslims would have eventually started resorting to 
Terrorism after they were released from under the control of the British and 
French protectorates.   The reason the Muslims would have resorted to 
terrorism is for two reasons:  1) No one was overseeing that democratic 
governments were formed within their new nations, and 2) Without democratic 
governments to curb the fanatical aspects of Islam, those fanatical aspects 
would spring forth in misapplied interpretations of Jihad, etc.,  3) Without 
democratic governments, the Muslims, when they could not get their way with 
aggression and force, would have dealt with stronger nations who did not 
support their jihadist philosophy with terrorism.  Just as they are doing 
today.
	Look at what the Extremist Muslims are doing today in Nations where their 
government leaders are not democratic.   The extremist Muslims have bloody 
borders with every religion they come across that does not immediately 
convert.   The extremist Muslims are stirring up things all over Africa, 
they are stirring up things all over the Middle East, they are stirring up 
things in parts of Eastern Europe, they are stirring up things in parts of 
Russian territory, they are stirring up things in Asia in such places as 
India.
	So the answer is that even if the nation of Israel had never come to exist, 
and even if not a single Jew had ever returned to Palestine, eventually the 
Muslims would have resorted to terrorism and developed it in all of its 
different forms because of their jihadist philosophy, and their lack of 
democratic institutions.  The world also might have been better off, if the 
Muslims had of never came into contact with the Mongols, as the Mongols 
after conquering the Muslims in many areas and merging with them, taught the 
Muslims a lot of all of their surprise and terrorist tactics.


3) 	So what are the main factors that are contributing to stirring up the 
	prejudice, hatred, and violence of the Muslims against Israel and other 
	Nations?

1)  First and foremost, the United Nations current stance is the first 
problem of all.  Their stance is both unfair and unjust to the Israelites, 
taking into consideration everything that the Arabs have done over the past 
58 years.  I will explain that below in a later section.

2)  Secondly it is the undemocratic governments in many Arab Nations and the 
undemocratic Islamic leaders that control those governments.   If that 
problem is not corrected also, along with No. 1 above, then you cannot even 
attempt to hope to find a solution that will work once and for all.

3) Third is the way in which Arab children are being socialized.  Once 
democracy takes the place of a corrupt Islamic regime, the occupying power 
must insure that any textbooks that are used in the public schools of the 
new nation are expressing and promoting ideas of peace, instead of ideas of 
hatred, war, and jihad.  Truth can be taught in textbooks without 
instigating the poor children to prejudice, hatred, and war also.

4)  Fourth, once a Arab Nation is converted to democracy, a new peaceful 
form of Islam must be strongly encouraged and developed in textbooks, 
organizations, and in the Mosques, in order to take the place of all 
intolerant jihadist views of Islam in Arab Nations.

5)  Comparative world religions and sociology should be strongly taught in 
Arab nations, even more strongly taught than it is in other parts of this 
world.  This would also help to get the Arabs to lighten up on their 
intolerance of other religions.  Along with this, the religious leaders of 
the various faiths should begin to dialogue more, maybe under the guidance 
of the United Nations.   The different Nations could send certain religious 
leaders that are open minded and respected in their fields to a new 
committee formed at the U.N.  The religious leaders could discuss such 
topics as tolerance between religions, and letting religious views be spread 
by truth instead of forced conversion.  They could discuss the things that 
they have in common, and how they might work together to help those who are 
starving and poor.   However, it is probably best that such a committee does 
not get into discussions about which religion is correct, or why their 
religion is correct as compared to the others, those discussions should be 
off limits for this particular committee, because of the committees 
particular purpose.  These religious leaders could then return to their 
respective nations and influence the government leaders to take more 
tolerant approaches in the world concerning other faiths, and to renounce 
all forms of jihadist ideologies.






A Brief History and Analysis



	The League of Nations turned the Middle Eastern areas, transjordan, etc. 
over to U.K. to monitor and control.   The British bended over backwards 
under their British mandate to accommodate both the Jews and the Arabs.  The 
Jews were cooperative with the U.K., but the Arabs were not.  The U.K. 
offered two plans on two different occasions for two separate states living 
side by side.   Israel accepted both offers and decisions, the Arabs refused 
both as they wanted all or nothing.  The U.K then referred the situation to 
the power and authority of the United Nations in order for them to 
investigate the matter further and make a decision.  The U.N. then 
investigated the matter, and with their authority said that both the Jews 
and Arabs must submit to their authority and agree to a two state plan and 
decision.  Again the Jews cooperated and accepted the U.N.’s authority, and 
again the Arabs rejected the U.N.’s authority, offer, and decision as they 
wanted it all or nothing.   The Arabs basically slapped every nation in the 
face, and told the U.N. that they did not recognize their authority and 
decision and that the U.N. had exceeded it’s authority, they then claimed 
under the United Nation’s Charter that every people in a territory has a 
right to determine their own destiny the way that they choose to do so.
	So the U.N. had made it’s decision and the Jews cooperated and accepted it 
in 1947.  The Arabs basically slapped everyone in the face, including the 
U.N.,  in 1947.  Then the U.K. pulled all of it’s troops out of the 
territory of Palestine.   According to the U.N.’s plan, Israel declared its 
Independence the same day.
	Then without warning the Palestinians along with the Nations of Lebanon, 
Syria, Jordan, Egypt, and Iraq all attacked Israel on all sides with the 
goal of exterminating Israel and fulfilling their interpretation of the 
United Nations Charter that says each People of a territory have a right to 
fulfill their own destiny.   However, the Arabs only liked that 
interpretation when they thought they were going to be the winners, but they 
are hypocrites when they are the losers, and do not abide by their own rules 
when they are the losers instead of the winners, and instead they want to go 
back to the rules that they had disrespected and rejected, and hope that 
someone lets them so they can get into a position to attack Israel again and 
violate the rules again, until somebody finally figures them out.
	Israel was a friendly and peaceful nation in the midst of non-peaceful 
nations.  When the U.K., as the authority at that time, told Israel it had a 
right to exist if it cooperated and accepted it’s decisions then Israel had 
a right to exist.  If the United Nations, who was then the authority, told 
Israel it had a right to exist if it cooperated and accepted it’s decisions 
then Israel had a right to exist.  However, if Israel had not cooperated or 
accepted their decision then Israel would not have had a right to exist, and 
all offers would have been off shortly thereafter, and each party that 
ignored and disrespected the United Nations’ authority, by not accepting 
their original decision, would do so at the peril of its own fate.  If it 
not only rejected all authority and sought to exterminate the Nation who had 
cooperated with the U.N., then any new territory acquired by the cooperating 
Nation, Israel, would belong to Israel to do with at its own discretion.  
Israel did not want any war in 1948 it was forced upon them by the Arabs who 
disrespected the entire International community.  Now since the Arabs have 
shown Israel that the Arabs cannot be trusted, Israel has not choice but to 
keep those territories for defensive reasons against Arabs that no one can 
trust, not the Jews, not the International community, and not the United 
Nations.   For the safety of Israel’s own existence it needed a buffer, and 
that is what function the West Bank has served.  It provides Israel some 
breathing room between it and the Jordanians, Syrians, and Palestinians.  
And until the Arabs show that they are willing to accept Israel as a Nation, 
and refrain from violence, Israel has no choice but to maintain a defensive 
position in order to protect its citizens and families.
	Once the Arab nations resorted to war when England pulled out, they gave up 
all rights to or claims to plans enacted by the U.K. or the U.N..   Plus 
because of the Arabs total disregard of everyone and everything, the U.N. no 
longer has a right to put any demands on Israel who had cooperated and done 
right in the beginning, and has only done what it had done since the 
beginning in complete self-defense.  The boundaries set out by the U.K. and 
the U.N. might have worked for a “two state solution” before one party 
showed that it could not be trusted and would exterminate the other if given 
a chance.  But once one party showed that as its intentions, the other party 
who had cooperated all along has every right to retain certain lands won in 
the conflict that enable it to protect itself from extermination by enemies 
that refuse to really recognize it’s existence.  Israel has to do whatever 
it has to do to protect its citizens and families.
	The United Nation is incorrect in making any statements saying that Israel 
must return any land that it acquired after the 1948 war.   Israel was not 
the attacker, the other Arab nations were, and they were malicious 
attackers.
	I propose that the United Nations pass new resolutions saying that Israel 
has a right to keep all the lands it acquired during the 1948 and 1967 “Six 
day war” for defensive purposes since Israel has never been the aggressor, 
attacker, or invader.  As the Arabs rejected the United Nations authority 
outright, and do not have a right to later call upon that authority when 
their plans of exterminating the Jews completely did not work out.  However, 
in the resolution it should also say that for the sake of world peace that 
once certain conditions are met, that the U.N. recommends to Israel that it 
return a good portion of the land to the Palestinians by which they could 
form their own nation, that is if Israel ever wants to know peace again..  
They should then also advise the Palestinians to desist from all terrorist 
activities if they ever hope to have a Nation state again after all the 
nations and authorities they have disrespected, as they currently from their 
past actions are in no way entitled to that land.   They can say it in a 
much lighter way than I did, but the U.N. must quit putting ideas in the 
Palestinians minds that even after all of their criminal behavior they have 
a right to the original plan in 1948 still, or even the plan in resolution 
242.  That is wrong and incorrect discernment, and it leads the Palestinians 
to believe that they can continue to engage in terrorist activities since 
Israel has not given back all the territories back from the original plan in 
1947, when the Arabs attacked Israel and tried to exterminate them.
	In summary, all armistice lines, treaties, agreements, and plans were off 
for the Palestinians once the Palestinians and their “war partners” invaded 
Israel in 1948.  The Palestinians actions totally and completely 
disrespected the United Nations, and is therefore in no way entitled to any 
support from the United Nations on the matter, as it is now in Israel‘s 
hands and no one else‘s.  No one else was going to fight for Israel in 1948 
and keep the Arabs from exterminating them and driving them to their deaths 
in the seas.  In other words if the United Nations now decides to ever put 
in a good word for the Palestinians and Arabs after what the Arabs have 
done, it is solely upon the United Nations good will and discretion.  But 
after what the Arabs did leading up to the 1948 war, the United Nations 
should be completely and totally on the Israelites side, and respect 
Israel‘s decisions, even though the U.N. can still voice their opinion to 
Israel to encourage Israel to take steps to bring about peace if possible..
	The United Nations must change its tone or it is going to create a nuclear 
war in the Middle East.  As long as those Islamic terrorists think they have 
a right to land that they forfeited there will be no stopping the violence, 
ever.   As long as the Palestinians who broke every treaty and deal and 
tried to exterminate the Jews in 1948 can say we have a right to that land 
because the United Nations says we have a right to it, then terrorism is 
going to continue to escalate and a peace solution will not be found.  The 
Arabs will not negotiate as long as they feel they have a right to take back 
all of the land that the Jews took in self-defense.   And they only think 
they have that right because the United Nations is making a big mistake in 
telling them that they do.    The United Nations should be telling the 
Palestinians that they forfeited all rights by ignoring both plans the U.K. 
offered before U.K. pulled out, and by ignoring and disregarding the plan 
that the United Nations offered while such a “two nation border solution” 
was possible .  If that was not enough they forfeited those rights when they 
engaged in aggressive and terrorist activities of invading Israel once the 
U.K. pulled out, seeking to exterminate Israel.
	The Palestinian liberation Organization was created in 1964 right before 
Syria, Jordan, Egypt, Iraq, and the Palestinians all initiated another 
surprise attack against Israel in 1967.  Before the 1967 war none of the PLO 
members wanted the Jews or Israel to remain alive, and still had plans to 
utterly destroy them.   Then after the 1967 war when the Arabs were defeated 
again, some PLO members hesitantly recognized Israel's right to exist within 
certain boundaries; while most still held that Israel must eventually be 
destroyed.   And under these conditions the United Nations wants to tell 
these aggressive Islamic Arabs that they have a legal right to the land that 
was offered to them by the British mandate, and the first United Nations 
resolution on the issue in 1947.  As soon as you give those Palestinians 
that land, they will soon shortly thereafter attack Israel again from 
Israel’s completely vulnerable and indefensible position, that the U.N. says 
that Israel has to take on.  We have no right, none of us, to ask Israel to 
commit suicide, when we know that the Nations and Arabs next to Israel do 
not recognize Israel as a Nation, and will attack Israel any chance that 
they get.
	Israel has a right to keep the land that is vital to their national 
security until at such time that the Palestinians and their “war partners” 
assure Israel that they recognize Israel as a Nation, and will not engage in 
any more invasions or hostilities toward Israel (that includes no more 
suicide bombings also).
	Knowing the current attitude of the Arabs, it is very evident that until 
the current Palestinian Liberation Organization is replaced with a 
democratic organization, the possibility of Palestinian statehood is not 
likely, and must be delayed until the existence and safety of Israel is 
secured from invasion again.
	 Israel has rightly stated also that its security requires that any 
Palestinian entity created in the future would not at first have all the 
attributes of a state, at least initially, so that in case things go wrong, 
Israel would not have to face a dangerous and nearby enemy.   Israel is open 
to there being a Palestinian state that is a self-administering entity.  
However, until such a Palestinian state is no longer dependent upon Israel’s 
economy and can stand on its own it may not be possible to give such a 
Palestinian state full sovereignty immediately, but instead in phases as the 
new Palestinians economy and infrastructure develops.  Israel is right in 
this regard and the United Nations needs to back them up and support them 
with resolutions in this regard.
	Some think that the Israelites are sometimes going to far when suicide 
bombers invade and kill hundreds of Israel’s innocent families.
	Do you want to know what the Arabs would have done if they had successfully 
conquered the Jews after slapping the United Nations in the face in 1947?  
Let me tell you.  They would have massacred the Jews, just like Saddam 
Hussein massacred his own citizens, and just like the Muslims are massacring 
innocent people in different parts of Africa.  The only Jews who would have 
survived would have been the ones who escaped on boats or floatation devices 
through the route of the Mediterranean sea.   Every other Jew that did not 
escape would have been either killed, tortured, or imprisoned.   And the 
Arabs would not have listened to a single word or demand by the United 
Nations that they stop the inhumane acts of extermination.  Just like Saddam 
Hussein did not listen to the U.N., and just like Iran is currently not 
listening to the U.N..  The Jews would have basically become extinct, and 
the name Israel would have been a name only remembered in ancient times in 
the Bible.
	God told Abraham to your descendants I am giving this land.  Abraham saved 
us all when he was willing to offer his only begotten son for God.  If God 
had not successfully found a human being that was willing to give their son 
for him, it would not have been right for any creation to expect God to give 
his only begotten son to them, where no one would have done the same for 
God.  Abraham helped save mankind.  And God told Abraham that his 
descendants would have the land of Israel in one form or another.
	Who would want to stand and tell God that Israel does not have a right to 
exist?  If God gave Israel to the Jews that supersedes the British Mandate 
and any United Nations resolutions.  But that is not the issue here as both 
the British Mandate and the United Nations resolutions also agreed that the 
Jews had a right to some of the territories of Palestine in order to create 
their nation, Israel.
	The Problem is that the Arabs are telling God, the British Mandate, and the 
United Nations that the Jews and Israel do not have a right to exist, and 
they rejected every and any plan offering a two state solution when such 
plans with particular boundaries could have been possible without posing 
security threats to either state.   And now the United Nations is making 
thing worse by leading these Palestinians to believe that after every one of 
their violations of everyone and every nation, that they still have a right 
to the land in the 1947 offer, when they outright turned down that offer 
because they wanted to exterminate the Jews and have it all to themselves.  
By their actions the Palestinians showed that the “two state solution” in 
that offer was no longer workable, because one of the parties could in no 
way be trusted, and to now establish a “two state solution” according to the 
boundaries of the 1947 plan or even resolution 242, would be disastrous for 
the peaceful nation who had cooperated and accepted the United Nations 
authority in the beginning in 1947.  It would put that nation into a 
complete indefensible position against another nation that could in no way 
be trusted.
	Listen to what the Palestinians said in 1947 when they completely rejected 
the United Nations authority.  They said that under the provisions of the 
United Nations Charter that the people in the Palestinian territories had 
the right to decide their own destiny.   In other words they said we will 
decide it our way by force and war, and whoever wins will have the right to 
decide the way it will be.   Well if the Arabs wanted it that way, then I 
say give it to them.  They got their war and started their war in 1948 and 
they got defeated.   Israel did not want it to go down that way, it was how 
the Arabs forced it to go down giving Israel no choice.  So Israel won, so 
according to the Arabs rules, under the United Nations Charter which were 
the only ones that the Arabs ever accepted and went by and rejected all 
others, whoever wins in a war between the people in a territory has a right 
to decide the destiny of that territory.  So let the Arabs live by the 
results of their own words, until at such time they learn to refrain from 
violence.   Israel now, as the victor, has the complete right under the 
Arabs own rules of engagement to decide how the Palestinian territories will 
be handled.  Plus what Israel is doing now to defend itself and its citizens 
after winning the war is justified as the Arabs have already shown on 
numerous occasions that they will not cooperate with any “two state 
solution“, and will attack Israel any chance they get.   Furthermore 
according to the Arabs own rules if they would have won in 1948, they would 
not have felt any obligation toward the Jews at all, and not a single Jew 
would have been left alive in the Palestinian territories except for those 
who were imprisoned instead of killed.  And many of the Jews would have 
drowned fleeing out through the Mediterranean sea.
	I believe now you all know which way I am leaning in the Jewish-Arab 
conflict.  Presently the United Nations is trying to solve the Palestine 
problem in to big of chunks.  There is no way to get both sides to totally 
agree on a solution concerning all of the disputed Palestinian territories 
in one move under one Palestinian government.  It’s impossible.  The best 
chance for peace in the Palestinian areas is to establish a democracy in one 
area of the Palestinian territories, and then another democracy in another 
area, and then possibly a final democracy in the last remaining Palestinian 
territories.  I believe the first and best move is to create a small 
sovereign nation out of the Gaza strip, which is completely separate from 
the West Bank.  That will solve the Gaza Strip problem.  Then we must decide 
whether to create one Palestinian nation out of the West Bank or to break 
the West Bank up into two sovereign Palestinian nations.  I’m pretty sure 
Israel does not wanted to be surrounded by just one government from 3 
different points of potential attack against Israel.  If Hamas is running 
the Gaza strip and both North West Bank and South West Bank, then it can 
coordinate attacks against Israel from three locations that pose security 
problems to Israel’s existence.   However, if two or three separate Nations 
are created out of some of the disputed Palestinian territories, then it’s 
possible the government of one of those Arab nations will lean toward 
democracy and peace, and will be one less area that Israel has to worry 
about being attacked from.
	I hope some of the ideas in the letter are helpful.  As all of you can tell 
I am on Israel’s side for many reasons, all of them, I feel, which are 
clearly justified.  In the Treatise I will send you in a couple of days I 
will go more in depth on the subject along with ideas for the division of 
the West Bank, ideas for some new security resolutions which will inform the 
Palestinians that they can no longer rely on any statements by the U.N. as 
grounds for continuing their terrorist activities, and a more in-depth 
history of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
	However, I would like to say that if the U.N. decides to take this new 
approach, which it should, it must do it in a very delicate way, so as to 
not give the impression to the Palestinian leaders that they no longer want 
to help them at all, but only to give the impression that the U.N. will no 
longer allow the Arabs to use any U.N. stances as reasons for continuing 
their violence and terrorism against Israel or the International community.


									Sincerely,

									Mike Ledbetter

Brett,  thank you for sending me tom's campaign statement,  i agree with almost all that you have included.   The portability of the Homestead exemption and save our homes  i see as a further transfer of the property tax burden to the business owner,  the apartment owner and the non-resident provider of tourist housing.  even though much of your constituency would like this, and might vote for Tom,  more and more Floridians now understand that if Florida becomes more expensive for the tourist because of the heavy tax burden being added to the rental rate,   they will find other places to go and those coveted "winter dollars" that provide for the majority of county and school services through sales tax revenue,  will be in jeoprody.  Please review his position on this and encourage him to not take action to further burden the part time resident with full time resident services.  john skalet

How does your evaluation program work?  What is the criteria that determines where a prisoner goes?  Was there something in is 'evaluation' that showed that he should be with repeat offenders and men that basically have do not much potential to be useful citizens in our society???

 

I feel that if Joey was properly evaluated that anyone can see that he is not a career criminal, and has a lot of potential to be 'corrected'.  We all make mistakes... most just do not get caught!  Joey is very remorseful and I know he has matured a lot in recent months and understands what mistakes he has made in his 'rebellious' teen/young adult years and will not repeat those mistakes.  He also has a very high I.Q. and that if allowed to he would be getting education while serving his time, as well as working!  He wants to better himself and never return to prison, but the 'SYSTEM' is not allowing him to do that!  WHY?

 

And why did the 'system' put him in a facility so far away from his family and friends... his only real support system at this time?  Is it the goal of the 'SYSTEM' to make young men like Joey as hardened and useless to society as most of the others?  

 

Can you tell me how I could find out if Joey can be moved to Sumter Correctional Institute where there are programs for him to better himself and, he would be closer to his family and friends?  Is there anyone I can write to?  This is a human being that still has great potential in life!  Shouldn't the system be trying to make useful citizens out of these type of young men?  Please someone help me to help my son... I know that I know that I know... that he is remorseful for his actions and WANTS to better himself!

 

Please at least re-evaluate him?

 

Blessings, Thank you for your time and consideration,

 

Jo-Ann Calmasini

In a message dated 7/14/2006 5:28:00 PM Central Standard Time,
Eva.Armstrong@dep.state.fl.us writes:

Jack, I have asked the appropriate DSL staff to look in to this. 

We will have to pull some records that have been archived.  

A note:  BOT acquisitions have hstorically required that sellers clear up
these types of issues when they are known before closing.  It is the title
company' responsibility to flush out any and all encumbrances or potential
clouds to a title before they commit to provide the insurance policy on that
deed/clear title.  If we find there is a problem we will file a claim to
resolve the issue for the BOT..

In a message dated 7/14/2006 5:08:05 PM Central Standard Time,
Mark.Glisson@dep.state.fl.us writes:

Jack: I'm certainly no expert on this issue, and will yield to whomever on
the e-mail list knows better, but I think there are several parts to the
answer: First, your question assumes that the company sold out some time ago
and maintained the mineral rights on at least some of their lands.  Well, if
we discovered (And we almost certainly would) during our due diligence
preceding acquisition that they owned those rights and there existed a risk
that they could come and exercise those rights, we probably would not buy the
land. Second, if they did not also have a right of access to the minerals,
their ownership of the rights would probably be moot. And finally, we might
not worry about mineral rights if the experts (Geology, etc) tell us there
are no minerals to extract. I think we're safe.

Mark

  <http://www.sun-sentinel.com/images/standard/logo_red_line.gif>
<http://www.sun-sentinel.com/images/standard/clear.gif>
<http://www.sun-sentinel.com/images/standard/clear.gif>
<http://www.sun-sentinel.com/images/standard/clear.gif>
<http://www.sun-sentinel.com/images/standard/clear.gif>
<http://www.sun-sentinel.com/images/standard/clear.gif>     
  <http://www.sun-sentinel.com/images/standard/under_logo.gif>     
http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/local/southflorida/sfl-pminerals14jul14,0,57
46890.story?coll=sfla-home-headlines 

Louisiana company claims mineral rights to 1,000 
properties in Palm Beach County 
  
By Marc Freeman
South Florida Sun-Sentinel

July 14, 2006


Wellington -- Ed Muller thought the form letter with its seemingly outrageous
claim looked like junk mail:

Could a Louisiana company really hold rights to dig up minerals beneath the
house he has owned here for 10 years? And would he have to pay at least
$1,000 to remove this sudden "cloud" over his Greenview Shores home's title?

"These guys came out of the woodwork," Muller, a commercial real estate
broker, said of the mailing from Southern States Land & Timber LLC. "It's
almost like an extortion attempt."

But a review of Palm Beach County court records verified the company's notice
as authentic and far-reaching: There are mineral rights claims affecting
1,000 properties, covering thousands of acres in Wellington and other areas
in the county.

On June 27, Southern States declared its interest in "oil, gas, and mineral
rights and deposits" on these lands, as well as the legal authority to "test
for, explore and conduct whatever extractive activities are necessary."

The company did not indicate when or whether that would take place. It only
wants homeowners to be aware of the possibility that the company could show
up to stake its claim.

"It's perhaps more intimidating or scary to the residents than it ought to
be," said Harry J. Smith, executive vice president and general manager of the
Franklin, La.-based business. He declined to reveal the company's plans, or
whether it intends to extract minerals.

"We feel there are valuable rights and the value will change over time," he
said. "We want to protect the asset, whatever it's worth."

Homeowners who want to avoid any chance of excavation may seek a company
waiver, Smith said.

The price is about one-third of 1 percent of the property's value, or $440
for a one-acre or smaller lot, whatever amount is greater. For a $500,000
home, the cost is $1,500.

Residents may opt to wait and obtain the waivers at the time they decide to
sell their properties, so there's a guaranteed clear title for real estate
deals, Smith said.

The 104-year-old company long ago owned the land -- among 2-million acres of
holdings in Florida -- but never relinquished mineral rights in some areas,
he said. Southern States reaffirms its interests every 30 years, as required
by Florida law.

Linda Culbertson, spokeswoman for the Palm Beach County Clerk of the Courts,
said Southern States' notices were properly filed according to state
statutes, Chapter 712, a section titled Marketable Record Titles To Real
Property.

Homeowners wondering whether they are at risk for similar mineral rights
claims can pay for a title search of their property. Such searches typically
are required for real estate transactions.

Southern States last filed its mineral rights notices in 1976, and will again
in 2036, Smith said, acknowledging that homeowners were caught off guard.
Along with Palm Beach County, notices were sent to owners of 2,000 properties
in Martin County.

Wellington resident Lew Blatte says the claim doesn't make any sense. He says
his Sugar Pond home of 14 years is surely not on top of an untapped oil
reserve or anything worthy of excavating.

"As far as I'm concerned there's nothing under anything out here except sand
and water," said Blatte, publisher of Wellington The Magazine.

But other homeowners are scurrying to figure out their legal options,
wondering whether drilling is imminent and whether they should pay for a
waiver from the company.

Muller says his attorney discovered that Southern States granted a release of
its mineral rights claim to his property in 1978, so it shouldn't be an issue
for him today. He's seeking to have the notice removed from his property
records, so it doesn't interfere with his ability to refinance his mortgage.

Smith says he expects challenges, noting that in some cases, "it could be our
records are wrong."

Title searches conducted before real estate closings should reveal whether
anyone has mineral or other rights to a property, said Larry E. Bray, a real
estate attorney in Palm Springs. In most cases, a release of those interests
is attached to the title and it doesn't become an issue.

Also, homeowners usually purchase title insurance to protect them against all
future claims.

"I don't think most [owners] have a worry," Bray said.

If title companies failed to uncover Southern States' mineral rights, people
may have purchased their homes without ever knowing about it, Smith said.

To Cathie Blatte, who along with her husband Lew plans to stay in their home,
it sounds questionable.

"It's totally ridiculous to hold this over us," she said. "It's like, `Come
up with some money or you'll have a hard time when you try to sell.'"

Marc Freeman can be reached at mjfreeman@sun-sentinel.com or 561-243-6642.


Copyright (c) 2006, South Florida Sun-Sentinel <http://www.sun-sentinel.com/>

Psychiatric Sydney
( AKA The code of the slob)
 
  _____  


Traditionally, ignoring their social responsibility has been the domain of the alcohol producers, but recently in Sydney that tendency to be socially irresponsible, has extended to main other business concerns, who have extreme consequences in terms of the health of others.
 
There have been many instances as I have delineated in previous emails.
 
In combination with this tendency however is the increasing emphasis on using psychiatry to accentuate the thought that if you can't cope in Sydney, or in Australia, you must drug yourself, so that you can cope, rather than the wider society, taking note of the problem, and taking steps to remedy the situation.
 
For instance:
 
1)  Alcohol and tobacco are still unregulated in Australia - the companies, need to come under the same laws as any other form of business.
 
2)  Increasing public funding to psychiatric hosptials, and police to stop people walking around, and so release their frustrations, is simply an approach which will see Sydney become sick and deranged, because they will eventually believe that it is inevitable that noone in society cares, and possibly then take their own actions.
 
This has been quite obvious from the crimes committed in Sydney and Australia recently, where business concerns, in my opinion, put extreme social pressure on the surrounding population, leading to killings, maimings, bashings, and social exclusion from work opportunties, based on the theory that activities such as walking around, for exercise, can be redirected into being used for increasing taxi cab fare rates, ie making people catch a taxi cab, using golf courses, at cost to avoid meeting dangerous dogs on bushtracks, feeling insecure enough and lonely enough to buy a mobile phone etc etc.
 
At the time of Janelle Patton' death, there was to be a large mobile phone system installed on Norfolk Island, and which, would put enormous stress on an already stressed economy.
This means, that the locals, would have panicked (not saying they are right in doing so), causing a social pressure, which could have, if not did, lead to killing Janelle Patton.
 
Same with Lauren Huxley, same with Molly wood and Sophie being run down by a car.  
 
So the issue is, is a $585 million dollar psychiatric hospital at Cumberland Hospital, near Northmead, where Laurne Huxley was hurt, going to solve the problem?
 
Well, it indicates to me, that if people walking are going to be persecuted, by people who wish to make a public statement about how bad things are going for them, then it is time, to be aware, that the government, police, and local businesses are doing nothing about the problem, nor are they willing to admit that their ignoring the needs of the general public, so as to keep their own jobs safe, is causing much hurt in the community.
 
There is a need therefore, to be cold blooded about the approach to remedy the society, by calling a spade a spade.
 
There is a need to access wider community opinion, other than that of government only, to evaluate just what the problems around Australia are, in terms of island economies, or simply, shut down Australia as a bad risk, until further notice.
 
It is easy to give Australia a bad reputation, just by stating what actually happened.  Do Australians have enough raw courage left, to admit, when things are going wrong, and do something about it.
 
Government in Australia, in my opinion, is not smart enough to cope with the complexity of the situation.  That is why parliament stopped recently, that is why they can't find it in themselves to ask more intelligent people for help and advice.  That is why they have people like Costello and Abott in positions of power, because they are very beligerent, difficult individuals, who will keep the fort, and not allow anyone else in.
 
Well what does Australia want to do about the problem?  Are you willing to sit down and discuss the issues,  or do you want to see more girls and children being hurt, when adults, who have a monopoly on the money, and who are even not poor, say a word in defence of themselves instead of having an happy social and community approach which will help many more people to find work, simply through cooperation, and not being too greedy.
 
Regards from the public

From:	Devitt Harrison <dharrison@stjohnsriverescape.com>
Sent:	Monday, July 17, 2006 9:23 PM
To:	'Olson, Steve'
Cc:	'Coto, Cindy'; 'Orth, James C'; 'Lewis, Marsha N.'; 'Trudy'; 'Bill Belleville'; 'Missynlas'; LegalSandy@aol.com; lroberts@orlandosentinel.com; 'Don Browning'; captainron@aol.com; FBruno@co.volusia.fl.us; 'Florida Hometown Democracy'; Governor Jeb Bush; 'Kelli McGee'; lovebergs@comcast.net; mgreeson@co.volusia.fl.us; 'Richard A. Markle'; 'Pat Northey'; sospeoplesrights@earthlink.net; tara.alford@fwc.state.fl.us; wkvandam@aol.com
Subject:	RE: Response to your airboat inquiry on web site

Thank you for your response.  I understand your opinion for I too once shared your sentiment (being a FL native) until I actually moved out on the St. Johns River and began witnessing first hand the destruction to our environment caused by airboats.  I used to think they were “cool” because they didn’t have props but now realize I was very naïve.  Comparing their footprint to that of a canoe is preposterous for their footprint is far greater than any other vessel on the water and their activities of poaching through scarce natural resources is devastating.  The db range they hit is not only damaging to the human ear, but seriously diminishes the enjoyment of the river for anyone else not wearing the hearing protection they do.

 

The use of exhaust pipes has just now been formalized in SB1958 and HB733 but enforcement is very difficult if not impossible for law enforcement lacks the tools necessary to measure the db’s and the muffler law is vague.  Please note that numerous counties have evolved legislation to protect their scarce natural resources and protect their citizens from hearing loss from inadvertent exposure.  You mentioned that they are legal to be on the waterways but I challenge you to look up our Florida Constitution on the issues of noise exposure and you will find that they do not qualify.  

 

The sad thing is there is nothing “Natural Choice” about airboats and on the contrary they are the means to an end of any natural beauty and the end of the Seminole slogan.  Many airboat operators are environmentally conscience and considerate citizens.  But like anything else, there are renegade elements that will ruin it for everyone.  I am hopeful that enforcement and laws that aren’t manipulated by the airboat lobbyists will be created that truly reflect the desire of the majority and good of all.  As far as history is concerned, the act of slavery was a part of our history as well but we don’t say that just because it was in our history that something barbaric like that should continue.  When I am on the river in my canoe or well muffled motorized vessel, I and other boaters are enslaved to the tremendous deafening sound which impedes our enjoyment of our hobby which also has a history.

 

All the environmental issues aside, I thought it really would have been a decent gesture to remove the airboat from the Seminole County website www.seminolecountyfl.gov  under the circumstances of the recent tragedy and their family.  Are you familiar with the Florida Atlantic University study?  

 

I again appreciate your response and copying County Manager Coto who I have already met with on the issue as well as law enforcement who I have already met with.  I am going to cc your response to the victims, the press, and the St. Johns River Keeper and Sierra Club so that they know your stance on the matter.  I am hopeful that you will reconsider your promotion of airboat activities in what is left of Seminole County natural resources for the safety, enjoyment, and preservation of all.  Especially out of respect for the parents who are bereaved!

 

Sincerely,

 

Devitt Harrison

 

  _____  

From: Olson, Steve [mailto:SOlson@seminolecountyfl.gov] 
Sent: Monday, July 17, 2006 5:56 PM
To: dharrison@stjohnsriverescape.com
Subject: Response to your airboat inquiry on web site

 

Dear Mr. Harrison, 
I am responding to your request(s). You are asking us to remove the airboat picture from our web site. 
First of all, let me say I agree with you that airboats can be noisy. If operators are not careful, the craft can be damaging to the environment and dangerous. The recent incident involving the little boy was unfortunate and tragic for all involved. 

However, airboats are legal to operate on our waterways, such as the St. Johns River. They are regulated by state laws and local ordinances, which are enforced by State Officers as well as Seminole and Volusia County Sheriffs' Offices. 

True, they do leave a larger environmental foot print than, let's say, a canoe. But, it could also be argued that any use of the river by humans, whether by airboat, canoe, or row boat has some impact. 

Thus, I am not going to recommend the removal of the airboat from our web site. Whether one agrees, or disagrees, it is part of the Florida outdoors and enjoys a history locally, statewide and throughout the South. The picture has as much standing on our web site as the canoe photo. 

I have cc'd this response to your question to our County Manager and to the two Deputy County Managers, as well as the acting Information Technologies Director 

I have also passed along your concerns to Lt. Brent Davison of the Seminole County Sheriff's Range and Water Unit. He says he has spoken with you about your concerns on prior occasions and is aware of the issues you have brought up. 

Thank you for your time and for your interest. 

Steve Olson 
Seminole County Government 
Community Information Department Director 
solson@seminolecountyfl.gov

-****Florida has a very broad Public Records Law. Virtually all written communications to or from State and Local Officials and employees are public records available to the public and media upon request. Seminole County policy does not differentiate between personal and business emails. E-mail sent on the County system will be considered public and will only be withheld from disclosure if deemed confidential pursuant to State Law.****-

Seminole County policy does not differentiate between personal and business emails. E-mail sent on the County system will be considered public and will only be withheld from disclosure if deemed confidential pursuant to State Law.****-

> FLORIDA REPORTS LOWEST CRIME RATE IN 35 YEARS
> 
> On Tuesday, Florida Department of Law Enforcement
> Commissioner Jerry Bailey
> and I released the state's 2005 Annual Uniform Crime
> Report and announced
> Florida's index crime rate has reached a 35-year
> low.  The index crime rate
> dropped by 3.7 percent in 2005, compared to 2004. I
> applaud the hard work of
> Florida's law enforcement officers who put their
> lives on the line each day
> to protect the residents of our state, and this
> report highlights the
> results of their efforts.  This report shows that
> staying tough on crime
> works.
> 
> 
> STATEWIDE LAW ENFORCEMENT RADIO SYSTEM FULLY
> IMPLEMENTED
> 
> On Friday, I announced the full implementation the
> Statewide Law Enforcement
> Radio System (SLERS).  SLERS gives more than 6,500
> law enforcement officers
> the ability to communicate with their peers
> throughout the state using a
> central radio system.  With this new system,
> officers from various state
> agencies are able to effectively communicate with
> one another on one system.
> By providing a single system, Florida is able to
> provide law enforcement
> officers responding to an emergency with a more
> efficient means of
> communications and the ability to talk to one
> another in real time.
> 
>

> BRIDGEWATER HOPE CENTER
>

> here:

From:	evags@earthlink.net
Sent:	Monday, July 17, 2006 7:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Read NAMI's report on the state of our health care for serious mental illness

 
Eva Gasser-Sanz, Esq.	
15039 Sterling Oaks Dr.	
	
Naples, FL, 34110	
 	
July 17, 2006	
 	
Hon. John Ellis Bush	
206 THE CAPITOL	
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001	
Fax: (850) 487-0801	
 	
Dear Governor John Ellis Bush:	
 	
On March 1, NAMI released "Grading the States: A Report on America's Health Care System for Serious Mental Illness." The report includes specific information on our state and I believe you will find the report helpful as you and your colleagues consider legislation and policy that impacts our state mental health system. A copy of the report is available online at: www.nami.org/grades. As you review this report, there are some key points that I hope you keep in mind. -- No state received an "A". We have significant room for improvement. We would not tolerate any grade but an "A" for cancer or cardiac care. Therefore, we cannot accept any other grade for our mental healthcare system either. -- A quality system must include a recovery focus and emphasis on consumer and family involvement. -- The grades represent a system-wide grade, not just a grade on our mental health agency. Treatment of mental illness requires a broad- based solution that reaches beyond agency boundaries. -- Please pay close attention to the urgent needs section of our state narrative. These are priority concerns and should be addressed quickly. Each state, including ours, is also credited for innovations. These are important and provide templates for improving our system of care. Medicaid now accounts for a majority of publicly- funded mental health services. Changes to our state Medicaid program can have negative consequences on people living with mental illness. As a constituent, I am counting on you to give serious attention to this report. The findings cannot be taken lightly. When quality treatment is available, people recover. When the system fails, lives are lost. Our state must do better and I am asking you to take leadership in helping meet the challenges outlined in this report.	
 	
Sincerely,	
 	
Eva Gasser-Sanz, Esq.

Dear Mrs. Bly:

Thank you for your July 7 email to Governor Bush regarding your
grandmother, Mrs. Montie Sells.  Governor Bush asked me to respond to you
on his behalf.

the investigation into this matter by the department has been closed.  The
case is presently within the court system.  Mr. Maicas also informed me
that Ms. Jean Costa, Senior Attorney, has been in contact with you and
advised you of the current legal process, future hearings and the legal
steps and actions that are needed.

Attorney, at 954-467-4551.

From:	Luella Duncan <luelladuncan@msn.com>
Sent:	Monday, July 17, 2006 7:25 PM
To:	Speaker Allan G. Bense
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush; lee.tom.web@flsenate.gov; Fasano, Mike
Subject:	[*] Re: Skyrocketing Home Owner Insurance Rates (Thread:52902)

Mr. Bense,
 
I am very disappointed in your response to this extremely important issue.  This is not just a homeowners' problem, but any business located in Florida will feel the impact of this insurance crisis.  I cannot believe that the legislature and governor cannot find a way to address this in a more timely manner.
 
These reforms in the so-called insurance reform bill are band-aid approaches.  Because of that, I am supporting any candidate that aggressively tackles the insurance problem.  That means I am supporting any candidate who calls for a special session of the legislature and if that does not happen, I will support any Democratic candidate running in my district or possibly a very liberal Republican who understands that the homeowners property insurance issue must be resolved in a deep-sweeping manner, not the band-aid approach that you described in your insurance reform bill. I will also never support any member of the Florida legislature who does not aggressively attack this homeowner insurance problem. 
 
Although I just bought a condo in November, 2005, and I am not yet a Florida resident, I am contributing money to a Democrat who is aggressively addressing the insurance crisis and wants to tackle the problem in a meaningful way, not in the way that the legislature and governor has responded.
 
There are 350 condos in my development and I will work hard to make sure that my neighbors will only support the Democratic candidate running in this district.  I will also make sure that they do not re-elect any incumbents back into power who do not or will not tackle this problem in an aggressive or profound way.
 
Eliot Frank and Luella Duncan

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Speaker Allan G. Bense 
To: luelladuncan@msn.com 
Sent: Monday, July 17, 2006 6:10 PM
Subject: RE: Skyrocketing Home Owner Insurance Rates (Thread:52902)


Thank you for your email regarding your homeowners insurance.

 

Unfortunately, with the increased hurricane activity Florida has seen over the last few years, insurance issues have become increasingly difficult, complex and, of course, more and more frustrating for people paying higher premiums and sometimes having a tough time finding any coverage at all.  

 

In the Florida House of Representatives, we have extensively debated and discussed insurance reform. We worked hard to weigh the positive and negative effects of ideas presented by Republican Representatives, Democratic Representatives, other government officials, industry experts and members of the public. What we found was that, while some ideas looked good at first glance, upon closer review they failed to provide a real solution to problems we face. The truth is that there is no quick fix to a problem that has been many years in the making.

 

However, I believe that the insurance reform bill we passed during the 2006 Legislative Session represents a meaningful and promising start on the road to reform. 

 

Our goal with the bill we passed, and that Governor Bush signed into law, was to create an environment that would increase both the availability and affordability of property insurance by focusing mainly on three areas. First, we decreased the mounting risk assumed by the state-run Citizens’ Property Insurance in order to reduce the financial obligation to Florida taxpayers. 

 

Second, we worked to encourage more insurance companies to enter the Florida market to increase competition and ultimately stabilize rates. We also set aside $250 million to help Florida homeowners harden their homes against future storms, which will further reduce the insurance risk borne by all of us with homeowners’ insurance.  For more information about these $5,000 matching grants, please visit http://www.mysafefloridahome.org or call 1-800-342-2762.

 

Finally, we used $715 million in unanticipated state revenue to decrease the deficit in Citizens’ Insurance and dramatically reduce the assessment on all insurance policies this year from an average of nearly $400 to less than $75.

 

Again, thank you for contacting me about your homeowners’ insurance. I understand your frustration with increasing rates and decreasing availability. While I cannot promise any short-term relief, I hope the reforms we have made will improve the situation over the long term.

 

Please let me know if I may be of additional assistance to you.

 

Allan Bense

Speaker of the House

Florida House of Representatives


  _____

Luella Duncan and Eliot Frank

In a message dated 7/14/2006 5:28:00 PM Central Standard Time, Eva.Armstrong@dep.state.fl.us writes:

Jack, I have asked the appropriate DSL staff to look in to this. 

We will have to pull some records that have been archived.  

A note:  BOT acquisitions have hstorically required that sellers clear up
these types of issues when they are known before closing.  It is the title
company' responsibility to flush out any and all encumbrances or potential
clouds to a title before they commit to provide the insurance policy on that
deed/clear title.  If we find there is a problem we will file a claim to
resolve the issue for the BOT..
Eva

In a message dated 7/14/2006 5:08:05 PM Central Standard Time,
Mark.Glisson@dep.state.fl.us writes:

Jack: I'm certainly no expert on this issue, and will yield to whomever on
the e-mail list knows better, but I think there are several parts to the
answer: First, your question assumes that the company sold out some time ago
and maintained the mineral rights on at least some of their lands.  Well, if
we discovered (And we almost certainly would) during our due diligence
preceding acquisition that they owned those rights and there existed a risk
that they could come and exercise those rights, we probably would not buy the
land. Second, if they did not also have a right of access to the minerals,
their ownership of the rights would probably be moot. And finally, we might
not worry about mineral rights if the experts (Geology, etc) tell us there
are no minerals to extract. I think we're safe.

Mark

  _____

  <http://www.sun-sentinel.com/images/standard/under_logo.gif>     
http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/local/southflorida/sfl-pminerals14jul14,0,57
46890.story?coll=sfla-home-headlines 

Louisiana company claims mineral rights to 1,000 
properties in Palm Beach County 
  
By Marc Freeman
South Florida Sun-Sentinel

July 14, 2006


Wellington -- Ed Muller thought the form letter with its seemingly outrageous
claim looked like junk mail:

Could a Louisiana company really hold rights to dig up minerals beneath the
house he has owned here for 10 years? And would he have to pay at least
$1,000 to remove this sudden "cloud" over his Greenview Shores home's title?

"These guys came out of the woodwork," Muller, a commercial real estate
broker, said of the mailing from Southern States Land & Timber LLC. "It's
almost like an extortion attempt."

But a review of Palm Beach County court records verified the company's notice
as authentic and far-reaching: There are mineral rights claims affecting
1,000 properties, covering thousands of acres in Wellington and other areas
in the county.

On June 27, Southern States declared its interest in "oil, gas, and mineral
rights and deposits" on these lands, as well as the legal authority to "test
for, explore and conduct whatever extractive activities are necessary."

The company did not indicate when or whether that would take place. It only
wants homeowners to be aware of the possibility that the company could show
up to stake its claim.

"It's perhaps more intimidating or scary to the residents than it ought to
be," said Harry J. Smith, executive vice president and general manager of the
Franklin, La.-based business. He declined to reveal the company's plans, or
whether it intends to extract minerals.

"We feel there are valuable rights and the value will change over time," he
said. "We want to protect the asset, whatever it's worth."

Homeowners who want to avoid any chance of excavation may seek a company
waiver, Smith said.

The price is about one-third of 1 percent of the property's value, or $440
for a one-acre or smaller lot, whatever amount is greater. For a $500,000
home, the cost is $1,500.

Residents may opt to wait and obtain the waivers at the time they decide to
sell their properties, so there's a guaranteed clear title for real estate
deals, Smith said.

The 104-year-old company long ago owned the land -- among 2-million acres of
holdings in Florida -- but never relinquished mineral rights in some areas,
he said. Southern States reaffirms its interests every 30 years, as required
by Florida law.

Linda Culbertson, spokeswoman for the Palm Beach County Clerk of the Courts,
said Southern States' notices were properly filed according to state
statutes, Chapter 712, a section titled Marketable Record Titles To Real
Property.

Homeowners wondering whether they are at risk for similar mineral rights
claims can pay for a title search of their property. Such searches typically
are required for real estate transactions.

Southern States last filed its mineral rights notices in 1976, and will again
in 2036, Smith said, acknowledging that homeowners were caught off guard.
Along with Palm Beach County, notices were sent to owners of 2,000 properties
in Martin County.

Wellington resident Lew Blatte says the claim doesn't make any sense. He says
his Sugar Pond home of 14 years is surely not on top of an untapped oil
reserve or anything worthy of excavating.

"As far as I'm concerned there's nothing under anything out here except sand
and water," said Blatte, publisher of Wellington The Magazine.

But other homeowners are scurrying to figure out their legal options,
wondering whether drilling is imminent and whether they should pay for a
waiver from the company.

Muller says his attorney discovered that Southern States granted a release of
its mineral rights claim to his property in 1978, so it shouldn't be an issue
for him today. He's seeking to have the notice removed from his property
records, so it doesn't interfere with his ability to refinance his mortgage.

Smith says he expects challenges, noting that in some cases, "it could be our
records are wrong."

Title searches conducted before real estate closings should reveal whether
anyone has mineral or other rights to a property, said Larry E. Bray, a real
estate attorney in Palm Springs. In most cases, a release of those interests
is attached to the title and it doesn't become an issue.

Also, homeowners usually purchase title insurance to protect them against all
future claims.

"I don't think most [owners] have a worry," Bray said.

If title companies failed to uncover Southern States' mineral rights, people
may have purchased their homes without ever knowing about it, Smith said.

To Cathie Blatte, who along with her husband Lew plans to stay in their home,
it sounds questionable.

"It's totally ridiculous to hold this over us," she said. "It's like, `Come
up with some money or you'll have a hard time when you try to sell.'"

Marc Freeman can be reached at mjfreeman@sun-sentinel.com or 561-243-6642.

July 15, 2006

 

Mr. Armando Nunez

Panama

Central America

 

Dear Mr. Nunez:

 

At the request of Salvatore Firrito, I am attaching several items which may not have been included in the package we sent to you recently.

 

Please note from the Annexes that our current price for a 10-kW Apollo Power Plant is $13,132.    Under the Federal Energy Policy Act of 2005, our customer, Hydrolec, Inc. of Jacksonville, Florida, would be entitled to a 30% tax credit against Federal Income Tax liability (dollar for dollar credit, not tax deduction).This amounts to $3,940.

 

Under the new Florida Energy Act SB 888, Hydrolec would be entitled a 75% tax credit against Florida Income Tax liability.   This amounts to $9,849.

 

Therefore, taking into account the Federal and Florida legislation, Hydrolec’s cost would be virtually zero. 

 

In the case of Voltage Vehicles Inc. of California, our current price for a Hydrogen Fuel Cell Electric Propulsion is $14,500.   Under the Federal Energy Policy Act of 2005, Voltage Vehicles would be entitled to an $8,000 tax credit against Federal Income Tax liability.   Therefore, the net cost to Voltage Vehicles would be $6,500.

 

There is a great need for our Power Plants in Florida because of the frequency of hurricanes and other storms which shut down the grid.   And due to the escalating War in the Middle East, there is a great need for our Electric Propulsion Systems for vehicles.  Our State and Federal Governments realize this and therefore are, in effect, subsidizing the sale of our products to those who need them.    We hope that Panama will adopt similar laws.

 

Best regards.

APOLLO ENERGY SYSTEMS, INC.

Robert R. Aronsson

From:	Paul Reynolds <PR@PaulReynolds.us>
Sent:	Monday, July 17, 2006 4:56 PM
To:	Paul Reynolds
Subject:	Lake Okeechobee water release schedule Public Meeting Wednesday July 12, 2006

You are receiving the text version of the ourSanibel Newsletter because I believe you are in a position to help. I hope you will take a moment and share my outrage with elected officials and bureaucrats who got us in this fix and now sit back while it WORSENS. 
 
The Bulldozer Bureaucrats
 
On November 14th, 2005 Col. Robert Carpenter of USACE stood before MORE of us in this same facility, the Lee County Courthouse, and admitted the water discharge plan is broken. He vowed that, by July 2006, they would come forward with a plan that would be fair for ALL stakeholders. Throwing out constraints, they would incorporate consideration of health of rivers and estuaries and present a plan sharing the adversity (their term) of the polluted, fresh water problem. Colonel Carpenter was spared the embarrassment of facing his untruth by Dennis Duke, who came in his place. Since both of these gentlemen are retiring soon, the natural sequence will likely be that Carpenter's replacement will come before us in a few months, shed a few crocodile tears, go back to the security of his office and, in some months, come forward with a plan that's "fair for all." 
    It's obviously a charade. Could there be more reliable proof of their intent to do nothing? We've waited since August 2004 for relief and for justice. Now as Condoleezza Rice says, "it's time to take justice to them". It's time to sue. Because we waited and trusted, it's PAST time to sue. Sanibel can't, PURRE won't, ergo Lee County MUST. The bottom line is that the Corps listened to public input and came up with a solution that is WORSE for us than the previous one. Obviously they  listened to us. They are just not motivated to help. Once the big bulldozers are pointed with the Corps, it's career threatening to recommend change. The only argument I've heard against lawsuit is that it will end negotiation and discourse between the parties. My question is, what negotiation?
 
The Plan
 
Better bolt an IPIRB to your house and have the kids(grand?) fitted with permanent flotation devices. The Corps is spooked by Katrina. We learned that THEIR identified capacity for water discharge into the Caloosahatchee River is 12,000cfs, which is about double the worst it's been so far, and with the guys playing cover your fanny the new "cap" for Okeechobee is 17.5'. What that means is that if the Lake APPROACHES 17.5' a wall of water is going to be sent toward us that would make Moses turn and flee. If you think the long delayed Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP) is going to help, let me sum it up for you. That Plan has very little to do with restoring the Everglades, it is a program to develop water storage areas for the EAA and SE Florida (who doesn't need it). Anybody who thinks the solution to a huge problem such as our polluted Lake O is to make it bigger has suffered too much exposure to red tide. Many others, as well as myself, think Congress should take the CERP money and put a bunch of Elmer's Glue in the San Andreas Fault, or make a big cork plug for Mt.St. Helen's. Both of those solutions make more sense than CERP. 
 
 
My Outrage
 
It's  disheartening to attend water discharge meetings and observe the apathy from the public. It stings to note the short attention span of our County newspaper, the News-Press. The "Stop the Muck" campaign ran for a couple of months and stopped. Most certainly it's due to public apathy. It's IRRITATING, however, to attend these meetings and note that the public officials who volunteered to serve and spent money to get elected, didn't bother to show up at CRITICAL events for our communities. This presentation was so vital to us that I'm submitting below the names of every elected official in attendance, to the best of my research, and the huge majority who I think SHOULD have been there. See www.oursanibel.com/noshows.htm for who was there and who should have been but wasn't. Please click here to contact those who can solve this problem with our encouragement  www.oursanibel.com/contacts.htm.

 
Frequently Asked Questions
 
The water has to go somewhere?
Yes it does, and it historically flowed to the South. It can and MUST flow that way again.
 
We can't flood private property?
We, the duped taxpaying public, provide free land to the ag industry called WSA's(water storage areas). Do you know what they use it for? They pump rainwater off the ag fields and dump it there. We can't utilize the WSA's because, thanks in part to the farmers, the water in Lake O is too polluted to go there. We don't need to flood the ag fields, we just need them to share some of this excess water that was stored for their exclusive benefit.
 
CERP is the solution?
It IS the answer if the problem is water storage for SE Florida. It is NOT the answer if the goal is to clean up Lake Okeechobee or save the St Lucie, the Caloosahatchee Rivers, or the estuaries. 
 
Things have gotten better?
Well, sure they have for now, we've had a DROUGHT!
 
What can we do?
The  answer to a fair solution is political. The people who represent the sugar industry are doing a FAR superior job to those who purport to represent us (see above article). We are not asking for any more than a plan that would share the consequences of a schedule designed to benefit the agricultural industry alone.
 
Why do I dislike and distrust SFWMD?
Out of the nine members of the Board two have direct ties to sugar industry, and shamefully one (Malcolm "Bubba" Wade) is even on the Board of US Sugar Corporation. Conflict of interest is clearly no hindrance to appointment to the Board of SFWMD.
 
What is the fair answer?
The Lake Activists and River and Estuary people have one, and only one, potential ally and that is the very unpredictable weather. A couple of 100-200 yard wide flow ways to the South, planted with nutrient collecting plants, would solve this problem forever, be of minor inconvenience to agriculture and be MUCH cheaper than CERP.
 
Who should sue, and who deserves suing?
We are the smallest town in Lee County. We can NOT bear this burden, that impacts all of Lee County, alone. It is County responsibility and they are well past due fulfilling their duty.

-----Original Message-----
From: James Allmon [mailto:jallmon@panhandle.rr.com]
Sent: Thursday, March 09, 2006 10:29 AM
To: Sharon_Caine@co.escambia.fl.us
Cc: dennis_moxley@co.escambia.fl.us; gbergosh@escambia.k12.fl.us; district1@co.escambia.fl.us; aalexander@panhandle.rr.com
Subject: Re: Child Safety


Sharon,
 
Now that the extra one cent sales tax has been approved by the voters, when are we going to see some work on the sidewalk between Miranda Sue and the school?
 
I have noticed on my daily bicycle ride children going home from school and walking on the edge of the pavement on Woodside Road, with their backs to vehicular traffic, even on days when the roadside ditch is NOT full of water.  I remember my teachers in elementary school warning us of the dangers of walking with the traffic flow, and insisting we walk facing traffic, off the pavement on the shoulder of the road.  In my opinion, children crossing Woodside Road to walk facing traffic would be even more dangerous than walking with the traffic, so this is not a valid option.
 
Not all driver's are courteous and safe -- I have been passed by vehicles on Woodside Road when I was going 30 MPH, and there are posted 30 MPH speed limit signs.  I have also noticed vehicles not observing the 20 MPH speed limit during the posted times the speed limit is in effect in the school zone.  
 
A couple of days ago a helicopter from one on the area hospitals circled our neighborhood and landed south of Woodside Road about the time school let out.  It alarmed me so that I had to go make sure one of our children had not been injured, or worse, walking home from school.  Luckily the emergency did not involve one of the children.
 
A sidewalk is the answer.  Let's not wait until a child is injured or killed to install one.
 
I've always heard that the squeaky wheel gets the grease.  I intend to start "squeaking" if I don't see some action soon.
 
Thanks again for you cooperation.
 
James A. Allmon
-----

From:	SHERRY OLDHAM <SOLDHAM@thig.com>

Subject:	Alexis Oldham Jazmine Oldham and Howard Drive Elementary prek program

Dear Ms. Hupp:

I do not know if you remember, but one June 28, 2006 my husband and Myself
met with you at your office to discuss my daughter being placed within the
Pre-K program at Howard Drive Elementary.  As you will recall my oldest
daughter Alexis was molested, at the Perrine Elementary, when she was in
Kindergarten.  Due to how the matter was handled before and after the fact,
I had to remove her from the public school and place her in private school.
Please keep in mind this was Kindergarten and therefore was her fist years
of school.  After completing one year of private school, at my cost, I was
told I could put her in at Howard Drive.  I did so and she has done well,
however she still has trouble dealing with what occurred to her, at Perrrine
Elementary, and she therefore makes a point to tell all of her new teachers,
what happened to her, so somehow they can protect her and she can feel safe.
I still feel this is not fair, as it is not my child's fault that this
horrific thing happened to her. 

Now I have another child who should begin Pre-K this year, however I am told
that she can not attend Howard Drive as she is out of area. I received a
call from Howard Drive  and I am told that there is an opening at Pinecrest
Elementary, but the problem is, this school is even farther away from my
home, and I therefore I can not be in two places at one time to pick up and
drop off my children. Also as you are aware, since they are out of area I do
not even get bus service.

The problem I am having, the school system has let my child down and for
some reason continues to let her down by treating her as an outcast. I have
lived in this same home for the past 14 years and I have paid my taxes to
support the schools. I have also paid for private school, when I felt my
child had no where to go, and this was complete fault of the school staff.
Not old did the staff did not keep my daughter safe to start with, but
horrible the way she was treated by the school administration once she told
what happened to her..  I think both of my children should be able to attend
the same school just as if they were in area.  Also I would like to point
out the children that molested my daughter were bussed in children from out
of area but they were not asked to change schools and they get bus service.
When my daughter goes to middle school and then to High School I will always
need to check to see if these students are there and she will need to go
elsewhere.  She will be inconvenience for the rest of her school life as a
result.  I also would like to point out my children do not have a home
school and therefore should be assigned one together other than Perrine
Elementary.

When this happened 3 years ago, I was going to pursue in court however  I
did not want to put my child through that, I just wanted her to have a
normal life, but the school system continues to treat her different,
therefore maybe I need to re-think this avenue. I feel I am backed into a
corner I if I don't fight for my child's rights/life, who will?

I have CC the Governor and Ms. Greer, to see if possibly they could shed
some light on this matter.  On TV everyone talks about the family unit,
however for some reason my family staying together and being treated fairly
does not matter.  If anyone would like to look it up the case number for the
police report that I filed because the school did not it is J05103 with
Miami Dade Public Schools.  I of course would be glad to provide a copy if
needed.
 
If you have any questions or suggestions please feel free to call me at
anytime.

Sincerely,

Sherry Oldham
