From:	baronvonkreb@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, July 17, 2006 1:50 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Curb illegal immigration to promote literacy in U.S.

Curb illegal immigration to promote literacy in U.S.

More at: 
http://nwitimes.com/articles/2006/07/17/opinion/letters_to_the_editor/06724283f6eeafc3862571ab007ec1a0.txt

As a multilingual immigrant, I wish to respond to Doug Ross' July 7 column, "Promoting literacy is essential in modern society." 

I agree literacy is important. But according to test scores, many American kids already fall behind in many schools across the U.S. compared to their counterparts in many countries in Asia and Europe.

One of the main reasons is our schools are overwhelmed by an explosion of immigration enrollments! Robert McNatt, a Business Week editor, wrote in April, "There are 1.8 million undocumented children in local school districts across the U.S. At an average cost of $7,500 per student, that totals $11.2 billion."

Pls pass along.

john carey
129 habersham dr.

July 17, 2006

The Honorable Jeb Bush
Governor of Florida
The Capitol, 400 S. Monroe St.
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001


Dear Governor Bush:

I am writing you today to ask you to put an end to the licensed extortion 
of American families by the cable industry.  

America’s families are underserved by the broadcast networks, so it is 
only natural that nearly 90% of Americans choose to subscribe to cable to 
increase their viewing options.  But as things stand now, if I want to 
subscribe to the Disney channel, I am also forced to get and pay for the 
FX network, MTV, Comedy Central, and a slew of other cable channels that I 
not only don’t want coming into my home, but which undermine the values I 
hold dear.  

It would be unthinkable for a magazine publisher to tell you that in order 
to get “Better Homes and Gardens,” you also have to pay for a subscription 
to “Playboy.”  But in effect, that’s exactly what the cable industry has 
been forcing cable subscribers to do for years.  

The cable industry’s response, of course, is to say that if you don’t want 
MTV, or FX you can always block the channel – but MTV is still getting a 
portion of my monthly cable bill, whether I watch or not. 

Why should I be forced to subsidize channels that assault my core values 
and beliefs?

Offering parents the ability to choose the channels they want, and to pay 
only for those channels, puts power back in the hands of the consumer – of 
parents – and forces the producers of indecent or violent programming to 
fund their own raunch.

The cable industry has been carried on the backs of American consumers 
long enough. It is time for this extortion to end.

Sincerely,


john carey
3864397946

From:	Brad Skipper <bradskipper@cox.net>

Subject:	[*] RE: Traffic Citation 0852 MEN

Importance:	High

Mr. Gonzalez:
 
I left you a voicemail earlier this afternoon, citing my absolute disbelief in the package of materials that was sent to me today, from your office, along with a piece of correspondence from Mr. Harvey Ruvin.  The package I received today, July 17, had all of my original notarized affidavits (2) from my two witnesses, along with my notarized statement and my certified check in the full amount of the fine of $133.50.  The only other communication was a 2" x 3" post it note with the handwritten comments "Missing $7.50 Processing Fee", signed "SF".
 
The letter from Mr. Ruvin, undated of course, is the first indication of this $7.50 fee, and I suspect that if it would have gone out in a timely fashion, I could have added that amount to the certified check, instead of the amount that you asked me send in writing and which is posted on the website, again with no mention of any "processing fee."
 
I followed your written instructions to the letter, as outlined in several emails between us, and never, ever is there a mention of a non-refundable processing fee of $7.50.  I can't wait to inform my wife, a general district court judge here in Virginia, that Miami-Dade County charges a non-refundable processing fee for simple access to the criminal justice system.
 
I am beside myself with the lack of due process, equal protection under the law and privacy issues.  What I mean by the privacy issue portion is that I've been "recruited" by several law firms that Miami-Dade County sold my personal contact to, by virtue of the "Premier Memberships" that you folks sell through your website.  
 
So, what do I do now?  I followed your written instruction to the letter, along with what is posted on the website, and the pre-trial hearing is Wednesday, 7/19/2006.  Your prompt response will be greatly appreciated.

From: Gonzalez, Joe (COC) [mailto:CRT1@miami-dadeclerk.com] 
Sent: Friday, June 23, 2006 8:24 AM
To: bradskipper@cox.net
Subject: RE: Traffic Citation 0852 MEN


Mr. Skipper
I hope this e-mail will help you understand this process; The citation is in to be set for court status at this moment. The $ 133.50 assessed to the citation is the civil penalty for this violation in case you want to pay it instead of going to court. You may appear at pre-trial when we notify you. Please be advised that no one will appear at pre-trial except you and the hearing officer. At this point,  the hearing officer will set the case for trial and your will have to make another court appearance. This is why, in your case, it may be beneficial to send the affidavit with the required bond. This case will not be set in front of a judge, but a hearing officer
Thank you

Reprinted from NewsMax.com

Saturday, July 15, 2006 8:52 p.m. EDT 

Jeb Bush Backs Terri Schiavo Nurse 

Florida Gov. Jeb Bush has gone to the aid of an embattled nurse facing the loss of her license for remarks she made in an interview with CNN recalling Michael Schiavo's treatment of his wife, Terri, her patient for over a year at the Palm Gardens nursing home. 

According to LifeNews.com, the Board of Nursing of the Florida Department of Health wants to revoke Carla Sauer-Iyer's license because of her remarks in a CNN interview last March in which she spoke of Michael Schiavo's behavior towards his stricken wife. 

Bush insists that the information Sauer-Iyer discussed in the interview was already public record in the ongoing lawsuit between Michael and Terry's parents, Bob and Mary Schindler. 

In an e-mail to the St. Petersburg Times, Bush spokesman Russell Schweiss wrote that "The governor feels the actions taken against Sauer-Iyer are not justified and hopes that the complaint will be reconsidered and dismissed. She did not disclose any information which was not already public." 

Sauer-Iyer, who now works at the Palm Garden of Largo Convalescent Center, told the Associated Press she was "glad but not surprised" to hear that Bush was taking her side "since he was instrumental in trying to save Terri's life." 

The nursing board's attempts to revoke Sauer-Iyer's license came in response to a complaint filed by a Massachusetts woman after she watched Sauer-Iyer's CNN interview. 

In the complaint filed last March, on the day following the CNN interview, the out-of-state complainant charged that Sauer-Iyer made "inflammatory remarks" regarding Michael Schiavo. 

In response to the nursing board's action, Sauer-Iyer's attorney's filed papers saying the information Sauer-Iyer discussed in the CNN interview was a matter of public record at the time. 

They cited an August 2003 affidavit for Terri's parents, Bob and Mary Schindler, in which Sauer-Iyer disclosed that that Michael would complain when staff would take care of her or feed her. He would also refused to provide her with any rehabilitative treatment. 

"[T]hat's therapy -- take that washcloth out," he would tell Iyer. 

In an affidavit for Bush backing his attempts to help Terri's parents prevent Terri's death, she wrote that, after one visit by Michael in Terri's room for 20 minutes with the door shut, she found Terri lethargic and "crying hysterically." She checked Terri's blood sugar levels and they were barely showing any reading on the glucometer, she indicated. She also saw a vial of "insulin concealed in the trash bin." 

She indicated there were needle marks underneath one of Terri's breasts, under her arms and in her groin area. 

She also said: "It was clear to me at Palm Garden that all decisions regarding Terri Schiavo were made by Michael Schiavo with no allowances made for any discussion, debate or normal professional judgment. My initial training there consists solely of the instruction, 'Do what Michael Schiavo tells you or you will be terminated.'" 

"Very few of us were allowed to see Terri," she said. However, she said she saw enough of Terri to know that she was not in a persistent vegetative state. 

LifeNews.com recalled that last year Sauer-Iyer said one of the problems in the long legal battle between Michael and the Schindlers had been courts not fully investigating every complaint and concern. 

"That's been the problem the whole time -- [presiding] Judge Greer not looking into all the evidence," she said, adding she had never been interviewed by any of the judges considering Terri's case. 

"None of us were able to testify," she said, referring to fellow nurses Heidi Law and Carolyn Johnson, who both filed affidavits to confirm Sauer-Iyer's contention that Michael withheld medical care and rehabilitative treatment. 

In the affidavit, Sauer-Iyer contends Michael repeatedly asked hospice staff when Terri was going to die, with demeaning questions such as, "When is that bitch gonna die?" 

Sauer-Iyer was fired from her position at Palm Garden after filing a police report regarding the insulin incident. She cared for Terri from April 1995 through August 1996. 

Interviewed in Colorado, where his is raising money for candidates who favor assisted suicide and euthanasia, Michael Schiavo blasted the governor. 

"This is America" he told the AP. "The governor is entitled to be wrong again. What Carla did is wrong, and what the governor is doing to protect her is wrong. Why does he want to help people who lie?" 

On Thursday, the Florida Department of Health asked the Board of Nursing to dismiss its complaint against Sauer-Iyer. 

The nursing board had originally proposed a one-sided deal by which Sauer-Iyer would relinquish her nursing license and pay nearly $1,700 in administrative fees. Her attorney responded by requesting an administrative hearing on the matter and no date has yet been set for it. 

Editor's note:

From:	Elko, Nicole A <nelko@co.pinellas.fl.us>
Sent:	Monday, July 17, 2006 11:05 AM
To:	irbgoot@aol.com
Cc:	ockunzzi1@aol.com; Bill.Young@mail.house.gov; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Indian Rocks Beach

Mr. Goot,

Thank you for your interest in the beaches of Pinellas County.  I was out of the office last week, but have received your emails.  Please be assured that I am actively pursuing federal emergency funding to repair the damage caused to the Indian Rocks Beach segment of the Sand Key Renourishment Project due to T.S. Alberto last month.  At the present time, Pinellas County does not have the local funds necessary to cost share on this portion of the project.  The post-storm surveys indicate that the estimated cost for repair is $1.6 million.

 

To answer your other question, Pinellas County manages the beaches on a long-term scale, i.e. beach nourishment, erosion-control structures, dune enhancement, etc.  The local municipalities are responsible for short-term management, such as lifeguards, swim buoys, daily trash removal, beach raking, etc.  Based on this beach management system, which has been in place for decades, beach grooming is handled by the City of Indian Rocks Beach and beach renourishment is handled by Pinellas County.

 

Feel free to contact me if you would like additional information or updates on beach renourishment and the possibility of federal rehabilitation funding in the coming weeks/months.

Nicole

 

 

Nicole A. Elko, Ph.D.

Coastal Coordinator

Pinellas County, Dept. of Envir. Mgmt.

512 S. Ft. Harrison Ave.

Clearwater, FL 33756

 

(727) 464-3774

(727) 464-3174 (fax)

nelko@pinellascounty.org

 

website: http://www.pinellascounty.org/Environment/pagesHTML/coastalMngmt/sandKeyRnourish/cm100.html



 

  _____

Dear Nicole

My wife and I spent some time on the beach with out of town company over the weekend.  The sea weed that is laying on the beach is starting to rot AND SMELL.  Could you help get money to I.R.B. to maintain this most precious Pinellas County asset?

From:	Rick.McCleery@swfwmd.state.fl.us
Sent:	Monday, July 17, 2006 10:22 AM
To:	mar12491@netzero.net
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush; cwilliam@sfwmd.gov; ddemaio@sfwmd.gov; Newman, Rex
Subject:	RE: Watering Regulations/Southwest Florida Problem

Dear South Florida Resident:

I am in receipt of your e-mail to Governor Bush expressing your concerns
with Lee County Water Restrictions.  I will attempt to respond, although
Lee County falls within the jurisdictional area of the South Florida Water
Management District (SFWMD), not the Southwest Florida Water Management
District (SWFWMD).

Within this District, year round conservation measures are currently in
effect District wide.  Localized water resource issues can be addressed by
more stringent emergency restrictions set by the jurisdictional local
government.  Regional shortages may be responded to by increased District
emergency water restrictions, such as those adopted by this District during
the previous drought.

All emergency water use restrictions issued within this District are based
on sound water resource data, and are not declared lightly.  They are
issued when necessary to ensure adequate supplies for the public, and
natural systems protection.

In Florida, water is a public resource, and restrictions to potable water
use apply regardless of the source (private or public wells and surface
water).

Concerns about local emergency restrictions should be directed to the
issuing local government.

I suggest that concerns about regional water resource issues be directed to
your District, the SFWMD.

You can contact the SFWMD Ombudsman, Ms. Carolyn Williams, at the above
noted e-mail address.

Sincerely,

Richard B. McCleery
District Ombudsman
Southwest Florida Water Management District
(800) 423-1476, extension 4670, or
(352) 796-7211


                                                                           
             "Governor Jeb                                                 
             Bush"                                                         
             <Jeb.Bush@MyFlori                                          To 
             da.com>                   <mar12491@netzero.net>              
                                                                        cc 
             07/17/2006 09:49          <rick.mccleery@swfwmd.state.fl.us>  
             AM                                                    Subject 
                                       RE: Watering Regulations/Southwest  
                                       Florida Problem                     
                                                                           
                                                                           
                                                                           
                                                                           
                                                                           
                                                                           




Thank you for your e-mail to Governor Bush.  The Governor understands your
concern and has asked me to respond.

Although the Governor appreciates the opportunity to review your concerns,
this is a local government matter.  As you may know, our government is
structured on the notion that local communities can best assess the needs
of their residents.  You would do well to continue to work with your
locally elected officials to resolve this problem.

I am forwarding your concerns to the Southwest Water Management District.
You should hear from someone in that office.

If Governor Bush can help you with a concern in the area of state
government, please let him know.


Sincerely,



                                                                        Rex
T. Newman

Office of Citizens’ Services

RN/cas



      -----Original Message-----
      From: mar12491@netzero.net [mailto:mar12491@netzero.net]
      Sent: Monday, July 03, 2006 8:31 PM
      To: Governor Jeb Bush
      Subject: Watering Regulations/Southwest Florida Problem



      Governor Bush,


      We are fellow residents/taxpayers here in Southwest Florida. Recent
      of late, Lee County had issued a more-demanding water restriction due
      to a self proclaimed lack of water. We say self-proclaimed, because
      the lack of water to the county never really existed. Lee County
      issued their water restriction of one watering day per week. With
      that came the threats of fines which you can see below:


      There is no warning ticket for the first violation. Violations can
      result in fines of $25.00 for the first violation, $100 for the
      second violation and up to $500.00 and/or more than 60 days in County
      jail for the third violation


      This information, along with the following is from the SouthWest
      Florida Water Management District:


      Residents of all other counties should follow the SouthWest Florida
      Water Management District <
      http://www.swfwmd.state.fl.us/conservation/restrictions/> (SWFWMD)
      water restrictions, which restrict irrigation to ONE DAY PER WEEK,
      before 10:00 a.m. or after 4:00 p.m.


      Along with the threats of heavy fines and possible prison time, the
      people who obeyed the new laws where under attack by fleas and other
      pests due to lawns that dried up. Lee County is becoming corrupt in a
      sense, as they continue to issue building permits and build immense
      sums of residential units along with creating man-made lakes thta in
      some cases are half the size of Charlotte Harbour. Lee County
      continues to oppress its citizens with these water restrictions. We
      come to the point we are trying to make. For the past month now,
      everyday, Lee County and Southwest Florida have received large
      amounts of rainfall to the point where in most areas the streets
      become partially flooded. We went to the local media(Wink News) and
      they did a story on everything that we have stated above. The story
      aired at 11:30 at night and was never seen again. A two minute clip
      aired once. It was clear that the county uses the local media as PR.
      We asked only that the restrictions be lifted and we got numerous
      feedback from the county representatives stating that conservation is
      the key. The citizens/taxpayers of Lee County wish to have there
      freedom of watering back. The water used in the county comes from
      individually dug wells, about 100+ feet below the soil. Where does
      the county's jurisdiction end? We ask you, in this day and age, are
      we the kings of our own castles? To what extent can the county
      government in this case tell you what you have and have not,
      especially when it was we, not the county who payued to have the
      wells dug. We ask for your help Governor Bush, as humbly as we can,
      to please make the counties of southwest Florida ease and/or lift the
      demanding water regulations.


      Thank You and we look forward to hearing from you soon,


      Lee County/Southwest Florida Residenst/Taxpayers

-----Original Message-----
From: John J Meyer [mailto:johanjj@juno.com] 
Sent: Sunday, July 16, 2006 9:40 AM
To: Lt. Governor Toni Jennings
Subject: Florida laws are violating Civil Rights Laws.


Dear Toni Jennings,

Every American has the right to have a hearing in a civil rights dispute.

I have been unable to receive a hearing by the Polk County School Board, denied representation from local Senators and Representatives. Polk County Commissioners and Florida attorneys are declining to look into my civil rights dispute. Governor Jeb Bush claims in writing that he is powerless to look into this matter.

Senators and Representatives in the State of Florida have an obligation to look into the misuse of the following Florida laws. The “Florida Home Rule” and the "Employment at-will State”. They are being misused interactively by  Polk County school politicians for their political interest and not for the best interest of our students and our educational system.  Ignoring this for political reasons is not justifiable. 

I have been official dismissed from teaching by Dr. Clinton Wright as a part-time Electrical Instructor for not donating to a private fundraising campaign. Conveniently called, dismissed for a difference of opinion, using Florida’s "employment at-will" state. 

The following is from desk of wendy.hosking@polk.fl.net, regarding private fundraising campaigns. There is no prohibition against participating in a private fund raising campaign; it should be noted that participation must be voluntary. It cannot be made, either implicitly or explicitly, a condition of employment, nor can participation or lack thereof form the basis of any employment action or disparate treatment. 

When I came back from summer vacation I found all my study material placed in boxes in the hallway. The hard drive had been take out of the school computer with my prepared lessons to start the second semester. This is a violation of 447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20). My civil rights have been violated by the Polk County School Board for not following due process.  

I have not only been discriminated against but also harassed, humiliate for all school employees and students to see. The fundraising campaign did run through March 10. I continued to receive pledge forms in my school mailbox including one illegally placed in my home mailbox. I kept on teaching under those absurd circumstances for 6 month. It ended with a dismissal for a difference of opinion in the middle of a semester. No one should have to accept this type of abuse in a Florida Public School System.  

From the desk of Glenda Hood, Florida’s Secretary of State; Florida is an "employment at-will" state. An employer can terminate an employee for any reason, at any time, without advance notification so long as there is no violation of federal or state law. Polk County violated 447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20), including school board regulation 60X53-8, 004 (C). School employee Debby Davis has been assigned to do the administration. The private fund raising campaign has been approved by the Polk County School Board for political reason. The All-Arian fund raising has been approved by the USF.

I donated my time to train minorities and women to pass a mechanics test. On August 17, 2005, School Board Attorney Deming Cowles wrote to me that the school “can dismiss you for you’ re [sic] ethnic background....’ no explanation needed “. Calling names in place of solving a problem. 

For the sake of our students, our educational and our justice system every Senator and Representative in the State of Florida has an obligation to look into this matter. Ignoring this for political reasons is not justifiable. 

I have been an excellent part-time electrical instructor at Brevard Community College for many years and should be entitled to teach again in the Polk County School system. 

I want you to know this whole matter has been eating me alive. 

Sincerely yours,

John J. Meyer
404 Whitman Rd.
Winter Haven Fl. 33884

From:	blossomgrimm <bgrimm2@tampabay.rr.com>

CRITICAL. Rabbi Morris Allen

Mr Jeb Bush, Gov. please read this and forward to the President... Isreal, 
needs help,  ..this came to me from a friend that received this from a 
cousin in  Isreal..

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------



I just wanted to write everyone to say hi and update you on the
situation.

I wish I could calm you and that I had good news .. . but things are
awful here .. . just awful. Seriously, there is this heavy
atmosphere, less people go out, nobody is smiling. .. when I walk
down the streets in Tel Aviv, all I hear through open windows are TV's
and radios that people are listening to in order to hear about the
latest threat and the latest death toll in the north. I can't
read the newspapers without starting to cry . .. listening to news
updates every hour there is another name read of someone else who has
been killed by a rocket attack.. . it is actually getting a bit scary
with all the talk of what if ... what if Syria, what if Iran, what if
the entire area .. . where will the rest of the world be .. . the
katusha rockets are awful and they have ones that can reach Tel Aviv.
In fact, Tel Aviv has just been raised to a higher alert level by the
Homefront Command and I just got an email from my work in order to
inform us where the bomb shelters are in our building. Many of my
friends are up north in the army and I two of my friends' friends'
have already been killed. More so, many of my friends are in the army
up north and I can't focus at work worrying for their safety and future.
The strike on the navy ship is becoming a national tragedy.. . we
feel like we underestimated our enemy and that we weren't ready . . .
that we don't have the intelligence that we need. Iran and Syria seem
to be trying to drag us into a war. To be honest, the scariest thing
is not, what if a missile attack hits Tel Aviv, its the meaning
of it. If or when a missile hits Tel Aviv, it will be all out
warfare in the middle east and we, not only us Israelis, but the entire
Jewish population will be fighting for our existence. These are
countries that want us (Jews, Israelis and Westerners) dead and wiped
off the map . .. and it seems as if they have the capabilities to do
so. What is even scarier, is that other countries are saying that we
are acting disproportionately . . . hearing those statements makes it
easier to understand how the world stood by as the Nazis murdered
6,000,000 Jews. I am telling you this for one reason, so that you will
not feel so far away from what is happening here. The fact of the
matter is, that this does affect you. Iran has not only said that he
wants to destroy Israel, but that it wants to create Europe into a
Pan-Islamic state and destroy the U.S. Don't be foolish, don't think
it can't happen . .. and don't think that the U.S. is untouchable
and invisible. There are Hezbollah factions in the U.S., they have
been arrested. . . watch where you are going and what you are doing ..
. because it would not be surprising if Hezbollah decided to wake
up sleeper terrorist cells abroad. Do NOT underestimate them .. .
the biggest mistake is to not respect the power of Hezbollah, Syria and
Iran. I do not mean to scare you, but to move you to action. Write to
your senators, write to the news media ... force the U.S., the U.N.
the G8, etc .. . to support Israel .. . force news media to
accurately and unbiasedly cover the war .. . and to correctly verbalize
the threat upon Israel, its people and its very existence. Force news
agencies to show the Golan Heights as part of Israel and NOT Syria .
.. Please, just do something.

In the meantime, life is fairly normal . .. depending on your
understanding of normal. ... I guess if normal is being called
into a meeting at work to be told where the bomb shelters are . .. . As
for me, I am waiting and hoping to be called up for reserve duty.

All my love,

Jessica

From: "Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
To: "Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
Sent: Sunday, July 16, 2006 7:19 AM
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, July 14, 2006


> For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
> Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:
>
> http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news
>
> The text version of the e-newsletter is below.
>
>
> INAUGURAL MEETING OF SPACE FLORIDA BOARD OF DIRECTORS HELD IN TALLHASSEE
>
> On Monday, I chaired the inaugural meeting of the Space Florida Board of
> Directors.  Established by House Bill 1489, Space Florida houses the 
> state's
> existing space and aerospace entities and will coordinate all 
> space-related
> issues in Florida.  The Space Florida board will provide leadership and
> advocacy and actively work to strengthen the state's position in the civil
> and military aerospace sectors. Space Florida was among the 
> recommendations
> put forth by the Governor's Commission on Space and Aeronautics. Growing
> Florida's economy through the space and aerospace industries is critical 
> to
> the state's long-term prosperity. Space Florida will lead our state's
> efforts to continue attracting aerospace businesses that create quality,
> high paying jobs for Floridians.
>
>
> ORLANDO HOSTS FIFTH ANNUAL JUST READ, FLORIDA! LEADERSHIP CONFERENCE
>
> On Monday, I joined more than 3,500 superintendents, principals, reading
> coaches and district staff for the fifth annual Just Read, Florida!
> Leadership Conference.   During the three-day conference, state and 
> national
> leaders, reading experts and guests share reading education strategies and
> best practices. Governor Bush was also joined today by Florida State Board
> of Education Chairman Philip Handy, Just Read, Florida! Director Evan
> Lefsky, Ph.D. and renowned author and screenwriter Antwone Fisher, who
> shared the importance of literacy and his personal struggle learning to
> read. Florida's commitment to high-quality instruction and accountability 
> is
> changing the statewide landscape, not only in our schools, but in our
> communities. I am proud that Florida leads the nation in rising student
> achievement and with each year our students are continuing to close the
> achievement gap. When education leaders, teachers and parents work 
> together
> to ensure the success of our students, we contribute to the overall 
> strength
> and success of our state.
>
>
> FLORIDA REPORTS LOWEST CRIME RATE IN 35 YEARS
>
> On Tuesday, Florida Department of Law Enforcement Commissioner Jerry 
> Bailey
> and I released the state's 2005 Annual Uniform Crime Report and announced
> Florida's index crime rate has reached a 35-year low.  The index crime 
> rate
> dropped by 3.7 percent in 2005, compared to 2004. I applaud the hard work 
> of
> Florida's law enforcement officers who put their lives on the line each 
> day
> to protect the residents of our state, and this report highlights the
> results of their efforts.  This report shows that staying tough on crime
> works.
>
>
> STATEWIDE LAW ENFORCEMENT RADIO SYSTEM FULLY IMPLEMENTED
>
> On Friday, I announced the full implementation the Statewide Law 
> Enforcement
> Radio System (SLERS).  SLERS gives more than 6,500 law enforcement 
> officers
> the ability to communicate with their peers throughout the state using a
> central radio system.  With this new system, officers from various state
> agencies are able to effectively communicate with one another on one 
> system.
> By providing a single system, Florida is able to provide law enforcement
> officers responding to an emergency with a more efficient means of
> communications and the ability to talk to one another in real time.
>
>
> POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD PRESENTED TO THE DASIE BRIDGEWATER HOPE CENTER
>
> Congratulations!
>
> To read more about this week's winner, please click here:
> http://www.flgov.com/release/7989
>
>
> GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES
>
> Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.
>

From:	Dan Wickham <D.Wickham@Verizon.Net>
Sent:	Sunday, July 16, 2006 8:17 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Growth & Development, Hillsborough / Tamp Florida

To: Mayor Pam Iorio
cc: Governor Jeb Bush
 
In reference to Residential Development in Tampa and Hillsborough
county in general,
 
I’ve noticed that our roadways & highways have become over-crowded
and are frequently jammed. Commute times have increased dramatically.
Stress and Road Rage seem to be on the rise, aggravated by rising
gasoline prices.

we have the dry season, which leads to drought and
mandatory water restrictions.  The price of water also has
increased dramatically.
 
Housing prices in general have skyrocketed along with
property taxes.  The price of housing insurance has
also sky-rocketed and is nearly un-obtainable.
 
I’ve also noticed that there are another 30,000 plus residential
units planned for downtown Tampa plus who knows how many
others across the county.
 
My question is, with all these things mentioned above,  how
can you possibly justify this continued development ?  It seems
to me that the area is already well beyond capacity.
 
Thanks,
Daniel R Wickham

Greetings, Governor Bush:

 

I am writing to express my concern about the conduct of the US government as it pertains to the conflicts in the Middle East, particularly the current crisis between Israel and the Palestinians in Gaza, and the country of Lebanon.

 

Our President, said yesterday, while attending the G8 Summit that "Israel has a right to defend itself but that it should be mindful of the consequences."  What are the consequences President Bush is referring to? Thus far, I have read where the President is not going to presume to tell Israel what to do. How then can Bush provide any warning that would sufficiently give Israel pause about its actions? I cannot imagine a more passive statement from a government head to another head of government in a country that is not just overly powerful compared to its neighbors, but has consistently provoked and encouraged the containment of a whole nation of people in ways that have proven for decades to be tantamount to genocide. In doing what Israel does best, that is taking a hard stance, it continues to be perceived as a brutal society by virtue of its heavy-handed militaristic treatment of the people in Gaza and, now again, in Beirut, Lebanon.

 

What people, country, organization, administration, etc. gets beat up time and time again and then does not eventually raise its hand to try to stop the beating? Is Israel being beat up by the Palestinians? Is Israel being beat up by the Lebanese? I think your honest answer to the last two questions would be no, and I do not think that you will tell anyone you loved to continue to take a brutal beating. You'd tell them to move away from the situation, you'd tell them to fight back or you would get involved to try to intervene in the situation such that the one you loved did not continue to be hurt. Of these three what is the US doing? We all agree that the US loves and is a best friend to Israel. Is the US condoning the actions of Israel presently? Is it okay to shell Beirut such that children and women, some of whom are US citizens, lives are at risk? Is it okay to destroy the infrastructure of the capital of Lebanon such that drinking water and electric power become non-existent? Since these two criminal acts have already happened in Gaza, and some of it happened in Iraq at the hands of the US military; I ask you where does it end?

 

I am not in support if these actions. This is far too much destruction and too many deaths for the life of a captured soldier. It appears that just as the Palestinian political structure became evolved such that there was a unified agreement to make peace with Israel so long as the territorial lines drawn back in 1967 were handed back to the Palestinians an Israeli weapon is dropped on a Palestinian family on a beach killing most of them. Is this not a provocation? 

 

I think the determinations being made by those representing the interest of the American people are wrong and damaging, further, the image of America to the Muslim world. These decisions to sit back and watch, to deny to back the request by Lebanon’s Prime Minister for intervention that could lead to a cease-fire, to offer gentle reminders to a country that is presently shelling not one, but two nations, demonstrates a lack of diplomacy, human decency, and a lack of moral conscience to protect the lives of those who have nothing to do, directly in many instances, with the decisions of government. Palestinian, Lebanese and Israeli lives all have the same value!  

 

Please do what you can to consider a position that will help to guide those in power making these God-Awful decisions to rethink their positions. It can start with the Bush administration responding positively to the plea of the Lebanese Prime Minister to help broker a cease-fire. It needs to continue, honestly, until discussions with the Hamas government, working with the other national governmental groups in Palestine, can arrive at a determination that is acceptable to both the Israeli government and that selected and elected by the Palestinian people. If these sincere efforts are made, perhaps then, by the Grace of god, these loved countries can enact a future that may be one of peace, and not a continued example of brutal domination and disregard for the sanctity of human life.  

 

Your consideration, prayers and fair action will be of benefit and likely save lives, God Willing. Thank you for your time and attention to this urgent letter.

 

Sincerely,

 

K. Ali

--------------------
A weaselly plan to undermine growth outline 
--------------------

Lauren Ritchie
COMMENTARY

July 16, 2006

Sniff the breeze in Sorrento. Smell a rat?

Oh, yeah. And the leader of this pack is Lake County Commission Chairwoman Catherine Hanson, who is on yet another mission to sabotage the work of residents so her developer buddies can make more money.

This is getting to be a habit with Hanson -- she claims publicly that she wants residents to plan the destiny of their community and when they do, she runs behind their backs with a gleaming machete and starts hacking at their necks.

She tried that trick earlier this year when the residents of Sorrento and Mount Plymouth set limits on the size of stores that they want in their mostly rural communities next to each other in east Lake County.

She got caught trying to increase the size and backed off.

Now the commissioner, who is seeking re-election in November, is at it again, and the consequences are bigger if she wins.

Here's what is going on:

For the last two years, members of the county's Local Planning Agency have been working diligently to articulate a vision of how and where Lake County should grow. The results of their thoughtful, dedicated work -- complicated policies and a map -- will turn into law when approved by county commissioners and state authorities. Their work will chart the growth of Lake for 15 years to come.

The agency came up with a reasonable vision for east Lake, where Hanson's real-estate company is based.

Inside the springshed of the fragile Wekiva River, land must stay rural. In the core areas of Mount Plymouth and Sorrento, developers could build up to 5.5 homes per acre. North of State Road 44 the land would stay mostly as large, equestrian-style lots, and to the south, the density would taper to a maximum of 1 home per acre.

That's where members thought that "conservation design" subdivisions would work well. They required homes be clustered onto smaller-than-normal lots and 50 percent of the property be left open for wildlife corridors, aquifer recharge and parks.

Sounds good, right? Enter the scammers who are out to pervert a fine idea with their weasel words.

This time, they've come in the form of a loose consortium of developers -- along with lawyers and planners -- who have been meeting privately since at least early April. They regularly prowl the hallways at the county's growth-management department, and they've hired a county planner, who also returns to carry their ideas. They've said that the number of homes on any given piece of property in that one-per-acre area isn't important to them, but their actions say otherwise. They're working to stuff more homes onto property in east Lake than would be allowed under the agency's plan -- all the while saying they're just trying to protect the little bunnies and turtles who call it home.

They've dubbed themselves the "Lake Hills Task Force," as if they were officially appointed by county commissioners. Heck, maybe they were -- at least by one. At the top of the membership list in this shadowy "task force" is none other than Hanson, followed by several folks from the Australian development group Heritage Green, a land lawyer, a business owner who tried to get more dense zoning last year and withdrew what was clearly a sinking request, and a smattering of hired do-boys who draw the pretty subdivision pictures.

On Heritage Green's Web site, they like to refer to themselves as working with "major stakeholders" in east Lake to lay out a "more sustainable vision for the region's future." How kind of them to assist the benighted yokels, considering that they don't own an acre of property out there.

Perhaps they'd like to fix a little whoopsie-daisy in their game plan. Seems that they forgot to include on their "task force" common people without development interests who actually live in the community. You know, the ones who for two years have been working on a "vision" for their own destiny, are real tickled with what they've written and don't think they need last-minute help from developers or their county commission traitor.

First on the written agenda of this "task force": "Remove past beliefs."

Alex Kane, vice president of Heritage Green, told the Local Planning Agency on April 20 that members should reconsider the way they calculate open space.

His suggestion was to set aside 50 percent of the land on each individual lot as open space. For that, members should consider awarding the developer "density bonuses" -- the right to build more houses than allowed.

"Constricting density is not the answer," he said.

He arrogantly warned that Lake would never be able to attract "award-winning" developers -- he'd already mentioned several times that Heritage Green was winning them left and right -- unless they did as he described.

The real conservationists in the room were gap-mouthed at this vision of "environmentalism."

"I don't know how you'd enforce that unless the county creates the Open Space Police to go around and see whether you expand your driveway too much or cut down a tree in your own back yard," countered planning agency member Keith Schue.

What Heritage Green suggested under the guise of "conservation" is an insult to people who genuinely care about wildlife, water resources, school overcrowding and a decent way of life.

It is just a fancier-than-usual case of out-of-town developers spitting on the shoes of us hillbillies, telling us that it's rain and it will make us grow. (The latter part is true; certainly, that company's policies, if adopted, would spur growth in rural areas.)

Unfortunately, this nonsense did not die in April.

After Kane got a thumbs-down reception, a new tactic or two emerged. Kane, sometimes with Hanson in tow, started talking about a marvelous idea called "sector plans." Hanson even appeared with Heritage Green representatives before the Orlando Sentinel's editorial board.

Hanson said Friday that she supports the idea of planning for an area rather than considering each subdivision as a separate entity. Asked how the Heritage plan was better than what her Land Planning Agency had sketched out for the area, Hanson said she didn't know. She said she was unaware of what the county's agency had in store for the area.

This sector-plan nonsense is just another opportunity to blast away the work of the Local Planning Agency, which would limit the density of homes in the semirural parts of east Lake.

Hanson said she has never talked with Heritage Green about the density they want. This seems a stretch. The commissioner has appeared with a developer before the local newspaper and allowed her name to be linked with theirs, but she does not know the basics of the company's proposal?

Last week, a county staffer told the Local Planning Agency that it would be taking a "fresh look" at some growth policies that the group thought were settled. Hanson said she hasn't asked anyone to do that -- she said she has stayed out of the planning process. How she can claim that while she actively supports a developer's "task force" to plan for parts of east Lake, all the while knowing that the land planning agency was doing the same, is a conundrum.

As the final touches are being put on the county's growth plan after two years of maddening, meticulous work, the agency Hanson helped to appoint is going to be asked to throw aside some of its most meaningful conclusions.

Why has Hanson allied herself with a group out to sabotage the work of an official county agency? Let's see . . . follow the money trail . . . could it be that Hanson owns a big real-estate company in east Lake and her fortune depends on keeping the growth machine humming?

OK, that's harsh. Maybe it's the $5,000 that the Lake Hills "task force" members, its employees, friends and lawyer just contributed to her campaign, representing 16 percent of the total as of June 30.

Whatever.

The members of the Local Planning Agency have done a remarkable job. They've created a framework that is fair to both developers and residents in east Lake, and it encourages innovation.

Members should keep their eye on the goal and refuse to buckle, regardless of what is dangled before them.

Lauren Ritchie can be reached at Lritchie@orlandosentinel.com or 352-742-5918.

Visit OrlandoSentinel.com

From:	remer5@netzero.net

Sir,  Did you hear about this?  I have long suspected that many developers in Florida were backed by foreign investors but this is ridiculous, Australia, and they want to form a task force!

---------- Forwarded Message ----------
This story was sent to you by: budd remer

--------------------
Group pushes Wekiva development 
--------------------

An advisory board's proposals are too stringent, developers and landowners say.

Nin-Hai Tseng
Sentinel Staff Writer

July 15, 2006

TAVARES -- A group of landowners and developers have united to push for more intense development than a county advisory board recommends in a large swath of land in the Wekiva River basin.

The effort has prompted concern among environmentalists who support the more-stringent development standards advocated by the Local Planning Agency.

Heritage Green, a relatively new developer in Central Florida, has aligned itself with several landowners in the environmentally sensitive Wekiva area to form the so-called Lake Hills task force. The group's meetings with county officials -- including County Commission Chairwoman Catherine Hanson -- have drawn criticism from environmentalists.

"To have a county commissioner and county staff secretly meet with developers without giving the public the opportunity to attend borders on the kind of activity that raises serious ethical questions, " said Charles Lee, director of advocacy for Audubon of Florida.

Talk of a separate plan could undercut "the good progress" of the advisory panel's work, Lee said.

Later this month, the Local Planning Agency's recommendations are scheduled to go before county commissioners who will decide whether the plans should move forward for state review. The development guidelines for the Wekiva area are part of a state mandate to protect sensitive springsheds in the area as it undergoes intense development pressures.

The Lake Hills group represents about 3,000 acres of mostly bare land south of State Road 44. The area crosses State Road 46, ending at the Orange County line. Landowners and developers see the area as ripe for development, as completion of the Wekiva Parkway will connect State Road 427 in Apopka to Interstate 4 in Sanford and give the rural area easy access to Orlando.

The Lake Hills group thinks development standards suggested by the Local Planning Agency are too restrictive, and it urges commissioners to consider another plan to allow developers to build more homes.

Members have held several private meetings that Hanson, Commissioner Debbie Stivender and some members of the county's planning staff attended.

Bruce Duncan, development attorney representing major landowners that make up part of the Lake Hills group, said his clients want an overall density of 2.5 to 3.5 homes per acre.

In contrast, the Local Planning Agency has suggested much less development -- a maximum of one home per acre as long as developers leave plenty of open land for such things as wildlife habitat and trails.

"What they are proposing is simply unreasonable," Duncan said of the panel's recommendations. He said there needs to be denser development clustered at one end so there's more room to leave as open land.

Hanson said she does not agree that more homes should be allowed in the area than the advisory board has recommended. However, she said she supports the way in which the Lake Hills group wants to develop the area by having an areawide growth plan where landowners help create and agree to a set of development guidelines.

"I support the process to keep developments from looking fragmented," she said.

Last month, Hanson applauded such efforts, along with Duncan and a representative from Heritage Green, during a meeting the developer requested with the Orlando Sentinel's editorial board.

At the time, Hanson's real-estate company was the broker for about 40 acres of land that Heritage Green was looking to buy. The commissioner said last week she was no longer the broker because the site was not suitable for development.

Still, the Lake Hills group continues to gain influence. Landowners and people connected to Heritage Green have contributed at least $5,000 to Republican Hanson's re-election campaign, exceeding Democrat Egor Emery's total contributions of $3,736.

Heritage Green is a subsidiary of Australia-based Aria Property International. The developer opened its office in downtown Orlando last year and has quickly moved forward with its project in Lake County on the Wekiva land.

The proposed Mount Dora Woods is showcased on the company's Web site as a family-friendly community five minutes from Mount Dora's historic downtown and 40 minutes from downtown Orlando with the future Wekiva Parkway access nearby.

Damian Winterburn, vice president of development research for Heritage Green, said the developer does not own any land in the Wekiva area yet. However, it is negotiating to buy about 500 acres.

Winterburn said Heritage Green wants development in the area to be better planned than in other parts of the county. He said creating a growth plan with landowners would promise more coordinated development so that growth does not continue in piecemeal fashion.

"It's like putting the pieces of a puzzle together," Winterburn said. "If you keep putting the pieces down with no overall plan, everyone is going to say it's ugly. But nobody ahead of time came in to say what it should look like."

Keith Schue, one of nine members on the advisory board, questioned whether Heritage Green is committed to leaving enough land undeveloped for parks, trails, wildlife habitat and recharge areas.

"I'm not impressed by what they described as conservation design," said Schue, referring to an April meeting at which company representatives presented the concept of "uncommon open space."

Nin-Hai Tseng can be reached at nhtseng@orlandosentinel.com or 352-742-5919.

Visit OrlandoSentinel.com

>INAUGURAL MEETING OF SPACE FLORIDA BOARD OF DIRECTORS HELD IN TALLHASSEE
>
>On Monday, I chaired the inaugural meeting of the Space Florida Board of
>Directors.  Established by House Bill 1489, Space Florida houses the 
>state's
>existing space and aerospace entities and will coordinate all space-related
>issues in Florida.  The Space Florida board will provide leadership and
>advocacy and actively work to strengthen the state's position in the civil
>and military aerospace sectors. Space Florida was among the recommendations
>put forth by the Governor's Commission on Space and Aeronautics. Growing
>Florida's economy through the space and aerospace industries is critical to
>the state's long-term prosperity. Space Florida will lead our state's
>efforts to continue attracting aerospace businesses that create quality,
>high paying jobs for Floridians.
>
>
>ORLANDO HOSTS FIFTH ANNUAL JUST READ, FLORIDA! LEADERSHIP CONFERENCE
>
>On Monday, I joined more than 3,500 superintendents, principals, reading
>coaches and district staff for the fifth annual Just Read, Florida!
>Leadership Conference.   During the three-day conference, state and 
>national
>leaders, reading experts and guests share reading education strategies and
>best practices. Governor Bush was also joined today by Florida State Board
>of Education Chairman Philip Handy, Just Read, Florida! Director Evan
>Lefsky, Ph.D. and renowned author and screenwriter Antwone Fisher, who
>shared the importance of literacy and his personal struggle learning to
>read. Florida's commitment to high-quality instruction and accountability 
>is
>changing the statewide landscape, not only in our schools, but in our
>communities. I am proud that Florida leads the nation in rising student
>achievement and with each year our students are continuing to close the
>achievement gap. When education leaders, teachers and parents work together
>to ensure the success of our students, we contribute to the overall 
>strength
>and success of our state.
>
>
>FLORIDA REPORTS LOWEST CRIME RATE IN 35 YEARS
>
>On Tuesday, Florida Department of Law Enforcement Commissioner Jerry Bailey
>and I released the state's 2005 Annual Uniform Crime Report and announced
>Florida's index crime rate has reached a 35-year low.  The index crime rate
>dropped by 3.7 percent in 2005, compared to 2004. I applaud the hard work 
>of
>Florida's law enforcement officers who put their lives on the line each day
>to protect the residents of our state, and this report highlights the
>results of their efforts.  This report shows that staying tough on crime
>works.
>
>
>STATEWIDE LAW ENFORCEMENT RADIO SYSTEM FULLY IMPLEMENTED
>
>On Friday, I announced the full implementation the Statewide Law 
>Enforcement
>Radio System (SLERS).  SLERS gives more than 6,500 law enforcement officers
>the ability to communicate with their peers throughout the state using a
>central radio system.  With this new system, officers from various state
>agencies are able to effectively communicate with one another on one 
>system.
>By providing a single system, Florida is able to provide law enforcement
>officers responding to an emergency with a more efficient means of
>communications and the ability to talk to one another in real time.
>

From: Jimmy Stanfield [mailto:jimmystanfield@gmail.com]

Subject: Fishing proponant


Dear Mr. Lyons,
My name is Jimmy Stanfield and I am a commercial fishermen (bay shrimper) in Texas. I have friends in Florida and have been following keenly the developing story of the struggle between Florida's commercial fishermen and the FWC. Thank you so much for that article about Mr.Van Munster. You are the first journalist I've ever read who would write about this, probably because, as you noted in the article, most people who fish for a living are not huggable lovable types. Sir the struggle that Florida's fishermen are going through is only a part of a bigger overall struggle against commercial fishing particularly in Florida and Texas. What makes Florida and Texas both unique is that only these states have given regulatory power to their state fish and wildlife agencies-FWC in Florida and Texas Parks and Wildlife Department (TPWD) in Texas. This was done at the insistance of a private lobbying group called the Coastal Conservation Association (CCA). It was started in the late 70's by Shell oil heir and friend of the Bush family named Walter Fondren. In Texas every big city has a road or building named  for the Fondren family, they are big philanthropists and very well connected to the highest of high society. Another founding member of CCA (a group dedicated to wiping out commercial fishing) was Perry Bass, of the famous Ft.Worth billionaire family, another obviously rich and very influential person. Sir these men pushed for TPWD to be given regulatory power and when that happened they got Mr.Bass appointed as a permanent member of the ten person commision that runs TPWD! In other words, a founding member of a group dedicated to wiping out commercial fishing was appointed to be in charge of the state agency that regulates commercial fishing! It's an almost laughable abuse of power and conflict of interest. You know, they joke about Texas' good old boy politics but the result has been anything but funny to many honest working people who have been cruelly and unjustly driven out of a livleihood.  As recently as ten years ago there were about 2000 working shrimp boats in Texas' bays, and today there are less than 200! Many of us have had to move to Louisiana to make a living. It has become so bad that I'll the word persecution to describe what they are doing to us. What if you got pulled over on your way to work every single day by the police? We do. What if they made you take a can of spray paint and deface your vehicle by painting FISH on it so they can identify us when we're driving and pull us over there as well? What's next, maybe make us wear a yellow star like the Nazis did to the Jews? Sir, I've gone on longer than I intended but the long and the short of it is that this is not a mere fisheries issue, it's an issue of equality under the law, and of the very principles of a democracy. Do we have government of the people, by the people and for the people, or can a bunch of rich good old boys just buy a government agency? I have a ton of materiel and documentation if you'd be interested and I know it would make an incredible story. If you're interested please let me know and I'll send you some stuff or you can call me at 409-948-0121. 
Thanks,
Jimmy
