Senator and Representative in the State of Florida have an obligation to
look into the misuse of the following Florida laws. The “Florida Home
Rule” and the "Employment at-will State”. They are being misused
interactively by the Polk County school politicians for their political
interest and not for the best interest of our students and our
educational system.  Ignoring this for political reasons is not
justifiable. The attached article by “The Ledger” our local newspaper is
also telling you that something is wrong. (See Attachment of a sign
placed at State Road # 27 in Lake Wales Fl.).

I have been official dismissed from teaching by Dr. Clinton Wright as a
part-time Electrical Instructor for not donating to a private fundraising
campaign. Conveniently called, dismissed for a difference of opinion,
using Florida’s "employment at-will" state. 

I have been unable to receive a hearing by the Polk County School Board
and no representation from local Senators or Representatives. Governor
Jeb Bush claims in writing that he is powerless to look into this matter.
Polk County  Commissioners and Florida attorneys are declining to look
into this matter.

The following is from desk of wendy.hosking@polk.fl.net, regarding
private fundraising campaigns. There is no prohibition against
participating in a private fund raising campaign; it should be noted that
participation must be voluntary. It cannot be made, either implicitly or
explicitly, a condition of employment, nor can participation or lack
thereof form the basis of any employment action or disparate treatment. 

When I came back from summer vacation I found all my study material
placed in boxes in the hallway. The hard drive had been take out of the
school computer with my prepared lessons to start the second semester.
This is a violation of 447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of Florida Status
(2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20). My civil rights have been
violated by the Polk County School Board for not following due process.  

I have not only been discriminated against but also harassed, humiliate
for all school employees and students to see. The fundraising campaign
did run through March 10. I continued to receive pledge forms in my
school mailbox including one illegally placed in my home mailbox. I kept
on teaching under those absurd circumstances for 6 month. It ended with a
dismissal for a difference of opinion in the middle of a semester. No one
should have to accept this type of abuse in a Florida Public School
System.  

From the desk of Glenda Hood, Florida’s Secretary of State; Florida is an
"employment at-will" state. An employer can terminate an employee for any
reason, at any time, without advance notification so long as there is no
violation of federal or state law. Polk County violated 447,501 (1) (a)
and (b) of Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20),
including school board regulation 60X53-8, 004 (C). School employee Debby
Davis has been assigned to do the administration. The private fund
raising campaign has been approved by the Polk County School Board for
political reason. The All-Arian fund raising has been approved by the
USF.

I donated my time to train minorities and women to pass a mechanics test.
On August 17, 2005, School Board Attorney Deming Cowles wrote to me that
the school “can dismiss you for you’ re [sic] ethnic background....’ no
explanation needed “. Calling names in place of solving a problem. 

For the sake of our students, our educational and our justice system
every Senator and Representative in the State of Florida has an
obligation to look into this matter. Ignoring this for political reasons
is not justifiable. 

I have been an excellent part-time electrical instructor at Brevard
Community College for many years and should be entitled to teach again in
the Polk County School system. 

Sincerely yours,

John J. Meyer
404 Whitman Rd. 
Winter Haven Fl. 33884

along the U. S. Gulf Coast. Federal government emergency funds restored
tracks on the CSX line west of Jacksonville, Fl. However, the Amtrak
trains that utilized the pre-storm route have not been sheduled to run.

overwhelming challenges just to survive. Now motorfuel prices are 
again on the increase. This is a request to increase transportation 
alternatives to these communities with a sustainable form of passenger
transport, especically for the economic well-being of North Florida.

While PDK print and electronic periodicals are on summer hiatus, take time to check out a new book or two to help jumpstart the coming academic year. Below are two suggestions. They can be purchased in our online Bookstore at www.pdkintl.org or by contacting the Order Department by phone (800-766-1156 or 812-339-1156), fax (812-339-5556), or e-mail (orders@pdkintl.org). Use the online search feature to find more titles you need. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Share the Quest for Success: How to Work Effectively with Parents
Mary Ann Smialek
Provides strategies that all teachers need to use in order to ensure that their students get the best possible education and that their students' parents can help guide their children in the shared quest for success in school and in life. A thoughtful, practical guide --written by a parent and educator. Includes step-by-step directions to guarantee productive parent-teacher-student partnerships.
SQS    Paperback    91 pp.    $19.95 ($14.95 members)

 

 

 

 

 

Joyful Classrooms in an Age of Accountability: The Project CHILD Recipe for Success
Sarah M. Butzin
Challenges educators to chart a new course in elementary education and provides readers with an inside look at the innovative approach delivering results in classrooms across the nation. Project CHILD (Changing How Instruction for Learning is Delivered) students demonstrate higher test scores and have fewer discipline problems and lower absenteeism. Includes case studies and standardized testing data. Experience a new way of teaching and learning.
JC    Paperback    126 pp.    $23.95 ($21.95 members)

-----Original Message-----
From: help@fmap.org
To: michaelsfl5@aol.com
Sent: Fri, 14 Jul 2006 11:47 AM
Subject: Florida Market Assistance Plan - Request Status


The status of your request for assistance in finding property insurance coverage 
has changed from "Offer Made But Not Accepted" to "Offer Made but not Accepted". 
Definitions are found below.

Status Definitions:
Pending - Request submitted and awaiting match to agents that MAY be able to 
provide coverage.
Offer Made but not Accepted - Agent provided a quote via mail, email or phone 
call but the offer was not accepted.
Offer Accepted - Agent or insurance company offered coverage and it was 
accepted.
No Offer - Your request for assistance in finding property insurance has passed 
your need coverage by date and is no longer active.  Please resubmit your 
request or call the Florida Market Assistance Plan directly at (800)524-9023, 
Monday-Friday, 8:00 a.m. - 5:30 p.m. EST and you will be provided with a 
referral.
Withdrawn - your request for assistance to find coverage on your property is no 
longer active.

If you have questions or need immediate assistance on your request call the 
Florida Market Assistance Plan directly at (800)524-9023, Monday-Friday, 8:00 
a.m. - 5:30 p.m. EST and you will be provided with a referral.

From:	LJMoller@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 11:54 AM
To:	Mark.Glisson@dep.state.fl.us; eva.armstrong@dep.state.fl.us; Castille, Colleen; Governor Jeb Bush; Wildfed@aol.com; lane.asaf@comcast.net; BARJNPWLL@aol.com; CaptFrankAdams@aol.com
Cc:	struting57@hughes.net
Subject:	The 104-year-old company long ago owned the land -- among 2-million acres

Mark
If this company did own 2-million acres and the mineral rights do they still own these rights under FL Conservation lands and BOT sovereign lands?  If so what can be done to protect these properties?
 
Jack



http://www.sun-sentinel.com/	  			
 	 	 	 	 	 	
 	
http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/local/southflorida/sfl-pminerals14jul14,0,5746890.story?coll=sfla-home-headlines 

Louisiana company claims mineral rights to 1,000 
properties in Palm Beach County 
  
By Marc Freeman
South Florida Sun-Sentinel

July 14, 2006


Wellington -- Ed Muller thought the form letter with its seemingly outrageous claim looked like junk mail:

Could a Louisiana company really hold rights to dig up minerals beneath the house he has owned here for 10 years? And would he have to pay at least $1,000 to remove this sudden "cloud" over his Greenview Shores home's title?

"These guys came out of the woodwork," Muller, a commercial real estate broker, said of the mailing from Southern States Land & Timber LLC. "It's almost like an extortion attempt."

But a review of Palm Beach County court records verified the company's notice as authentic and far-reaching: There are mineral rights claims affecting 1,000 properties, covering thousands of acres in Wellington and other areas in the county.

On June 27, Southern States declared its interest in "oil, gas, and mineral rights and deposits" on these lands, as well as the legal authority to "test for, explore and conduct whatever extractive activities are necessary."

The company did not indicate when or whether that would take place. It only wants homeowners to be aware of the possibility that the company could show up to stake its claim.

"It's perhaps more intimidating or scary to the residents than it ought to be," said Harry J. Smith, executive vice president and general manager of the Franklin, La.-based business. He declined to reveal the company's plans, or whether it intends to extract minerals.

"We feel there are valuable rights and the value will change over time," he said. "We want to protect the asset, whatever it's worth."

Homeowners who want to avoid any chance of excavation may seek a company waiver, Smith said.

The price is about one-third of 1 percent of the property's value, or $440 for a one-acre or smaller lot, whatever amount is greater. For a $500,000 home, the cost is $1,500.

Residents may opt to wait and obtain the waivers at the time they decide to sell their properties, so there's a guaranteed clear title for real estate deals, Smith said.

The 104-year-old company long ago owned the land -- among 2-million acres of holdings in Florida -- but never relinquished mineral rights in some areas, he said. Southern States reaffirms its interests every 30 years, as required by Florida law.

Linda Culbertson, spokeswoman for the Palm Beach County Clerk of the Courts, said Southern States' notices were properly filed according to state statutes, Chapter 712, a section titled Marketable Record Titles To Real Property.

Homeowners wondering whether they are at risk for similar mineral rights claims can pay for a title search of their property. Such searches typically are required for real estate transactions.

Southern States last filed its mineral rights notices in 1976, and will again in 2036, Smith said, acknowledging that homeowners were caught off guard. Along with Palm Beach County, notices were sent to owners of 2,000 properties in Martin County.

Wellington resident Lew Blatte says the claim doesn't make any sense. He says his Sugar Pond home of 14 years is surely not on top of an untapped oil reserve or anything worthy of excavating.

"As far as I'm concerned there's nothing under anything out here except sand and water," said Blatte, publisher of Wellington The Magazine.

But other homeowners are scurrying to figure out their legal options, wondering whether drilling is imminent and whether they should pay for a waiver from the company.

Muller says his attorney discovered that Southern States granted a release of its mineral rights claim to his property in 1978, so it shouldn't be an issue for him today. He's seeking to have the notice removed from his property records, so it doesn't interfere with his ability to refinance his mortgage.

Smith says he expects challenges, noting that in some cases, "it could be our records are wrong."

Title searches conducted before real estate closings should reveal whether anyone has mineral or other rights to a property, said Larry E. Bray, a real estate attorney in Palm Springs. In most cases, a release of those interests is attached to the title and it doesn't become an issue.

Also, homeowners usually purchase title insurance to protect them against all future claims.

"I don't think most [owners] have a worry," Bray said.

If title companies failed to uncover Southern States' mineral rights, people may have purchased their homes without ever knowing about it, Smith said.

To Cathie Blatte, who along with her husband Lew plans to stay in their home, it sounds questionable.

"It's totally ridiculous to hold this over us," she said. "It's like, `Come up with some money or you'll have a hard time when you try to sell.'"

Marc Freeman can be reached at mjfreeman@sun-sentinel.com or 561-243-6642.


Copyright © 2006, South Florida Sun-Sentinel

10188 Winterview Drive
Naples, FL  34109-1520

An IRS-Approved, Not-For-Profit Corporation 

July 14th, 2006
 
Dear Friends,
 
The attached letter is not the kind of letter I care to share with anyone. 
 
Please read the words of a Jewish inmate. My friends, these men are living in a state of constant fear and anxiety. They have had to go silent because to share what has and is happening could mean beatings, possibly even death!
 
How long will these officers be allowed to allegedly violate hate-crime laws and use fear of retaliation as a means of protecting themselves from termination and prosecution? I am not being conned or taken advantage of. There are too many similar reports to attribute this to a con job.  Logically, why would inmates refuse further contact and assistance? The answer would appear to be that they have been so effectively intimidated that they are forced to remain silent.
 
Surely, these ongoing incidents are hardly in accord with the laudable objectives of the new FDOC administration.
 
Please tell me what is being done to rein in the staff terrorists that have turned serving a sentence into an endless nightmare for Jewish prisoners. This is very serious business!
 
Thanks for your instant assistance,
Sid Kleiner
SKLEINER@COMCAST.NET
239-591-2649

From:	kimnugentp@aim.com
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 10:30 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Please help in Charlotte County!!!

 Dear Governor Bush,
 
I was born and raised in Florida.  I have lived in Charlotte County for about 14 years.  Since Hurricane Charlie things have run amock here.  Not only did Charlie destroy us but now our own county government is destroying us.  After Charlie our insurance sky-rocketed, our property rates tripled, and our FPL (due to fuel prices) has doubled.  Now the good higher ups in Charlotte County have raised impact fees from $9,000 to $19,000.  Charlotte county now is going to have a meeting or continuation of meeting, original meeting got too heated and had to reschedule, on July 20th, at 5:00, in the Tentatorium, in order to raise the property taxes to a rediculous amount.  How is a average, hard-working family of four supposed to live these days?
 
Now that the building and property boom have slowed why is Charlotte County being so greedy?  Don't you ever get tired of all the greed and lies?  I know you have heard numerous complaints about the high cost of living but I'm sure you have to agree something has got to give, hopefully not the human spirit.
 
Thank You For Your Time,
Kimberly Nugent in Port Charlotte, Florida

From:	indianpeterack@aol.com
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 10:21 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Senate denies funds for new border fence

Senate denies funds for new border fence

Complete article at: 
http://www.washtimes.com/national/20060714-120633-1188r.htm

Less than two months after voting overwhelmingly to build 370 miles of new fencing along the border with Mexico, the Senate yesterday voted against providing funds to build it.  "We do a lot of talking. We do a lot of legislating," said Sen. Jeff Sessions, the Alabama Republican whose amendment to fund the fence was killed on a 71-29 vote. "The things we do often sound very good, but we never quite get there." 

    Mr. Sessions offered his amendment to authorize $1.8 billion to pay for the fencing that the Senate voted 83-16 to build along high-traffic areas of the border with Mexico. In the same vote on May 17, the Senate also directed 500 miles of vehicle barriers to be built along the border. 

    "If we never appropriate the money needed to construct these miles of fencing and vehicle barriers, those miles of fencing and vehicle barriers will never actually be constructed," Mr. Sessions told his colleagues yesterday before the vote.

 Dear Ms. Shreve:

 Thank you for your recent correspondence to Governor Bush regarding your
 applications for assistance. The Governor asked that I respond to you on
 his behalf.

 According to case notes, your children were approved for Medically Needy
 coverage with a share of cost, effective June 1, 2006. Notes also reflect
 that you were denied Medicaid coverage for yourself and Food Stamps
 because
 you failed to comply with up-front registration with Child Support
 Enforcement. Although you verified you were receiving child support,
 program policy requires that you go to the Child Support Enforcement
 Office
 and complete necessary paperwork.

 I suggest that you reapply for benefits and complete the necessary
 paperwork for Child Support Enforcement.

 850-595-8107.

From:	DMS22@aol.com

From:	June Maxam <jmaxam1@nycap.rr.com>
Sent:	Friday, July 14, 2006 8:27 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Does Florida Have Double Standards?

http://www.northcountrygazette.org/articles/071306DoubleStandards.html
Double Standards

By June Maxam 	

The St. Petersburg Times, long an advocate for Michael Schiavo, has gone on the attack against one of his accusers, registered nurse Carla Sauer Iyer, a former caregiver of Terri Schindler Schiavo.

Florida's Department of Health says Iyer broke confidentiality rules for discussing the Schiavo case and the medical condition of the disabled woman on national television and is.

In their "balanced" article, Times reporter Lorri Helfand neglected to mention that Michael Schiavo himself is the subject of a complaint before the state's Board of Nursing for filing false statements with the court, submitting a guardianship application containing falsified academic credentials.
http://www.northcountrygazette.org/articles/062506SchiavoNurse.html
http://www.northcountrygazette.org/articles/031606NoProbableCause.html 
http://www.northcountrygazette.org/articles/042006BushRevisit.html

In fact, The Times failed to mention that Schiavo himself is a registered nurse and subject to the same rules and regulations as Iyer. The Times, apparently trying to portray Schiavo in the best light possible while attempting to discredit Iyer, also forgot to mention that Schiavo flunked his nursing exam on the first try.

In a classic case of the pot calling the kettle black, saying something about someone else that is actually true of yourself, Michael Schiavo is quoted as saying that Iyer "violated her oath" and "is getting what she deserves".

Schiavo and his attorney, right to die advocate George Felos who was paid with monies from Terri's trust fund that were earmarked by a malpractice jury and judge and for her rehabilitation and therapy, had claimed that they were defending Terri's right to privacy. In an interview on the Larry King show in October 2003, Felos claimed that Michael had tried to protect Terri's right to privacy.

Terri had sustained brain damage during a still unexplained incident on Feb. 25, 1990, when her brain was deprived of oxygen for four to six minutes. After her husband unsuccessfully tried to kill her by sepsis by withholding medical treatment, illegal in Florida, he then sought to end her life by obtaining a court order to withhold her food and water and on March 31, 2005, Terri died of marked dehydration 13 days after her feeding tube was removed, ending nearly 12 years of court battles between Schiavo and Terri's parents, Bob and Mary Schindler who fought to keep her alive.

"I have fought so long to keep her out of the public eye", Schiavo said, yet his actions did just the opposite and he is now exploiting her name to advance his and Derek Newton's political interests, retaliating against those who voted against killing Terri. Michael Schiavo has decimated Terri's right to privacy in his book by revealing embarrassing and intimate details about Terri's medical condition. Schiavo is the one who made Terri's name and her plight recognizable worldwide by taking the matter into the court, seeking a court order to end her life. He has pandered for money for the political action committee which exploits Terri's name for his politicial vindictiveness and has used Terri for financial gain in speaking appearances, selling the movie rights to his book and the book itself.

The St. Petersburg Times is owned by the Poynter Institute of which bioethicist Arthur Caplan is a member of the board of trustees. Caplan, one of the most outspoken advocates for Terri's death, appeared at his home University of Pennsylvania in May at a bioethics symposium with Schiavo, death Judge George Greer, hospice CEO Mary Labyak, the late Ronald Cranford and others who were joined in the long effort to end the disabled woman's life.
http://www.northcountrygazette.org/articles/021606MediaBias.html
http://www.northcountrygazette.org/articles/051206SchiavoInsult.html
http://www.northcountrygazette.org/articles/050306OverTheLine.html

The Times quoted DOH spokesman Doc Kokol as saying that "divulging confidential patient information violates state code and federal law". 

The Times article said that "While federal privacy regulations allow the release of patient information in some judicial proceedings, that doesn't open the door to discussing it on TV or elsewhere", attributing to George Annas, chairman of the department of health law, bioethics and human rights at Boston University School of Public Health.

And that includes Michael Schiavo.

Annas hosted a symposium at Boston University on the first anniversary of Terri's death at which death judge George Greer appeared with Cranford. Greer was given another superficial award called the Pike Prize.
http://www.northcountrygazette.org/articles/050306OverTheLine.html

What Annas is in essence saying, if Carla Iyer violated federal privacy regulations, so did Michael Schiavo, egregiously and in violation of his "oath". If Florida's DOH is preparing to revoke Iyer's nursing license for divulging confidential patient information by giving a television interview 10 years after she was a caregiver for Terri, then Michael Schiavo's must also be revoked for divulging confidential information about his "patient" Terri whom he and others have publicly acknowledged was under his direct supervision and care. Such violation of Terri's privacy by her husband and guardian would be in addition to his falsification of the academic credentials and submission of a false guardianship application to the court.

Iyer had been employed as the charge nurse from April of 1995 to Aug. 11, 1996 at Palm Gardens while Terri Schiavo was a resident there and in August, 2003, gave a sworn affidavit to the attorney representing Terri's parents, Mary and Robert Schindler Sr., in their challenge to the guardianship of Michael Schiavo and his petition to remove his wife's feeding tube in order to cause her death.
http://www.terrisfight.org/userfiles/File/Affidavit%20C%20Iyer%20082903.pdf

Iyer said in her affidavit that Schiavo was fixated on when his wife was going to die, allegedly asking "When is that bitch gonna die?", "Has she died yet?" and "When is she going to die?"

She later, at the request of legal counsel for Gov. Jeb Bush gave a sworn affidavit in December, 2003 for submission with the Governor's response the legal challenge of Terri's Law which was signed into law in October, 2003 by Gov. Bush resulting in the reinsertion of the feeding tube after Judge George Greer had ordered it removed. Ultimately, Terri's Law was ruled unconstitutional. 
AFFIDAVIT

She says that when she agreed to aid in the Governor's defense of Schiavo's lawsuit against him challenging the constitutionality of Terri's Law, she didn't expect retaliation by a state agency against her that would result in the revocation of her nursing license and single her out for speaking out against Michael Schiavo, a violation of her First Amendment rights and for discussing what was already a matter of public record.

On March, 21, 2005, and in the days following the removal of Terri's feeding tube on March 18 until her death of March 31, Iyer and many others, including nurse Michael Schiavo, were interviewed on television about their roles in the Schiavo case.

Although Iyer was simply relating what was already a matter of court record and a topic in many living rooms worldwide, a woman from Sutton, Massachusetts, herself a registered nurse, took exception to Iyer being interviewed on CNN, complaining to DOH's Division of Medical Quality Assurance on March 22, 2005, the day after Iyer's interview initially aired, saying that Iyer had made "inflammatory remarks" regarding Michael Schiavo.

"On March 22, 2005, I watched and heard Carla Sauer-Iyer interviewed on CNN television", Eileen Sullivan's complaint says. "The interview was repeated several times during the day on March 22nd. Ms. Sauer-Iyer was commenting on her relationship with Theresa Schiavo, a patient at Woodside Hospice, as her LPN at the time of their relationship of patient nurse. Ms. Sauer-Iyer made inflammatory comments regarding Mrs. Schiavo's husband, Michael (e.g., "when is that b-i-t-c-h (spelled out by Ms. Sauer-Iyer) going to die?" Ms. Sauer Iyer also made unsubstantiated comments regarding her patient's medical condition commenting that with "just a little bit of therapy", Mrs. Schiavo could be rehabilitated. I suggest the Florida Board of Registration view the complete interview that Ms. Sauer-Iyer gave to CNN".

Sullivan maintains that Iyer's comments violated the Nurse Practice Act, the same code which Michael Schiavo is subject to as a nurse.
The 2005 Florida Statutes - Title XXXII - Chapter 464 - Nursing

Schiavo, self-acknowledged principal caregiver of Terri Schindler Schiavo, discussed intimate and private details of his wife's medical condition on the Larry King Show on Oct. 27, 2003, and other shows, totally decimating any claim that he was protecting her right to privacy.
AUDIO TAPE OF LARRY KING SHOW Oct. 27, 2003 (requires Real Player)
TRANSCRIPT OF THE LARRY KING SHOW Oct. 27, 2003

KING: We're back with Michael Schiavo. With him is his attorney, George Felos. What is the current medical state of Terri? 

SCHIAVO: Terri is in a chronic, persistent vegetative state.

KING: Meaning she has...

SCHIAVO: She has no awareness, no consciousness. She's in a contracted state. Her hands, her arms, her legs are contracted. 

Later in the interview:

SCHIAVO: Yes. Terri's had perfect care. She just had her teeth cleaned three months ago.(Editor's Note: After years of neglect) And to touch on the gynecological, the gynecologists that took care of her told me -- and I'm only following what doctors tell me to do -- because it's so hard -- and I'm sorry to be so explicit -- to open her legs. She doesn't open them like you and I would at a gynecological examine. 

KING: You to pry them apart? 

SCHIAVO: Yes. 

KING: So it's hard to do a gynecological exam? 

SCHIAVO: Right. Right. So unless there's blood, or if there's foul smelling -- I'm sorry to be so explicit, but that's what it's all about.

In the section on the complaint which asked what would satisfy her complaint, Sullivan said that "Ms. Sauer-Iyer should be disciplined for her breach of faith with Theresa Schiavo and with her profession as a registered nurse. I was embarrassed that she would violate her oath on national television".

Michael Schiavo not only violated his oath as a nurse on national television, he grossly and intentionally for his own purposes and those of his attorney violated Terri Schindler Schiavo's right to privacy and continues to do so.

That was not only unjust and unconstitutional but a violation of the Nurse Practice Act.

That begs the question: when is the Board of Nursing going to revoke Michael Schiavo's nursing license? 7-13-06

Walt Cook <Walt_Cook@dcf.state.fl.us> wrote:





Dear Ms. Shreve:

Thank you for your recent correspondence to Governor Bush regarding your
applications for assistance. The Governor asked that I respond to you on
his behalf.

According to case notes, your children were approved for Medically Needy
coverage with a share of cost, effective June 1, 2006. Notes also reflect
that you were denied Medicaid coverage for yourself and Food Stamps because
you failed to comply with up-front registration with Child Support
Enforcement. Although you verified you were receiving child support,
program policy requires that you go to the Child Support Enforcement Office
and complete necessary paperwork.

I suggest that you reapply for benefits and complete the necessary
paperwork for Child Support Enforcement.

If you have questions, please contact our Client Relations Office at
850-595-8107.

Sincerely,

Walter R. Cook
District Administrator - Team "1"
Escambia, Santa Rosa , Okaloosa, Walton Counties
160 Government Center, Suite 611
Pensacola, Florida 32502-5734
(850) 595-8211

From: Rhonda Vroman [mailto:rvroman@insync-com.com] 
Sent: Thursday, July 06, 2006 7:49 PM
To: 'jeb.bush@myflorida.com'
Subject: Continue Navarre Beach Renourishment Now 

 

Dear Governor Bush,

 

I am a property owner on Navarre Beach, specifically Navarre Towers, unit 203 and my purpose in writing today is to express concern for the recent decision made to halt beach renourishment until October, and to seek your assistance in reversing this decision. 

 

Like many other people, I have concern for the recent killing of turtles during the dredging operation and understand that the turtles, and other species that are protected, require careful consideration.  It is also my understanding that the number of turtles lost is far below that allowed for the Gulf this year. This, coupled with the fact that the to close the gap between the renourishment areas will take less than a month to complete, and without completion leaves the beach at great risk, causes me to make this appeal. 

 

The balance between progress and exploitation, between man and nature is precarious at best, and both sides of the issue can be readily debated. The decision was made to renourish Navarre Beach; and putting this decision into action took far too long. Nevertheless, the danger the current situation presents can be minimized with the continuations of dredging.  

 

I thank you for your consideration and understand decisions like this must carefully balance all sides, weighing short and long term consequences. I ask that you consider what can be done now to complete the beach renourishment at Navarre Beach. 

 

Sincerely, 

 

 

 

Rhonda Vroman Alexander 

602.840.7463 

rvroman@insync-com.com

From:	Michael Bohannon <MFB1143@peoplepc.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 6:25 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	My 2 Cents Worth of Florida Insurance Companies that Shouldn't Exist

I sent this to letters to the editor, but it hasn't been published...thought maybe you'd like to see it, since you're being bombarded on the protection rackets.
Mike Bohannon
Melbourne, Fl   
757-3699

Protection Rackets
We are now seeing the true colors of the Florida insurance industry showing through.  The so-called insurance industry is the result of the evolution from the mob protection rackets and it looks like they are again resorting to some of their old methods.  State Farm, and now Nationwide, are demanding 70+% premium increases after years of increases…not to mention years of record profits *.  Worse, they use no rhyme or reason in their demands.  Lake County, which is way inland, has the highest increase.  Flagler County, which is on the coast, has the lowest increase.  All increases are predicated on a worst-case scenario…like Armageddon.  None are necessary.
The only thing wrong with Florida insurance is that the inept Florida Insurance Commission allowed these mob protection rackets to set up "Florida-only" subsidiaries...such as Allstate Floridian, State Farm Florida, Nationwide Florida, et al.
All this accomplished, other than providing proof-positive that the Florida Insurance Commission is worthless, was to allow the national insurance companies to protect their massive profits and their massive catastrophic funds.  State Farm alone has a $44 billion catastrophic fund and no claim from Florida is paid from it.
Florida should do 3 things right now:
1.	Disband the Florida Insurance Commission - we'd be better off with nothing than what we have.
2.	Un-incorporate all of the "Floridian" insurance subsidiaries.
3.	Tell these companies to either settle for good profits nationwide or take all of their insurance products and get out of Florida.  
Mike Bohannon
Melbourne
757-3699

* After catastrophic storm seasons in 2004 and 2005, State Farm recorded net profits of $5.3 billion in 2005, Allstate reported $3.2 Billion, and on and on and on.

8.         First Reading of an ordinance and scheduling of public hearing.  

(Note: The First Reading is not a public hearing and no discussion or testimony will be taken unless the ordinance changes permitted conditional or prohibited uses as required by State Statute.)

 

a.         ORDINANCE 06-009 AMENDING THE SANIBEL CODE, PART II LAND DEVELOPMENT CODE, CHAPTER 126 ZONING, ARTICLE XIV SUPPLEMENTARY DISTRICT REGULATIONS, TO ADD A NEW SECTION 126-1029 BONUS OUTDOOR SEATS FOR DINING, TO ESTABLISH PROCEDURES AND STANDARDS FOR PROVIDING BONUS OUTDOOR DINING AT RESTAURANTS; PROVIDING FOR CONFLICT AND SEVERANCE; PROVIDING FOR CODIFICATION; AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE

 

b.         ORDINANCE 06-010 CALLING FOR AN ELECTION TO SUBMIT TO THE SANIBEL ELECTORATE AN AMENDMENT TO THE SANIBEL CHARTER; PROPOSING AN AMENDMENT TO ARTICLE III, LEGISLATIVE, TO ADD A NEW SECTION 3.18 TO THE SANIBEL CITY CHARTER (AS CODIFIED) ENTITLED THE SANIBEL VISION STATEMENT; PROVIDING FOR THE CONDUCT OF THE ELECTION BY THE LEE COUNTY SUPERVISOR OF ELECTIONS; PROVIDING BALLOT LANGUAGE; PROVIDING FOR NOTICE OF ELECTION AND CANVASSING OF RESULTS; PROVIDING FOR ELECTION AND EFFECTIVE DATE OF AMENDMENTS UPON REFERENDUM APPROVAL; AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE (Councilman Brown)

 

c.         ORDINANCE 06-011 AMENDING THE SANIBEL CODE, PART II, SUBPART A, GENERAL ORDINANCES, CHAPTER 10 ANIMALS, ARTICLE 1, BY AMENDING SECTION 10-1 DEFINITIONS, TO INCLUDE A DEFINITION FOR EXOTIC ANIMAL; ADDING A NEW SECTION 10-10 ENTITLED EXOTIC ANIMAL; RELEASE PROHIBITED; PROVIDING FOR THE PROHIBITION ON THE INTENTIONAL OF UNINTENTIONAL RELEASE OF ANY EXOTIC ANIMAL, SPECIALLY INCLUDING ANY BIRD, FISH, AND/OR REPTILE, WITHIN THE BOUNDARY OF THE CITY OF SANIBEL, FLORIDA; PROVIDING THAT NOTHING IN THIS ORDINANCE SHOULD BE CONSTRUED TO PERTAIN TI MIGRATORY BIRDS OR FISH THAT MAY TEMPORARILY INHABIT THE ISLAND OR ITS WATERS AS THEY PASS THROUGH SANIBEL ON THEIR WAY TO AND/OR FROM OTHER JURISDICTIONS; PROVIDING FOR PENALTY; PROVIDING FOR CODIFICATION; PROVIDING FOR CONFLICT AND SEVERANCE; AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE (Councilman Rothman)

 

9.         CONSENT AGENDA (ANY PERSON MAY REQUEST THAT COUNCIL REMOVE AN ITEM FROM THE CONSENT AGENDA FOR DISCUSSION BY NOTIFYING THE CITY MANAGER/CITY CLERK, OR A COUNCIL MEMBER, PRIOR TO THE MEETING)

 

a.         Approval of minutes:     May 18, 2006 Regular Meeting, June 06, 2006 Regular Meeting, and June 20, 2006 Regular Meeting

 

b.         RESOLUTION 06-095 AMENDING RESOLUTIONS NO. 03-071 AND 03-087 WHICH LEVIED THE RESPECTIVE PRELIMINARY AND FINAL SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS, AND THE ASSOCIATED PROPERTY LIENS THEREFORE, FOR THE SANIBEL SEWER COLLECTION SYSTEM EXPANSION PHASE 3A; DEFERRING THE INTEREST ACCRUAL DATE FROM JULY 1, 2004 TO NOVEMBER 1, 2004; AND DEFERRING THE COLLECTION DATE FROM TAX YEAR 2004 TO 2006, AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE

 

c.         RESOLUTION 06-096 ESTABLISHING AN AUDIT COMMITTEE PURSUANT TO FLORIDA STATUTE, SECTION 218.391 FOR THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF ASSISTING THE CITY OF SANIBEL IN SELECTING AN AUDITOR TO CONDUCT THE ANNUAL FINANCIAL AUDIT; AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE

 

d.            RESOLUTION NO. 06-097 AUTHORIZING A SEPARATE INVESTMENT ACCOUNT IN THE LOCAL GOVERNMENT TRUST FUND ADMINISTERED BY THE FLORIDA STATE BOARD OF ADMINISTRATION FOR INVESTMENT OF THE $8.35 MILLION GENERAL OBLIGATION BOND PROCEEDS FOR THE SANIBEL RECREATION CENTER PROJECT, AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE

 

e.         Reject bid received for construction of a Shared Use Path on Bailey Road.  Cougar Contracting submitted the only bid in the amount of $235,405, while only $50,000 was budgeted for the project

 

f.          Renewal of an Interagency Agreement for Juvenile Assessment Center between the City of Sanibel and Lee County Sheriffs Department

j.          RESOLUTION 06-101 APPROVING A LEASE AGREEMENT FOR THE WEST LIGHTHOUSE CARETAKERS COTTAGE WITH RANDAL D. WRIGHT; AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE

 

k.         RESOLUTION 06-102 APPROVING BUDGET AMENDMENT/TRANSFER NO. 2006-071 AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE (to roll forward unspent grant and local match funds from FY 2005 to FY 2006 to complete the Clams/Dinkins Bayou Capital Project in the amount of $287,112)

 

l.          RESOLUTION 06-103 APPROVING BUDGET AMENDMENT/TRANSFER NO. 2006-072 AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE (roll forward actual beginning fund balances from FY 2005 to FY 2006.  Funds are being appropriated to Ending Fund Balance for re-appropriation in the subsequent fiscal year (FY 07) except for certain Special Revenue and Capital Project Funds, which are being appropriated for the completion of the respective projects in the amount of $206,637)

 

m.        RESOLUTION 06-104 APPROVING BUDGET AMENDMENT/TRANSFER NO. 2006-073 AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE (to roll forward unspent South Florida Water Management District grant funds which were awarded in FY 2005 to FY 2006 to complete the Sanibel River Restoration Project)

 

n.         RESOLUTION 06-105 APPROVING BUDGET AMENDMENT/TRANSFER NO. 2006-074 AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE (to reimburse the General Fund Disaster Reserve Fund for $670,272 of the $1,345,000 from the Disaster Reserve for the clean-up of Hurricane Wilma and to appropriate the estimated $908,782 to be received from FEMA.  $804,397 has already been received from FEMA as of June 30, 2006)

 

o.         RESOLUTION 06-106 APPROVING BUDGET AMENDMENT/TRANSFER NO. 2006-075 AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE (to appropriate the FY 2006 and final Hurricane Charley recovery expenditures (Fund #113) and transfer of excess bond proceeds of $1,135,768 to the $10M FLGFC Debt Service Fund to pay down the principal balance on the Hurricane Charley debt.  After this pay down, the projected principal balance remaining at September 30, 2006 will be $1,707,000)

 

p.         RESOLUTION 06-107 APPROVING BUDGET AMENDMENT/TRANSFER NO. 2006-076 AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE (to appropriate a one-time award of $5,000 from the L. A. T. Foundation to fund the design, construction and installation of interpretive signage for each of the Sanibel Historical Village and Museums 9 buildings)

 

q.         Authorize the Shared Use Path Master Plan consultant, Sprinkle Consulting, Inc., to proceed with the previously deferred tasks and subtask

 

r.          Request from B. I. G. Arts for approval 2006/2007 Special Event Permits to serve wine during intermissions

 

s.          Approval of an Interlocal Agreement between the City of Sanibel and Lee County for the construction of restrooms (outhouse replica) at the Historical Museum and authorize the City Manager to execute agreement

5.   RESOLUTION 06-089 AUTHORIZING AND SCHEDULING A BINDING REFERENDUM PERTAINING TO THE EXPENDITURE OF CITY FUNDS FOR LITIGATION RELATING TO LAKE OKEECHOBEE AND CALOOSAHATCHEE RIVER FRESHWATER RELEASES WHICH HAVE DEGRADED AND ARE DEGRADING THE WATERS ADJACENT TO SANIBEL, INCLUDING NEARBY BAYS AND ESTUARIES; CALLING FOR AND ORDERING A BINDING REFERENDUM TO BE HELD IN THE CITY OF SANIBEL TO DETERMINE WHETHER A MAJORITY OF ELECTORS PARTICIPATING IN SUCH REFERENDUM APPROVE THE USE OF CITY FUNDS TO INITIATE AND PURSUE LITIGATION WITH THE PURPOSE OF REDUCING, MINIMIZING AND ELIMINATING THE DEGRADED AND DEGRADING WATER QUALITY DIRECTLY RESULTING FROM FRESH WATER RELEASES FROM LAKE OKEECHOBEE AND THE CALOOSAHATCHEE RIVER; ESTABLISHING THE DATE OF THE ELECTION; REQUESTING THE LEE COUNTY SUPERVISOR OF ELECTIONS CONDUCT THE ELECTION IN ACCORDANCE WITH LAWS AND REGULATIONS AND CERTIFY THE RESULTS TO THE SANIBEL CITY COUNCIL; AND PROVIDING AN EFFECTIVE DATE

17.       ADJOURNMENT

 

IF A PERSON DECIDES TO APPEAL A DECISION MADE BY THE COUNCIL ON ANY MATTER CONSIDERED AT THIS MEETING/HEARING, SUCH PERSON MAY NEED TO ENSURE THAT A VERBATIM RECORD OF THE PROCEEDINGS IS MADE, TO INCLUDE THE TESTIMONY AND EVIDENCE UPON WHICH ANY SUCH APPEAL IS TO BE BASED.

 

IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT, PERSONS NEEDING A SPECIAL ACCOMMODATION TO PARTICIPATE IN THIS PROCEEDING SHOULD CONTACT JIM ISOM, DIRECTOR OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES NO LATER THAN ONE DAY PRIOR TO THE PROCEEDINGS AT (239) 472-3700 FOR ASSISTANCE IF HEARING IMPAIRED OR TELEPHONE THE FLORIDA RELAY SERVICE AT 711.

 

Citizens may request to receive Sanibel City Council and Planning Commission meeting agenda directly via e-mail.  Citizens wishing to receive a copy of the agenda via e-mail may do so by visiting the Citys website at www.mysanibel.com Additionally, citizens may register to receive City announcements such as press releases.  Prior to requesting the agendas, the website reminds citizens that all e-mail addresses and requests submitted to the City are public information and governed by the applicable Florida Statute.

Sanibel City Council

 

 

RULES OF CIVILITY FOR PUBLIC PARTICIPATION

 

In recognition that public discourse is essential to the democratic system of government on April 16, 2002, Sanibel City Council adopted a Proclamation embracing civility in public deliberations.  

 

Therefore, Sanibel City Council sanctioned these rules for public participation while conducting meetings and workshops:

 

1.      Speakers are permitted to deliver his or her comments without interruption.

 

2.      Speakers and debates should focus on issues, not on persons or personalities.

 

3.      Persons are encouraged to participate in the governmental process.

 

4.      To allow time to hear all points of view, speakers are allotted 5 minutes each time they are recognized.

 

5.      Sidebar discussions while others are speaking are not permitted in Council Chambers.  These discussions are to be removed from the chamber so as not to be disruptive to those conducting and following Council business.  

 

6.      Only the speaker recognized by the Chairperson has the floor.  Speakers should raise their hand to be recognized.  Speakers should identify themselves for the record.  Speakers should utilize the microphone so that their comments can be recorded.

 

7.      Everyone wishing to speak on an issue is given an opportunity to speak before speakers are recognized for an opportunity to speak a second time on an issue.

 

8.      We seek to understand one anothers points of view.

 

9.      Anger, rudeness, ridicule, impatience and lack of respect for others are not acceptable behavior.  Demonstrations in support or opposition to a speaker or idea such as clapping, cheering, booing or hissing or intimidating body language are not permitted in Council Chambers or workshop facilities.

 

10.  We should all take initiative to make things better.  Our goal is to foster an environment, which encourages a fair discussion and exchange of ideas without fear of personal attacks.

 

Web Bug from http://rd.bcentral.com/op.aspx?ID=4269693&s=1518427

This is from sptimes.com and was in Sunday's paper.   


 


A house of human trafficking



The case of a Clearwater house that police say was a brothel has produced leads in targeting the No. 2 criminal industry.


By JACOB H. FRIES
Published July 2, 2006

  _____  


CLEARWATER - To look at the small tan house with orange trim and a scraggly tree in the front yard, one might never suspect it was a brothel.

But for several years up to 40 men a day slipped into the neighborhood unnoticed, many of them parking in a Sears lot across the street, police say.

They paid a doorman $25 and took a seat in the living room to wait their turn. On a television played pornographic videos while on the wall hung a calendar, the name of a different woman written across each week.

On the evening in May when police raided the house on Camellia Drive, officers found a 32-year-old woman named Mareielli, six customers and the doorman in charge, police say. They also discovered signs of something even more sinister.

"Human trafficking is alive and well in Clearwater," deputy police Chief Dewey Williams told the St. Petersburg Times recently. "We now know that for a fact."

The woman found at the house, detectives later learned, was not held against her will. But evidence and testimony from the doorman suggested that other prostitutes brought there had been lured from Mexico and forced into the sex industry, police say.

A clear signal, they say, is how the women were never seen outside and how the doorman, when he stepped out for a moment, always secured the door behind him.

This is not the first time Clearwater police think they have encountered a tentacle of human trafficking. In 2003, they shut down a prostitution operation at an apartment near Drew Street and U.S. 19 - similar to the one on Camellia Drive - but investigators couldn't tie it to a trafficking network.

Now, with leads produced from the most recent case, investigators have begun to watch another location in the city.

"It's here if we look for it," Williams said. "But it's going to take a dedicated effort to find it."

Clearwater police are trying to get some help. In April, the department, along with a victim services organization, submitted a federal grant application for $900,000 to create the Clearwater Area Task Force on Human Trafficking. With the funds, two full-time officers would be assigned to investigate human trafficking cases.

"Without the money, we will continue to struggle with the resources we have," Williams said.

* * *

Trafficking in people is not the same as smuggling them.

Human smugglers are typically paid to take people illegally across international borders, leaving them alone once they do so.

Traffickers, meanwhile, may transport people across borders, but they generate their profits through exploitation, coercing their victims into slavery, involuntary servitude or the commercial sex industry.

Each year, officials estimate, about 18,000 human trafficking victims are smuggled into the United States, with 2-million in the country at any time. After drug dealing, it is tied with illegal arms sales as the second largest criminal industry in the world, according to the Health and Human Services Department.

Florida ranks as the second most common destination for trafficking victims, behind California, with both states being home to large immigrant populations, says the Florida Coalition Against Human Trafficking.

But until recent years, Florida police and sheriff's deputies didn't give it much attention, officials say. Most agencies across the Tampa Bay area, from Pinellas to Hillsborough and Pasco counties, have now trained at least a few investigators how to spot signs of human trafficking.

"It's always been there, but like domestic violence was in 1970s, it has stayed in the shadows," said Shawn Ramsey, a detective at the Lee County Sheriff's Office. "As law enforcement, we've really been behind the curve on this."

The Lee County agency, however, created a specialized unit at the end of 2005 and then received the same federal grant that Clearwater police are now pursuing. Ramsey said detectives have now identified 15 brothels and helped to rescue seven women they believe to be victims.

"It's really too early to determine how widespread human trafficking is," Ramsey said.

Ramsey and others in law enforcement say investigating such cases present unique problems. The organizers are adept at blending into communities. They also intimidate their victims, threatening them or their families back home, and convincing them police are corrupt. The result is many victims hide themselves from officials and lie when discovered.

"The slave is not going to come to you," Ramsey said. "You have to find them."

To do that, officials need the public's help, he said. Authorities do not have enough resources to infiltrate all these networks without tips from residents living nearby.

* * *

Delivery driver Richard Wright, who has lived in the Skycrest neighborhood for six years, said he hadn't noticed anything strange until he saw squad cars surrounding 2095 Camellia Drive.

"I had no idea whatsoever," said Wright, 73, who had seen people often entering and leaving the home but didn't considered it unusual. "I really don't want to know."

The brothel had taken many precautions to avoid detection, in addition to having many customers park in the Sears lot, Clearwater police say. For example, the doorman, identified as 45-year-old Daniel Varela Rodriguez, regularly patrolled the neighborhood on foot or by bicycle, looking out for police, and changed his clothing each time. He also went to the office of the property owner, who was unaware of the brothel, to pay rent.

Rodriguez, who has been charged with deriving funds from prostitution, remains at the Pinellas County Jail in connection to his immigration status and could not be reached for comment. He does not face any charges of human trafficking, but police say he acknowledged knowing men who recruited women in Mexico, promising them jobs as nannies, only to force them to become prostitutes.

Once in Florida, the women, either freely or by coercion, would typically rotate each week among a network of brothels across the state, police say. This makes tracking the women difficult.

"These operations don't sit still," said Williams, the Clearwater deputy police chief. "They're here today and in Fort Myers tomorrow."

When officers raided the home on May 16, they found birth certificates, W-2 forms, receipts, bus tickets and other documents that detectives continue to sort through, police say. They also recovered a stash of playing cards that were distributed to customers when they paid and then left with the woman after sex.

The woman would return the cards, receiving a portion of the proceeds from the doorman, Williams said.

If Clearwater police and their partner nonprofit agency, World Relief, get the federal grant, half of the task force's money will be earmarked for rescued victims, he said. Without friends or family, the victims need temporary visas, housing and other support as the cases wind through the court system.

"It's horrible," Williams said. "These women are not only physically abused, but psychologically abused as well. They may be saved one day, but they may never be the same."

Please find below a letter I sent to our local paper which pretty much says it all. more than doubled.  This additional cost after making the “Charlie” repairs is typical of many business people throughout Florida.  I’m finding many of my customers leaving the state.  It sure would help if we could get something positive on this matter.  Thank you for anything you and your office can do to improve this situation.  

 

Respectfully,

 

 

Beth Headrick

 

 

 

Letter to the Editor

 

Punta Gorda and surrounding areas have done a fantastic job of helping their selves since Hurricane Charlie but I think it is time that our Local, State and Federal Representatives and our hopeful candidates get involved with a serious problem affecting all of us who work, live and play here whether full time or part time.   The insurance companies are pulling out of Florida in vast numbers, especially for condominiums and manufactured homes.  From what I’ve been told the only insurance available in many cases is Citizens, which with their monthly rate increases, approved by our government, is making cost unobtainable for many.   I can’t understand how the continued building of Condos in the area are going to be sold when insurance is so difficult to get.  This is not an isolated issue but affects everyone.  If people can’t afford to live here, they will leave.  Many already have.  Our State legislators don’t meet again until March.  Perhaps if we all got serious about this we could cause them to meet in a special session to help us all with this serious problem.  Get involved and call, write or email your legislators.  It can’t hurt and it just might help!

 

Beth Headrick

The Retreat Condominiums of Burnt Store Isles

1315 Narranja St. – Punta Gorda, FL 33950

From:	SMay1gator@aol.com

Subject:	Hurricane Mitigation Program - Question about its implementation

Thanks for the new hurricane damage mitigation program.  Was glad to see it passed and looked forward to having windows, gabled part of roof and garage doors looked at.  In the meantime, a week ago, my double garage door spring broke, making the garage unusable due to the weight of the door.  With a neighbor's help, was able lift the door to get my car out, but for all intents and purposes, it is unusable.  
 
Since I was planning to use this program to have both my double and the single car doors replaced with hurricane wind resistant/approved doors, I am having to go ahead this weekend to have the work done.  
 
When I inquired about the program and its provisions, I was distressed to learn that work done now cannot count toward or be reimbursed under the program.  
 
The effective date of work done under this program should become effective with the date that the legislation was approved and put into law.  The procedures development process should have nothing to do with the effective date of the law.  Isn't that the case?  What if it takes the procedure development/makers until January to get their act together?  We are in the midst of hurricane season NOW, and I am fortunate to find a garage door firm to do the work for me NOW.  As retirees, we need all the help we can get, with the rising costs of insurance, etc.
 
This implementation date oversight in the law must be addressed and corrected soonest.
 
Thank you.
 
Bruce May

Subject:	[*] Sandler Ranch

Brenda,
 
Mr. King, City of Venice Stormwater was kind enough to send me an electronic format of the 06/28/2006 investigation.  
 
This report is inconsistent with previous investigations that found pollution on the property.  In addition, we take two more exceptions to the report.  My interest is to follow the process and stay informed regarding Sandler Ranch.  The person responsible for your current investigation is Sarasota County Commissioner, Jon Thaxton
 
 

From: Jon Thaxton 

To: tmoconnor@comcast.net

Jon

Date:	 Fri, 17 Mar 2006 11:44:31 -0500	
From:	 "Bruce Maloney" <BMALONEY@scgov.net>	
To:	 "Jon Thaxton" <jthaxton@scgov.net>	
CC:	 "Laura Ammeson" <LAMMESO.SCGPost3.SCGDOM1@scgov.net>, "Theresa Connor" <Tconnor.SCGPost3.SCGDOM1@scgov.net>, tmoc917@yahoo.com	
Subject:	 Sanndler Ranch RV, boat & vehicle storage area	

We inspected this entire site on 2/23/06.

There are approx. 100 cars, trucks, boats and RVs on the site. I spoke 
with the owner of the site and obtained permission to enter. I checked 
under and around each for discharges. There were no large problems. The 
site was mowed and well kept with no evidence of discharges to ditches.
 I found 3 small areas of grass with oil (each less than 6" square) 
under outboard engines, one open gas can with no spillage & one area with 
dead grass approx. 2' by 5' and a fuel odor on the grass but not into 
the soil. 
The owner was informed of each location and will clean up and notify 
the renters in those spots. She says they are not allowed to work on 
vehicles and will put language to that effect in her lease agreements. She 
stated that 2 people from a craft fair in Venice did stay overnight 1 
night a week ago but it is not allowed and there are no water, sewer or 
electric hook ups.
The fields do have cows grazing in them and she says she will put up 
with no discharges.

 We informed DEP, County Code Enforcement, City Of Venice and the 
caller of our findings. We originally thought half the site was in Sarasota 
County and the other half in the City Of Venice. I have found that the 
entire property has been annexed into the City Of Venice and is under 
their zoning. 
I called Roger Clark with The City Of Venice Zoning Dept. yesterday & 
today, left the info and have had no response. I will let you know when 
I here more.

Tim O'Connor

 Governor Bush:

What do expect you are getting what you give.
READ BELOW:
ENERGY -- SENATE DEAL REACHED ON OFF-SHORE DRILLING EXPANSION: Yesterday, 
Sen. Barack Obama (D-IL) helped launch the Kick the Oil Habit Road Trip, a 
cross-country road trip in a flex-fuel vehicle to raise awareness about 
E85 fuel (85 percent ethanol, 15 percent gasoline) and the severe lack of 
E85 fueling stations around the country. (Come along for the ride.) The 
same day, Senate conservatives decided to feed America's oil addiction. A 
deal was announced "on legislation to expand offshore drilling that would 
open up vast tracts to exploration," CongressDaily reports. "The agreement 
would allow for drilling in 1.7 million acres in the eastern Gulf of 
Mexico" and "lift production bans in 6.3 million acres south of that 
area," covering "most federal waters outside of the Gulf of Mexico." Sen. 
Bill Nelson (D-FL) "may still try to filibuster the legislation," and Gov. 
Jeb Bush (R-FL) "has been especially adamant in opposition to efforts to 
increase offshore drilling." But the bill has bipartisan support, possibly 
enough to overcome a filibuster, despite the fact that it's a bad idea. 
Drilling close to the shore is an environmental hazard and even "a small 
spill could wreak havoc on the fragile coastline and beach areas of 
numerous states and jeopardize billions in tourism revenue." It's also not 
an efficient or necessary way to increase energy supplies. Currently, 
there are 328 trillion cubic feet of natural gas in offshore locations 
already available for drilling and the industry has only leased 10 percent 
of the area available. There are only 78 trillion cubic feet of natural 
gas available in the coastal areas that are currently off limits. While 
gimmicks like coastal drilling move forward, real long-term solutions -- 
including energy efficiency and the development of alternative fuels -- 
have been overlooked.


Sincerely,


Joseph Daraio
(561) 965-9178

gpierce@azleg.state.az.us; jburges@azleg.state.az.us; maalvarez@azleg.state.az.us; tprezels@azleg.state.az.us; BillFrist@US.senate.tn.us; dateline@nbc.com
Subject:	HOA Flag Issue Going National

From the industry of the CAI 
June 18, 2006 
Posted by Joe West at 08:15 PM 


It must be an election year; 

Its that time again ---- time to roll out all of the legislation to cater to the emotions of the activist, advocates and special interest groups -- in other words an election year. 

Federal Congressman Bartlett (R-MD) expects to bring to the House floor the "Freedom to Display the Flag Act," a resolution that would bar condominium associations, cooperative associations homeowner associations, property owners associations or 
real estate management associations from creating restrictions on flagpoles to fit building or neighborhood standards. 

Here is the bill, originally introduced in 2005: 

109th CONGRESS 
1st Session 

H. R. 42 
To ensure that the right of an individual to display the flag of the United States on residential property not be abridged. 

IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES 

January 4, 2005 

Mr. BARTLETT of Maryland introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services 
            ---------------------------------------------------------- 

A BILL 
To ensure that the right of an individual to display the flag of the United States on residential property not be abridged. 

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, 

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. 

This Act may be cited as the `Freedom to Display the American Flag, Act of 2005'. 

SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. 

For purposes of this Act -- 

(1) the term `flag of the United States' has the meaning given the term `flag, standard, colors, or ensign' under section 3 of title 4, United States Code; 

(2) the terms `condominium association' and `cooperative association' 
have the meanings given such terms under section 604 of Public Law 96- 
399 (15 U.S.C. 3603); 

(3) the term `residential real estate management association' has the meaning of homeowner and property owner associations as given such term under section 528 of the Internal Revenue 
Code of 1986 (26 U.S.C. 528); and 

(4) the term `member'-- 

(A) as used with respect to a condominium association, means an owner of a condominium unit (as defined under section 604 of Public Law 96- 
399 (15 U.S.C. 3603) within such association; 

(B) as used with respect to a cooperative association, means a cooperative unit owners (as defined under section 604 of Public Law 96-399 (15 U.S.C. 3603) within such association; and 

(C) as used with respect to a residential real estate management association, means an owner of a residential property within a subdivision, development, or similar area subject to any policy or deed restriction adopted by such association. 

SEC. 3. RIGHT TO DISPLAY THE FLAG OF THE UNITED STATES. 

A condominium association, cooperative association, or residential real estate management association may not adopt or enforce any policy, or enter into any agreement, that would restrict or prevent a member of the association from displaying the flag of the United 
States on residential property within the association with respect to which such member has a separate ownership interest or a right to exclusive possession or use. 

SEC. 4. LIMITATIONS. 

Nothing in this Act shall be considered to permit any display or use that is inconsistent with-- 

(1) any provision of chapter 1 of title 4, United States Code, or any rule or custom pertaining to the proper display or use of the flag of the United States (as established pursuant to such chapter or any 
otherwise applicable provision of law); or 

(2) any reasonable restriction pertaining to the time, place, or manner of displaying the flag of the United States necessary to protect a substantial interest of the condominium association, cooperative association, or residential real estate management 
association. 

This last part is interesting, since no one will be able to agree on what is "reasonable" or what a "substantial interest" means. 
I see more litigation ahead. 

In California, the state Senate just passed SB 551, which created an ombudsman's office, and in order to reduce the trial load of civil courts, establishes a mechanism that allows owners to file complaints 
against associations (of course if they were serious about reducing the court cases, they would also handle enforcement issues, actions by the board 
against a homeowner and homeowner against board members, so reducing the trial load is not the real issue), 
allows for associations to be fined if they don't correct anything the new bureau tells them to (of course it doesn't mention that it will be the homeowners who will actually be paying the fines), and establishes a new 
level of bureaucracy that the associations will have to pay to support. 
It requires board members to sign a document that they've read all of the CC&R's, rules, and the statues of Non-Profit Davis-Sterling Act (or summary - its the 
state's Common Interest Development Act) and provides for education of board members. 

This one is going to be fun to watch. 
If it passes the House and is signed by the Governor, its going to take years and a lot of litigation to work out. 

Florida, Nevada and Arizona are also hotly in pursuit of Pro-Homeowner legislation designed to reign in those thousands of incompetent and abusive boards. 

Well, the problem is going to be solved fairly soon, when it becomes next-to-impossible to find 
anyone to run for a board of directors in these associations. 
I'm sure homeowners will prefer instead a court-appointed receiver telling them what to do. 
MailScanner has detected a possible fraud attempt from "www.communityassociations.net" claiming to be CAI.net 
Posted by joewest at 08:15 PM

To: Jeb Bush ; martinez@myflorida.com ; USAtty Gonzales ; George W Bush 
Sent: Thursday, July 13, 2006 12:14 PM
Subject: "I want my Country back"

 
Please pass this along.  Let's see if we can send it to everyone in the USA that has a computer.
 
"I WANT MY COUNTRY BACK!"- 
 
 
 
 
By Rick Roberts - 760 KFMB AM 
 
I don't mean to go off on a rant here, but here's the bottom line, I want my country back.
 
I want my kids to be able to walk to the store or walk to school without being abducted by some 3-time convicted child molester.  And the politically correct powers that be in this country just can't seem to get over themselves with "CAN'T WE JUST HELP THIS PERSON!" No!  You can't.  But they're let loose to prey on more children.  I want my kids back. 
 
I want my country back.
 
I don't agree with everything this President does.  I've never agreed with anything 100% that any President has done or said.
 
You know, I was very young during the Vietnam War.  So I probably missed that thing by a hair.    I don't know whether I would have agreed with that or not at the time.  I was too stupid to have an opinion at that point and time even though I thought I did.
 
I want my country back.
 
I want some semblance of respect for authority, whether I agree with it all or not.
 
I want the Boy Scouts to be "boy" scouts, not boy and "we think she's a girl" scouts.  I want Girl Scouts to be "girl" scouts not Girl Scouts and "Bruce."
 
I want my country back.
 
I want to be able to wake up in the morning knowing that I can walk outside without some gang-banger on parole taking my life. 
 
Or being able to go down and purchase a car without having to worry about you know 90% of the parts being made overseas in some sweatshop.
 
I want my politicians, when they finally do get my vote, to do what they said they were going to do in the first place.
 
I want the Abramoff's of the world to be labeled what they....nothing more than organized crime in a better suit.
 
I want people to say something and when they say something look at me in the eye.  And mean what they say.    Not say what they think I want to hear.
And then do what they want to later politically or any other way.
 
I want to be able to go out and work and make a decent wage and buy a home.  Half the people that are listening to me right now can't even afford to buy a house unless they're working three jobs.
 
And I want America to be America.    All of those opportunities, all of those things that made her great, I want those returned to the forefront.   If you want to come to this country we welcome you with open arms.   We simply ask that you abide by our laws.  I don't want you to snub your nose at our laws,  then take advantage of our opportunities, and then cling to the constitution most of which you can't even read because you don't speak the language.
 
I want us to secure our borders because the country is worth securing.  The people that live here are worth protecting.
 
I want my country back. 
 
I want my children back.   I want some semblance of what this country used to be.
 
It's worth protecting.   It's worth defending.   I don't recognize this country anymore.
 
Not politically,  not philosophically,  not spiritually.
 
Whether you like it or whether you don't,  God was a part of building this great nation.  To remove him is to take away the very foundation of what this country was all about.
 
I don't care about your political correctness!
 
I don't want to know your sexual preference!
 
I could care less about all of that.  Stop making it the headline of the day! 
 
That's not America.
 
I want my country back!
 
And the only way I'm ever going to be able to get this country back is if I reach out to the brothers and the sisters that all feel the same way and we say   " No!  You can't have our country.   It's not for sale!"
Take the price tag off this country!
 
Take the price tag off the heads of our children!  Stop it already! 
 
The politically-correct-psychobabble-hug-a-tree-experts ~~ You are not qualified to release sex offenders back into our neighborhoods.
 
The southern border,  more than any other border, needs to be secured tomorrow.   For all those that wish to come to this country to take advantage of her opportunity,  to live under a constitution~ a living document that breathes in and out just like you do. This country is not for sale.  I should know.  I'm one of the owners.  You can't sell it without my permission. 
 
I want my country back!

from Boynton Beach Code Enforcement because our lawn was a little tall while 
we were away for a month, but the LWDD negligently refuses to maintain their 
land. In some neighboring areas along the bank, the weeds have gotten to be 
5- 6 feet high.

Furthermore, the weeds in the canal have gotten so thick the water has 
become stagnant. This results in a drastic increase in the mosquito 
population, and increases the odds of a West Nile Virus outbreak.

Additionally please advise why all the un-permitted boat docks and docks 
with roofs still remain on the canal. As you know, Bill Winters the 
Scoundrel….. vindictively requested that we remove our dock's roof even 
though he personally granted permission years earlier. Winters was denied 
his request at a LWDD hearing.... but coincidentally.....vandals removed it 
shortly after.

Winters dodged a bullet when I filed an extensive complaint against him and 
his cronies Kurt Bressner, Matt Immler, Scott Blaise and Don Johnson from 
Boynton's City Government. The Florida Commission on Ethics obviously caters 
to the "Good Ol Boys" network. (see attached)

Many of these docks were not permitted from both the LWDD and the Boynton 
Beach Building Dept, yet they are allowed to remain in their shabby 
condition. These docks do not abide by the Florida Building Codes, and 
should have been removed years ago when they were discovered.

Sadly, it appears that harassing senior citizens with a legal boat dock 
takes on more importance than boat docks that lack any permits. Some of 
these docks present an obvious Danger to Public Safety.

Regards,
Fred Galas

Subject:	World War III has begun

World War III has begun.  Well it actually began for us, with the attacks on September 11, 2001 and in how an unintelligent, inept and power-hungry coward reacted to those events.

 

Almost everything that is going disastrously wrong in the world today:  Iraq in full civil war, nuclear capable North Korea firing long range missiles, Afghanistan’s return to a fully armed Taliban, Iran vigorously pursuing nukes, Syria & Iran just as vigorously supporting Hezbollah’s and Hamas’ terrorist tactics of kidnappings and blackmailing Israel into an obviously fruitless submission and Israel responding by bombing Gaza’s infrastructure and Lebanese airports and supply routes – all this can be directly attributed to the lack of even the most basic leadership from a man who after 9/11 had the worlds sympathy and allegiance in his hands, yet instead of comforting and guiding them (or hunting down and eliminating Bin Laden completely) –instead received a “my way or the highway” brain-dead, simplistic mentality of decision making and a lashing out at what was obviously the weakest link in litany of threats against our county (Iraq), in a pathetic thump your chest, “I’m an American damn it, so go fuck yourselves” attitude – inevitably spitting the worlds adoration (and its “were all Americans” attitudes) back in its shocked face.

 

There is no turning back from the incompetence and blatant stupidity of this coward of man we call a President.  The diplomacy he scoffed at when taking office simply because it began with a Clinton – Israel on the brink of peace with the Palestinians, a treaty on the table with North Korea, Russia on the brink of a stable democracy (instead of the thuggery now ruling it people) and Iranian youth on the verge of overthrowing their hateful and barbaric Mullah-Islamist rulers – are all now dust in the wind. 

 

September 11, 2001 was not the abortion of an Al Qaeda threat still in its embryonic infancy, but the premature, induced birth of a cause (and a World War) on all of civilization.  A “C” student at a my-parents-got-me-into-this-elitist-school-I-never-want-to-attend-in-the-first-place is a failing student of life, liberty and the basic ability to play well with others.

 

God help us all.

 

Joshua Epstein

364 West 18th Street (6A)

New York, New York 10011

917-345-6326

Hate Mail, Threats Probed in Maywood
LA Times ^ | July 13, 2006 | Hector Becerra and Richard Winton


Posted on 07/13/2006 8:12:12 AM PDT by LNewman


Deputy clerk has been linked to an alleged plot to kill a councilman in the 'sanctuary city' for illegal immigrants. 

After the city of Maywood made national headlines earlier this year for its embrace of illegal immigrants, Councilman Felipe Aguirre and Mayor Thomas Martin began receiving threats in the mail. 

Now, the Los Angeles County district attorney's office and Maywood police are investigating whether the town's deputy city clerk not only sent some of the hate mail but also tried to have Aguirre killed. 

Hector Duarte, 29, was arrested last week by Maywood police officers on suspicion of soliciting to commit murder, ... 

... 

As soon as he got into office, Aguirre and the council majority enacted policies that benefited illegal immigrants. 

The city eliminated the Maywood Police Department's Traffic Division after complaints that officers unfairly targeted illegal immigrants. Then the city made it much more difficult for police to tow cars whose owners didn't have driver's licenses, a practice that had affected mostly undocumented people who could not obtain licenses. 

In January, the City Council passed a resolution opposing a proposed federal law that would criminalize illegal immigration and make local police enforce immigration law. 

... 

"There's been a lot of bad blood," said Peña, a political rival of Aguirre. "They talk about a city of no laws and order, and I think Maywood is becoming that. When you let go of the Traffic Division, which takes care of moving violations in your city, you have a problem." 

... 

Maywood, south of downtown Los Angeles, is one of the nation's most densely populated cities — nearly 45,000 people (when illegal immigrants are factored in) live in 1.2 square miles. An estimated 96% of the residents are Latino and more than half are foreign-born. 

...


(Excerpt) Read more at latimes.com ...
