GOP schedules more immigration hearings
AP on Yahoo ^ | 7/12/06 | Suzanne Gamboa - ap


Posted on 07/12/2006 3:43:00 PM PDT by NormsRevenge


WASHINGTON - House Republican leaders are scheduling a new round of immigration hearings, saying three already held have strengthened their case for enforcement-heavy legislation. 

Majority Leader John Boehner, R-Ohio, said Wednesday the hearings have made clear that a Senate bill that opens an avenue toward citizenship for millions of illegal immigrants would undermine border security. 

He contended that members of both parties are moving toward the House position that the nation's estimated 12 million illegal immigrants should be offered no guarantees against being deported. 

"The hearings have been an absolute success and they've put us in a stronger position to pass a responsible that secures our border and strictly enforces our immigration law," Boehner said. 

Last week's House hearings were in Laredo, Texas, San Diego and Washington. Senators held a hearing last week in Philadelphia and one on Monday in Miami; witnesses generally supported the position held by the Senate and President Bush that many illegal immigrants should be allowed to stay in the U.S. 

At a hearing Wednesday, Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez told the Senate Judiciary Committee that Bush wants a comprehensive bill. He said an approach of only enforcement does not encourage immigrants to learn English, assimilate or be part of society. 

"The more this issue becomes one of enforcement only, we're driving them farther and father underground. What we want for our national security is to drive them above the shadows so we know who they are," said Gutierrez, who left his native Cuba in 1960 as a political refugee. 

During last week's congressional recess, some lawmakers suggested a compromise could be forming around "triggers" that would allow a phasing in of guest worker or legalization measures after enforcement benchmarks are met. 

Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Arlen Specter, R-Pa., said such "delays" already are in the Senate bill. A guest worker program for illegal immigrants could begin only after money has been appropriated for a system that employers could use to verify their workers are legal, he said. 

"We may not be so very far apart," Specter suggested. 

Seven new House hearings are scheduled, all but one in Washington. The House International Relations Committee will hold a hearing July 27 at a location to be determined on whether the Senate bill undermines diplomatic efforts to curb illegal immigration. 

The other six hearings are scheduled from July 18 to July 27. 

Sen. Edward M. Kennedy (news, bio, voting record), D-Mass., one of the authors of the Senate bill, said that while Bush as stood up to the "Republican right wing," his party's leaders in the House continue to play politics with the issue. 

"Clearly, the House hearings are more about politics than about serious immigration reform," Kennedy said. 

___ 

On the Net: 

Information on the bills, H.R. 4437 and S. 2611, can be found at http://thomas.loc.gov/

12 posted on 07/12/2006 5:23:15 PM PDT by swampfox98 (Lou Dobbs ! Michael Savage, Frosty Wooldridge - True patriots!) 
[ Post Reply | Private Reply | To 1 | View Replies | Report Abuse ]
  _____  

To: NormsRevenge

A Somali arrives in Minneapolis as a new immigrant to the United States. He 
stops the first person he sees walking down the street and says, "Thank 
you 
Mr. American for letting me in this country, and giving me housing, food 
stamps, free medical care and free education!" 

But the passer-by says "You are mistaken, I am Mexican." 

The man goes on and encounters another passer-by. "Thank you for having 
such 
a beautiful country here in America!" 

The person says "I no American, I Vietnamese." 

The new arrival walks further, and the next person he sees he stops, shakes 
his hand and says "Thank you for the wonderful America!" 

That person puts up his hand and says "I am from Middle East, I am not an 
American!" 

He finally sees a nice lady and asks suspiciously, "Are you an 
American?" 

She says, "No, I am from Russia!" So he is puzzled, and asks her, 
"Where are 
all the Americans?" 

The Russian lady looks at her watch, shrugs, and says ... "Probably at 
work!"

From:	Gerry Huntenburg <huntenburg@comcast.net>
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 12:02 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Senior Station

Dear Governor Bush,
 
Many families, especially Florida families, are facing the dilemma of providing a safe and enjoyable environment for their aging parents.  I feel fortunate that my mother's financial status allows her to reside in an assisted living facility with a wing for those who are memory impaired but there is a limit what they can even provide during their waking hours.  What about those who live alone or are in less attentive facilities, their days must be long and with little stimulation.
 
Are you aware if anyone has considered providing television programming geared to those who are experiencing symptoms associated with Alzheimer disease or other types of dementia associated with the aging process?  We have such wonderful programs for our children, geared for a variety of developmental stages.  I think our aging parents could benefit (even if it's just for a moment) from the stimulation that could be provided through well developed programming.  (How comforting it would be to have presenters who would speak slowly, briefly sum up the news of the day, talk about interesting topics such as animals, plants, travel, provide time for spiritual reflection and simple chair exercises, etc.)
 
I realize that programs exist on a variety of channels that are interesting and exciting but sometimes it's a challenge for some elderly to work the remote control!  It would be so helpful to turn on the TV at 8:00 am, on one particular station, that would be accessible throughout the day until the early evening.  I firmly believe that there is nothing like human contact but many of our seniors lack that touch.  This could be an alternative!
 
I don't necessary believe that this is something that should be provided by our state or federal governments but it might be an idea that could be initiated by our leaders.
 
Governor Bush, I look forward to your thoughts and guidance on this particular idea!
 
It's a comfort to know that Florida is in your very capable hands!
 
Sincerely,
Liz Huntenburg
 
 
From:	John J Meyer <johanjj@juno.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 11:10 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Education
Attachments:	charter.jpg

Dear Mr. Newman,  

For the sake of our students and our educational system you have an
obligation to look into the following matters. I can prove that it has
affected our educational and justice system. 

The “Florida Home Rule” and the "employment at-will" state are being
misused interactively by the Polk County school politician for their
political interest and not for the best interest of our students and our
educational system.  

I have been official dismissed from teaching by Dr. Clinton Wright as a
part-time Electrical Instructor for not donating to a private fundraising
campaign. Conveniently called, dismissed for a difference of opinion,
using Florida’s "employment at-will" state. 

20 Teacher and 7 Paraprofessionals have also been dismissed no reason
given. The attached picture is telling you that something is wrong. 

The following is from desk of wendy.hosking@polk.fl.net, regarding
private fundraising campaigns. There is no prohibition against
participating in a private fund raising campaign; it should be noted that
participation must be voluntary. It cannot be made, either implicitly or
explicitly, a condition of employment, nor can participation or lack
thereof form the basis of any employment action or disparate treatment. 

When I came back from summer vacation I found all my study material
placed in boxes in the hallway. The hard drive had been take out of the
school computer with my prepared lessons to start the second semester.
This is a violation of 447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of Florida Status
(2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20). My civil rights have been
violated by the Polk County School Board for not following due process.  

On March 12, 2002, Mr. Bob Butterworth one of Florida Attorney Generals
made a statement that Florida would possess zero tolerance for
discrimination. I have not only been discriminated against but also
harassed, humiliate for all school employees and students to see. The
fundraising campaign did run through March 10. I continued to receive
pledge forms in my school mailbox including one illegally placed in my
home mailbox. I kept on teaching under those absurd circumstances for 6
month. It ended with a dismissal for a difference of opinion in the
middle of a semester. No one should have to accept this type of abuse in
a Florida Public School System.  

From the desk of Glenda Hood, Florida’s Secretary of State; Florida is an
"employment at-will" state. An employer can terminate an employee for any
reason, at any time, without advance notification so long as there is no
violation of federal or state law. Polk County violated 447,501 (1) (a)
and (b) of Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20),
including school board regulation 60X53-8, 004 (C). School employee Debby
Davis has been assigned to do the administration. The private fund
raising campaign has been approved by the Polk County School Board for
political reason. The All-Arian fund raising has been approved by the
USF.

I donated my time to train minorities and women to pass a mechanics test.
On August 17, 2005, School Board Attorney Deming Cowles wrote to me that
the school “can dismiss you for you’ re [sic] ethnic background....’ no
explanation needed “. Calling names in place of solving a problem. I am
presently tutoring a child of the (No Child Left behind Act of 2001) to
prepare her for her electrical journeyman exam. 

I have been unable to receive representation from local Senators or
Representatives. Governor Jeb Bush claims in writing that he is powerless
to look into this matter. As soon I mention the “Florida Home Rule” to an
attorney, my free consultations are going down the drain. 

For the sake of our students and our educational system you have an
obligation to look into this matter. 

Sincerely yours,

John J. Meyer
404 Whitman Rd. 
Winter Haven Fl. 33884

An urgent request for assistance from Rabbi Spritzer in Brooklyn, NY!
 
 A non-Jewish inmate wrote us a letter regarding the conditions of Arthur Rudick 395349, currently at Santa Rosa. He wrote that Arthur Rudick is currently not allowed to write and is not allowed any writing utensils, as he is under the suicide watch.

This after a 6/2 event in which Rudick was held down by three officers while an inmate barber shaved off his hair. The most serious offense that Rudick is not being allowed to exercise the grievance procedure, which makes whatever they did to him very suspicious. On top of this, Arthur Rudick has not eaten any solid foods for three weeks.

As I said, this was sent over by another caring inmate and needs to be forwarded to FDOC people as soon as possible. You know how long it takes them to look into something, someone has got to look into this matter. If at all possible, I would like also the phone number of the warden (and his name) from this facility, whom I plan on calling. I consider this an emergency.
RSS     

Good Morning, Rabbi Spritzer!

I am willing to speak with the Inspector General on this matter, but I do need plenty of facts to back up what I say to him.


Thanks for getting involved,


Sid

U.S. Authorities Fired on by Border Bandits (Shots Coming from Mexican Side of Rio Grande) 
The Monitor (Texas) ^ | 07/13/2006 | Andres R. Martinez


Posted on 07/13/2006 4:56:14 AM PDT by KentTrappedInLiberalSeattle


DONNA — Bandits shot hundreds of rounds of automatic gun fire at Hidalgo County Sheriff’s deputies and Border Patrol agents Wednesday from the Mexican side of the Rio Grande. 

The deputies were responding to a call from two brothers who swam across the river after an initial gunfight at a ranch in Mexico, Hidalgo County Sheriff Lupe Treviño said. 

Treviño would not identify the two brothers, but said the two U.S. citizens are suspects in other criminal investigations. 

The two brothers called 911 around 7:45 p.m. Wednesday and told the operator that they were near the Brewster Ranch south of Donna. 

They say an unknown number of gunmen burst into their family ranch in Mexico and killed a ranch hand. The two brothers escaped, but the kidnappers took their father, Treviño said. 

The brothers made it across the Rio Grande and called 911. 

At least three deputies and four Border Patrol agents took the two brothers back to the riverbank to see if they might find any evidence or the shooters. 

Instead, shooters from Mexico fired automatic weapons at the group. The barrage went on for almost 10 minutes, alternating between shots coming from Mexico and the east. 

Treviño believes that the shots from the east were most likely on American soil. The heaviest gunfire came after the shots from the east ended, most likely an attempt to divert attention and allow the shooters from the east to cross back. 

Border Patrol officials did not respond to phone calls last night. 

Treviño plans to search for evidence tomorrow at the sight of the shooting, south of Valley View Road and Military Highway. 

If authorities find weapons or casings that can be traced, they might be able to charge someone with attempted capital murder of the agents, deputies and two brothers, Treviño said. 

Treviño says that his deputies have never been shot at from the Mexican side of the river. 

"This is one of the reasons that I do not allow my deputies to patrol the riverbanks or levies close to the river," Treviño said, "because we do know there are drug gangs and human trafficking gangs that will not hesitate to shoot in our direction to get us out of the area."

Commerce's Gutierrez Backs Senate Immigration Bill [Illegal Alien Shamnesty Bill]
NewsMax ^ | July 13, 2006 | Reuters


Posted on 07/13/2006 6:30:43 AM PDT by conservativecorner


WASHINGTON -- Tighter borders and workplace enforcement alone will not solve the country's problem with illegal immigration and may make the situation worse by driving millions of people deeper in the shadows, U.S. Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez said Wednesday. 

In testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee on behalf of the Bush administration, the Cuban-born Gutierrez backed the Senate's comprehensive approach combining border security and new employer enforcement measures with a plan that gives many of the estimated 12 million illegal immigrants a path to citizenship. 

"The more this issue becomes one of enforcement only, we are driving them (illegal immigrants) further and further underground," Gutierrez said, adding it was important to bring illegals out of the shadows "so we know who they are." 

Wednesday's session was one of a number of dueling hearings being held by the Senate and U.S. House of Representatives in a battle to win public support for vastly different immigration reform bills ahead of the November congressional elections. 

The House-passed bill focuses solely on border security and enforcement and further criminalizes illegal presence in the United States. A solid group of House Republicans oppose the Senate bill, calling it an amnesty that rewards people who broke U.S. law. 

Mindful of the growing political clout of Hispanic voters, President Bush backs a comprehensive approach along the lines of the Senate bill. But House leaders Wednesday said they are winning the battle. 

"I think the hearings have been an absolute success and they've put us in a stronger position to craft a responsible bill that secures our borders and strictly enforces our immigration laws," said House Majority Leader John Boehner, an Ohio Republican. 

The House already has held a number of hearings around the country stressing border security issues and Boehner said more will be held through August. 

It is unclear the Senate and House will be able to settle their differences and send a final bill to Bush before the November elections. The two bodies have held no formal negotiating sessions but lawmakers have been discussing possible compromises behind the scenes. 

House leaders say the Senate is shifting to their point of view. A number of senators oppose the House's enforcement only approach but some said they are discussing a phased approach that would put border security and enforcement measures in place before a guest worker and other legalization programs go into effect.


  _____

Katherine Harris's Campaign Staff To Resign
National Journal Hotline ^ | 7/13/06


Posted on 07/13/2006 6:25:07 AM PDT by MplsSteve


The high command of Rep. Katherine Harris's FL Senate bid plans to resign by the end of the week, two people familiar with the campaign tell the Hotline. 

The departing staff includes Glen Hodas, Harris's campaign manager, her spokesperson, Chris Ingram, and Pat Thomas, her field director. The status of Harris's chief fundraiser, Erin Delullo, is not clear. 

The resignations will take effect by Friday, according to the sources. TooConservative, a Virginia-based blog, first reported this afternoon that several staffers would quit. 

One person involved in the campaign said there was no single precipitating factor. "She's just very difficult to work with. It's all the same stuff. The more than we put her out there, the more she shot herself in the foot," this person said.


(Excerpt) Read more at hotlineblog.nationaljournal.com ...

How they vote in the United Nations: 



Below are the actual voting records of various Arabic/Islamic States which are recorded in both the US State Department and United Nations records: 



Kuwait votes against the United States 67% of the time 



Qatar votes against the United States 67% of the time 



Morocco votes against the United States 70% of the time 



United Arab Emirates votes against the U. S. 70% of the time. 



Jordan votes against the United States 71% of the time. 



Tunisia votes against the United States 71% of the time. 



Saudi Arabia votes against the United States 73% of the time. 



Yemen votes against the United States 74% of the time. 



Algeria votes against the United States 74% of the time. 



Oman votes against the United States 74% of the time. 



Sudan votes against the United States 75% of the time. 



Pakistan votes against the United States 75% of the time. 



Libya votes against the United States 76% of the time. 



Egypt votes against the United States 79% of the time. 



Lebanon votes against the United States 80% of the time. 



India votes against the United States 81% of the time. 



Syria votes against the United States 84% of the time. 



Mauritania votes against the United States 87% of the time. 



U S Foreign Aid to those that hate us: 



Egypt, for example, after voting 79% of the time against the United States, still receives $2 billion annually in US Foreign Aid. 



Jordan votes 71% against the United States 



And receives $192,814,000 annually in US Foreign Aid. 



Pakistan votes 75% against the United States 



Receives $6,721,000 annually in US Foreign Aid. 



India votes 81% against the United States 



Receives $143,699,000 annually. 



Perhaps it is time to get out of the UN and give the tax savings back to the American workers who are having to skimp and sacrifice to pay the taxes (and gasoline). 



Pass this along to every taxpaying citizen you know.

So, issue a public statement that what is needed in a disaster, is for civil minded people, who have public safety records, or are not criminals, to make contact with the hospitals, and offer their services, as patient transport together with staff and patient of course (together for safety reasons), and make sure it doesn't happen again.

From:	JWK <jkenney1@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 7:29 AM
To:	lorri@sptimes.com
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Schiavo nurse may lose license:  Great Article

Great Article:  I hope she loses her licence.  I would not want someone who lies and breaks the law caring for me.
 

Schiavo nurse may lose license



The state says she broke the rules by discussing the case on national television.


By LORRI HELFAND, Times Staff Writer
Published July 13, 2006

  _____  


The state wants to revoke the license of a nurse who cared for Terri Schiavo because she discussed Schiavo's medical condition on national TV.

Carla Sauer-Iyer said on CNN and other stations last year that Schiavo laughed, told the staff she was in pain, said "Mommy" and "Help me" and ate pudding and milkshakes.

Schiavo, for years the center of national controversy, died March 31, 2005, 13 days after her feeding tube was removed.

Now the Florida Health Department says Sauer-Iyer, 42, a registered nurse who works in Lakeland, improperly disclosed confidential patient information.

Sauer-Iyer, who worked for Palm Garden of Largo as a licensed practical nurse while Schiavo was there, said she was only rehashing on TV what she said in two affidavits, one of which she provided at the request of Gov. Jeb Bush's legal team.

"This was my First Amendment right," she said.

The state disagrees.

Divulging confidential patient information violates state code and federal law, said Florida Health Department spokesman Doc Kokol.

The case against Sauer-Iyer began on March 28, 2005, when the Health Department received a complaint from a Massachusetts registered nurse who said Sauer-Iyer made "unsubstantiated comments" on CNN "that with 'just a little bit of therapy' Mrs. Schiavo could be rehabilitated."

Two months ago, the state offered to settle the complaint if Sauer-Iyer gave up her nursing license, paid up to $1,683 in administrative costs and agreed not to apply for a license in the future.

Sauer-Iyer refused and requested an administrative hearing. No date has been set for that hearing.

"It will kill me if I can't practice nursing, if I can't help people have a fair chance at rehabilitation and help people get better," said Sauer-Iyer of Plant City.

Michael Schiavo, who bore the brunt of Sauer-Iyer's accusations, said she "violated her oath" and "is getting what she deserves."

Sauer-Iyer stated in affidavits that Michael Schiavo often was gleeful when his wife was sick, blurting out statements like, "I'm going to be rich!" She also quoted him saying, "When is that b---- gonna die?"

Sauer-Iyer is lying, Michael Schiavo said.

"Where's the proof?" asked Schiavo, 43, a registered nurse and registered respiratory therapist. "Why would she be the only one that ever heard that?"

While federal privacy regulations allow the release of patient information in some judicial proceedings, that doesn't open the door to discussing it on TV or elsewhere, said George Annas, chairman of the department of health law, bioethics and human rights at Boston University School of Public Health.

Seven years after she cared for Schiavo, Sauer-Iyer said in affidavits that Schiavo communicated clearly, ate from a baby bottle and chuckled when Sauer-Iyer told her humorous stories.

"If that ever happened, it was never on my shift," said Carolyn "Andi" Adams, 68, a licensed practical nurse who worked at Palm Garden at the time.

The chances of Schiavo recovering the ability to talk, clothe herself or take care of her bodily needs "were close to zero," said Dr. Leon Prockop, a professor of neurology at the University of South Florida who has reviewed Terri Schiavo's CT scans and her postmortem neurological report. "The brain cells that serve those functions were not present in her brain."

Sauer-Iyer said she filed a report with the Pinellas County Sheriff's Office in 1996 saying she found a vial of insulin in the trash after Michael Schiavo visited Terri Schiavo.

The Sheriff's Office has no record of the complaint, but does have a July 23, 1996, report in which Sauer-Iyer said Adams may have put threatening notes on her car. Adams said she knew nothing of that.

Sauer-Iyer's affidavit said she regularly informed Terri Schiavo's parents about their daughter's condition in the mid 1990s.

In response to the affidavit, Pinellas-Pasco Circuit Judge George Greer concluded that it's "impossible to believe" that Terri Schiavo's parents wouldn't have subpoenaed her to testify years earlier.

On Oct. 17, 2003, two days after Terri Schiavo's feeding tube was removed the second time, Sauer-Iyer filed a complaint to the Pinellas County Sheriff's Office about Michael Schiavo, saying she found a vial of insulin in a trash can after he visited Terri one day in 1996, but saw no syringes and never saw anyone give Schiavo a shot.

State investigators reviewed nine years of medical records but found no signs of any problems with Terri Schiavo's glucose levels, which would be affected had she received insulin injections, according to records released in April 2005.

On March 18, 2005, Terri's feeding tube was removed for the third time. That week, Sauer-Iyer made her claims on CNN and other TV shows.

Sauer-Iyer thinks she's being persecuted because of her involvement in the case but said she has no regrets even if she loses her license.

"I live a 24-karat life," Sauer-Iyer said. "I have clean hands. I'll be disappointed, but I'll know I've done the right thing."

From:	zeki kentel <zkentel2001@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 5:12 AM
To:	govdocs@umich.edu; constituentsvcs@governor.state; office_of_the_governor@gov.sta; mike.huckabee@state.ar.us; governor@governor.ca.gov; governorowens@state.co.us; governor.rowland@po.state.ct.u; Governor.Rowland@po.state.ct.u; gminner@state.de.us; Governor Jeb Bush; gov@hawaii.gov; governor@state.il.us; fobannon@state.in.us; governor@state.ks.us; governor@mail.state.ky.us
Subject:	THE  WHOLE  OF  IRAQ  HAS  BECOME ABU GHRAIB

The whole of Iraq has become Abu Ghraib

By Haifa Zangana 
 
http://www.informationclearinghouse.info/article13913.htm

Our streets are prison corridors and our homes cells as the occupiers go about their strategic humiliation and intimidation.

07/06/06 "The Guardian" -- -- A'beer Qassim al-Janaby, a 15-year-old Iraqi girl, was with her family in Mahmudiyah, 20 miles south of Baghdad, when US troops raided the house. A group of soldiers have been charged with her rape and the murder of her father, mother, and nine-year-old sister. They are also accused of setting A'beer's body on fire.

The al-Janaby family lived near a US checkpoint, and the killings happened at 2pm on March 11. As usual, a US spokesman ascribed the killings to "Sunni Arab insurgents active in the area", contrary to local eyewitnesses.


A'beer's rape and murder is neither incidental nor the product of a US soldier's "personality disorder": it is part of a pattern that includes Abu Ghraib, as well as the Haditha, Ishaqi and Qaiem
massacres. And we see this pattern as serving a strategic function beyond indiscriminate revenge: to couple collective humiliation with intimidation and terror.


Today, four years into the Anglo-American occupation, the whole of Iraq has become Abu Ghraib, with our streets as prison corridors and homes as cells. Iraqis are attacked in detention, on the streets and in their homes.


It took almost a year, and published photographs of horrific torture in Abu Ghraib, before the world began to heed the voices of the detainees and those trying to defend them. The same is happening to women victims.


Abuses, torture and the rape of Iraqi women have been reported for three years now by independent Iraqi organisations. But the racist logic of occupation means that occupied people are not to be trusted,  and truth is the private ownership of the occupiers.

Families of the abused, raped, and killed Iraqi civilians have to wait for months, if not years, until a US soldier comes forward to admit responsibility and the US military begins an investigation. (For the US military to investigate a US soldier's crime has been seen by Iraqis as the killers investigating their own technical skills.)
 
On the October 19 2005, Freedom Voice, an Iraqi Human Rights society, reported the rape of three women from the "Saad Bin Abi Waqqas neighbourhood" in Tell Afar after a US raid.

The alleged rape took place by soldiers inside the women's own house after the arrest of their male relatives. Medical sources in the town said one of the women died. A US commander ordered some soldiers detained, and no more was heard of this.

Immunity from prosecution under Iraqi or international law is the main fact of the occupation and renders laughable any claims of sovereignty. It is based on UN security council resolution 1546 and
the accompanying exchange of letters between Iraqi and American authorities. This immunity applies equally to the marine units accused of roaming our streets high on drugs and to advisers running ministries, to prison guards, security guards, multinational forces and corporate contractors of all kinds.

 
The Iraqi women's ordeal began the moment occupation forces descended upon them. Most arrests and raids take place after midnight. In some neighborhoods, women now sleep fully dressed so as not to be caught in their nightgowns. Armoured cars and helicopters are sometimes deployed
in raids, in a variant on "shock and awe". Troops force women and children to watch as they deliberately humiliate their husbands, sons or fathers, and sometimes order them to take pictures with US soldiers' cameras. Money and jewellery are taken. Are these "terrorist assets confiscated" or spoils of war? 

Random arrests, rapes and killings by the occupation forces continue under the so-called "national unity government", which renewed their mandate and immunity while at the same time talking of a "national reconciliation initiative".

Despite all the rhetoric, a female minister for human rights and dozens of US-funded Iraqi women's organisations, the only outcry we have heard condemning the rape of A' beer and the plight of Iraqi
women under occupation is from the anti-occupation Islamist movement.

Occupation authorities and their puppet regime share the denial of violence against women. After the sexual abuse scandal at Abu Ghraib, the authorities talked about respecting local traditions, and the need to avoid provoking anger and give the Iraqi people the sense that the occupation recognises the sensitive status of women. 

On occasion, Iraqi collaborators joined in. On April 18 2004, the ministry of interior chief, Ahmed Youssef, issued a statement denying maltreatment of female detainees. He said: "We are Muslims. We know very well how to treat our female detainees." As if violence against women were not a universal crime. 

The abuses continue also in the puppet regime's prisons. On October 20 2005, officials of the Kazemiya women's prison reported an instance of rape. The UN was refused permission to investigate. According to a report of the UN assistance mission to Iraq, Iraqi police tortured a
woman who had been detained in Diwaniya police station since March 2005. The victim recounted that electric March 2005. The victim recounted that electric shocks were applied to her
heels. She was reportedly told her teenage daughter would be raped if she did not supply the information her interrogators wanted.

A report published by the Iraqi National Association for Human Rights on October 29 2005 found that women held in interior ministry detention centres are subject to numerous human rights violations, including "systematic rape by the investigators and ... other forms of bodily harm in order to coerce them into making confessions". The report added that prisons fail to meet even the most basic standards of hygiene, and that the women were deprived of facilities as fundamental as toilets. The ministry of justice has confirmed the accuracy of the report.

The wall of denial is cracking. On June 12, al-Jazeera showed footage of Mohammed al-Diaeny, a member of parliament, going to a prison in Baquba, near Baghdad, where men showed evidence of torture and talked of being raped. Seven women detainees were shown but refused to talk.

"Too ashamed", whispered one of them. In response, Jawad al-Bolani, minister of the interior, promised investigation. He later vowed to release all women prisoners and negotiate with the multinational forces to release theirs.

There will be no end to these violations as long as Iraq remains occupied by forces that enjoy immunity from prosecution under Iraqi law and as long as the occupation authorities continue to treat Iraqi citizens with racist contempt in order to feel better about plundering the nation's wealth and depriving its people of their most fundamental rights under international law and human rights conventions. 

The Iraqi puppet regime's promises and US investigations of the "personality disorders" of their soldiers and the "few bad apples" are irrelevant for Iraqis: for them, the Anglo-American occupation means destruction, rape and pillage.

Haifa Zangana is a novelist and former prisoner of Saddam Hussein's Iraqi regime.

From:	infoweb@newsbank.com
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 1:44 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Requested NewsBank Article

Paper: South Florida Sun-Sentinel (Fort Lauderdale, FL)
Title: AMONG THE RANKS OF THE HOMELESS? - RESIDENTS OF AZTEC ESTATES IN MARGATE FEAR THEY MAY BE FORCED TO LEAVE THEIR MOBILE HOMES.
Author: Lisa J. Huriash Staff Writer
Date: July 9, 2006
Section: COMMUNITY NEWS
Page: 1

The letter alerted  residents  to a grim possibility: They might be forced out of their mobile home park.

    Residents of the 100-acre Aztec Estates have received a notice that Uniprop Inc., which manages the park, is considering alternatives for the property that include the sale of Aztec "in response to market conditions."

    The company's president, Roger Zlotoff, cited "a decline in occupancy" as the reason for the possibility of a sale.

    "The home sales effort has not been successful," he wrote in his letter dated June 21, which most residents received June 26. "Hurricane Wilma was a devastating blow as it destroyed many homes."

    Aztec Estates, which is off State Road 7, has 645 home sites, but only about 184 homes are occupied, management officials said. The community is marred by many mobile homes with blue tarps. Other lots are empty; those homes were demolished after crushing damage from Wilma last year. Interspersed throughout the mobile home park are about 150 Federal Emergency Management Agency trailers used to help Wilma victims left homeless.

    There is no date given for a final decision to be made, and residents don't have to start packing yet, but they are panicking about what will happen.

    Patti Pye and her husband almost two years ago sank $65,000 of their savings into a three-bedroom trailer with a 9-by-12-foot master bathroom.

    Pye said she was promised the park "would be here the next 20 years."

    The retiree said she and her husband live off a combined $2,000 Social Security each month and are terribly worried about where they will go next.

    "Ever since I got the letter I have not been sleeping," she said. "Everyone here says: `Where in the hell are we supposed to go now?' I cannot believe this is happening. I cannot believe we are going to lose everything. And I don't know what I'm going to do."

    Stanley Cyrway, 73, has lived in his mobile home with his wife, Ann, for 15 years. He  long ago paid off his $20,000 trailer and was fine getting by with $1,700 a month in Social Security and his pension.

    "You could rent for that, but you want to eat, too," Cyrway said.

    He fears his 1971 three-bedroom mobile home is too old to be moved to another location. "It'll fall apart, it'll shake apart on the highway," he said. And if he were to move to another park, "what's to stop the same thing from going on down there?"

    If Aztec is closed, the only mobile home park left in the city will be Coral Cay, which was formerly known as the Colonies of Margate.

    Aztec would be the second mobile home park in the city to be closed. Residents at Rancho Margate have until Sept. 30 to be out of their homes. The developer there is trying to receive the city's OK to build 413 townhouses just south of Sample Road at 2900 N. State Road 7 to replace the mobile home park, which also sustained extensive damage from Wilma.

    Throughout Broward County, other parks are closing, too, including locations in Coconut Creek and Fort Lauderdale.

    In Plantation, Sunshine City, which dead-ends off Broward Boulevard near State Road 84, is being closed. Affordable Residential Communities, which has owned the park since 2000, is selling the land for an undisclosed price. Company officials are blaming Wilma for extensive damage that would be too costly to pass on to residents, who have until November to leave.

    Uniprop's lobbyist, former state Rep. Jack Tobin, said it would be months before a final decision is made. He also said any move would be easier for these residents than at other parks because the company owns two mobile home parks in Davie with available units and also available lots if people have the means to move their entire homes.

    "The land has become so much more valuable than as a usage for mobile home parks," Tobin said. "He [the developer] has to first decide what he's going to do. They're looking at different options, maybe a mixed use with townhomes and villas and single-family homes, but they aren't even at that point. He has architects and engineers who are looking at the property and deciding the best use."

    Lisa J. Huriash can be reached at lhuriash@sun-sentinel.com or 954-572-2008.

Caption:
PHOTO

Caption:
HOME FRONT: Aztec Estates mobile home park residents Stanley Cyrway and neighbor Patti Pye stand in the shade as they talk about the bleak future of leaving their homes, a possibility they may face if the park is sold. They and other residents received letters notifying them of management's possible plan to sell the property to developers. Staff photo/Angel Valentin

Author: Lisa J. Huriash Staff Writer
Section: COMMUNITY NEWS
Page: 1
Dateline: MARGATE

Copyright 2006  Sun-Sentinel Company


From:	robertp@icdus.com
Sent:	Thursday, July 13, 2006 1:32 AM
To:	comments@whitehouse.gov; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Land sale puts end to residents' way of life

This story was sent to you by: Robert Perkis

Florida citizens losing their homes, no help from the state or federal government, maybe we should ask the U.N. for assistance. Wake HUD up and tell them to help us !!!!!!

--------------------
Land sale puts end to residents' way of life 
--------------------

Jack Snyder and Lynn Thomasson
Sentinel Staff Writers

July 12, 2006

Four years ago, Mary Everson bought a mobile home in College Park so she could care for her 83-year-old mother and 85-year-old aunt. But now they've been told their quaint community could be part of a mega-development.

Demetree Builders Inc. of Orlando recently bought the half-century-old College Park Leisure Homes to make way for a $100 million-plus development of stores, offices and condominiums.

The Orange County School Board also is looking at the property as possibly part of a proposed expansion of Edgewater High School and could acquire the 133-home neighborhood.

Either way, moving day is six months or more away.

"I'm young; I can bounce back, but for all these elderly people, it's sad," said Everson, 51, who lives in the same community near her mother and aunt.

Some residents of the tightknit park -- dotted with miniature statues, tiny clay angels and other yard ornaments -- said they will go to live with relatives or temporarily stay in motels until they can find other housing. But for others, the answer is less clear.

"I think half the residents here don't have the money to move," said Ed Eagleson, 74, a retired custodian at College Park Baptist Church. Eagleson said he bought a mobile home four years ago after his wife died and he couldn't afford his house payments.

"I thought when I moved here, I was going to die here," he said.

Eagleson said he plans to move in with his daughter.

Like Eagleson, many of the residents of College Park Leisure Homes are retirees who now count their neighbors as family. They look out for one another -- cooking meals, running errands, keeping track of doctors appointments.

And they also know that on their fixed incomes, finding affordable housing is a challenge, if not impossible, especially given the Orlando area's soaring property values. Some talked about paying several hundred dollars a month to live in the Maury Road park, rather than the $1,000 or more they expect to pay elsewhere.

Everson's mother, Dorothy Everson, said she and her family have been searching for another mobile-home park and visited one, but they're worried about the cost.

"They told us you have to have an income of at least $1,500 a month. Well, I said, 'Holy mackerel! That knocks me out of the water.' "

Ron Schwartz, Demetree Builders vice president, said the company will operate the park for the time being. "But we are moving forward with our [development] plans," he said.

Those plans call for retail space, offices, more than 500 condominiums and parking garages with rooftop pools and other recreational amenities.

Schwartz earlier announced a smaller mixed-use development on the neighboring 8-acre Edgewater Corporate Center property the company owns. He said he has been trying for months to buy the mobile-home park to expand the proposed development.

The park was bought, reportedly for $8 million, from Affordable Residential Communities Inc. of Englewood, Colo. The seller owned the land and rented lots to mobile-home owners.

Both Demetree properties are just north of Edgewater High School, a growing school crowded onto 29 acres. Most high schools in Orange County are on 60 acres.

The School Board late last year voted to acquire the 8-acre property, also known as Edgewater Plaza for the shopping-center portion, suggesting a price of $7.5 million.

At the time, Schwartz argued against the acquisition, suggesting the school could benefit from the parking garages and possibly a branch YMCA.

This week, Schwartz said the company is still dealing with the School Board on the issue.

Jay Small of the law firm Wilson Garber & Small, which handles condemnation cases for the School Board, said appraisals for the initial offer for the Edgewater Corporate Center property are being prepared now.

He said the School Board staff is still studying whether the mobile-home-park property would be needed for the $65 million expansion.

"The School Board is sensitive to the issue of dislocating people," Small said.

Schwartz said the company will give residents six months' notice to move as required by law.

"I know a lot of those homes are too old to move," he said. "There are a lot of questions, and I don't have all the answers."

Called The Quad at College Park, the massive development would transform the north end of College Park.

"If we get the opportunity to do it, it's going to be a great project," Schwartz said.

The only question Florence Jacobs has is what she'll do. The 89-year-old woman, a park resident for 35 years, said she may go to live with her sister in Canada.

"I wish they'd just leave us alone," she said.

Jack Snyder can be reached at jsnyder@orlandosentinel.com or 407-420-5094. Lynn Thomasson can be reached at 407-420-5277 or lthomasson@orlandosentinel.com. 

Copyright (c) 2006, Orlando Sentinel 

Visit Sun-Sentinel.com

"yellow card" didn't cover "acute care" only "chronic care."  While he met

covered.

they need.

citizens and fall on hard times.  The system is kicking them in the teeth.

on the sidewalk  with IVs in our arms because the hospitals don't have room 
just like they do in Honduras.  I know because my son was there on a medical 
mission trip.

                        Letters To Leaders 
                                 
                                 
                                All messages are published with permission of the sender. The general topic of this message is Immigration: 
                                 
                                 
                                Subject:
                                I AGREE TOTALLY WITH THIS!!!

                                To:
                                President George Bush
                                Vice President Richard Cheney

                                July 12, 2006

                                No to amnesty and guest workers


                                Why have we not been enforcing our immigration laws? Why have we let anybody in the world who wants to, come to the USA, stay here illegally and demand full citizenship benefits. We actually don't need laws if those laws are not going to be enforced. Should we let anyone vote as often as he wants? Why not let all the prisoners out of jail? Without laws, shouldn't we disband all police departments since they are not at all necessary. While we're at it, if there's no need for law, we really don't need city, county, state, or national government. Why waste our money on the court system?

                                For decades, those of you in the legislative and executive branches of government whom have sworn to uphold our laws have neglected your duty, allowing at minimum 12million illegal aliens to either overstay visas or sneak into the promised land and take up residence here. You have hardly ever reprimanded the employers of those illegal aliens. This would be the most effective way to tackle the problem. ICE and Homeland Security, which you oversee, could not possibly be more ineffective, and our border protection could not be more lacking. No one in Washington seems to care or have the will correct the situation. Comparing the problem to prohibition is not appropriate. The problem is more akin to the slavery problem that Abraham Lincoln faced. Volunteer slavery is just as abominable

                                Obviously, the Democrats don't want the problem solved so that the Latino vote will go their way, and the Republicans, benefitting from campaign contributions from commercial interests, rule in favor of the business community, supplying industry with scab labor. The middle class worker, who actually plays by the rules is misrepresented by you once again. What total frustration we are experiencing. Also, your arrogant disregard for our plight is maddening.

                                Certainly you are aware that amnesty didn't work the last time, it only made matters worse. You can never reward lawbreakers without encouraging more of the same behavior.

                                As responsible citizens, we should take pride in abiding by the rule of law. As responsible voters, we will demand that our elected officials enforce those laws which are in place to protect society. Anything else is anarchy.


                                Raymond S. Becker, Jr.
                                3878 Lehigh Dr.
                                Northampton (Lehigh Township)
                                PA 18067
                                Phone-610-262-8135

                                Shasta Lake , CA

From:	CHUCK BORTELL <surfrider@prodigy.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 8:53 PM
To:	Tom Gallagher; Kevin McCarty; Mary Alice Palmer
Cc:	Belinda Miller; Carlos Muniz; Charlie Crist; Dave Kaiser; Eric Miller; Gary Pullen; Hazel Muhammad; Governor Jeb Bush; Michael T. Ruff; Philip Fountain; Rick Mahler; Justice, Charlie
Subject:	Section THREE of  Formal Complaint re: Multinational Underwriters dated April 25, 2006
Attachments:	pat1067614933

To: The Honorable Tom Gallagher, CFO
plus, Commissioner Kevin McCarty and
Division Director Mary Alice Palmer
 
 
Dear Chief Financial Officer Gallagher, Commissioner McCarty and Division Director Palmer: 
 
On April 25th, 2006, I submitted several Formal Complaints; one was styled in a similar fashion to the "Subject" line above. For your ease of reference, I am forwarding a computer file copy of the letter, but without the Attachments.
 
The only reply or advisory I have received thus far, was a non-response, dated June 8, 2006, from Senior Attorney Michael T. Ruff. His final paragraph read as follows: 
 
"Regarding your other inquiries as dictated by you to my assistant early last week, the Department has no information to share with you".  
 
In contrast, I do have information to share with each of you. 
 
One of my verbal inquiries - during the earlier week as cited by Attorney Ruff - related to "Example I" in my Formal Complaint dated April 25, 2006. "Example I" dealt with a newborn infant who was Unlawfully rejected by the Underwriting department of Multinational Underwriters (MNU). To the best of my knowledge, that infant is still without health insurance more than 77 days since I lodged a complaint with the Florida Department of Financial Services (DFS). In addition, more than ninety days have elapsed since the infant's health insurance was unlawfully denied. Furthermore, as with numerous other contractual deficiencies, the dollar limit allowed by Multinational Underwriters (MNU) for the initial 31-day period subsequent to birth, also contravenes Florida Statutes. 
 
I also have something else to share with each of you.
 
A couple of weeks ago, it became necessary for the infant's mother to utilize - without the benefit of rightfully due health insurance - the services of a hospital Emergency Room; as is sometimes necessary with infants. Incidentally, the malady prompting the visit to the Emergency Room was totally unrelated to the reason for the unlawful Underwriting rejection by MultiNational Underwriters (MNU). 
 
Nevertheless, the upshot: 
 
In addition to the worry about the illness of the newborn, the infant's mother also had to suffer the stress of not having rightfully due health insurance. Why?  The inordinate delays, inaction and shirking of its responsibilities by the DFS - all combined with the non-responses of Attorney Ruff, in his representing the Florida Department of Financial Services.
 
Consequently, in accordance with the provisions of the Florida Customer Service Standards Act, I am submitting the following questions regarding the status of this instant case; as well as for the benefit of other health insurance consumers, whose health insurance matters may also be Unlawfully handled by MultiNational Underwriters (MNU):
 
1. As of July 13, 2006, has MultiNational Underwriters (MNU) been compelled by the Florida Department of Financial Services to issue coverage to the infant referred to in "Example I" in Section THREE of my Complaint dated April 25, 2006?
 
2. If not, does the Florida Department of Financial Services plan to compel the issuance of the rightfully due coverage? 
 
3. If the response to Question Number 2 is affirmative, then when? 
 
4. If the response to Question Number 2 is negative, then when will the Florida Department of Financial Services issue the "Immediate Final Cease and Desist Order"; as previously requested in the "Summary" section of my Complaint filed nearly three months ago?
 
In conclusion: Florida consumers and agents suffer untold injuries and potential financial damages; when the Florida Department of Financial Services fails to enforce the insurance laws contained in the Florida Statutes.
 
Fair winds and following seas....
 
Very respectfully submitted,
Chuck Bortell
Charles K. Bortell Jr.
Florida Agent # A026291
954.553.1704 (Personal cellular)
954.772.8740 fax

VERY LUCKY AND HID MYSELF INSIDE THE TOILET,WHERE I HAERD SOME SCREAMS FROM MY MUM BEEN RAPED BY THE ROBBERS BEFORE SHE GOT SHOT DEAD IN COLD BLOOD,I CANT REMEMBER MUCH BY THEN BECAUSE I WAS STILL SMALL BY THAT TIME,I WAS THE ONLY CHILD MY FOLKS HAD THEN,I TRIED ALL MY BEST TO GET SOME HELP HERE IN NIGERIA BUT THERE WAS NO ONE TO RESCUE ME THEN SO I HAD TO GO OUT OF THE HOUSE AND GET SOMEONE TO HELP ME BUT I WAS NOT LUCKY BECAUSE I WAS 4 YEARS OLD THEN AND I CANT LOCATE ANY OF MY FAMILY CONTACTS ABROAD, A MAN WAS WITNESSING THE SCENE THEN WHICH I DID NOT EVEN KNOW MUCH ABOUT HIM,BUT HE TOOK EMBASSY HERE AND WAS TOLD THAT I HAVE TO GIVE THEM ALL MY PASSPORT INFORMATION AND MY BIRTH CERTIFICATES WHICH I DONT HAVE ON MY MEMORY,IT WAS STOLEN FOR ALMOST 13 YEARS NOW,I LATER IMMIGRATE TO THE COUNTRY WHICH I HAVE THERE PASSPORT NOW BUT I CANT SECURE A VISA AND TICKETS TO COME,KINDLY HELP ME TO CALL THE EMBASSY ON MY BEHALF TO ISSUE ME A VISA TO COME BACK,THOUGH I CANT REALLY IMAGINE HOW TO LOCATE ANY OF MY FAMILY THERE TOO BUT I WONT MIND GOING TO STAY IN ANY CHARITY HOMES THERE IF I COME AND GET ALONG WITH MY LIFE THERE BECAUSE THERE IS NO HOPE FOR ME HERE AGAIN,KINDLY DO THIS FOR ME FAST TO HELP ME IN TIME TO BE IN UNITED STATES BACK.I WILL LIKE TO HAVE AN URGENT RESPONSE FROM YOU SIR AND WITH BEST CONSIDERATION,EITHER GETTING THE VISA OR SENDING ME MONEY SIR.IT WILL BE MY PLEASURE TO HEAR SOON SIR.

TARA JACKSON.

Aztlan Acadmey: Coming to your neighborhood? (Rove makes nice with La Raza racial separatists)
Michelle Malkin Website ^ | 12 July 2006 | Michelle Malkin


Posted on 07/12/2006 11:34:24 AM PDT by Spiff


AZTLAN ACADEMY: COMING TO YOUR NEIGHBORHOOD?

By Michelle Malkin 

  ·   July 12, 2006 11:40 AM 

So, Karl Rove gave his "We are all Americans" speech to the National Council of La Raza--The Race--yesterday. Today, my syndicated column digs into the millions of dollars in Bush administration federal education grants The Race has received for its nationwide charter school initiative. 

It’s bad enough the White House lent its prestige to The Race’s annual conference. But did you know the Bush administration has forked over millions of federal tax dollars directly to The Race? 

According to GOP Rep. Charlie Norwood of Georgia, The Race snapped up $15.2 million in federal grants last year alone and more than $30 million since 1996. Undisclosed amounts went to get-out-the-vote efforts supporting La Raza political positions. The U.S. Department of Education funneled nearly $8 million in taxpayer grants to the group for a nationwide charter schools initiative. 

You may remember the reconquista school in Los Angeles whose principal teaches ethnic separatism along with Aztec math. The Race was a co-sponsor of that school with extremist activists from MECHA. Remember this interview with the principal of the school, La Academia Semillas del Pubelo: 

We don’t want to drink from a White water fountain, we have our own wells and our natural reservoirs and our way of collecting rain in our aqueducts. We don’t need a White water fountain. So the whole issue of segregation and the whole issue of the Civil Rights Movement is all within the box of White culture and White supremacy. We should not still be fighting for what they have. We are not interested in what they have because we have so much more and because the world is so much larger. And ultimately the White way, the American way, the neo liberal, capitalist way of life will eventually lead to our own destruction.


Turns out there are more where that one came from, folks. 

I have found dozens of other publicly-subsidized charter schools sponsored by The Race and funded with our money, including: 

*Aztlan Academy in Tuscon, Arizona. According to The Race, the school’s success rests on “Aztlan's ability to integrate a meaningful Chicano Studies program into their lives, language, and academics, as a means of developing their intellects as well as their pride and self-esteem.” The school’s name--a reference to a mythical swath of the vast Southwestern U.S. expanse, which Latino activists claim is their rightful homeland and which they seek to reconquer for Mexico--says it all. 

*Mexicayotl Academy in Nogales, Arizona. Who needs the three R’s? At Mexicayotl, it’s all about the three M’s: me, me, me! The school’s program is “structured and developed around the concepts of identity, culture, and language.” Second mission: supporting local ethnic lobbying efforts “to right social injustices by educating the community and helping create social change.” Under “greatest achievements,” the school’s website lists its participation in a “Peace & Dignity Run;” its visit from Rigoberta Menchu (the Marxist academic fraud from Guatemala who lied her way to a Nobel Peace Prize); and its sponsorship of
the local annual Día de los Muertos (the Mexican holiday). 

*The Dolores Huerta Preparatory High School in Pueblo, Colorado. It’s named after the far-Left Latina labor union activist who recently railed that “Republicans hate Latinos,” praised illegal alien marchers, and screeched that “We didn’t cross the borders, the borders crossed us” in a hate-filled tirade before Arizona students. 

*Academia Cesar Chavez Charter School in St. Paul, Minn. Board of Directors member Louis Mendoza, an activist Chicano Studies professor, pushed the school to lobby for the federal DREAM Act (providing in-state tuition discounts to illegal alien students not available to legal non-residents). The school’s website features one flag on its front page: the Mexican flag. 

  

The White House will tell you that The National Council of The Race is a “moderate,” mainstream civil rights group. But there’s nothing “moderate” about The Race’s advocacy of driver’s licenses and in-state tuition discounts for illegal aliens. Or its opposition to strengthening security for identity documents and improving cooperation on immigration enforcement between state, local, and federal enforcement immigration officials. Or its all-out war on the House GOP’s border security and enforcement-first bill passed last December. 

President Bush pays lip service to immigration enforcement and assimilation, while the White House sends Karl Rove to make nice with the separatist leaders of The Race and the Bush Education Department showers our tax dollars on radical Reconquista schools. It doesn’t add up. 

Unless, of course, you’re using Aztec math.

Dear Credit Monitoring Participant,


As you know, a company working for Convergys/People First! used offshore 
services, almost two years ago, to electronically categorize some state employee
personnel files. To date, there have been no confirmed cases of credit fraud or 
identity theft resulting from this work. 

Your personnel file may have been involved. As a precautionary measure, we have 
partnered with ConsumerInfo.com, an Experian company (“ConsumerInfo”), to 
provide you with a full year of credit monitoring, at no charge. Experian is one
of the three recognized national credit reporting agencies. 

In May you were contacted, either via email or US Postal Service, with 
instructions for enrolling in the Credit Protection Program.  You were also sent
a promotional code, which is required to complete your enrollment in the Credit 
Protection Program.

to activate your Credit Protection Program membership, visit 
http://partner.consumerinfo.com/fla and follow the instructions.  For 
verification purposes, you will be asked to provide your name, address and other
personal information, along with the promotional code that was sent to you in 
May.

If you have not already activated your membership, we encourage you to do so as 
soon as possible.  In order to receive the benefits of the Credit Protection 
Program, you must activate your membership by 5pm on Thursday, August 10, 2006, 
or you will forfeit your opportunity to participate in the program.

If you have any additional questions about your promotional code, or concerning 
your registration in the Credit Protection Program, please visit 
www.dms.myflorida.com/PeopleFirstSecurityUpdate or call 1-866-663-4735, prompt 5.


People First! Customer Service

From: Runkle, Beverly [mailto:Beverly.Runkle@awi.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 12, 2006 3:55 PM
To: Ines.Marriott
Subject: FW: Ines Marriott-Wells - FW: Thanks 18058

 

July 12, 2006

 

 

 

 

Dear Ms. Wells:

 

Governor Bush has asked the Agency for Workforce Innovation to respond to your

e-mail regarding concerns with labor laws.  The Agency for Workforce Innovation is the State entity that partners with the local Workforce Boards to provide employment assistance. We regret that your friend lost her employment after 30 years.

 

However, Florida is an "employment at-will” state.  This means the employer establishes terms and conditions of employment.  The employer can terminate an employee for any reason, at any time, without advance notification; so long, as there is no violation of federal or state law. 

 

To assist job seekers, Florida has established a comprehensive Workforce Investment System that brings most education, job training, and employment assistance agencies and organizations under one roof.  These sites are known as One-Stop Career Centers and are located throughout the State.  The One-Stop Career Center staff can provide assistance to your friend in her job search, including job referrals, counseling, and other services.  In the resource rooms at the centers she can find current government and private listings of job opportunities.  Computers with Internet access and fax machines can be used at no cost to her.  Prior to visiting the Center, I encourage your friend to call and make an appointment to speak with a One-Stop representative about your employment needs.

 

Your friend may also call toll free 1-877-US2-JOBS (1-877-872-5627) to get the location of One-Stop Career Centers and other employment-related services throughout the United States. 

 

If your friend has a computer with Internet access, she may search the AWI’s website at http://www.floridajobs.org/ to find employment information.  I would also encourage her to utilize the EMPLOY FLORIDA web site at www.employflorida.net.   She can access jobs in the public and private sector directly via this site.  It is important that your friend keeps apprised of vacancies as they are announced and file the necessary application, if appropriate.

 

I hope this information is helpful to you and that your concerns are expeditiously resolved.

 

                                                            Sincerely,

 

 

 

                                                            Marion S. Little

                                                            Government Operations Consultant II

                                                            One-Stop and Program Support

 

 

MSL/olr

Pat,

Hamilton county in Ohio (Cincinnati) has a yearly inspection program for 
electrical components and a 5 yr inspection for non-electric componments.  
They also require a service contract with a reputable septic tank (HIST) 
comnpany to be maintained in effect.  In the below email address, I call 
your attention to 529.03 (P) and 529.06 A-T, and 529.02 R and M.  These 
people are progressive and didicated to properly maintained septic systems.  
Do they know someting that we don't?????   Hope this helps.

>poses a
>great and unneccessary health hazzard to the residents and tourists
>that use
>our beaches and waterways, including our bay (as evidenced by the many
>beach
>closings due to high fecal colliform counts).  According to Dr.
>Harwood's
>pie chart, that I'm sure you have all seen (if not, I can send you her
>ppt.
>presentation), on a national average, about 20% of all waterway
>polution
>comes from poorly maintained septic tanks.  Also in her chart, another
>40%
>nationally comes from unknown sources.  With the high water table in
>Florida
>(you hit water about 3 feet down in most places), it stands to reason
>that
>within Hillsborough County the probablility of the entire 40% of the
>"unknown" polution source could be attributed to septic tanks and
>sewage
>spills.  This suggests the PROBABLILITY OF AT LEAST 20% AND POSSIBLY
>60% OF
>ALL POLUTION IN hILLSBOROUGH COUNTY WATERWAYS MAY BE DUE TO SEPTIC
>TANKS.
>
>Hillsborough County doesn't know how many septic tanks there are in the
>
>county, but an educated guess by the permitting department is in the
>neighborhood of 100,000.  EPA estimates that the nationwide average is
>15%
>OF ALL SEPTIC TANKS ARE PLUGGED UP and not functioning properly at any
>one
>time.  This means 15,000 septic tanks are pouring raw sewage into the
>stormwater ditches and canals that lead directly into our BAY WITH
>EVERY
>FLUSH.  What has the BOCC done about this?  Nothing that I have heard
>about.
>   You can't put in sewars to everybody in the county, but you can
>inspect
>existing septic tanks on a yearly basis.  I suggest you do what is
>being
>done in some PROGRESSIVE, ENVIRONMENTALLY CONSCIOUS communities
>througout
>the U.S.:
>1.  Charge a $25 yearly inspeciton fee to those on septic tanks.  Send
>a
>person out to inspect each system on a yearly basis.  Let the Homeowner
>know
>when you are going to inspect so he can be present.
>2.  If they find a maintainance problem (plugged system) give them 90
>days
>to have it corrected.  Charge them another $25 for reinspection and
>certification.
>3.  If they refuse to fix the problem, shut off their water until it is
>
>fixed.
>
>This probably makes too much sense to have it implemented here, but
>with
>100,000 septice tanks being inspected yearly at $25 each gives the
>county
>$2.5 mm to work with yearly, and will greatly reduce the polution going
>into
>our bay.  Lets be pro-active for a change, and do something NOW,
>instead of
>waiting till someone gets sick and DIES from using our public beaches
>and
>waterways.  I've given you a plan, I'd like to hear your plans to

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: Dawn Nemethy 
Sent: Wednesday, July 12, 2006 3:31 PM
Subject: RE:


Thank you for your recent e-mail to Governor Bush asking for assistance in obtaining affordable housing.  I appreciate the opportunity to respond on his behalf.

 

As you may know, subsidized housing programs are under local and/or federal government control, and your best source of assistance is the executive director of the housing authority.  I suggest you write or call that person.  His or her address and telephone number can be found in the local government section of your telephone book.  

 

In an effort to provide affordable rental housing for Floridians earning low to moderate incomes, the Florida Housing Finance Corporation has compiled a county-by-county listing of apartment properties that it has financed throughout the state of Florida.  You can obtain this listing online at http://www.floridahousing.org/home or by calling their office at (850) 488-4197.

 

I hope this information is helpful, and if I can assist you with any other issue or concern, please let me know. 

 

                                                                        Sincerely, 

 

 

 

                                                                        Rex T. Newman

                                                                        Office of Citizens' Services

 

RN/h

Aztlan Acadmey: Coming to your neighborhood? (Rove makes nice with La Raza racial separatists)
Michelle Malkin Website ^ | 12 July 2006 | Michelle Malkin


Posted on 07/12/2006 11:34:24 AM PDT by Spiff


AZTLAN ACADEMY: COMING TO YOUR NEIGHBORHOOD?

By Michelle Malkin 

  ·   July 12, 2006 11:40 AM 

So, Karl Rove gave his "We are all Americans" speech to the National Council of La Raza--The Race--yesterday. Today, my syndicated column digs into the millions of dollars in Bush administration federal education grants The Race has received for its nationwide charter school initiative. 

It’s bad enough the White House lent its prestige to The Race’s annual conference. But did you know the Bush administration has forked over millions of federal tax dollars directly to The Race? 

According to GOP Rep. Charlie Norwood of Georgia, The Race snapped up $15.2 million in federal grants last year alone and more than $30 million since 1996. Undisclosed amounts went to get-out-the-vote efforts supporting La Raza political positions. The U.S. Department of Education funneled nearly $8 million in taxpayer grants to the group for a nationwide charter schools initiative. 

You may remember the reconquista school in Los Angeles whose principal teaches ethnic separatism along with Aztec math. The Race was a co-sponsor of that school with extremist activists from MECHA. Remember this interview with the principal of the school, La Academia Semillas del Pubelo: 

We don’t want to drink from a White water fountain, we have our own wells and our natural reservoirs and our way of collecting rain in our aqueducts. We don’t need a White water fountain. So the whole issue of segregation and the whole issue of the Civil Rights Movement is all within the box of White culture and White supremacy. We should not still be fighting for what they have. We are not interested in what they have because we have so much more and because the world is so much larger. And ultimately the White way, the American way, the neo liberal, capitalist way of life will eventually lead to our own destruction.


Turns out there are more where that one came from, folks. 

I have found dozens of other publicly-subsidized charter schools sponsored by The Race and funded with our money, including: 

*Aztlan Academy in Tuscon, Arizona. According to The Race, the school’s success rests on “Aztlan's ability to integrate a meaningful Chicano Studies program into their lives, language, and academics, as a means of developing their intellects as well as their pride and self-esteem.” The school’s name--a reference to a mythical swath of the vast Southwestern U.S. expanse, which Latino activists claim is their rightful homeland and which they seek to reconquer for Mexico--says it all. 

*Mexicayotl Academy in Nogales, Arizona. Who needs the three R’s? At Mexicayotl, it’s all about the three M’s: me, me, me! The school’s program is “structured and developed around the concepts of identity, culture, and language.” Second mission: supporting local ethnic lobbying efforts “to right social injustices by educating the community and helping create social change.” Under “greatest achievements,” the school’s website lists its participation in a “Peace & Dignity Run;” its visit from Rigoberta Menchu (the Marxist academic fraud from Guatemala who lied her way to a Nobel Peace Prize); and its sponsorship of
the local annual Día de los Muertos (the Mexican holiday). 

*The Dolores Huerta Preparatory High School in Pueblo, Colorado. It’s named after the far-Left Latina labor union activist who recently railed that “Republicans hate Latinos,” praised illegal alien marchers, and screeched that “We didn’t cross the borders, the borders crossed us” in a hate-filled tirade before Arizona students. 

*Academia Cesar Chavez Charter School in St. Paul, Minn. Board of Directors member Louis Mendoza, an activist Chicano Studies professor, pushed the school to lobby for the federal DREAM Act (providing in-state tuition discounts to illegal alien students not available to legal non-residents). The school’s website features one flag on its front page: the Mexican flag. 

  

The White House will tell you that The National Council of The Race is a “moderate,” mainstream civil rights group. But there’s nothing “moderate” about The Race’s advocacy of driver’s licenses and in-state tuition discounts for illegal aliens. Or its opposition to strengthening security for identity documents and improving cooperation on immigration enforcement between state, local, and federal enforcement immigration officials. Or its all-out war on the House GOP’s border security and enforcement-first bill passed last December. 

President Bush pays lip service to immigration enforcement and assimilation, while the White House sends Karl Rove to make nice with the separatist leaders of The Race and the Bush Education Department showers our tax dollars on radical Reconquista schools. It doesn’t add up. 

Unless, of course, you’re using Aztec math.


  _____

Subject: Makay Scholarships and Special Ed
From:    rwelsh@cdp.com

Cc:      rwelsh@cdp.com

Dear Mr. Bush,
I wanted to share in real life not on paper how decisions can effect or
let me say have an unintended consequence if left alone. Let me a share a
real story as of yesterday. My wife and daughter God Bless them are
Special Ed teachers here in Florida. My wife works with kids with very
special needs at Champion School in Longwood Florida. Last night my wife
shares with me a conversation she had with Vicki the founder of the
school. Here are the key points. Vicki learned that the Makay group is
going to require a facility in order for any place like Champion to offer
teaching these very needy kids.Although in Longwood there is a facility
accross florida Special Ed teachers are teaching needy kids in there homes
and churches or wherever they can. As of yesterday if that happens
hundreds of thousands of kids State wide will lose the individual teaching
they desperately need. Lets look at the goal here. The goal with no one
left behind is, in my paraphrased version, find a way no matter what to
teach our children especially those with extreme needs and here we are
with one stroke of a pen in essence firing Teachers all over the State and
leaving the needy student and parent with no answer.Let me go on with
these needy kids in real life..These Special Ed kids need to continue
through the summer with the same process because these kids do not have
the retention as others do and if they stop they lose too much ground and
they never get ahead but the parent cannot afford to pay during the summer
as Makay stops until fall. I plead with you on 2 fronts. DO not let a
decision happen that hurts our kids and as of now that is on the plan.
Second get a summer grant of whatever vehicle in place so parents and us
as a community can help these kids progress.

I hope and pray my concerns are not just read but action occurs because of
it. If not I have failed.

Rex Welsh
General Manager
CDP

www.cdp.com

that he must entrust certain aspects to be handled by those most qualified
to do so. In this instance forwarding your e-mail directly to the Florida
Lottery was the most effective means of alerting us to a constituent's
input. We appreciate you contacting us with your concern regarding our Web
site and we wanted to ensure you that while the Web may have been down, it
had no effect on the actual drawing which was broadcast live as it is every
night. We understand the inconvenience you and many other players
experienced, but please be assured it did not alter the drawing. As
mentioned in the previous e-mail, our drawings are conducted under strict
security and are monitored by a company that is not affiliated with the
Lottery.
