From:	Charles Sobchak <charles.sobchak@freescale.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 12:41 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; Atwater, Jeff; Campbell, Walter; rnethery@humana.com; Jlenahan@humana.com; mlubitz@humana.com; bkerr@humana.com; dbaker@humana.com; cdickson@humana.com; susan.sheridan@cignabehavioral.com; keith.dixon@cignabehavioral.com
Cc:	Alicia Sobchak Work; CHARLES SOBCHAK
Subject:	Health Care Issue - dual coverage = no coverage?

To All:

We are being sued by a medical company for fees ($3,565) because our 
health insurance companies will not pay for it (due to an unknown dual 
coverage of Medical companies).  In addition, previously we've paid fees 
out of pocket that should have been covered by our health insurance 
company.  I greatly appreciate all of your time as this has been an 
extremely stressful situation that I do not comprehend.

From 1998 to 2005 my wife Alicia Bellini Sobchak was on my medical plan 
at Motorola (and then Freescale Semiconductor - Freescale was spun off 
from Motorola). The medical plan was called Motorla HAP and then HUMANA 
PPO : ChoiceCare+, Caremark (when Freescale was spun off from Motorola). 
This is a medical plan that I pay a monthly fee to include her on the 
plan. This medical plan was her primary plan since it cost us in excess 
of $600 per year to include her. In 2005 while filling out yearly paper 
work she unknowingly did not mark a box that said she declined her 
medical plan at her teaching position in Broward Community College. This 
free plan from BCC was CIGNA (HMO).  It was never our intention for her 
to take a free plan with less coverage that would cause her to change 
all of her doctors that she had for the previous 7 years while under my 
plan at Motorola.

In 2005 Alicia had some serious health issues and went to the same 
doctor that she has been going to for the previous 7 years. HUMANA PPO 
(Freescale plan of which I pay for) is telling us that because she 
unknowingly did not mark that box declining CIGNA coverage while filling 
out some yearly paperwork at BCC, the new free plan (of which she was 
never a part of) is her primary and that the Motorola/Freescale Health 
Care plan that I have been paying her for 7 years (and never had a 
problem with) is now deemed her secondary plan. First I must say we 
never even knew that there was such a thing as a primary or a secondary 
plan or that she didn't mark the box saying that she declined CIGNA 
coverage on the BCC paperwork.

HUMANA does not want to pay the medical bills because they say regardless that we 
have been on a paid plan by my employer for 7 years that they are not 
the primary (because of the BCC paper work saying she didn't decline 
CIGNA HMO coverage). CIGNA does not want to pay the bill since the doctor is 
not on their plan (the doctor is on my paid plan that we were part of 
for 7 years). We didn't even know she was insured by CIGNA.

So we are caught in the middle, the medical company wants its money and 
is thus suing us (and we've already paid fees out of pocket that 
should have been covered in our HUMANA plan). CIGNA says that we went to a doctor out of 
their coverage and shouldn't have to pay. HUMANA says they are our 
secondary and shouldn't pay anything? I desperately appreciate anyone's 
help in this matter. I don't think it makes logical sense.

1)    It was our assumption over the past 7 years that Alicia was only 
on my medical plan HUMANA (at Motorola and the Freescale Semiconductor).
2)    This is the plan with all of our doctors that we have built up a 
rapport with and never had any intention of changing it (or of changing 
our doctors to go on a free plan with less coverage).
3)    Even though she unknowingly didn't decline CIGNA coverage why does 
it matter?

Thank you,

Charles and Alicia Sobchak

954.915.8820
Charles.sobchak@freescale.com
Asobchak@broward.edu

-----Original Message-----
From: owner-govnews@elist.myflorida.com
[mailto:owner-govnews@elist.myflorida.com] On Behalf Of Governor Jeb
Bush
Sent: Saturday, July 08, 2006 6:47 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, July 7, 2006

For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader,
Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


RECORD NUMBER OF FLORIDIANS USING SAFETY BELTS

On Thursday I announced that a record number of Floridians are using
safety
belts. The Preusser Research Group recently reported that 80.7 percent
of
drivers and their front seat passengers are using safety belts on
Florida
highways.  Overall, safety belt usage rates in Florida have climbed more
than 20 percent since 2000. A vast majority of Floridians are using
safety
belts. Wearing a safety belt saves lives. It is the single most
effective
way to prevent injuries and reduce fatalities in motor vehicle crashes.
For
more information on Florida's 'Click It or Ticket' safety belt campaign,
please visit www.clickitfla.com.


CHRISTA CALAMAS APPOINTED SECRETARY OF THE FLORIDA AGENCY FOR HEALTH
CARE
ADMINISTRATION

On Thursday I named Christa Calamas as Secretary of the Florida Agency
for
Health Care Administration (AHCA). Calamas most recently served as the
General Counsel for AHCA.  The appointment is effective July 8.
Previously,
she served as Assistant General Counsel to Governor Bush from 2002 to
2005.
Calamas replaces Secretary Alan Levine who was recently selected as the
new
CEO of the North Broward Hospital District. Christa's extensive
experience
in health care policy continues to be a great asset to my
administration. I
am confident Christa will continue the good work done by Secretary
Levine as
Florida implements landmark Medicaid reform, leads the nation in public
reporting of hospital information and begins the process of creating
networks for electronic medical records. All three of these priorities
will
fundamentally improve the way health care is delivered in our state. For
more information on Florida's consumer-driven health care initiatives,
please visit http://ahca.myflorida.com or www.floridacomparecare.gov. 


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD PRESENTED TO ALICIA CRABTREE

On Wednesday I recognized Alicia Crabtree of Melbourne as this week's
Points
of Light Award recipient.  For over three years, Alicia has dedicated
her
time to volunteer efforts at the Melbourne Children's Home Society, an
organization designed to prevent child abuse and neglect. I am proud to
recognize Alicia for the tremendous impact she has had on the lives of
others less fortunate. She has given selflessly of her time and
resources
for the enhancement of others.  Alicia is to be commended for her
extraordinary commitment to the community and should serve as an example
to
us all.  For more information, or to nominate, go to
www.VolunteerFloridaFoundation.org.

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/7975


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.

http://www.myflorida.com/myflorida/subscribe.html


Thank you.

A gem from the pandering speech: 

"You know there's an important parallel between the perception of Irish immigrants, or German immigrants, or Italian immigrants, or Nordic immigrants, or Chinese or Japanese immigrants, in the 19th and 20th century in what we're seeing in the debate today over immigration. Unfortunately, the debate has clouded the views of some people in America and lead them to fail to understand that Hispanics and all immigrants are real Americans."

With comments like this, Rove doesn't distinguish between legal immigrants and illegal aliens. And he states that his opposition (those who are against amnesty and rewards for illegal aliens) are "clouded" by some sort of misperception towards hispanics. 

Rove can go screw himself. It has nothing to do with whether the illegal aliens are hispanic or norwegian or even martians. It has to do with national security, national sovereignty, the rule of law, right and wrong, and what illegal aliens of every race, creed, nationality, color, and stripe are doing to our communities.

9 posted on 07/12/2006 7:40:08 AM PDT by kellynla (Freedom of speech makes it easier to spot the idiots! Semper Fi!)

  _____  

To: Spiff
Michelle also noticed that Rove was speaking at a La Raza [The Race] conference. You just can't believe they could pander this hard after reading Michelle's article, but damn if it's not happening. 

‘La Raza’ schools: Your tax dollars at work 

Top White House adviser Karl Rove traveled to Los Angeles this week to pay homage to the anti-immigration enforcement lobbying group for Latinos: the National Council of La Raza. 

"La Raza" is Spanish for "The Race." 

It's bad enough the White House lent its prestige to The Race's annual conference. But did you know the Bush administration has forked over millions of federal tax dollars directly to The Race? 

According to GOP Rep. Charlie Norwood of Georgia, The Race snapped up $15.2 million in federal grants last year alone and more than $30 million since 1996. Undisclosed amounts went to get-out-the-vote efforts supporting La Raza political positions. The U.S. Department of Education funneled nearly $8 million in taxpayer grants to the group for a nationwide charter schools initiative. 

Among The Race's most infamous government-funded charter schools is La Academia Semillas del Pubelo, the Los Angeles public school that teaches "Aztec math" (ancient dot math is the new math) and the Mexican indigenous language of "Nahuatl." The ethnic separatist principal of the school, Marcos Aguilar, told a sympathetic UCLA interviewer: 

"We don't want to drink from a White water fountain, we have our own wells and our natural reservoirs and our way of collecting rain in our aqueducts. We don't need a White water fountain…We are not interested in what they have because we have so much more and because the world is so much larger. And ultimately the White way, the American way, the neo liberal, capitalist way of life will eventually lead to our own destruction." 

[Excerpt] 

‘La Raza’ schools: Your tax dollars at work

I strongly urge you to do everything in your power to stop the marketing and sale of junk food in schools, and to introduce and pass legislation to implement the Childhood Obesity Prevention Agenda (www.commercialalert.org/copa.pdf).

The Childhood Obesity Prevention Agenda has been endorsed by leading authors, scientists and obesity experts from Harvard, Johns Hopkins, Stanford, Yale and other major research institutions, including Lawrence Cheskin (Director, Johns Hopkins Weight Management Center); Frances Moore Lappe (author, Diet for a Small Planet); Marion Nestle (author, Food Politics); Alvin Poussaint (Harvard Medical School); Walter Willett (Harvard School of Public Health).

The Open Borders Mayor [Illegal Immigration Shamnesty Is Dead Mayor Bloomberg]
FrontPage ^ | July 12, 2006 | Heather MacDonald


Posted on 07/12/2006 5:02:26 AM PDT by conservativecorner


Last week, New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg put the world on notice that when an open borders enthusiast talks tough on enforcement, he’s probably faking it. 

Bloomberg testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee’s hearings on immigration reform in Philadelphia, convened to counter the House’s simultaneous hearings on the costs and risks of illegal immigration. The mayor offered an eloquent defense of open borders. The flow of people into the United States is a force of nature, beyond mortal control, he said. We can no more stop the influx than a beachgoer can stop the tides. The decision about whether to enter the country and under what conditions is entirely the immigrant’s, not the American people’s. 

But not to worry, Bloomberg reassured his audience. Immigration is at all times and in all forms an unmitigated boon. Illiterate, literate, skilled, unskilled—all immigrants are necessary. Without our current levels of immigration, Bloomberg said, the New York and national economies would “collapse” (apparently New York business deals rest precariously on free pizza delivery and low-cost restaurant dish-washing). 

In fact, we risk collapse for lack of immigrants, Bloomberg warned. High-skill industries like science and medicine are growing faster in other countries, he claimed. The solution: more immigrants—manual laborers as well as engineers. But no country has a higher rate or absolute number of immigrants than the U.S. If other countries are producing more skilled graduates, maybe it is because their school systems aren’t saddled with an ever-growing pool of foreign students from cultures that do not highly value academic achievement and their schools aren’t dragged by ethnic politics into enforced academic mediocrity. 

Predictably, Bloomberg called for amnesty for the 12 million illegals already here. Like all such advocates, he held out mass deportations as the only alternative—a straw man “solution” that no serious immigration reformer has proposed. 

Yet Bloomberg also tried to sound like an immigration cop. He decried the federal government’s failure to penalize employers who hire illegal aliens. He mocked the 1986 immigration reform law that prohibited employers from verifying a worker’s legal status. He called for a biometric social security card that would defeat counterfeiting. And he wanly conceded that perhaps a little bit of fencing on the border might be necessary, though he would prefer a “virtual wall.” 

So is a commitment to immigration enforcement compatible with the belief that the U.S. has a duty to take all non-terrorist comers, regardless of whether they enter in the trunk of a car or through customs? Nope. The ending of Bloomberg’s testimony thoroughly undermined his gestures toward the rule of law, making clear that the instincts that lead people to support amnesty and an unrestricted right of entry will defeat enforcement in the blink of an eye. 

In those final remarks, Bloomberg blasted a House proposal to penalize cities and counties that have “sanctuary laws.” These ubiquitous laws prohibit local government employees from notifying federal immigration authorities about the presence of illegal aliens. Sanctuary mandates create vast law-free zones where illegal immigrants know that they face virtually no risk of apprehension; the zones have notoriously protected criminals as well as itinerant roofers. 

In 1996, Congress responded by prohibiting local governments from restricting the speech of their workers in this way. To no avail. Virtually every sanctuary city proceeded to ignore this new federal law as well as the preexisting immigration laws. New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani took his defiance to federal court. He lost his suit against the 1996 law, but—on September 10, 2001—declared his intention to continue violating it anyway. 

Mayor Mike Bloomberg has gone even further in backing the sanctuary policy. In 2003, the city faced a massive public relations fiasco following the rape of a Queens mother by a group of illegal Mexicans. New York police had arrested several of the Mexicans previously for other crimes, but reported none of them to the immigration agency. Congress hauled in the city’s criminal justice coordinator to testify about the city’s sanctuary law, after which Mayor Bloomberg—amazingly—strengthened the policy. And last week he declared his defiance of the Congressional will yet again. If Congress goes forward with its proposal to cut homeland security funds to localities with sanctuary rules, he told the Senate Judiciary Committee, it would have “one heck of a battle” on its hands. 

Bloomberg’s discussion of New York’s sanctuary law, like the law itself, was a clever piece of evasion. Trying to sound reasonable, the mayor told the hearing that “New York City cooperates fully with the Federal government when an illegal immigrant commits a criminal act.” But the crucial issue is whether the New York Police Department will report an illegal crime suspect to Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or whether it will merely “cooperate” with ICE when the federal agency is already seeking an illegal suspect. When the NYPD stops the next potential illegal rapist on a robbery charge, in other words, will it tell ICE to come and get him? 

Bloomberg’s updated sanctuary policy, Executive Order No. 41, is as misleading on this question as was his testimony. The order declares that law enforcement officers shall “cooperate with federal authorities in investigating and apprehending aliens suspected of criminal activity” but leaves ambiguous the question of the NYPD’s affirmative duty to report. City officers may report an illegal alien suspected of non-immigration-related illegal activity but have no obligation to do so. 

So how does the NYPD interpret its authority? Asked what the threshold was for reporting an illegal alien suspect to ICE, the NYPD press office simply referred to Executive Order No. 41—itself silent on the matter. Nor could the department say how many suspects it has reported to ICE over the past year and whether they represented all of the undocumented suspects who have come to the force’s attention. The department simply does not keep statistics on such matters. Needless to say, this ignorance about a crime problem and about the official response to it represents a remarkable lacuna of record-keeping for an agency that lives and dies by the numbers. 

Maybe ICE would know about how many illegal alien criminals the NYPD has reported to it? If so, it isn’t saying. Department of Homeland Security spokesman Mark Raimondi replied diplomatically when asked about the NYPD’s illegal alien reporting: “We have a strong working relationship with the NYPD; we work closely with the department and solve a lot of crimes together.” Yes, but there is this little matter of Executive Order 41. “The order does at times prevent the NYPD from sharing information that we’d like to have,” admitted Raimondi cautiously. 

It’s hard to blame the NYPD for what looks likely to be passivity regarding the reporting of illegal alien criminals. The message from the mayor’s office and from New York political elites runs in exactly the opposite direction, and without a clear affirmative mandate regarding illegal reporting, the safe policy is to do nothing. Executive Order No. 41 lays out the remarkable proposition that one’s status as an illegal alien is “confidential information” of the same order as one’s sexual orientation, status as a victim of sexual assault, or tax records. Mayor Bloomberg really does believe that illegal entry is an uncontrollable force of nature like “the tide,” as he puts it—people who come here illegally are no more responsible for their movements across the border than pieces of plankton. Given the protections that Executive Order No. 41 confers on illegal aliens, the NYPD might understandably demur from testing the reach of its authority under the order. 

So in Philadelphia, Bloomberg thumbed his nose at Congress yet again and dared that body to penalize him for violating the 1996 federal anti-sanctuary statute. New York would continue to ban its employees from reporting illegal aliens to the federal government, he said. The irony is that whenever anyone suggests allowing local law enforcement and other officials to cooperate with immigration agents, the open borders crowd responds that immigration enforcement is exclusively a federal responsibility. But how can federal agents discharge that responsibility when the people closest to the problem withhold needed information? 

Mayor Bloomberg provided a valuable service with his testimony last week. He demonstrated that the belief that “no person is illegal”—watchword of the amnesty movement, popularized by Los Angeles Cardinal Roger Mahoney—will trump the willingness to enforce immigration laws every time. That’s why those who believe in the rule of law must insist on the “enforcement first” strategy for immigration reform: defer amnesty and the liberalization of immigration rules until border security and interior enforcement are demonstrably working. Mayor Bloomberg and President Bush’s “comprehensive” approach of combining amnesty and higher levels of immigration with a promise of increased enforcement will inevitably lose its second half along the way.

If you have any special message or even a little greeting for the Irish speaking public, I will be thrilled to pass it on for you via radio.

I hope you get to meet  Eamon o Cuiv, the grandson of the late  President De Valera who is a great hero of mine.  In his early 20's he left his very comfortable lifestyle in Dublin and went to work and live in Connemara at a farmers co-op so that the Irish Language speaking people there would have a better life.  We call him  Young Dev.

It would be wonderful if they could bring you to either see the coffin of  Matt Talbot or the Laneway where he died on his way to Mass.  He will eventually become a saint.  He came from a very poor family and worked at a mill.  In his younger days he drank a lot and is now the saint that people pray to for their families who have addictions.  He is very much the patron saint of Dublin but he let me down badly when he let Terri Schaivo die.

You will probably see the General Post Office in O'Connell Street, Dublin where the fighting took place in 1916 and as a result we got our freedom.

Knock, Co. Mayo is where the Blessed Virgin was said to appear on the Gabel End of the Church there.  

Holy Cross Abbey in Tipperary has a portion of the True Cross on display.  It is tiny but you can actually see it.

Holy Cross Abbey is not far from the Rock of Cashel  where my ancestor,  King Brian Boru, the King of Munster. (from Ahearne, brother of King Brian Boru who had a son called Floinn and his son was Raith from whom my grandmother's family, The McGraths are descended).  My ancestor Bishop Miller McGrath is buried on the Rock of Cashel).  Close to the Rock of Cashel, as you approach it from Dublin and look down to the right, that land belongs to Vincent O'Brien the famous race horse trainer where JR Ewing (Larry Haggman) and other famous people have their horses trained.
I do not know if our greatly loved prime Minister Bertie Ahearne knows that King Brian Boru, King of Munster, who was killed at the battle of Clontarf in 1014 had a brother called Ahearne?

Gaelic Greetings:

Ta athas orm a bheith anseo  = I am pleased to be here.
Phonetic:   Thaw awhas orm (like worm without the w) a veh onsho.
                  Thaw awhas orm a veh onshow.
----------------

Gura Maith agaibh = Thank You All  
Phonetic:  Gorra Mawh Agiv

-------------
Gura Maith agat, A Thaoiseach =  Thank You Taoiseach.
Phonetic:  Gorra Mawh aguth, A Heeshoch.

-----------
On a toast raising a glass:   Slainte  (Good Health) = phonetically Slawnte.
You can reply by also saying just Slawnte.

------------
Slan =  Goodbye.
Phonetic:  Slawn

-------------
Famous Dublin Characters:   Forty Coats (A vagrant).  Old Bang Bang ran from Church to Church saying Bang Bang both in the 1920's.

Molly Malone one of Dublin's best known songs...a ficticious character, a fish seller:  "she wheeled her wheelbarrow through streets broad and narrow".

Dicey Riley:  another song about a ficticious person: 

"Poor Auld Dicey Riley, she has taken to the sup,
Poor Auld Dicey Riley,  she cannot give it up,
It's off each morning to the hop, then she pops in for another little drop.

The relatively new sculpture near Trinity College is nicknamed "The Flousie in the Jaccouzi".

If you land in Shannon,  they may take you to Dromoland Castle home of the O'Brien Chieftain, Conor O'Brien, Lord Insequin.  (Some of the family were called Heffernan and Quinn,  thus the town in Co. Clare called Quinn and thus the title Lord Insequin).
The Blind Poet Liam Dall O'Heffernan, of the Lord Insequin family wrote a poem Called Kathleen Ni hUallachain which became the secret name for Ireland and a painting of a woman called Lady Lavery depicted Kathleen Ni hUallachain on the old Irish Pound Note now out of circulation,  you will be using Euro coins now.  If Mrs. Bush is going with you,  this is somewhere she should see.  Very interesting but not as beautiful is the nearby Bunratty Castle.  If given a choice,  go to Dromoland Castle.

-------------


If there are any other Gaelic words that you need,  I will be thrilled to send them to you.  Every year in the past I called the White House Speech Writers Dept. and asked if they needed any words for your brother the President for his St. Patrick's Day speech and nobody ever called me back.

I hope you will really enjoy your visit to Ireland.

Kind regards,
Maire Peters (from Ireland, living in Naples)

Hello All --

Reynolds, Indiana's renewable natural gas effort points the way toward general renewable natural gas solutions, see below.  Reynolds uses waste as the basis for their effort -- this waste effort is similar to many  around the world -- there are at least 3000 manure matches in Germany and millions, large and small mostly in Asia.   Historically, such production has been associated with waste water treatment systems.

Our direction is non-waste, Renewable natural gas, “RNG”, produced under similar anaerobic fermentation conditions along with compost-fertilizer from biomass grown specifically as process feedstock.  

With a similar objective, perhaps, we offer the application of anaerobic fermentation to a familiar problem associated with water treatment.  Under our conditions, we offer a solution to the waste water spray irrigation problem.  Our process has these advantages:

1.     There are no waste products affecting the environment – 

2.     Process useful biomass comes in many forms –

a.     the principle forms are mostly giant, perennial legumes

b.    several other plant types would be of use in spray fields 

                                          i.    such that each 500 acres could produce as much as 

1.     4 megawatt equivalents of useful power and other forms of energy

2.     assuming a spray field of  500 acres would satisfy the needs of 25,000

3.     outstanding compost-fertilizer-soil amendment that, after application, would further reduce runoff 

                                         ii.    Tallahassee would need 5000 acres producing 40 MW equivalents

                                        iii.    Florida 320000 acres that would provide in excess of 2500 MW 

 

Application in other Southern U. S. states could involve some ten times that in Florida and produce as much as 25000 MW equivalents of energy.

More tomorrow -- but remember:

 The State of Florida announced in summer 2003 a Governor's initiated program ....... ".... to develop a Statewide Energy Plan: Energy Planning for Florida's Future".  The report contain this admonition:
"The prime source of funds to support advances in energy efficiency and 
renewable energy resources in Florida is controlled by private utilities, 
whose business objective is to maximize profits rather than to conserve 
scarce energy resources."  

And the petroleum and the automobile and the ... so on and so on!
Best, Dick Glick --

U.S. farm town tries for all-renewable energy 	  	  	  	
Written by ASHLEY M. HEHER    http://planetsave.com/	
Sunday, 09 July 2006 	
REYNOLDS, Indiana (AP) _ This farming hamlet is aiming to generate its own electricity and gas, using everything from municipal trash to farm waste, hog manure and even town sewage. 

Some of the 20,000 hogs on the William Shroeder farm Thursday, June 22, 2006 in Reynolds, Ind. The waste generated by area hogs will help Reynolds become the nation's first community to use renewable resources to fuel their entire energy needs. (AP Photo/John Harrell) 

If the experiment works, Reynolds and its 500 residents will be America's first community to use renewable resources to meet the energy needs of all their homes and businesses. 

``It's not like we have a blueprint to follow,'' said farmer William Schroeder, 52. ``We're going by the seat of our pants.'' 

Dubbed Biotown USA, the project is the brainchild of Indiana's Department of Agriculture. State officials hope to break ground in November on a $10 million (euro7.8 million) ``technology suite,'' a privately funded center that will house the core equipment needed to turn manure and other biomass material into energy. It should generate electricity for the town by July 2007. 

From there, state officials hope another $10 million (euro7.8 million) from private investors will upgrade the system so it can also produce natural gas. 

Much of the technology has been implemented elsewhere in waste treatment centers and industries like paper manufacturing, researchers said. But Biotown would be the first time the machinery is combined and working in synch. 

Proponents say the project will lower local utility costs and help the environment. Organizers estimate a barrel of biomass will cost about $40 (euro31.30). Crude oil edged above $75 a barrel this past week. 

``Our goal, and what we're going to continue to work on, is for it to cost less,'' said Ryan West, who is leading the Biotown project for the Agriculture Department. ``We said we'd call it a failure if energy bills went up.'' 

If the project succeeds, Reynolds could be a prototype for reducing America's dependence on foreign oil. 

``This becomes a living laboratory for us,'' said Bernie Engel, head of the agricultural and biological engineering department at nearby Purdue University. ``Reynolds may be a demonstration location for some of this initially. And then we'll see it hopefully spreading beyond that.'' 

First, however, it has to take hold in Reynolds. 

Farmer Roger Wiese, 65, has not decided yet whether to sell 2 million gallons (7.6 million liters) of hog manure to Biotown instead of using it as fertilizer on his fields. He will agree only if he can make a profit. 

``There's not enough money in agriculture that we can run it as a charity,'' he said. ``Without it working economically, it doesn't become feasible.'' 

State officials said they do not need total participation from local farmers. A study found there were more than 150,000 hogs within 15 miles (24 kilometers) of town, and organizers estimate the animals, along with other organic waste in the area, are enough to produce 74 times the energy Reynolds needs. 

Town fire chief Rick Buschman says Biotown is ``the greatest thing to hit Reynolds'' in years. His family has bought a half-dozen new flex-fuel vehicles _ able to run on various fuels including ethanol-gasoline blends _ as part of a deal offered by General Motors. 

``We want to participate in the program any way we can,'' he said. 

So far, residents have bought more than 100 new cars and trucks under the program. A $400,000 (euro313,038) renovation project of the town's single gas station should add a pump for E-85 fuel _ 85 percent ethanol and 15 percent gasoline _ by the end of the summer. 

``Some people are questioning if we save money,'' said Christine McGill, a cook, waitress and hostess at USA Family Restaurant. ``To me, what if we don't? We're still saving the environment.''

From: patriciadina@comcast.net [mailto:patriciadina@comcast.net]
Sent: Sunday, June 25, 2006 10:38 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: [*] My Grandson - Pvt. Justin C. Dina


Dear Governor Bush:

From the moment my grandson, Justin, turned 17 years old on November 25,
2004, many branches of the military had vigorously pursued his enlistment.
In 
particular, the U.S. Army literally wined and dined Justin for a solid year
and 
a half.  We had realized that the military was allowed to talk to high school

students,  but we believed that they could not do so without our knowledge or

consent.  We recently learned that Spanish River High School coach, Mrs.
Miller, 
escorted Justin out to see a recruiter when he was only 17 years old.  This
was accomplished without any advance notice to us that she planned on
becoming Justin's "adult" escort.  That a high school coach took the liberty
upon herself 
to alter the course of an underage person for whom she was not their legal 
guardian is horrifying to say the least.  Justin was a great student and good

tennis player.  He lost interest in both after being literally brain-washed
for 
a year and a half by the U.S. Army recruiter, Sgt. Gaddy.  This recruiter
painted such a grandiose, adventurous picture of military life that even he
couldn't possibly believe what he was saying.  But my grandson was very
naive.  Sgt. Gaddy even had Justin convinced that there was a very good
possibility that Justin would never be sent to Iraq once his training had
been completed.  By the time Justin was going away, he would not listen to a
word his family said.  Justin had advised me on numerous occasions that the
Army was his "real" family.  That the Army was the only one who cared about
him.  That his 
Army buddies were his "brothers" and they, not us, would always have his
back.  We (his family) became the enemy.  When we would try to discuss his
enlistment, Justin would put his hands over his ears, mumble unintelligible
words and walk away from us.  It was insane.  He was like some kind of
robotic zombie.  He was truly the victim of some serious brain-washing. His
attitude and temperament had dramatically changed. This was not the Jus
tin we raised. 

	When Justin turned 18 years old, he was a senior in high school.  He 
signed up for the delayed enlistment program to go into airborne infantry.
They 
had Justin swear in and take a physical at that time.  Immediately after the 
swear-in, which was shortly after his eighteenth birthday, Sgt. Gaddy told 
Justin he was now the property of the U.S. Army and that he was committed to 
serving 8 years in the military.  He told Justin that he had to report to
boot 
camp at the end of high school or face serious consequences such as 
court-martial, etc.  And, during this entire time you had to realize that
Sgt. 
Gaddy was keeping in touch with Justin on a daily basis.  He constantly
filled 
Justin with unrealistic views of military life.  He convinced Justin who was 
supposed to pursue a tennis scholarship at FSU, that college life was not for

him.  He told Justin a real man defended his family and country.  This went
on 
for months on end.  Sgt. Gaddy was relentless in his pursuit of Justin.  And
in the end he won!

	
	On Memorial Day, May 29, 2006, we took Justin to the Recruiting
Office.  
Once there, Sergeant First Class Stephen J. Canonico, told Justin that he
would 
be taken to Miami, stay overnight in a hotel and then catch a plane the next
day to Ft. Benning, GA.  He told Justin he would be sworn in a second time
and 
undergo a second physical.  At that point, I tried to tell Justin that if he 
needed to be sworn in again, that the first swear-in apparently didn't mean 
anything and that he could walk away.  But the recruiter kept telling Justin
it 
was only a formality and inferred that Justin needed to keep his promise and
be a "man".  He also told Justin to tell the Medic that he had no physical 
ailments.  I then reminded Justin and the recruiter that Justin had trouble
with 
his knees and back.  Sgt. Canonico told Justin not to say anything about any 
kind of medical problems.  If asked, he told Justin to say he had no physical

impairments or had no past injuries.  I was just not being heard.  The Army
had Justin thoroughly under their power.  It was very frustrating.  

	After we dropped Justin off, I hadn't heard from Justin until last 
Thursday night, June 15, 2006.  It was 10:11 PM.  Justin was crying on the 
phone.  He said that he couldn't take it anymore and wanted to come home.  He
said that he was on "profile" for injuries to his knee and foot.  He said he 
couldn't take the physical pain and was being verbally abused on a daily
basis.  
He said that they gave him an inhaler to help him breathe.  (Justin has lived
in 
Florida all of his life and has never required an inhaler.)  He told his
drill 
sergeant that he couldn't take anymore mental and physical pain and wanted to
leave the military.  The drill sergeant told him that he would never leave.
He 
was stuck in there for 8 years and that if Justin didn't finish boot camp,  
Justin would be continually re-cycled with each new group of enlistees for an

eternity.  Justin was devastated and wanted to go awol that night.  We knew
he couldn't get out that evening, so we told Justin to try to hang in there
and go to the infirmary every chance he got.  Justin told his grandfather
that if he didn't go back to training the next day, the re-cycling process
would begin immediately.  He was terrified of the drill sergeants and was
emotionally 
a wreck.  He was continually sobbing.  It was quite evident that Justin was 
emotionally unstable and probably at his breaking point.  We talked to Justin

until we were able to calm him somewhat and told him we would support any 
decision he made.  My husband told him to ignore the drill sergeants.  But 
apparently, he couldn't because that Saturday, June 17, 2006, I talked to his

Commanding Officer who advised me that Justin went back to training and was
on "partial" profile for his knee.  I begged the Officer to allow me to speak
with Justin so that I could determine that Justin was actually fine, but he
refused.

	After continual calls to Justin's commanding officer, they finally 
allowed Justin to call us again on Saturday, June 23, 2006.  Justin was once 
again uncontrollably crying.  He told us that he was now seeing a
psychiatrist 
because of severe depression.  Even though his knee is still hurting him, his

commanding officer told him he will get an article 15 if he doesn't get back
to 
training.  So Justin once again is attempting to run on a severely injured
knee.  
Justin is more desperate than ever.  For his sake, I implore your help in 
assisting Justin to be released from the Army as soon as possible.  I am now
in 
a state of panic. I truly fear for his safety.  Can you please, please help
us.  
I worry to the point of sleep deprivation.  Justin is in the 3rd Platoon, D 
Company, 2nd Brigade, 54th Infantry with a Roster # of 312 at Ft. Benning,
GA. 
31905

	Please, please help us.  I am desperate!  Justin is our only
grandchild.  
We will never have anymore.  We raised Justin so he not only is my grandson, 
he is my son as well.  I beg you, one parent to another, please please help
me.   I will be eternally grateful for all of your assistance.  And, I
strongly believe 
you maybe our only hope to help save the sanity and physical well-being of a 
very naive, sensitive and vulnerable young man.

	
						Sincerely,


						Patricia Dina
						Mother & Grandmother

-----Original Message-----
From: patriciadina@comcast.net [mailto:patriciadina@comcast.net]
Sent: Monday, June 19, 2006 8:52 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: [*] Pvt. Justin C. Dina


Dear Governor Bush:

From the moment Justin turned 17 years old on November 25, 2004, many
branches of the military had vigorously pursued his enlistment.  In
particular, the U.S. Army literally wined and dined Justin for a solid year
and a half.  We had realized that the military was allowed to talk to high
school students,  but we believed that they could not do so without our
knowledge or consent.  We recently learned that Spanish River High School
coach, Mrs. Miller, escorted Justin out to see a recruiter when he was only
17 years old.  This was accomplished without any advance notice to us that
she planned on becoming Justin's "adult" escort.  That a high school coach
took the liberty upon herself to alter the course of an underage person for
whom she was not their legal guardian is horrifying to say the least.  This
must be stopped immediately.  Justin was a great student and good tennis
player.  He lost interest in both after being literally brain-washed for a
year and a half by the U.S. Army re
cruiter, Sgt. Gady.  This recruiter painted such a grandiose, adventurous
picture of military life that even he couldn't possibly believe what he was
saying.  But my grandson was very naive.  Sgt. Gady even had Justin convinced
that there was a very good possibly that Justin would never be sent to Iraq
once his training had been completed.  By the time Justin was going away, he
would not listen to a word his family said.  Justin had advised me on
numerous occasions that the Army was his "real" family.  That the Army was
the only one who cared about him.  That his Army buddies were his "brothers"
and they, not us, would always have his back.  We (his family) became the
enemy.  When we would try to discuss his enlistment, Justin would put his
hands over his ears, mumble unintelligible words and walk away from us.  It
was insane.  He was like some kind of robotic zombie.  He was truly the
victim of some serious brain-washing. His attitude and temperament had
dramatically changed. This
 was not the Justin we raised. 

When Justin turned 18 years old, he was a senior in high school.  He signed
up for the delayed enlistment program to go into airborne infantry. They had
Justin swear in and take a physical at that time.  Immediately after the
swear-in, which was shortly after his eighteenth birthday, Sgt. Gady told
Justin he was now the property of the U.S. Army and that he was committed to
serving 8 years in the military.  He told Justin that he had to report to
boot camp at the end of high school or face serious consequences such as
court-martial, etc.  And, during this entire time you had to realize that
Sgt. Gady was keeping in touch with Justin on a daily basis.  He constantly
filled Justin with unrealistic views of military life.  He convinced Justin
who was supposed to pursue a tennis scholarship at FSU, that college life was
not for him.  He told Justin a real man defended his family and country.
This went on for months on end.  Sgt. Gady was relentless in his pursuit of
Justin.  And in th
e end he won!

On Memorial Day, May 29, 2006, we took Justin to the Recruiting Office.  Once
there, Sergeant First Class Stephen J. Canonico, told Justin that he would be
taken to Miami, stay overnight in a hotel and then catch a plane the next day
to Ft. Benning, GA.  He told Justin he would be sworn in a second time and
undergo a second physical.  At that point, I tried to tell Justin that if he
needed to be sworn in again, that the first swear-in apparently didn't mean
anything and that he could walk away.  But the recruiter kept telling Justin
it was only a formality and inferred that Justin needed to keep his promise
and be a "man".  He also told Justin to tell the Medic that he had no
physical ailments.  I then reminded Justin and the recruiter that Justin had
trouble with his knees and back.  Sgt. Canonico told Justin not to say
anything about any kind of medical problems.  If asked, he told Justin to say
he had no physical impairments or had no past injuries.  I was just not being
heard. 
 The Army had Justin thoroughly under their power.  It was very frustrating.


After we dropped Justin off, I hadn't heard from Justin until last Thursday
night, June 15, 2006.  It was 10:11 PM.  Justin was crying on the phone.  He
said that he couldn't take it anymore and wanted to come home.  He said that
he was on "profile" for injuries to his knee and foot.  He said he couldn't
take the physical pain and was being verbally abused on a daily basis.  He
told his drill sergeant that he couldn't take anymore mental and physical
pain and wanted to leave the military.  The drill sergeant told him that he
would never leave.  He was stuck in there for 8 years and that if Justin
didn't finish boot camp, that Justin would be continually re-cycled with each
new group of new enlistees forever.  Justin was devastated and wanted to go
awol that night.  We knew he couldn't get out that evening, so we told Justin
to try to hang in there and go to the infirmary every chance he got.  Justin
told his grandfather that if he didn't go back to training the next day, that
the r
e-cycling process would begin tomorrow.  He was terrified of the drill
sergeants and was emotionally a wreck.  He was continually sobbing.  At that
point, we knew he was emotionally unstable and probably at his breaking
point.  We talked to Justin until we were able to calm him somewhat and told
him we would support any decision he made.  My husband told him to ignore the
drill sergeants.  But apparently, he couldn't because that Saturday, June 17,
2006, I talked to his Commanding Officer who advised me that Justin went back
to training and was on "partial" profile for his knee.  I begged the Officer
to allow me to speak with Justin so that I could determine that Justin was
actually fine, but he refused.

I am now in a state of panic.  I have not heard from Justin and I am going
out of my mind with worry.  Please, please help us find out if Justin is
truly ok.  Justin is in the 3rd Platoon, D Company, 2nd Brigade, 54th
Infantry with a Roster # of 312 at Ft. Benning, GA. 31905

I will be eternally grateful for all of your assistance.  And, you may just
saving the life of a very young and vulnerable new recruit.

Thank you!


Patricia Dina
2601 Rock Island Rd. #105
Margate, FL 33063
Phone 561.715.3743
patriciadina@comcast.net

              Jeb,

                 Recently my wife and myself came to Florida for a vacation. We came to visit my father who resides there, for a few days , and then we proceeded to the Florida Keys. I did not mind spending the 2000 but it really irked me that Florida wasn't happy enough to get that, they wanted the rest of it.  I really do not 
 see  how  you can justify putting another 'tax' on people willing to come to your state and spend their hard earned money.  The burden should be placed on either your residents or on the government of Florida.  You recieve enough tax revenue from people out of state, that we should not have to refurbish your roads.  To pay that much money just to come down there once a year is not justifiable in my book.  The government should be doing what they can to make sure people keep returning.  Well I know two people who will not be returning. I will fly my father up here before I step back in your state.

-----Original Message-----
From: wrsavdru@netzero.net [mailto:wrsavdru@netzero.net]
Sent: Friday, June 16, 2006 7:57 AM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Subject: Florida National Guard

I am taking this opportunity to first say it has been my pleasure to serve the great State of Florida with you. I have been employed with the State of Florida, Department of Corrections for the past 12+ years. It has been a fantastic career and I am looking for to the second half of my career. 

 

With this said, I embarked approximately one year ago to join the Florida National Guard in Chipley, Florida. It was a long road with many obstacles in the way. My recruiter, Sgt. Bill Sellers, advised me, during our initial meeting, I would have to loose 50 pounds before he would even begin the paperwork. Unmoved by this statement, with my chin held high, I began a strict regiment of exercise and diet, and, seven weeks later, I was back in the recruiter's office, ready to go to the MEPS station.

 

It was not over, there were issues, both past and present. Sgt. Sellers submitted waivers for an issue the day of my physical, my blood pressure was high, I had drank coffee and an energy drink prior to being seen by the doctor. I followed the instructions of my recruiter, obtained blood pressure checks for three consecutive days, both in the am and pm, returned the form. Also, I was told I would have to loose an additional ten pounds and return again. Again, I accomplished this in short order and returned to pass my physical. 

 

Governor, if this was the only issue I probably wouldn't be writing you, however, there is more. I attempted a career in the Army when I was in my teens, while your father was President. This did not go well, not on the part of the Army, but due to me. Young and immature, I was not Army material. The problem now is that it follows me. Due to this, HQ denied the last waiver submitted by Sgt. Seller. He called yesterday to break the news, along with encouragement. He said that there was nothing else he could do for me, wished I would have been enlisted, but really couldn't help anymore. 

 

Not deterred, I have prayed and considered my options, thus my letter to you. As I have stated, I have been employed with Florida DC for 12+ years, been a member of the Confrontation Teams for the past 10 years. I have an impeccable record with outstanding evaluations from my superiors. I have sacrificed greatly to be able to be fit for service in the National Guard, and continue to run 5 miles per day. I attend college and maintain a 3.89 Grade Point Average along with being an Ordained Southern Baptist Preacher/Pastor.

 

Governor, I am asking for the opportunity to serve the great State of Florida and the United States of America. I'm not asking for nothing more than a chance, yes, a risky second chance. I cannot ask for more than your consideration, but I do request it quickly, I am 38 years old, I started this when I was 37, my birthday is in February, the window is closing quickly. 

 

Thank you in advance for your review of this matter, may God bless you as you lead, I will be looking forward to hearing from you.

 

Respectfully and in the service of Jesus Christ,

Miles A. Anderson

From: John J Meyer [mailto:johanjj@juno.com]

Subject: Education


Dear Toni Jennings,

Our Florida Senators and Representatives have an obligation to look into the following matter. I have prove that they are matters that affect our state, nation, educational and justice system. 

The “Florida Home Rule” and the "employment at-will" state are being misused interactively by the Polk County  school politician for their political interest and not for the best interest of our students and our educational system.  

I have been official dismissed from teaching by Dr. Clinton Wright as a part-time Electrical Instructor for not donating to a private fundraising campaign. Conveniently called, dismissed for a difference of opinion, using Florida’s "employment at-will" state.  I have not been aware that there has been an difference of opinion. 

The following is from desk of wendy.hosking@polk.fl.net, regarding private fundraising campaigns. There is no prohibition against participating in a private fund raising campaign; it should be noted that participation must be voluntary. It cannot be made, either implicitly or explicitly, a condition of employment, nor can participation or lack thereof form the basis of any employment action or disparate treatment. 

When I came back from summer vacation I found all my study material placed in boxes in the hallway. The hard drive had been take out of the school computer with my prepared lessons to start the second semester. This is a violation of 447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20). My civil rights have been violated by the Polk County School Board for not following due process, (see harassment attachment). 

On March 12, 2002, Mr. Bob Butterworth one of Florida Attorney Generals made a statement that Florida would possess zero tolerance for discrimination. I have not only been discriminated against but also harassed, humiliate for all school employees and students to see. The fundraising campaign did run through March 10. I continued to receive pledge forms in my school mailbox including one illegally placed in my home mailbox. I kept on teaching under those absurd circumstances for 6 month. It ended with a dismissal for a difference of opinion in the middle of a semester. No one should have to accept this type of abuse in a Florida Public School System.  

From the desk of Glenda Hood, Florida’s Secretary of State; Florida is an "employment at-will" state. An employer can terminate an employee for any reason, at any time, without advance notification so long as there is no violation of federal or state law. Polk County violated 447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20), including school board regulation 60X53-8, 004 (C). School employee Debby Davis has been assigned to do the administration. The private fund raising campaign has been approved by the Polk County School Board for political reason. The All-Arian fund raising has been approved by the USF.

I donated my time to train minorities and women to pass a mechanics test. On August 17, 2005, School Board Attorney Deming Cowles wrote to me that the school “can dismiss you for you’ re [sic] ethnic background....’ no explanation needed “. Calling names in place of solving a problem. I am presently tutoring a child of the (No Child Left behind Act of 2001) to prepare her for her electrical journeyman exam. 

I  have been unable to receive representation from local Senators or Representatives. Governor Jeb Bush claims in writing that he is powerless to look into this matter. As soon I mention the “Florida Home Rule” to an attorney, my free consultations are going down the drain. 

For the sake of our students and our educational system you have an obligation to look into the this matter. 

Sincerely yours,

John J. Meyer
404 Whitman Rd. 
Winter Haven Fl. 33884

SPECIAL NOTE TO CHARLOTTE COUNTY COMMISSIONER TOM D'APRILE:  Tom, Am hoping you're not away on vacation and that, if you are, your secretary will let me know when you are expected to return and be able to tend to the below matter.  If you are in town, please let me know if you were in touch with this individual back in October 2004 regarding her parents' problems with hurricane-related repairs on their home which is located in your district.  The severity of their situation has apparently escalated since then and it now appears they stand to lose their home to foreclosure as a result of a lien placed on their property emanating from faulty or incomplete work performed on their residence by others.  This appears to be one of those "unfortunate" experiences in which they deserve any help you can give them at this time.  Regards, Marilyn


Dear Ms. Fowler,

I note and do recall that you had written me previously regarding this unfortunate series of events which your parents are continuing to experience; and as you will recall, I pointed out to you that their property is outside the City of Punta Gorda, in which case you should be communicating with County Commissioner, Tom D'Aprile, in whose county district your parents' property is located.  I had assumed that after I advised you of that fact back in October of 2004, that Commissioner D'Aprile would have communicated with you or you with him, as I provided him with a copy of my reply to you back in October, 2004 and provided you with the county's web page address at which you could locate information on how you could contact him by phone.  Again, that contact information for Commissioner Tom D'Aprile is -- office phone: 941-743-1307 and e-mail: tom.d'aprile@charlottefl.com

Can you please advise me if Commissioner D'Aprile did communicate with you back then and; if so, what was the outcome of that communication at that time?  I am again copying Commissioner D'April on this additional reply from me to you with the expectation that he will initiate a followup contact with you to determine how he might be able to help you further at this time.

In the interim, I do understand the urgency of the situation relative to the lien that has been placed on the home and the notice of foreclosure by the mortgage holder that has resulted therefrom.  If you would please call me after 3 p.m. today at my home (941-637-0355), perhaps we can discuss the situation in greater detail and you can advise me of their immediate needs at this time, in the event I can be of any voluntary assistance even though their property is outside of my city's jurisdictional boundaries; as I certainly would not want anyone to lose a home to forclosure (regardless of where the home is located in the county) due to such a series of unfortunate incidents resulting from the hurricane we expeienced here in August 2004.  Be prepared to provide me with the name and contact information of the attorney in our area who is currently representing them, should I need to contact that individual to learn additional details of any needed assistance I might be able to facilitate.

From: Kathy Fowler [mailto:kfowler@foodesignassociates.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 1:11 PM
To: airhart@sunline.net
Cc: jeb.bush@myflorida.com; bcc@charlottefl.com; tom.d'aprile@charlottefl.com; Sue Foster
Subject: Re: FW: Victimized by Hurricanes PLEASE READ
Importance: High


Marilyn,
Please read, please........
I am writing again in hopes that someone out there can give our family a little guidance in handling the continued effects that Hurricane Charley is having on my parents. In brief my parents did find a contractor back in January of 2005 that would be able to repair the damage to their home caused by the hurricane. They actually started the process in mid-January and promised completion by the end of March (which then changed to first part of April). I am not sure if the contractor ever got the proper permits required for this or even if he got any inspections done (which are required in the state I reside in) for the work he actually did (which wasn't much work at all, since he never came back to finish what he started, stating he needed more upfront money to complete the project) While all this is going on my parents are having to rent a house to live in, keep making their mortgage and "increased" insurance payments along with storage faculties, amoung other living costs. Insurance claims were approved, however they would not issue claim payments as needed. Needless to say the contractor never returned to finish the project, leaving my 70 year old parents to clean-up his mess, and find ways to make their home livable again. At the advice of their lawyer they fired the contractor and finished the work themselves. My Dad was leaning towards pure exhaustion, but kept at it, determined to make this wreck of a house a "home" again, when out the blue the contractor put a lien against their house (for an amount much more than repairs would have cost) which caused any remaining claim payments from the insurance to stop. My parents had not received near enough money yet to get all repairs made, so there again another hardship. They have a different lawyer to handle this but for some reason there is no hope in sight. My parents did finally receive claim payments from the insurance and just this past month were able to finish about everything that needed to get done, however we got word this morning that their home is in foreclosure (much to my parent's surprise) I do not understand, they have kept up with all their payments and have worked so hard all their lives......to have it all be taken away because of some contractors need to take advantage of victims such as my parents is very disheartening.
I am not sure where to turn to get the help my parents deserve. I feel as if this contractor has been given a licence to steal and is about to get away with it. As if my parents have not been through enough already, just living through the hurricane. 
 
Just an added note: I do realize that my parents are probably not the only people going through this, but I cannot understand why there is nothing that can be done statewide to prevent such events from taking place after a natural disaster.
 
Thank you very much for your valuable time,
Kathy Fowler
Stanfield, North Carolina

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Marilyn Smith-Mooney - Council Member & Former Mayor 
To: Kathy Fowler

CITY OF PUNTA GORDA 
City Council Member Communication

  _____  

Please note: Florida has a very broad public records law.  Most written communications to City officials regarding City business are public records available to the public and media upon request.  Your e-mail communications may be subject to public disclosure.

  _____  





Dear Ms. Fowler,

I can certainly appreciate your concern for your parents.  I presume you sent us -- the Punta Gorda City Council -- a copy of your correspondence to Governor Bush because you believed your parents' home to be located within our city's jurisdictional boundaries.  Unfortunately, it is not.  Their residence merely has "Punta Gorda" as its post office address because that is the post office that serves the area in which they live.

Their residence is located in what is referred to as the unincorporated portion of Charlotte County.  Therefore, you would want to bring this to the immediate attention of the County Commissioner for the County District #1 in which they reside.  The County Commissioner for their district is Commissioner Tom D'Aprile.  I know him to be a very caring individual, diligent in his responsiveness to citizens' needs and concerns, and a person who I am sure will do whatever he can to bring about some rational thinking among those members or officers of the Deep Creek Association who appear to be overly inflexible regarding relaxation of certain community deed restrictions during a time where many have been hard-hit by Hurricane Charley.  Complete information on how to contact Commissioner Tom D'Aprile can be found at the following web page, as well as a district map for the county which indicates your parents' home is located in District #1 -- the portion shaded in gray:  http://www.charlottecountyfl.com/commissioners/ 

You will note I am also sending him a copy of this response to you so that he can anticipate hearing from you and possibly begin looking into the matter as soon as he receives this informational copy from me.




Sincerely yours,
Marilyn P. Smith-Mooney
Marilyn P. Smith-Mooney
District #2 Council Member & Former Mayor

Subject: Victimized by Hurricanes PLEASE READ



Dear Governor Bush,

I am writing with much anguish for my parents who live in Punta Gorda, Florida.

They have lost use of their home as a result of Hurricane Charley on August 13, 2004. 

They were turned down for assistance from FEMA and applied for a grant without any response to that as of yet.

It has been just about impossible to get contractors out there for estimates to turn into their insurance company.

Storage facilities and the means to move what they have left are extremely hard if not impossible to find still. 

They had to resort to getting a POD delivered to their home for storing their belongings so that their house can be repaired. The POD is also being used to keep their belongings protected since their house was severely damaged.

My parents live in Deep Creek sub-division in Punta Gorda, Florida. They just found out today that the Deep Creek Association is holding a meeting this Thursday Oct. 28th at 6:00 pm at Victoria Estates on Rampart Dr., Port Charlotte. The association is planning on ordering ALL residents of Deep Creek to have PODs removed by Monday, Nov. 1st. There is NO PLACE else they can store their belongings and there are many residents in the very same predicament that my parents are in. Please help some how, by sending a representative or someone to speak on your behalf. I sense you have a heart for all residents of Florida and under these circumstances they should allow temporary storage units to be used until they can have repairs completed. Please help somehow, I don't know who else to write to. 

Thank you very much for your valuable time,

Kathy Fowler

Stanfield, North Carolina

From:	Terry Kimbrell <terrybeth2@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 8:30 AM
To:	cbmeallen@cs.com; Governor Jeb Bush; gsca700@adelphia.net; joannecox@tampabay.rr.com; stananna1@verizon.net; anh1099@yahoo.com; jacadaniels@prodigy.net; srdaniels82@hotmail.com; kfortin@tampabay.rr.com; cordajohnson@hotmail.com; katiejkicksa@yahoo.com; vlmack@southernco.com; Mel_Martinez@martinez.senate.gov; rsmoe@charter.net; pegmolson@netzero.com; msschnebly@netzero.net; Stormsr@hillsboroughcounty.org; comments@whitehouse.gov
Subject:	Here is what your state is doing or not doing on Illegal Immigration

As the federal government wrestles with the immigration issue, states are 
implementing their own plans. Here's a state-by-state look: Colorado is the 
best.

Alabama

• Training 70 state troopers with the power to arrest illegal immigrants.

Arizona

• Required U.S. citizenship or legal immigrant status to receive health 
benefits. Illegal immigrants can receive emergency care only.

• Sent troops to assist with vehicle inspections along Arizona's border with 
Mexico.

• Approved ballot initiatives to be decided by voters in November:

Making English the official language of Arizona.

Prohibiting undocumented immigrants from receiving state services such as 
adult education, child care and in-state tuition rates at public colleges 
and universities.

Prohibiting undocumented immigrants from receiving punitive damages in civil 
lawsuits.

Requiring judges to deny bail to undocumented immigrants arrested for 
serious offenses.

Arkansas

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

California

• Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and the Legislature agreed on a $131 billion 
state budget after dropping proposals to provide health care to children of 
undocumented immigrants.

• Sent National Guard troops to the Mexico border.

Colorado

• Continued a special legislative session Sunday on illegal immigration.

• Made smuggling people into the USA a felony.

• Barred state agencies from awarding contracts to businesses that knowingly 
employ illegal immigrants.

• Required businesses seeking state contracts to verify immigration status 
of workers.

• Created a $50,000 civil fine for counterfeiting identification documents.

Connecticut

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Delaware

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Florida

Required proof of legal immigrant status for driver's license applicants.

Georgia

• Required, in a phased-in program that will begin July 1, 2007, that 
contractors doing business with state or local governments verify 
citizenship status of new workers.

• Required adult applicants for public benefits to verify eligibility.

• Required all Georgia employers to verify the legal status of employees 
hired on or after Jan. 1, 2008, in order to claim a state income tax 
deduction on such employees' salaries.

• Required jails to determine the legal status of prisoners charged with a 
felony or driving under the influence.

Idaho

Limited unemployment benefits to citizens and legal immigrants.

Illinois

Required that people be citizens or legal immigrants to receive state health 
plan coverage.

Kansas

Limited unemployment benefits to citizens and legal immigrants.

Kentucky

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Louisiana

Authorized the state to investigate contractors suspected of hiring illegal 
immigrants. The state can order such workers fired and fine businesses that 
don't comply.

Maine

Tightened requirements for issuing driver's licenses to non-citizens.

Maryland

Required the governor to fund health care services for certain legal 
immigrant children and pregnant women.

Massachusetts

Gov. Mitt Romney said he would seek federal authority to empower state 
police to detain illegal immigrants encountered during normal law 
enforcement activity.

Minnesota

Will send up to 200 National Guard troops to Mexico border.

Missouri

Denied unemployment benefits to workers who aren't citizens.

Montana

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Nebraska

In an effort to assist illegal immigrants, made unauthorized immigrant 
students eligible for in-state tuition at public universities.

New Hampshire

Required proof of citizenship to register to vote.

New Jersey

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

New Mexico

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

New York

• A state appeals court ruled that the state Department of Motor Vehicles 
can require immigrants to prove they are in the USA legally before obtaining 
driver's licenses.

• Will send 150 National Guard troops to the Mexico border.

North Carolina

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Oklahoma

Denied unemployment benefits to illegal immigrants.

Pennsylvania

Prohibited use of illegal immigrants on state projects.

Rhode Island

Effective Jan. 1, children who are not U.S. citizens will not be added to 
the state's health care program for the poor, even if they are in the USA 
legally. Children who enroll by Dec. 31 will keep their benefits.

South Dakota

• Required passport or another government-issued identification card when 
voting.

• Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Tennessee

• Barred state contracts for a year from businesses that knowingly employ 
illegal immigrants.

• Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Texas

• Prohibited businesses from deducting the costs of salaries and benefits 
for undocumented workers from their taxable revenue.

• Spent $20 million to expand Operation Rio Grande, a border security 
initiative.

• Will spend $5 million to put hundreds of surveillance cameras along the 
border at hot spots for criminal activity and routes frequently used to 
enter the USA.

Virginia

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Wisconsin

Pledged to send troops to the Mexico border.

Wyoming

Barred non-citizens from certain state-funded scholarships.

Source: National Conference of State Legislatures. USA TODAY research by 
Charisse Jones, Kate McGinty and Beth Walton. Contributing: Dennis Wagner of 
The Arizona Republic, Associated Press




Take care,
Terry and Beth Kimbrell

SPECIAL NOTE TO CHARLOTTE COUNTY COMMISSIONER TOM D'APRILE:  Tom, Am hoping you're not away on vacation and that, if you are, your secretary will let me know when you are expected to return and be able to tend to the below matter.  If you are in town, please let me know if you were in touch with this individual back in October 2004 regarding her parents' problems with hurricane-related repairs on their home which is located in your district.  The severity of their situation has apparently escalated since then and it now appears they stand to lose their home to foreclosure as a result of a lien placed on their property emanating from faulty or incomplete work performed on their residence by others.  This appears to be one of those "unfortunate" experiences in which they deserve any help you can give them at this time.  Regards, Marilyn


Dear Ms. Fowler,

I note and do recall that you had written me previously regarding this unfortunate series of events which your parents are continuing to experience; and as you will recall, I pointed out to you that their property is outside the City of Punta Gorda, in which case you should be communicating with County Commissioner, Tom D'Aprile, in whose county district your parents' property is located.  I had assumed that after I advised you of that fact back in October of 2004, that Commissioner D'Aprile would have communicated with you or you with him, as I provided him with a copy of my reply to you back in October, 2004 and provided you with the county's web page address at which you could locate information on how you could contact him by phone.  Again, that contact information for Commissioner Tom D'Aprile is -- office phone: 941-743-1307 and e-mail: tom.d'aprile@charlottefl.com

Can you please advise me if Commissioner D'Aprile did communicate with you back then and; if so, what was the outcome of that communication at that time?  I am again copying Commissioner D'April on this additional reply from me to you with the expectation that he will initiate a followup contact with you to determine how he might be able to help you further at this time.

In the interim, I do understand the urgency of the situation relative to the lien that has been placed on the home and the notice of foreclosure by the mortgage holder that has resulted therefrom.  If you would please call me after 3 p.m. today at my home (941-637-0355), perhaps we can discuss the situation in greater detail and you can advise me of their immediate needs at this time, in the event I can be of any voluntary assistance even though their property is outside of my city's jurisdictional boundaries; as I certainly would not want anyone to lose a home to forclosure (regardless of where the home is located in the county) due to such a series of unfortunate incidents resulting from the hurricane we expeienced here in August 2004.  Be prepared to provide me with the name and contact information of the attorney in our area who is currently representing them, should I need to contact that individual to learn additional details of any needed assistance I might be able to facilitate.

From: Kathy Fowler [mailto:kfowler@foodesignassociates.com] 
Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 1:11 PM
To: airhart@sunline.net
Cc: jeb.bush@myflorida.com; bcc@charlottefl.com; tom.d'aprile@charlottefl.com; Sue Foster
Subject: Re: FW: Victimized by Hurricanes PLEASE READ
Importance: High


Marilyn,
Please read, please........
I am writing again in hopes that someone out there can give our family a little guidance in handling the continued effects that Hurricane Charley is having on my parents. In brief my parents did find a contractor back in January of 2005 that would be able to repair the damage to their home caused by the hurricane. They actually started the process in mid-January and promised completion by the end of March (which then changed to first part of April). I am not sure if the contractor ever got the proper permits required for this or even if he got any inspections done (which are required in the state I reside in) for the work he actually did (which wasn't much work at all, since he never came back to finish what he started, stating he needed more upfront money to complete the project) While all this is going on my parents are having to rent a house to live in, keep making their mortgage and "increased" insurance payments along with storage faculties, amoung other living costs. Insurance claims were approved, however they would not issue claim payments as needed. Needless to say the contractor never returned to finish the project, leaving my 70 year old parents to clean-up his mess, and find ways to make their home livable again. At the advice of their lawyer they fired the contractor and finished the work themselves. My Dad was leaning towards pure exhaustion, but kept at it, determined to make this wreck of a house a "home" again, when out the blue the contractor put a lien against their house (for an amount much more than repairs would have cost) which caused any remaining claim payments from the insurance to stop. My parents had not received near enough money yet to get all repairs made, so there again another hardship. They have a different lawyer to handle this but for some reason there is no hope in sight. My parents did finally receive claim payments from the insurance and just this past month were able to finish about everything that needed to get done, however we got word this morning that their home is in foreclosure (much to my parent's surprise) I do not understand, they have kept up with all their payments and have worked so hard all their lives......to have it all be taken away because of some contractors need to take advantage of victims such as my parents is very disheartening.
I am not sure where to turn to get the help my parents deserve. I feel as if this contractor has been given a licence to steal and is about to get away with it. As if my parents have not been through enough already, just living through the hurricane. 
 
Just an added note: I do realize that my parents are probably not the only people going through this, but I cannot understand why there is nothing that can be done statewide to prevent such events from taking place after a natural disaster.
 
Thank you very much for your valuable time,
Kathy Fowler
Stanfield, North Carolina

Dear Ms. Fowler,

I can certainly appreciate your concern for your parents.  I presume you sent us -- the Punta Gorda City Council -- a copy of your correspondence to Governor Bush because you believed your parents' home to be located within our city's jurisdictional boundaries.  Unfortunately, it is not.  Their residence merely has "Punta Gorda" as its post office address because that is the post office that serves the area in which they live.

Their residence is located in what is referred to as the unincorporated portion of Charlotte County.  Therefore, you would want to bring this to the immediate attention of the County Commissioner for the County District #1 in which they reside.  The County Commissioner for their district is Commissioner Tom D'Aprile.  I know him to be a very caring individual, diligent in his responsiveness to citizens' needs and concerns, and a person who I am sure will do whatever he can to bring about some rational thinking among those members or officers of the Deep Creek Association who appear to be overly inflexible regarding relaxation of certain community deed restrictions during a time where many have been hard-hit by Hurricane Charley.  Complete information on how to contact Commissioner Tom D'Aprile can be found at the following web page, as well as a district map for the county which indicates your parents' home is located in District #1 -- the portion shaded in gray:  http://www.charlottecountyfl.com/commissioners/ 

You will note I am also sending him a copy of this response to you so that he can anticipate hearing from you and possibly begin looking into the matter as soon as he receives this informational copy from me.




Sincerely yours,
Marilyn P. Smith-Mooney
