From:	Terry Kimbrell <terrybeth2@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 8:19 AM
To:	comments@whitehouse.gov; Mel_Martinez@martinez.senate.gov; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Look what Colorado is doing for their illegal immigrant problem.

I'd like to see Florida address this issue.

Colorado passes bill to bar illegal immigrants from state benefits
By Charisse Jones, USA TODAY
Colorado lawmakers have passed a sweeping measure that could deny tens of 
thousands of illegal immigrants access to public housing, unemployment 
insurance and other state benefits.
The bill, which Gov. Bill Owens said he will sign soon, is the latest action 
by states as Congress struggles to agree on a federal strategy to deal with 
the nation's estimated 12 million illegal immigrants.

Colorado's legislation, one of several immigration bills passed during a 
five-day special session that ended late Monday, would bar adult 
undocumented immigrants from receiving most state benefits.

Up to 50,000 illegal immigrants could be stripped of benefits they receive, 
according to Nate Strauch, a spokesman for Owens.

More than 1 million people in Colorado receive services such as Medicaid and 
food stamps. Under the bill, new applicants or those reapplying for such 
services would have to verify their legal status by showing a 
government-issued photo ID and signing an affidavit. The bill would go into 
effect Aug. 1. Those under age 18 would not be affected, and undocumented 
immigrants still would receive services such as public education, emergency 
medical care and prenatal care. Federal law requires states to provide those 
benefits.

Owens, a Republican, called the special session to address the issue of 
about 250,000 undocumented immigrants living and working in Colorado. "I 
think the vast majority of illegal immigrants in Colorado are good people," 
Owens said Tuesday. "However, at some point, a state has to look out for the 
interest of its own citizens."

The Legislature is controlled by Democrats. Lawmakers and advocates of 
changes in immigration policy applauded the bipartisanship that led to the 
bill's passage.

"We got more done on this issue in five days than Congress has managed in 
two decades," said Andrew Romanoff, a Democrat who is speaker of the House. 
"I hope the package we put together will serve as a national model, not just 
in terms of the substance but also the spirit. We proved that Democrats and 
Republicans can work together to solve problems."

Congress is sharply divided on immigration. The Senate wants to provide a 
path to citizenship for most illegal immigrants. The House wants to make 
being an illegal immigrant a crime.

Like many other states this year, Colorado lawmakers also approved fines for 
employers who knowingly hire undocumented workers.

Supporters and opponents of a onetime ballot initiative to deny most public 
services to illegal immigrants praised what came out of the special 
legislative session.

"It's a very good start and a very good compromise," says Fred Elbel, 
director of Defend Colorado Now, which had backed the initiative. In June, 
the Colorado Supreme Court banished the initiative from the November ballot 
on technical grounds. Elbel said mass immigration dramatically increases the 
nation's population and strains its resources. "We're on a path that is not 
sustainable," he said.

"Compared to what we were facing a few months ago, this is a better option 
and a better outcome for immigrants," said Federico Pea, a former Denver 
mayor and a Clinton administration Transportation secretary who is chairman 
of Keep Colorado Safe, which fought the ballot initiative. "We have 
protected a significant number of benefits and privileges for undocumented 
individuals."

Posted 7/11/2006 8:24 PM ET
Updated 7/11/2006 10:48 PM ET E-mail | Save | Print | Reprints & Permissions

Take care,
Terry and Beth Kimbrell
Email - terrybeth2.hotmail.com

From:	Goldenrush59@aol.com

Subject:	miramar resident news

PRESS RELEASE- FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE- JULY 10, 2006

 

POET ANASTASIA CLARK TO BE GUEST SPEAKER FOR FREE TELE-CLASS FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES- OFFERED THROUGH THE NATIONAL WRITERS UNION AT-LARGE CHAPTER, LOCAL 1981 OF UAW, AFL-CIO

 

(Miramar, FL) Poet ANASTASIA CLARK announces she will be a Guest Speaker for a free tele-class offered by The National Writers Union At-Large chapter, Local 1981 of the United Auto Workers, a member of the AFL-CIO. The event will take place on Sunday, July 30, 2006 from 8:00pm- 9:00pm. EST.  The tele-class is part of a new program designed to help people with disabilities explore the field of writing. Each tele-class is approximately one hour long. Membership in the union is not required. If you would like to participate in the class, please call 954-537-7557 to sign up.

 

Sanford Rosenthal, a South Florida activist, who is blind himself, led the campaign to establish the new program which began in March 2006.  The goal was to create a forum whereby persons with disabilities could dial in to a teleconference and interact with each other- while also meeting representatives from the writing industry. So far, the program has been successful, with participants dialing in from all over the country. Rosenthal, who is the Disabilities Chairman for the At-Large Chapter of the National Writers Union (Local 1981), coordinates and leads each tele-class. Seth Eisenberg, Co-Chair for Organizing and Membership for the At-Large Chapter of the National Writers Union (Local 1981) also helps mentor each session. For more information, contact SanfordRosenthal@www.nwuatlarge.org or visit the website at MailScanner has detected a possible fraud attempt from "www.nwuatlarge.com" claiming to be www.nwuatlarge.org.

 

 

Anastasia Clark is the author of several books published by Sun Rising Poetry Press.  She grew up in Framingham, MA where she served as Poet-In-Residence to the public schools during 1977-78. She currently resides in Miramar, FL and conducts various poetry readings and appearances at libraries, schools, book stores and other venues. Her full-length titles include Grieving With Poetry (2004)- poems written after the death of her parents, Bloodsongs (2004)- poetry about women’s issues, Skeletons and Other Complaints (2004)- poetry about life’s challenges, Vagabond Pond (Spring 2006)- poems about feeling lost, and Electric Petticoats (Fall 2006)- poetry celebrating the spicier side of life.  Chapbooks include the POETRY PETALS collection- themed booklets designed for gift and floral baskets. Titles include Friendship Poems, Healing Poems, Holiday Poems, Humorous Poems, Inspirational Poems, Kaleidoscope Poems, Nostalgic Poems and Romantic Poems. Visit her website at www.anastasiaclark.com   or contact goldenrush59@aol.com to schedule an event.

Our Florida Senators and Representatives have an obligation to look into

The “Florida Home Rule” and the "employment at-will" state are being
misused interactively by the Polk County  school politician for their
political interest and not for the best interest of our students and our
educational system.  

I have been official dismissed from teaching by Dr. Clinton Wright as a
part-time Electrical Instructor for not donating to a private fundraising
campaign. Conveniently called, dismissed for a difference of opinion,
using Florida’s "employment at-will" state.  I have not been aware that
there has been an difference of opinion. 

The following is from desk of wendy.hosking@polk.fl.net, regarding
private fundraising campaigns. There is no prohibition against
participating in a private fund raising campaign; it should be noted that
participation must be voluntary. It cannot be made, either implicitly or
explicitly, a condition of employment, nor can participation or lack
thereof form the basis of any employment action or disparate treatment. 

When I came back from summer vacation I found all my study material
placed in boxes in the hallway. The hard drive had been take out of the
school computer with my prepared lessons to start the second semester.
This is a violation of 447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of Florida Status
(2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20). My civil rights have been
violated by the Polk County School Board for not following due process,
(see harassment attachment). 

On March 12, 2002, Mr. Bob Butterworth one of Florida Attorney Generals
made a statement that Florida would possess zero tolerance for
discrimination. I have not only been discriminated against but also
harassed, humiliate for all school employees and students to see. The
fundraising campaign did run through March 10. I continued to receive
pledge forms in my school mailbox including one illegally placed in my
home mailbox. I kept on teaching under those absurd circumstances for 6
month. It ended with a dismissal for a difference of opinion in the
middle of a semester. No one should have to accept this type of abuse in
a Florida Public School System.  

From the desk of Glenda Hood, Florida’s Secretary of State; Florida is an
"employment at-will" state. An employer can terminate an employee for any
reason, at any time, without advance notification so long as there is no
violation of federal or state law. Polk County violated 447,501 (1) (a)
and (b) of Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20),
including school board regulation 60X53-8, 004 (C). School employee Debby
Davis has been assigned to do the administration. The private fund
raising campaign has been approved by the Polk County School Board for
political reason. The All-Arian fund raising has been approved by the
USF.

I donated my time to train minorities and women to pass a mechanics test.
On August 17, 2005, School Board Attorney Deming Cowles wrote to me that
the school “can dismiss you for you’ re [sic] ethnic background....’ no
explanation needed “. Calling names in place of solving a problem. I am
presently tutoring a child of the (No Child Left behind Act of 2001) to
prepare her for her electrical journeyman exam. 

I  have been unable to receive representation from local Senators or
Representatives. Governor Jeb Bush claims in writing that he is powerless
to look into this matter. As soon I mention the “Florida Home Rule” to an
attorney, my free consultations are going down the drain. 

For the sake of our students and our educational system you have an
obligation to look into the this matter. 

Sincerely yours,

John J. Meyer
404 Whitman Rd.

From:	robertp@icdus.com
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 2:35 AM
To:	comments@whitehouse.gov; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Seminole's plan to build housing leaves displaced residents scrambling in a rough market

This story was sent to you by: Robert Perkis

Once again we see you failed to protect your citizens who live in mobile home parks. This is a crime, when are you going to take action?

--------------------
Seminole's plan to build housing leaves displaced residents scrambling in a rough market 
--------------------

By Adrianna C. Rodriguez
South Florida Sun-Sentinel

July 12, 2006

DAVIE -- Even the Seminole Tribe, which earns hundreds of millions yearly from its casinos and other holdings, is facing a housing crunch.

"The tribe is in a position like so many entities in South Florida. There's just not enough affordable housing," said Gary Bitner, spokesman for the more than 3,000-member tribe.

Bitner said there is a "long waiting list" of people, mostly young families, waiting for a home. "These are people who grew up on the Hollywood reservation and want to stay," he said.

To accommodate them, in February the Seminoles purchased the Stirling Road Mobile Home Park near State Road 7 for $6.9 million. But their solution means the mobile home park's 150 low-income residents must move.

On May 26, they were told they have until Dec. 1 to find a new place to live. But their choices are few as affordable housing opportunities shrink by the day.

"We are in the midst of an affordable housing crisis which was exacerbated by Hurricane Wilma," said Shirley Taylor-Prakelt, director of housing and community development for the town.

The town lost 985 structures in the hurricane, including 832 mobile homes, said Taylor-Prakelt. In addition, the town has lost more than 889 affordable rental apartments to condo conversion.

Nearly all the mobile homes in the Stirling Road park are too old to move, according to state statute, so the residents must leave them behind.

"It's really hard knowing we have to start all over again," said Donna Hanner, 55, who has lived in the park with husband Jim Hanner for more than 20 years.

They bought their mid-1970's home for $12,500. The tribe has offered them $2,750 to move out by August.

"They really done us a raw deal," said Jim, 59, who has postponed retirement indefinitely because he expects his housing payments will double once he moves.

The tribe has not decided what type of homes or how many it will build on the property. And it has not made a final decision on whether it will seek to de-annex the land, Bitner said.

In order to de-annex, the tribe must petition the U.S. Department of Interior to hold the land in trust for them. If granted, the property becomes part of the sovereign Seminole nation and is no longer part of Davie or the town's tax roll.

The park's residents recently got some support from the town council, which passed a resolution opposing the eviction without evidence of available comparable housing, and also opposed future attempts by the tribe to de-annex land from Davie.

"It sends a very loud message that we are putting ourselves on the record," said Taylor-Prakelt of the resolution that is meant to reflect the town's opinion but has no legal weight.

Mayor Tom Truex said the resolution's main purpose was to ask the tribe to help residents leave with more than the minimum required by law.

"It means that we want to do what we can to assist them," he said. "It's a tough situation."

The Seminole tribe first offered to pay residents $1,375 for a singlewide and $2,750 for a doublewide mobile home, the minimum required by Florida statute.

Last month, the tribe offered residents double that amount if they left by August.

The Seminoles will also forgive the 14 outstanding mortgages they assumed when they purchased the property if residents keep their rent and mortgage payments current until they move.

But neither plan provides the displaced residents with comparable housing, said Taylor-Prakelt.

She said she and acting town administrator Ken Cohen plan to meet with the tribe in the coming months.

"I feel confident they will come back with an adequate plan," she said.

Adrianna C. Rodriguez can be reached at acrodriguez@sun-sentinel.com or 954- 385-7916 .



Copyright (c) 2006, South Florida Sun-Sentinel 

Visit Sun-Sentinel.com

From:	wildflower4ever1961 <wildflower4ever1961@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 12, 2006 12:11 AM
To:	scso@seminolesheriff.org
Cc:	dmerkt@seminolecountyfl.gov; Constantine, Lee; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] 911 call

I would like to take some of your time to bring to your attention a matter that is really bothering me and I feel really needs to be corrected immediately. 
This evening (Tuesday, July 11), my mother, (Marge Patterson, 1029 Manchester Circle, Winter Park, 407-678-4071) called the Seminole County Sheriff Department because she had been threatened and was scared.  An adult male had entered her house, uninvited, and refused to leave until my younger brother was forced to pull out a machete and, with the machete swinging, my mother was able to use the door to push the man out of her house.  Her call to the sheriff was "poo-poo'ed" ... no-one showed up!  
There has been an ongoing problem with some young men and my younger brother (my brother, Paul, is 17 and the young men he is having trouble with are between 17-21 or older.)  Paul has been attacked when outside the house on several occasions.  These young men have come up into my mothers yard and home, yelling obscenities and threatening to kill Paul, damage my mothers cars, etc.  This "trouble" has been ongoing for quite some time, with both sides adding to the melee.
This "ongoing problem" or "teenage brawl" is why the deputy who answered the 911 call would NOT send anyone to my mothers home when she called.  She was told they would not get involved in a teenage dispute!  
A teenage dispute?!?  My mother was threatened.  My mother instructed this gentleman out of her house, and he refused.  My mother had to stand there, with younger children in the home, as a strange man she did not know (along with another who stood outside the door) screamed through her home.  She was in fear for her life and for the lives of her family.  Had my brother not found a weapon to scare this stranger out of my mothers home, who knows what he would have done.  Two others showed up shortly afterwards, standing in the yard and screaming threats.  This time there was no call to the sheriff ... after all, what good would that do?  My mother has to sit in her home, living in fear that these men are going to come back, because the police WOULD NOT do their job!  
Yes, this may have all started as a "teenage brawl".  But that does not negate the fact that some men committed a crime when they came into my mothers home and screamed threats.  Because of a "teenage brawl", the sheriffs office should NOT be relieved of their duty to enforce the law. Because of a "teenage brawl" young men should NOT be allowed to stalk a young man, jump him and beat him, enter into a home uninvited and refuse to leave when asked, or be allowed to return to that home to destroy cars and property (as they yelled they would do). 
Didn't the Deltona murders begin with a "teenage brawl"???  Is that what this is going to come to?  
What do I want to see happen?  I want deputies at my mothers home IMMEDIATELY upon reading this!  I want this problem taken care of and the young men who come to my mothers home arrested!  The law does provide for that, doesn't it?  It does say that if someone illegally enters your home (and refuses to leave when asked) then they are breaking the law ... doesn't it?  
Do I sound angry?  You betcha!  I am angry that my mother exercised her right to have the sheriff provide required protection and they neglected her!  I am angry that someone at the sheriffs office had the audacity to try to make my mother feel like an idiot when she called to report that she was in fear!  I am angry that I may some time soon go to her home and find dead bodies laying around!  A "teenage brawl"????  NO ... it has escalted beyond that point and it has become dangerous!  
Please take care of this matter before it is too late.
Again, my mom's info is:
Winter Park Fl
407-678-4071
Thank you,
Teresa Patterson Kemper

just swayin' with the breeze

The Capitol, 400 S. Monroe St.
Tallahassee, FL 32399-0001


Dear Governor Bush:

Dear, Governor Bush
PLEASE READ THIS AND DO NOT IGNORE WHAT I HAVE TO SAY,AND PLEASE RESPOND 
SOON!!!
 I am very concerned about the new law the mayor of Avon Park has proposed 
and intends to put into action because I live in Frostproof and I am 
Mexican-American. I do not believe that what he is trying to do is right, 
it is simply being racist and discriminating against hard working people 
who only come here to work. I am very proud to be mexican-american and it 
hurts me to know how this mayor is trying to make mexicans and other 
immigrants look as if they are worthless and do not belong. I am very 
upset that he wants to enforce a law in which English is the only language 
allowed to be spoken because I am an american and there is no way that he 
can get rid of me, and I do not want him to take away my heritage and my 
right to speak my language simply because he feels that we should only be 
allowed to speak english.I have always believed that this country is the 
land of the free and the land of opportunity, so then why is the mayor not 
giving these people the opportunity to do what they came here to do, which 
is to work and make a better life for themselves. I do not believe that he 
remembers what this land stands for. I do, it stands for freedom.I do not 
want my little brother or my nephew who are mexican-american  growing up 
being discriminated against just because they are MEXICAN.This mayor with 
his proposed law is just paving the road for racism and discrimination. He 
is teaching the youth of Florida to discriminate against anyone who is not 
"WHITE" and therefore in his own close-minded point of view do not belong 
here. It hurts me to know how much hatred there is for mexicans like my 
father who only come here to fulfill the american dream.They go through 
many hardships to still come here and be hated only because they were not 
born here,only because of that one piece of paper that says they do not 
belong.This is why I am writing to you Governor Bush because I am very 
worried, stressed and afraid that the country I was born in and that I 
have come to know as the land of the free is now becoming a land of 
discrimination and racism.I want that mayor to know that I belong here, I 
have the right to speak my two languages English and Spanish whether he 
likes it or not and I am willing to fight for my rights and for the rights 
of my mexican people who are afraid to speak for themselves because of 
people like the mayor of Avon Park who feel superior to everyone else 
because he is white and because he was born here. Well I would like him to 
know that I was born here too and there is no way  I am going to sit back 
and watch quitely while he destroys the peace and freedom of people in my 
community. I realize that I am only eighteen and recently graduated but I 
will do anything in my power to fight for my rights I will not let him 
take away what is rightfully mine like my freedom to be who I am. I am 
hoping that you as governor will put an end to this non-sense before it 
gets out of control.America needs to realize that this country is what it 
is because of the DIVERSITY of its people.I write to you in desperation 
because I feel degraded as an american because of this one man, who thinks 
he is better than me, and I hope and trust that you will do your best to 
protect our freedom and our country and all of its people whether they be 
White,Mexican,Black,Haiti or anyone else.Governor I remember when you came 
to visit our school in Frostproof and our principal let us know that you 
were not only a great governor but also a very nice person and that is why 
I will trust that you will do the right thing to help "AMERICANS". By the 
way my definition for an American is not someone who was born here,but 
someone who is willing to work extremely hard for this country and what it 
has to offer.Please do something to stop this from happening!!

Sincerely,


Ana Maria Sanchez
(863)635-6230

From:	Priscilla Marin <bebita412000@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 11, 2006 10:47 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; First Lady
Subject:	[*] Need help for my daughter frances

July 5, 2006
 
 
 
Dear Mr. and Mrs. Bush:
 
My name is Priscilla Colon. Before explaining to you the reason for this letter I would like to tell you a little about my family and myself. I was born in New York City, my parents are Puerto Rican. I lived all my childhood and teenage years in Puerto Rico. At the age of   twenty four I married Francisco Colon, father of my two children. After one year of marriage, I gave birth to my first born child, Frances. It was then when we moved from Puerto Rico to Orlando, Florida in search of better job opportunities and a better education for our daughter in the future that was to come. My husband obtained two jobs so that I could stay home to raise my child until she was ready to begin her school years. At that point in time, it was not easy for me due to the language barrier and not getting to see my husband that much. I give thanks to God every day of my life for my persistence along the way. My first job experience was at the Orange County Health Department. At the interview I remember not understanding nor speaking too much English therefore most of my answers to the interviewer were in written. They needed a person who could speak in Spanish, therefore I got the job. At the beginning it was a difficult experience for me because many of the people who I attended did not understand what they so called   my “broken English”. Little did they realize that their comments gave me the strength, willpower and persistence to not give up on learning the English language. Today I can say that with practice and immersion in the English language, I feel proud that, although with an accent, I can speak it correctly and quite fluently. I worked at the Orange County WIC Department for eight years. Currently, I have been working at an Orange County school for six years as an Instructional Clerk. This year I was elected Support Person of the Year at the school. I am proud of having obtained many of the goals I set for myself eighteen years ago when I first arrived to Florida. My husband and I have never had to ask for any financial help from the government because we as responsible parents and citizens of this nation under God, have always worked as hard as possible to obtain our financial needs. There are times when the journey of life becomes harder than we may handle. The reason for my letter to you today is to ask for your help in regards to my daughter Frances. She attended the public schools of Florida since her kinder year until this year (2006) where she recently graduated from her senior year from Colonial High School located in Orlando, Florida. Although Frances never obtained more than a 3 in her FCAT scores due to her nervousness while taking her FCATS, she was always an honor student graduating from high school with a 3.53 average. Frances’ most ultimate dream is to become an English teacher. I contemplate and admire her as she constantly tutors the children of our neighborhood including her ten year old brother Franco. Although we have always been here to provide her in all her financial needs, it is almost impossible for us to provide her with her college expenses. We have applied for FASFA and are waiting for an answer. On the other hand, Frances applied for the Two Plus Two Scholarship which would provide for two years at the Valencia University and two years at UCF, including books. Two weeks ago we received a letter stating that financial help from this scholarship was denied to my daughter. Frances was very discouraged and so were we. Mr. Bush we need your help. We are all aware of the shortage of teachers in Florida. Frances has the potential, the desire, the will power and most of all, the dream of becoming a successful teacher. May you help us with Frances’ dream of inspiring, encouraging, energizing and illuminating the hearts of so many children? We need your  help to fulfill her desire of becoming an agent of change so that our society can be enriched with educated people shaping them into responsible citizens within our nation. Highly qualified and devoted teachers are needed more than ever in our society. Once again I do ask you to please help us in any way possible you may so that Frances may obtain a higher education, a rewarding profession which without the financial help she needs will not be able to do so. Frances is scheduled to start her college classes in August 26, 2006. We are running out of time and do not know how she is going to make it without financial help being the fact that we cannot afford it. As I mentioned before, she has applied for many other scholarships which up until today we have not had any answers from them. It is in a classroom, with a highly qualified teacher where the American Dream really does come true. Frances wants to be one of those qualified teachers.  Is there anyway you may help us to make her dream come true? We would appreciate all the help we may get from you in helping her  becoming one  more of the many responsible, inspiring and devoted teachers in our nation who inspire our children and youth to fulfill their potentials. Frances will live eternally thankful for being helped by you to achieve the most challenging and most rewarding profession there will always be: Education. Her pay back to you will be the satisfaction of having awakening the expectations and affected the eternity of so many that will have passed through her classroom; as a result, touching the future of our nation.  
Thank you and God bless you.
 
Sincerely,
 
 
Priscilla Colon
838 Grenadier Drive
Orlando, Florida  32807
bebita412000@yahoo.com  
407-737-8583 (H)
407-435-6492 (C)

From:	J.L. Harty <immuchbetternow@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 11, 2006 10:15 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	oversee your counties work

Tuesday night was my displeasure to attend the Winter Haven planning committee for a zoning change off Thompson Nursery Road. Oddly, going into the circus, thoughts of presenting a studious case swaying pro growth minds seemed reachable. After all, a valid case demonstrating land usage should produce logical results. Too bad residents weren’t speaking to logical recipients.

In short, not only was the developer given a green light to build nine massive four story buildings two hundred feet wide, while painting an illusion of similarity between that and two story condo’s like those at Winterset and Lake Ashton but the opposition was silenced. Apparently it is appropriate cut minutes from those who support current zoning laws when not supported by the commission. (Certainly, the commission would neither resort to personal retribution as some fear.)

Adding insult, the developer was permitted further rebuttal not to mention the extensive overage minutes in his prelude. Disingenuous points were cross examined only by the beneficiary, while the status quo remained stifled. Notwithstanding, what could it matter, since the commission clearly made a back room deal preceding the farce.

Some residents claimed payoffs! One resident approached and chided the chair person exclaiming foul! In fairness, perhaps the only deal was the trade off to construct Coon Road in exchange for our demise. Or, it could be as simple as we in the county are represented by those in the city. One thing is for sure..these residents are banding together and don’t seem to be buckling to non representation or possible corruption.

Those from Savannah Point suggest no changes to existing single family housing, no compromises. At least those of us from Hart Lake Hills begged for compromise. Ironically, future battles could result in eliminating all developer gains from an ill conceived nelgect of power. Time will tell. And, the residents don’t mind the time.

J.L. Harty

676 Hart Lake Drive

Winter Haven, Florida 33884

863-325-9196

Subject:	Thank You

Governor Bush,
 
I emailed your office late last month regarding a child care situation that my son was experiencing with his two sons.  Mr. Alan Abramowitz responded to me on your behalf
and directed me to Ms. Richelle Holmes with Community Based Care of Brevard.  
 
Ms. Holmes was able to assist us with our situation.  She did so immediately, without reservation and with much kindness.  She immediately knew of a child care program my son qualified for. 
 
I cannot tell you what this means to my son, his boys and me.  The children are able to stay in the safe, familiar child care facility they have been in and my son is able to work knowing they are safe and well cared for and he can afford to keep them there.  We are very much appreciative of the child care program.
 
We thank you, Mr. Abramowitz and Ms. Holmes.  You are our heroes!  
 
Again, Ms. Holmes knew immediately what was available, how long the program would be available to my son and did the necessary paperwork while I was on the phone with her.  When my son went to her office to pick up the paperwork, she came out and spoke with him.  I believe taking the time to come out and speak with him personally was above and beyond her responsibility.  It was exceptional!
 
Prior to contacting your office, I had contacted several agencies in Brevard County.  It appears the employees I had the opportunity to speak with were not aware of a program for this particular situation.  My biggest hurdle in contacting the agencies was the lack of response, it was almost impossible to get anyone to return my phone call.  The fact alone that your office responded is sincerely appreciated.  The outcome of the direction we received is also sincerely appreciated.
 
Thank you and God Bless.
 
Brenda Smith-Hayduk
From:	Kleanthis N. Andreadakis <kleanthis@andreadakisinc.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 11, 2006 9:01 PM
To:	'wgkozak'; Governor Jeb Bush; ag@oag.state.fl.us; 'Zane E. Burdette'; 'Lee Grzymala'
Cc:	Sebesta, Jim; Crist, Victor; jeb@jeb.org
Subject:	RE: Stop The Unlawful Regulation Of Interstate Transportation

It's unfortunate that they have TOTALLY IGNORED us.  Aside from the blatantly arrogant actions of these agencies in being aware of these laws but violating them anyhow, they are using quasi-police powers in the enforcement of these acts thus subjecting the counties and the state to further liabilities.  At the end of this week, I'm going to be pushing my cases forward now that I have plenty of evidence and ammunition to do so.  Not only was I arrested and charged, falsely, six different times, only to have all charges dismissed from the system because of the deliberate acts of this agency, but after educating the agency that says it was entrusted to regulate and enforce fairly, I was singled out and witch-hunted into extinction.  And I do not stand alone.  There are others.  And if you remember from Social Studies and American History 101, gentleman and gentlewomen, WE, THE PEOPLE, MAKE UP THE GOVERNMENT.  AND WE THE PEOPLE CAN AND WILL CHANGE THE GOVERNMENT WHEN NECESSARY.
 
Charlie Christ, you should be ashamed of yourself in making an AOG Opinion for the Hillsborough County Public Transportation Commission based solely off the written request of their director.  I'm glad to see that our potential future governor is so ignorant to this issue that a simple letter stating shielded opinions crafted as facts can lead such an individual in high authority to draft an opinion that bears weight, one simply an opinion based on mis-information.  You had your chance when I called your office a dozen times trying to gain your involvement in our dilemmas down here.  You have no excuse - and when the federal courts get a hold of all of this nonsense, I hope it ends up as egg on your face in the media.
 
No one is against regulations.  We are only looking for consistency, equality, and sensibility in the way this industry is regulated.  I'm out of business now because of this agency and yet, I didn't do anything wrong or in violation to deserve that. But they know that they can run you through the mud by using the system against anyone that challenges them.
 
"I have only begun to fight" as so stated.  The more people I tell about what happened to me, the more people I affect and educate.  I spend time with many influential people in my new role and they are very interested to hear how our county and state government has totally sandbagged us.  It's nice to see that our state leaders are so yellow that a local county organization has a leash around their necks and is leading them around like a dog being taken for his morning bathroom break.  This organization is not even abiding by it's own charter, and yet who is going to tell them otherwise?  The county court judges don't have a clue.  The state attorney's office cannot intelligibly explain what this agency does, how, why or how they should prosecute violators.  The sheriff turns a blind eye to the matter citing how it does not involve his agency all the while giving the HCPTC the authority that it so abuses.  And from that point on up the ladder everyone passes the buck and doesn't want to get involved.
 
Does the truth hurt?  Maybe if you guys would come out of your cushy offices long enough to gain some intelligence about the real world and what is really going on then we'd all be little better off.  But no you rely on memos, presentations, statistical analysis, hearings, meetings, conferences, lunch gossip, and so on to make your decisions.  All the while we suffer because we don't have the money to hire lobbyists and do some ass kissing of our own.
 
But then again it's just too easy to hit the DELETE button on this and forget that it ever happened.
 

  _____  

From: wgkozak [mailto:wgkozak@hotmail.com] 
Sent: Sunday, July 09, 2006 8:40 PM
To: Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com; ag@oag.state.fl.us; Zane E. Burdette; Lee Grzymala; kleanthis@andreadakisinc.com
Subject: Stop The Unlawful Regulation Of Intrstate Transportation


Stop The Unlawful Restrictions Placed On Intrastate Motor Carriers & The Traveling Consumer!!
 
Fact: Most municipalities in the State of Florida that hold the major transportation hubs that numerous Counties are reliant upon extort monies and restrict intrastate motor carriers from entering to load their prearranged and/or chartered passengers for transportation back home!
 
Fact: Under the influence of political pandering taxi companies, the local municipalities create under color of law, monopolies servicing the major transportation hubs servicing interstate commerce! 
 
Fact: Cab Owners serve as lobbyist for politicos serving as commissioners on business entry level decision boards!
 
Fact: The economic regulatory restrictions placed on intrastate motor carriers are in violation of Federal and Florida Statutes!
 
Fact: Residents in the State of Florida reliant on nonpublic forms of transportation are restricted in travel choices, type of service provisions and geographical limitations due to the States failure to enforce its own laws! 
 
Fact: State Senators Lee, Crist, Sebesta and Fasano have been apprised of this situation numerous times over the past 3 years and have failed to take corrective action! 
 
Send a message to the Governor and the Florida Attorney General that the unlawful restrictions placed on the intrastate motor carrier and the traveling consumers must stop!

            Press Releases 


      Fact Sheet: Securing Our Nation’s Borders 

      Through the Secure Border Initiative (SBI) and other efforts, DHS is strengthening security along our northern and southern borders through the integrated use of increased manpower and infrastructure, cutting-edge technology, enhanced immigration enforcement, and cooperation with our state, local, and international partners.

      Expanding Infrastructure and Building a Virtual Fence 

      The Administration is constructing new fencing and barriers, and improving and expanding existing infrastructure.  DHS is also using 21st century technology to increase the effectiveness of operations.  The use of radiation detectors, sensors, cameras, and biometric information dramatically increase the likelihood of apprehending criminal or terrorist elements attempting to enter the U.S.  


        a.. Expanding Infrastructure Along the Border:  Where it makes sense, DHS is erecting fencing and barriers to improve security along the border.  The President’s $1.9 billion supplemental request includes $500 million for additional infrastructure including more barriers, lighting, roads, fencing, communications equipment, and new stations and bases along the border.  Infrastructure enhancement is already underway in many areas.  In San Diego, for example, Secretary Chertoff has authorized the expansion and completion of a 14-mile Border Infrastructure System.


        b.. Building a Virtual Fence:  Through SBInet and other efforts, DHS is procuring and deploying a virtual fence along the borders comprised of detection equipment, sensors, cameras, and other high-tech tools.  This improved technology will be integrated with new investments in infrastructure and will greatly increase the apprehension capabilities of the Border Patrol.   





      Increasing Manpower and Assets Along the Borders 

      Since President Bush has taken office, the size and budget of the Border Patrol has increased dramatically and additional agents are being trained and assigned to the northern and southern borders.  


        a.. Increasing the Number of Agents:  By the end of 2008, the number of Border Patrol agents are expected to double since the President took office.  Border security funding has also increased 66%.
        - Agents When the President Took Office: 9,096
        - Agents Today: Approximately 11,600 (a 27% increase)
        - Agents By December 31, 2008: 18,319 (an expected 101% increase) 


        b.. Tripling the Number of Border Patrol Agents Along the Northern Border and Doubling the Number of Inspectors:  The number of agents along the northern border has almost tripled from 340 agents in 2001 to 980 agents today.  Customs and Border Protection (CBP) has also more than doubled the number of inspectors from 1,615 to 3,391.  This increase in manpower improves CBP’s ability to detect, apprehend, and deter illegal aliens, criminal elements, and terrorist threats along the border with Canada.  


        c.. Moving Agents From Administrative Positions to the Field:  With National Guard support, nearly 600 Border Patrol agents along the southern border will be moved from non-law enforcement jobs and be made available for border operations, apprehensions, and interdictions. 





      Enhancing Immigration Enforcement 

      Since President Bush took office, millions of illegal aliens have been apprehended and returned, funding for interior enforcement has grown dramatically, and the policy of “catch and release” is being replaced with “catch and return.”  



        a.. Getting Results:  Since President Bush took office, agents have apprehended and sent home more than 6 million people entering the country illegally – including more than 400,000 with criminal records.   





      Launching Joint Operations 

      In conjunction with federal, state, and local partners, and as part of the broader border security strategy, DHS has launched major operations to target violent street gangs and other criminal elements within our communities.  



        a.. Operation Community Shield:  Launched in March 2005, Community Shield targets violent gangs across the country that pose a threat to our communities and present concerns for national security.  Since its inception, Operation Community Shield has resulted in the arrest of more than 3,100 gang members from more than 300 different gangs. 


        - Operation Return to Sender:  In the largest operation of its kind in US history, ICE agents and officers apprehended approximately 2,200 criminal aliens, illegal alien gang members, fugitive aliens, and other immigration status violators as part of a nationwide interior immigration enforcement effort.  Roughly half of the individuals arrested had criminal records, and roughly 370 were members or associates of violent street gangs, including Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13).  



      Supporting State and Local Partners 

      By providing additional funding and training, the Administration is strengthening its partnerships and coordination with state and local authorities.  



        a.. Providing $65 Million in State and Local Assistance:  DHS is working with state and local partners to expand targeted immigration enforcement activities.  $50 million is being requested for the expansion of training for these authorities.   ICE will provide training for up to 1,500 local law enforcement officers to bolster border security efforts.  $15 million will also be provided for Operation Stonegarden, which can be used by border states for operational overtime, National Guard deployments, and other border security related activities.     


      Deploying the National Guard to Provide Support 

      The National Guard will support and assist DHS’ security efforts, particularly with the Border Patrol as their new agents are trained and added.  


        a.. Coordinating with Governors:  The Administration is coordinating with governors for the deployment of up to 6,000 National Guardsmen to the southern border. 
        b.. Role of the Guard:   National Guard units will assist DHS by operating surveillance systems, analyzing intelligence, installing fences and vehicle barriers, building patrol roads, and providing training.  Apprehensions and detention operations will be conducted by DHS. 
        c.. Duration of the Guard’s Deployment:  The initial National Guard deployment would last for a period of up to two years and will be reduced in the second year as new Border Patrol agents and new technologies come online.   


      Overcoming Significant Obstacles Blocking Immigration Enforcement 

      Several major obstacles are blocking DHS’ efforts to apprehend and return illegal migrants.  The Department is working with Congress and through legal avenues to overcome them.



        a.. Aiding Employers in Detecting Social Security Number Fraud:  Each year, hundreds of thousands of Social Security numbers are reported by the Social Security Administration (SSA) as registering a “no-match”.  DHS has issued a proposed regulation that describes an employer’s current obligations under the immigration laws, and its options for avoiding liability, after receiving a no-match letter from either SSA or DHS.  But this is only part of the solution.  We also need to give our Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents a better way to determine which employers are habitually using or providing fraudulent Social Security information.  One way to do that is by giving our agents sufficient access to “no match” data.  DHS is working closely with Congress on the passage of meaningful legislation that will improve our ability to find potential immigration fraud.  The Department will also permit I-9 records to be kept electronically, which will enable employers and investigators to more accurately investigate potential problems.   




       ###

      June 29, 2006

From: Governor Jeb Bush [mailto:Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 12, 2006 5:26 AM
To: Kensinger-Clark, Sheila M CTR USA J2 (Northrop Grumman)
Subject: RE: Florida Residency for Military . . .



 

Thank you for your e-mail to Governor Bush requesting information on establishing residency in Florida.  Whether one is considered a Florida resident may vary depending on the purpose--for example, tax reasons versus claiming in-state tuition rates for our universities.  Therefore, I cannot give you complete information in this letter.

 

Chapter 222.17, Florida Statutes, pertains to Florida domicile.  Not only can a copy of this law be obtained in Florida's libraries, out-of-state residents can often read the statute at any law school, obtain it through interlibrary loan, or access it on the internet.

 

You can also contact the Clerk of the Court in the county where you want to live for certain information.  The Clerk can provide you with the necessary form to declare residency for certain purposes.  You must first, however, live in Florida to make the declaration.

 

Thank you for writing, and I hope the information I have provided is helpful.  I also want to take this opportunity to thank you for your service to our country.
 
Sincerely,
 

Rex T. Newman

-----Original Message-----

Our truck is with a friend in Tampa and we continue to keep up the Florida registration and insurance.

LA Times Op-Ed Condemns USA for Deporting . . . Violent Criminal Illegals
LA Times/NewsBusters ^ | Mark Finkelstein


Posted on 07/11/2006 12:02:47 PM PDT by governsleastgovernsbest


by Mark Finkelstein 

July 11, 2006 - 14:53 

Just when you thought the arguments of the pro-illegal immigrant crowd couldn't get any more preposterous . . . Now, the United States is being condemned for deporting illegal aliens who are violent, hardened criminals, members of homicidal street gangs. 

The Los Angeles Times saw fit to allot some of its precious op-ed space today to this column by Ricardo Pollack [pictured here], who, we are told is a "documentary director and producer. His film, '18 with a Bullet,' airs tonight on KCET as part of PBS' 'Wide Angle' series." PBS, eh? Your tax dollars at work! 

Pollack argues that gang violence in San Salvador, El Salvador has burgeoned due to the US policy of deporting gang members from Los Angeles who are illegal aliens. Pollack tells the story of 'Duke', "who was deported from the U.S. after being convicted of a criminal offense — in his case, robbery. Although he had lived most of his life in Los Angeles, he was never a citizen. As soon as he got into trouble with the law, he was deported to the country where he was born but that he hardly knew." 

Never a citizen? Is Pollack implying Duke had a green card but never got around to taking the oath? Come on, Ricardo - Duke was an illegal. He was deported "as soon as he got into trouble with the law." Really? I'd like to think so, but I'll bet you dollars to donuts the robbery that led to his deportation wasn't Duke's first brush with the law. 

Continues Pollack: "Duke helped set up 18th Street in El Salvador, a country awash in weapons from a decades-old civil war but without the means to deal with U.S.-trained gang members." So the USA should keep Duke and his compadres and let them commit mayhem here because we have "the means" to deal with gangs? Are you crazy? 

And later: "The problem is far more complex than the authorities claim." It always is for liberals. 

And finally: "As long as the U.S. continues to deport hardened criminals to countries that can't deal with them . . . then El Salvador will remain one of the world's most violent places." 

Sorry, Ricardo, sorry, El Salvador, but the US officials who deport these violent thugs are sworn to uphold the laws and defend the interests of . . the US.

Subject:	Child Support Case

She said she can see where they agreed to take $2500 in 2005, but as she was laughing she said I am now going to raise it to $3000 down and $70 per week. She said that July 1st, 2004 they had changed the law that gave her this right. She said it was in FS chapter 61. From:	Ken McClelland <iwrote1@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 11, 2006 4:39 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Brevard County Tax Collector unfair labor practices

07-11-06
 
Dear Governor,
 
Tax Collectors have always been given a bad rap, though the truth is that many times it’s been justified. But the employees at the Brevard County Florida Tax Collectors Office under Rod Northcutt are a good bunch of people, there to serve you whenever you need your license plate renewed or to get a fishing license or a host of other county and state required documents. And they do so in spite of being yelled at by customers who want something done that cannot be accomplished because they brought the wrong information in or want to pay with a check that does not even have the customers name on it.
 
Yet they are often derided as being lazy, uncooperative, or other such derogatory terms by irate customers upset at having to wait in line like everybody else. These county workers serve our citizens with a smile despite being coughed upon and sneezed at by the sick and even inadvertently spat upon by some of the angry people who come to their stations huffing and puffing with unsigned out of state car registrations, bogus checks, or forged signatures. They serve with pride and professionalism and even force a smile while otherwise normal, grandmotherly, professional, and even religious people of the community, approach them with all the manners and vocabulary of a drunken sailor 
 
But there’s another problem at the Brevard County Tax Collectors office, and it starts at the very top. Employees were told a couple of years ago by one of Rod Northcutt’s ‘Generals’ that the employees needed to have a weeks ‘leave time’ on reserve that they weren’t allowed to use. Before this mandate any employee who had a week of earned leave could go on vacation with their families or take time off to care for a sick loved one. But wait a minute, was that rule in the employee handbook? Well actually they were never given an employee handbook and such a rule never existed before this, in fact, they still do not have a book of rules or guidelines for employees to follow (UPDATE: On May 1st 2006 Rod Northcutt issued the employees their first handbook after threats of unionizing by employees). The rules at the Brevard County Tax Collectors Office are made up as they go along by Rod Northcutt or his next in command. Anyone with less than 40 hours was immediately subject to being disciplined. And guess what, several people were disciplined as the new rule even became retroactive. People that had been on vacation or were sick in the hospital were disciplined for using their time off - BEFORE - this rule ever was issued. Imagine showing up for your job in a blue suit and your boss suddenly announcing that everyone wearing blue will be immediately fired, well that’s a parallel to what happened to Tax Collector employees. A year later the Tax Collectors office announced a new rule regarding earned leave time. Employees must now have 80 hours of leave time that they will not be allowed to use. It is their time though, as granted to them by their hours and years of service, they just aren’t allowed to use it for fear of losing their jobs. Who in the real world would like to be told that they weren’t allowed to use two weeks of their vacation time or sick leave that they’d legally earned? At the Tax Collectors office you have no choice or you risk losing your job. (Update; after seeing that Unions might be calling him to task about these unfair labor practices Rod Northcutt is talking of changing this unfair leave time policy).
 
What is the measure of a man or the substance of his character? If you were the man in charge of the Brevard County Tax Collectors Office, Rod Northcutt, your character would likely get you visited by three ghosts during the holidays. After much complaining about low wages by county workers in his office, a study was done to compare wages of Brevard County Tax Collector employees with that of other Florida counties. Trouble started immediately. To make it look like Rod wasn’t so cheap in the wages he was offering, certain positions in his organization were ‘hidden’ from the study – perhaps because those positions were nearing the $100,000 per year pay range while the worker bees who do the actual work earn in the low to mid twenties.
 
Yet after the study Rod Northcutt decided to relent and tossed a few pennies out of his dusty old change purse when he showered his hourly employees with a twenty cent raise, which amounts to less than a 2% increase. But what about him? What kind of a raise does Mister Northcutt or his upper management get? He won’t say how large of an increase his $140k + per year job demands or how the raises for his upper level managers are determined - or if he would ever settle for such an insulting amount of 2 % or less.
 
How about employees not in the upper echelon or inner sanctum? It’s still unclear as a lot of secrecy still abounds with this miserly Tax Collector. What has been suspected and confirmed however, is that good old boy Rod Northcutt does pay some of his employees better than others – oh, but did I mention that those employees just happen to be men. Yes that’s right, the Brevard County Tax Collector who tossed a dime and a penny at ‘his girls,’ pays some of his male employees more money for doing the same job as the women do. (Note: this may have recently been changed to cover his butt as he must know this is illegal under Federal Wage Laws to name but one law).
 
But wait a minute, the Tax Collector can’t be all that bad can he? During the holidays Rod Northcutt proved the extent of his generosity. This past Christmas or 2006, Ebenezer Northcutt came waltzing through one of the Tax Collector branch offices and announced to everyone that he managed to save $2,000,000 dollars of the budget allotted to his office – of which he was going to send it back. And to show how much he appreciated those employees for all the hard work they did that made him look so good, he gave them all a Christmas bonus to warm them during the holidays. No, not a lump of coal for the fire as you might expect - he gave them a $2 dollar coffee mug from his office.
 
 -------------------------------
 
Please look into what wage laws, EEOC violations, unfair labor practices, or other laws this tyrant may have broken because Brevard County seems to be shielding him - or themselves. I can't get further involved because I don't want someone on the inside of this story to lose their job in retaliation. Rod Northcutt has responded to the talks of unionizing by threatening to do away with all of their jobs and has gotten his attorney involved. It’s time for this arrogant man to retire or be removed from his ivory tower.
 
A Concerned Citizen
 

  _____

RE: Michael Larner, #P08840
Hendry Correctional Institution

12551 Wainwright Drive


Immokalee, Florida 34142-4797

 
Dear Concerned State Officials:
 
I had the opportunity to visit with inmate Michael Larner this morning. Michael promptly showed me that the left side of his face was bruised. Elevating his trouser cuffs revealed visible trauma to the calf area. This unwarranted attack occurred between 6:30 and 7:00 PM on Friday, July 7th, 2006. 
 
When I inquired about who was responsible for this apparent beating, Michael explained that Corrections Officer Thesson had ordered three of his inmate thugs to go over and beat Michael Larner. Then I inquired as to the reason for this beating. Without hesitation, Michael revealed that because Larner had revealed the previous attack to higher authorities a beating was in order. How did Larner know that the attack was an order from C.O. Thesson? Very simple! He heard Thesson bragging about ordering his thugs into action with his own ears! Purely and simply, this was retaliation because an inmate “blew the whistle” about being attacked and threatened by Corrections Officer Thesson. How dare a lowly inmate challenge the authority they have in their domain!
 
It is my understanding that the FDOC has rules and regulations regarding retaliation. It is also my understanding that staff-ordered beatings are not a facet of the rehabilitation rituals. All too many officers have made it a point to threaten those who dare to protest abuse, harassment, bogus disciplinary reports, beatings, retaliation and other forms unacceptable conduct.
 
For the safety, survival and good of all concerned, please advise C.O. Thesson that he is obligated to adhere to the rules, just as those in his custody must do. The Florida Department of Corrections is not run by those who believe in anarchy and lawlessness. There are rules and guidelines that apply to all who are in the corrections orbit. Treating people with dignity and respect, refraining from beatings and threats, following the rules and conducting one’s self with professional demeanor---these are requisite and laudable qualities for all human beings when interacting with others.
 
I respectfully request that Officer Thesson conduct his duties in a manner that is consistent with FDOC rules, regulations and guidelines. It would appear that the man needs some anger management therapy too!
 
In appreciation and with thanks,
Sid Kleiner
SKLEINER@COMCAST.NET

Subject:	[*] abuse update against my daughter

Dear Mr. Moss:

I had to return home from New York where I went to care for my elderly great aunt, after my daughter called me to inform me that her father was rubbing her virgina. I asked why didn't she call 911 because nothing happens when I report his abuses on her. I told her she is old enough to call 911 herself now because they don't listen to me. She is afraid to defend herself. She said her father told her he was putting cream on her rash. I then spoke to him, and that was his excuse. He then begins describing how much pubic hair she has, I NEARLY FAINTED! I had to pay extra money to get a flight out immediately to get home. My daughter continued to call me to come and get her. When I picked her up she began to tell me how much she hates her father. I have been warned by my ex-husband's neighbors to be careful in Cooper City because when there is an incident between Blacks and Whites the police always sides with the Whites. I didn't believe it before, but I am starting to believe it now because my daughter has gone through: being forced to sleep in her father's bed while he slept naked and she wakes up red and later a rash around her virgina; her father has hit her with a belt and left a red mark; neighbors hearing her scream through her window and call 911; my daughter running away from home and attempting suicide; cigarette burn on her hand after Judge Luzzo ordered her father not to smoke in her presence; she is dropped off to me with a black eye and bruise on her face; I am awaken in the middle of the night with her screaming that her father slapped her in the face; she is now hurting kids at school where one incident the kid ended up going to the hospital with a spranged arm and the parents threatening to file charges at the advice of the Cooper City school police; she is searching online for pornographic material because her father has exposed her to it, and Detective Gainey at the Cooper City Police said there was nothing wrong with it after I reported her father for exposing her to it; now she is turning what should be love for her father to hate because she is being forced to live with him while he is still molesting her. This time he admitted to me he touched her virgina but with the excuse that he was rubbing cream on her rash. She is eleven years old; I don't touch her body at all. I teach her how to care for herself, and if the rash doesn't go away I take her to the doctor, which he doesn't. 

Let's not forget that one of the reasons I divorced him besides his abuse is that he had an affair with a 16-year-old high school minor, and no one seems to care because the girl was Black, and he is White. I want my daughter removed from this man immediately and returned back to me (her mother). She was taken from me based on lies my ex-husband told that I threaten to take her away from him, without having to prove it. I took her to safety because he was molesting her. I had proof then and I have proof now, but no one cares to speak to any of my witnesses. Now she is causing harm to other kids at her school. I am afraid my daughter is going to grow up and end up in jail due to this corrupt system.

I have done everything I could to protect my daughter and try and get her away from her father, who is continuing to molest her. Every time I report the things she tells me he is doing, he calls me with threats because according to him the police and sheriff are on his side and they tell him how to get back at me. The last time I reported her black eye and bruises on her face, he called me with threats. I also reported that he looked like he had been smoking marijuana, he called me shouting profanities and threats to accuse me of being strung out on cocaine as he knows I have never experimented with drugs in my life; I don't even take over the counter drugs. That day there was a police officer with him listening to our conversation; I could hear the police radio in the background. When I mentioned that I knew he was recording my phone calls without my permission the call went dead.

Lastly, my daughter told me she stole candy from the store. This too is a habit she picked up from her father; in the past I used to catch him shop lifting. I admonished that if he did it again I would report him, and of course he threaten me. 

I do have an attorney now, but I have run out of money and can't pay her. It is only a matter of time when she will have to withdraw from my case. I am also receiving more threats from my ex-husband that his attorney, Cindy Vova will be filing a motion to have me incarcerated because I can't pay her fees too. These are fees that she unethically filed in court after Judge Luzzo ruled that each of us is responsible for our own fees. He did not order me to pay my ex-husband's fees. However, Cindy Vova re-entered the order with her changes and filed them so that when my cased was turned over to Judge Aramony, I would be forced to pay her or go to jail. I tried paying those fees for the sake of proving to the court that I am not disobedient, but I am flat out broke now. I have no more money. There are other creditors calling me threatening to take me to court because I can't pay them either because this case has taken everything I had.

I need help before my daughter does something desperate. She is getting older now, and I am afraid that she is going to end up in prison or dead. The last time my daughter spoke with DCF without her father present, she told them she did not want to live with her father. She told them she wanted to live with her mother. She wasn't afraid to speak her own mind, but when her father is present she says what he has coerced her to say. My daughter even told me that when Melinda Brown was her guardian ad litem, she tried to turn her against me (her mother).  My daughter said Melinda Brown told her things that she knew wasn't true because she knew she was with me during the incidents in question, and she now she is even afraid of the legal system. The legal system is causing my daughter to hate her father, as is her father with his own lies.

P.S. I have tried to contact James Walker in the past by phone and email, but I have not received any responses from him or his office. I do not feel that I can trust Broward County's legal system. There has been too many cases involving Black and White issues where the system sided with the White party. I have met with other people who have suffered from discrimination and lost their children due to this racist legal system. Something has got to be done to clean up the legal system in Broward County and disbar unethical attorneys and police officers. I have spent my entire life obeying the law and teaching my daughter as well as my students how important it is to obey. What do I have to show for it? I am the one being punished for trying to protect my child from abuse. I do believe that if my ex-husband were Black, he would be in jail just as what happened to another case similar to mine where the man was Black and the wife was White. She violated court order and left the jurisdiction with their minor child, and nothing was done about it. The Black man filed contempt charges against his White ex-wife, and nothing was done. She is still in Jacksonville. In fact, after I received permission from him to use his case as an example Cindy Vova, my ex-husband's attorney, read it and suddenly became legal representative to the White ex-wife of the Black man who has not seen his child in nearly four years. Cindy Vova is unethical, but when I filed a claim against her to the Bar they too took her side and threw out my complaint.

Sincerely,
Gail Becker

Dear Ms. Barineau,

Regarding the impending case of Mrs. Vina Mclain and our previous
conversations, I have personally attempted to secure an "audit trail" at
your behest of Mrs. Mclain's name change directly through the
Immigration
and Naturalization Service (INS) by calling their contact phone number.

While expending more time and finally talking with a Federal Agent who
identified himself as Chris Agent # 2378; the United States Government
does
not facilitate providing Naturalized Citizens with copies of their
original
Naturalization Application (i.e. Document N-400 you cited earlier today
which was the form she would have had to have filed).

Their official position remains steadfast. THE NATURALIZATION
CERTIFICATE IS
THE LEGAL POINT AT WHICH THE NAME CHANGE OCCURRED. That statement
therefore
becomes axiomatic and sacrosanct to this citizen. In my estimation, no
lower
authority may have any superseding rule in this matter. According to the
same aforementioned form N-400; subsection D; the question states: Name
change (optional); Please read the Instructions before you decide to
whether
to change your name. (1) Would you like to change your name? (Y/N); 2.
If
"Yes," Print new name you would like to use. Do not use initials or
abbreviations when writing your name.

When you stated earlier to me that a certified copy of the N-400 would
suffice, what logic supports the notion that an application for any
request
of any governmental agency has a greater precedence or priority as
opposed
to the final issued legal document that is recognized world-wide? Does
not
the actual certificate prove beyond any reasonable doubt, the
authenticity
or veracity of this citizen and licensed barber? 

I also verified your earlier assertion that Mrs. Mclain can renew under
her
birth name; that claim on your part, appears to be flawed. According to
each
and every source of reference I checked, the fact that the USA and the
State
of Florida and her local municipality recognizes her as Vina Mclain and
because the DBPR agent that Mrs. Mclain dealt with earlier stated that
she
CAN NOT apply under her birth name for renewal, raises more doubts about
your statement as she is no longer that person.

I think that this matter is clear and simple. Unless there is a question
as
to the authenticity of the actual Naturalization Certificate, then this
citizen would ask that you proceed with the renewal process straightway
so
that she does not miss her deadline of July 31, 2006; if this applicant
is
in good standings with your department (which I believe her to be). In
this
instance, if a question remains as the veracity of either the Federal
Government; Government Branch (DBPR) (Driver's License) or citizen
Mclain
making claims, one fact remains persistent; Mrs. Mclain is recognized by
the
Federal Government; the State of Florida; and the County of Duval - but
not
the DBPR. That is what logic prescribes to me. Either way, this matter
is
resolved and simple to move forward with.

If I am incorrect by having missed some valuable point you made earlier,
then please forgive me and appraise me immediately. As before, I am
simply
attempting to help a neighbor. Since you also stated that you have
evidence
contrary to my claim, were you able to sanitize the document you
described
so that I may see its notation and point of origin?

Since you also indicated you are out of pocket from the end of day today
until next Monday, I would like to see the momentum of this renewal
process
continue forward (despite your absence) so that Mrs. Mclain does not
miss
out in life.

What are the next steps and what should I tell Mrs. Mclain? I anxiously
await your response. Thanks in advance.


Best regards,
Alex Szabo

-----Original Message-----
From: Alex Szabo [mailto:alex@alex-szabo.com]
Sent: Wednesday, July 05, 2006 9:18 PM
To: Governor Jeb Bush
Cc: Mack Mcclain
Subject: Request for help
Importance: High


My Dear Governor Jeb,

I trust all is well with you and your family.

My neighbor's; Mack & Vina Mclain are a young married couple that lives
across the street from me (along with their new daughter, Livia). I
write
you on behalf of Mrs. Mclain to inform you of her plight and to
potentially
enlist your direct help. 

Mrs. Mclain is a licensed barber under the Florida Department of
Business &
Professional Regulation (DBPR) and whose license up for routine and
recurring renewal by the end of this month. Unfortunately, Mrs. Mclain's
attempt to renew her professional license since last April has been meet
with numerous bureaucratic debacles and resistance on the part of this
department upon my initial review of her documentation. 

Mrs. Mclain's license was originally issued under her birth name prior
to
her acquiring her citizenship. Her initial name change occurred at the
time
she became a citizen of the U.S.A. during her Naturalization Ceremony on
September 17, 2004. Immediately after that event she was issued a United
States Passport. Subsequent to that event was her marriage in which
[again]
her surname changed due to marriage and duly recorded officially and
made a
part of public record. In addition, she possesses a valid Florida
Driver's
license issued under her current legal name.

Mrs. Mclain submitted all required documentation requested of her
including
fees (taxation) levied against her so that she may pursue prosperity
within
her regulated profession in her current legal name. She has submitted
all
documentation copies when requested.

At this time, the DPBR has suspended the entire renewal process in lieu
of
requesting a certified copy for a Petition for Name Change from the
Immigration and Naturalization Service, a completely unnecessary and
inconsequential request on their part. The only sequence of events this
demand shall spawn is (a) cost this young couple another $250 (plus)
dollars; (b) expiration of license and thusly requiring additional fees
from
the normal renewal fees; (c) loss of time and wages to chase an
inaccessible
reply to a nebulous request; (d) loss of potential wages due to
inability to
practice profession.

To recap; the United States of America recognizes Vina (at every
junction);
the State of Florida recognizes Vina (as a driver); but NOT the DBPR.
For
you see, their authority supersedes the authority of the United States
government by undue delay for the renewal of this citizens license in
favor
of delays for unessential and nonsensical demands. DBPR make the
statement
of request, the United States Government tells her that her
Naturalization
Papers are sufficient. 

If I am having difficulty digesting this request, who is she supposed to
believe? I find a great deal of humor on one side of this equation in
the
application of logic and disdain on the other side for the incongruence
of
logic. Moreover, wasn't this issue ultimately settled back when Lee
surrendered to Grant?

The DBPR has NOT listened to the fact that this name change occurred at
the
time of the naturalization ceremony and that no such petition exists.

If you were in my shoes, how would you advise this neighbor? 

I anxiously look forward to your reply.

My Best regards,
Alex Szabo

***********************************************************************************************************

                                                     SAMPLE LETTER 

 

Frederick P. Gaske

Bureau of Historic Preservation

Florida Department of State

500 S. Bronough Street


Tallahassee, FL   32399-0250


 

 

Dear Mr. Gaske:

 

Please accept this letter as support for the Historic Preservation Special Category Grant application submitted for the restoration of the North New River Lock/Sewell Lock Boating Park, Broward County, Florida. The site has been Designated historical in the National Registry, this boating / barge lock was known as” The Gateway to The Everglades” one of two from the original waterway that allowed shipping from Fort Lauderdale ( Port Everglades ) west to Lake Okeechobee and on to The Gulf of Mexico.

This ocean access Lock was in use until the late 1950’s, when the waterway was turned  over to The State of Florida  for maintenance by The Army Corps of Engineers .

 Rehabilitation and major improvements to this Historic Lock , Buildings and Park site have been long overdue.  This is a worthwhile restoration of a historical site and one that will bring enjoyment from its use by the residents and visitors to the State of Florida and Broward County. 

 Thank you.

 

Signed - 

************************************************************

( See attachments-History )

Please make sure to copy your letter to    The  Historical  Society   ( Mr, Chris Eck ) ceck@broward.org    and       P.W.O.A.  Inc.       ( Mr. N. Camparscone )     pwoa2005@bellsouth.net 

 

Again , Thank You

*********************************************************************************************************

                                         More History about The Sewell Lock ,below

Dear Bob,

 

I know and appreciate how concerned you are for the restoration and rehabilitation of the Sewell Lock Boating Park.  long as you like – that you would like to see the state Historic Preservation Special Category Grant for the North New River Lock/Sewell Lock Boating Park be funded.  His contact information is as follows
