Subject:	Insurance Cancellations and Increases

Dear Mr. Gallagher:
I have copied an e-mail sent to Gov. Bush by my Condo Association President regarding our attempt to obtain insurance coverage for our buildings after we were canceled by Allstate. That e-mail is below.
 
Today I spoke with someone from a leading insurance company who said that the Insurance Companies are not going to subsidize the homeowner segment with profits from their Auto Insurance arms going forward and thus will raise homeowner rates dramatically on business they wish to keep and nonrenew business that they deem too risky; read more than 5 (sometimes 3) years old.
 
It may be time for your office to tell these companies, since you regulate them, to stop cherry-picking and offer affordable insurance to all. It is unconscionable for these companies to cancel so many thousands of policies and ask for such exhorbidant rate increases also. The insurance industry is about spreading risk and overall these companies are very profitable and have been for years. Why don't they add the past profits into the equation before crying about losses in one year? They could also spread it around to the rest of the individual companies under their umbrella throughout the country, I'm sure most of them have the same top management and shareholders.
 
I was also told that the insurance companies are asking for such high increases now because they think that this Republican administration will be more receptive to them than if a new Democratic administration and Legislature were to be elected.
 
I would like to see your Agency tell these Insurance Companies that if they wish to continue doing business in Florida they will have to keep their current policies in force, with realistic premium increases which could be as high as 50%, or do NO business at all in Florida, which would include no auto, business, Life or Financial services if they do them. 
 
You must do something to stop the hardship that this situation is causing to hundreds of thousands of Floridians.
 
Please read the letter below.
 
 
 
Dear Governor Bush,
 
I am the 2006 President of the Cedar Hollow Condominium Association in Bradenton, Florida. I have been a full time resident of the Sarasota-Bradenton area since February 1995. I know you are acutely aware of the insurance rate crisis. However, I am offering a real example of the drastic affects upon our condominium owners.
 
Our budget year runs from January 1 to December 31 each year. Our insurance annual premium was approximately $27,000.00 with Allstate Insurance, payable in monthly installments, until they notified us in late May that they were dropping our policy effective August 17, 2006, our renewal date. The development consisting of 96 units was completed in late 2001 and we are located approximately one (1) mile west of I75, off of SR 70, Tara at the Preserve, in a non flood zone.
 
We have been attempting to obtain insurance quotes since February of this year. We were told by numerous insurance agents that we must wait until we received the 60 day cancellation notice from Allstate. Our Board of Directors were certain that Allstate would drop us as they had thousands of other Florida policy holders. After receipt of the cancellation notice, the agents were again contacted. However, it was not until Thursday, July 6, 2006 that the following quotes were received.
 

*	Agent, Vince Madina, Quote from Strategic Insurance Company = $140,000.00 annually. Requires the full amount of the premium on August 17th. They offer a loan at 11% to pay their premium. 
*	Agent, Dave McMahn, Atlas, Quote from Strategic Insurance Company = $140,000.00 annually. Requires the full amount of the premium on August 17th. They offer a loan at 11% to pay their premium. 
*	Chris Boston, Bushong Insurance - Requires a $2,000.00 appraisal before presenting quotes for binder. 
*	Gar Reese, Moody Agency (This is the agent that Allstate referred to us, awaiting reply.) 
*	Mike Angers, Brown & Brown = $212,482.00 annually. 
*	Meda Wilson, Al Purport Insurance Agency, Cincinnati Insurance Company. Cincinnati Ins. will not insure any property older than three (3) years in Florida.  
*	State of Florida Citizens Insurance - If you can obtain a quote for insurance from an admitted carrier ( A carrier admitted to sell insurance in the State of Florida) you cannot utilize Citizens. 

 
Our 96 owners consist of part time residents from out of State, owners who are employed, retired owners, retired widows and retired widowers.
 
Our present 2006 Quarterly Assessment with $35,000.00 budgeted for insurance that included an anticipated rate increase is $475.00. The 2007 estimated Quarterly Assessment without any insurance costs = $380.84. The 2007 estimated Quarterly Assessment with new insurance costs estimated at $140,000.00 would be $866.95 for the first three quarters of which $486.11 is for insurance to meet the August 17, 2007 renewal date premium payment in full. The ability to sell these units will be extremely difficult with the new quarterly assessment amount. 
 
However, our immediate crisis is to create a Special Assessment for owners to pay the $140,000.00 by August 17, 2006. This will require a payment of $1,458.33 from each of our 96 owners by August 15, 2006. 
 
I know you have no magic solution for our situation, but the last three days have left me drained attempting to find a way to make things easier for our owners. If this information is actually presented to you to read, you can imagine the negative future affects on Florida's residents, growth and economy.
 
If there is a direction that our property management firm or Board should pursue, please let me know at your earliest convenience as the clock is running and the insurance quotes are only good for 15 days of which 3 have elapsed as of this writing.
 
G. Dan Boone
7274 Cedar Hollow Circle
Bradenton, Florida 34203
941-753-3993
 
Ned O'Meara
7127 Cedar Hollow Circle
Bradenton, FL 34203
941-758-3856

From:	ratech <ratech@bigpond.com>
Sent:	Monday, July 10, 2006 9:14 AM
To:	minister.downer@dfat.gov.au; ministerfordefence@defence.gov.au; Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Copy of note sent to the US Departmen of Energy

To the US Department of Energy,
 
As a layman, with no political affiliations, and without even an involvement in modern day fuel useage, apart from a very efficient system of sharing responsibility, could I make some suggestions to the world of energy, so as to make my particular however small contribution, to my fellow man (who I would suspect uses far more fuel than mayself)?
 
Well read on if I may, scuse my intrustion into "your" protected lair.
 
 In Australia, the best country , in the world, I have noticed that our particularly nice climate has been interfered with recently by noticeably hotter days, when the sky is very clear.  We used to call this an Indian summer's day, in honour of the red indians, in your country.  Whether they are the Indians, everyone else refers to, I don't know.  But the UV factor is noticeably higher, in fact so high, it is very likely to get burnt in the middle of winter, on even a coolish day.  This never used to be the case, although in summer it was.
 
So there is a definite and recogniseable problem, and it is in fact in my opinion, already so bad, that extreme measures are now required to counteract the effect of what they call, global warming, due to an increase in greenhouse gases.
 
The constant media hype about fuel prices going up and the availability of fuel, although relevant to the lifestyles of many, I think the attention being given to the imminent decline of comfortable living standards, whilst outdoors, is far too low, and this situation could in fact be a much more catastrophic situation, waiting to happen, in fact is happening whilst everyone with a job, is whingeing about getting their pint of fuel.
 
I would suggest that there is some definite move made by the US Department of Energy, together with other world energy departments, such as Saudi Arabia, Africa, Russia, China and Australia, to start saying something about a change in fuel use habits world wide, crisis level changes, which could bring the world back into sync with a balance of natural forces which will help both the ozone layer recover and see a generational preservation of fuel reserves for the future, effective immediately.
 
New fuel reserves being found, such as oil sands, suggest an increased availability of fuel, however also suggest an increasing use of existing fuel reserves required to refine them, ie natural gas, which both removes existing reserves and increases green house gases.
 
It is my suggestion, that the world does not have that much time.
 
By increasing fuel production, as has been suggested by the world energy forecasters, the increased use of fossil fuel to refine some of that fuel, the ongoing inefficient useage of that fuel and the neglect of our environment, by the communities of the world who over use fuel, could mean, for us, that not only will the polar ice cap melt, and deprive future generations to come, of any sightings of polar bears and penguins, but will increase smog levels world wide, crippling many cities who need fresh air to breath and stay healthy, increase the UV factor, in all countries, especially countries, near the ozone holes, and will also affect crop growth, which is needed to manufacture new age fuels, if we don't even consider food supplies.
 
I don't think, we have as much time as suggested by the fuel companies, to constantly introspect about whether we can continue massive production levels of fuels, for the sake of jobs, or for the sake of just keeping the show going.
 
The world I think, the energy using world, I think has now run out of time, because a UV factor felt in countries like mine Australia, which is very used to high solar radiation levels, and is quite proud of the fact, means we won't be able to go outdoors, and then the next step is crops won't survive.
 
Australia is going through a drought at the moment, an extended drought, and that drought demonstrates what can happen, when crops fail, water supplies to cities, fail, and noone is very concerned about the issue, because they are being an outright bitch just because they can't get their pint of diesel or petrol from the local service station.
 
Our civilisation, largely was not built on fuel alone, but on the good will and health of many.  To say that fuel is the major priority for our civilisation is like saying, if we are all fat ugly overweight jallopy drivers, who don't have legs and our faces are the only thing important to thank God for giving us, there is no other need to life or enjoy life, there couldn't be, because it is not a consideration, in social planning.
 
I have some suggestions to help the world alone the road to recovery, if you have time to listen.  The time is short, the time is short, because the world wishes to open its mouth and complain, instead of being a cooperative, interested and appreciative world, full of people who consider society, for the sake of community, rather than for being indolent with greed.
 
1)  We must consider that future generations need fuel too.  The fossil fuel reserves we have now, are very good, they are very effective, but they have only lasted 50 years or so.  Millions of years, went into making them, but because the energy hungry modern age is using them so fast, the grandchildren of this generation, may not even understand anything of their existence from personal experience, only to remember wars fought over them, and countless civilian and government bitches who complained they were not given more.
 
Therefore, there is both a need to consider fuel useage from an efficiency point of view as well as a prosterity point of view and the time is running out to do so.
 
To plan to use more fuel, faster, world wide in the next 10 years, therefore, although possible, demonstrates a severe lack of both planning, a severe lack of desire to consider future generations, a lack of willingness to consider the broader needs of our world outside the energy sector, possibly even the mindset of one beset by a desire to committ suicide, rather than look towards his or her own behaviour, and in doing so, secure the future of our planet.
 
Nasa has forecast arctic warming, to such a degree that the polar icecap will melt, the oceans will rise, some countries will go into another ice age within a possible 50 years, and yet, the energy production people, do not heed these warnings, instead they are planning greater levels of fuel production and useage.
 
One would think perhaps, they have gone mad.
 
2)  Fuel efficiencies:
 
Although fuel efficiences are present in the car market, and although changes look planned and suitable to the task at hand, there are still some issues which seem unresolved to me.
 
a)  The fuel companies burn, huge, and I mean absolutely massive amounts of burn off gases from the oil rigs, from oil refineries, and other installations.
 
These burn off jets, instead of just wasting the energy, could be used to heat water, produce clean water for drinking, and if not utilised for drinking, the steam from heating water, could simply be allowed to go into the atmosphere to produce rain, which will fall somewhere.  When the steam goes up into the atmosphere, it will produce some more ozone, it will produce humidity, and rainfall by seeding, and all up, will be used better than just to produce toxic gases and CO2 gases released into the atmosphere, to foster more public media based complaining that our world is falling apart.
 
Could the oil companies therefore, immediately take steps to turn their burn off gas outlets, into steam producing plants?  
 
CO2 emissions would be less, Ozone production would increase in the atmosphere due to the seeding material, namely water, in the atmosphere, and possibly even rain would come to some dry countries, or be assisted to come if nothing else.  Complaining would be less, and that in itself, would be a great boon for all western countries.  Women's scorn is one thing, but I think too much scorn can wear you out.
 
b)  The use of heavy military equipment - eg jet fighter planes 
 
Jet fighter planes, use 11,000 US Gallons per trip, which I think is 44,000 litres of Aviation fuel per trip, and this suggests, not just an enormous and in many cases unnecessary use of fuel, but would be the equivalent of 8,000 people driving to a shop at any one time.  
 
An aircraft carrier full of jet fighter planes, would therefore use, the equivalent of 200,000 people, yes, an entire cities worth of fuel in one trip.  Yes one trip, imagine if they conducted 10 sauties or more each, then the fuel useage would be absolutely enormous.  
 
The water produced by the oil companies, from steam producing gas outlets, could provide the water needed to satisfy those countries, against which the US military has been pitched, taking away their lust for war, taking away the need to even go to war.  
 
c)  Heavy truck traffic.
 
Well we do find heavy truck traffic difficult, and trying to drive a mini minor near a large semi (sem eye for you USAians) is not everyone's cup of tea.
 
Heavy truck traffic which is destined for major towns, could be diverted through a rail link perhaps, which is both more efficient fuel wise, safer for the civilian drivers, and heavy truck traffic could be restricted from the rail link to the sales outlet only.
 
Not easy to do, but would save a lot of fuel and prevent many truck accidents which are currently happening.
 
d)  Civilian use of vehicles.
 
  >  go to the supermarket less often.
  >  use a smaller car
  >  car pool with friends (this is an interesting one isn't it.  Car pooling with enemies is not such a good idea)  Car pooling with friends, may even help to solve the very severe sociality problem which is present now in western countries, where people are increasingly isolated, with noone to talk to, no way to contribute to the common good, and if people were responsible enough to drive as safely and slowly as possible, car pooling, although seen to be unreaslistic because of one reason and another, if only some people did it, it could become a cult in itself, perhaps the first good religious cult, which the world has seen for a long time.
 
e)  Placement of supermarket outlets, and places of employment.
 
Supermarket outlet locations, determine the distances travelled to the supermarkets and therefore the use of fuel by the community.
 
Now against the US military machine, western civilian petrol useage is probably minor.....cough.  Or is it.
 
Employment location, means, also use of fuel.
 
The modern world is finding large supermarkets, difficult at times due to overcrowding, (yes in the car park, how did you guess), intimidating, because women's breasts can't compare with 17 square acres of red apples in Wooldworths and some women get shy and anorexia then results, for some, especially the elderly, the shops are too far away and because of that, they can't get their dinner, and then they get sick, their families, break up, because the young want to live in an area where supermarkets are more upmarket and then our entire community, breaks apart.
 
Lack of food, too much fuel, too much money needed, too much pressure on the elderly and thereby the family unit, and down we all go, into the sewers of success, in what it means to be a rich man in an modern world.
 
Local employment is good, local food outlets are good.  Less fuel, less money needed, allowing for an increased population, and who wouldn't want that?  Eh girls?  and the ozone layer, saying thankyou, but not taking the skin on the tip of your nose off, as you water the garden.
 
f)  Bio fuels.
 
Can I say, that this is both the dilemna, and condemnation of the western world.  A world convinced, verily stamped in government ink on the death certificates of so many soldiers, and on so many civilians, in third world countries, that there is no fuel to provide fresh water, and warmth to many, and now, to say we can run a jet ski, we have both the means, and permissions, to get it running loudly, we have the means, to run campervans on ethanol, and we have the means to keep politicians alive with loungeroom heaters, and we have the fuel to keep government buses running, when so many others are driving a Rolls Royce.
 
We have no fuel is the catch cry of the modern age, and it was held as a victor's sword against our conscience, when we have been asked to help others survive, and now, out of that same need, the same need for survival, when the government wants not to be seen as defeated, a solution is found.
 
The solution though I think is fragile.
 
The solution depends on rain, on the fat cut from the food we eat, from food grown (corn) to make ethanol, the same ethanol which has been produced by western countries, yeh verily, the same ethanol which helps the economy of the western world's survive, and yet, so many have died, because "they" said, there is NO FUEL.
 
The rains, can't come because we are in a drought.
The UV levels are set to go up and up, as if to say God does love us, enough to give us a clear warning, before our world dies from overheating.   The UV levels are set to go up because the production and useage of fuel is considered more a priority than our own survival, more a priority than an increasing gratitude towards a God who has given us sight, and hearing, arms and legs with which to walk, a nose to smell the flowers, but all the western world can think and train itself for is war, and to hide inside concrete and steel buildings, away from the beauty which makes our world, worth living in.
 
The priorities, of the modern world, now are put to the test.
 
North Korea, I think, prophesied in the Bible as demonstrating the judgement of God, by suggesting our time is up, that a nuclear war is imminent, now acts, from its heart, yes, from its experience of knowing of just what it is, to be without help, for long long periods of time.  
 
It is not a nuclear threat though in itself.  It is not a futile plea for mercy, it is in fact God's judgement, that if we do not immediately value our world, and take definite and immediate steps, to reduce fuel useage world wide in a very dramatic sense, we will, lose our world, and for future generations, our legacy will be one of poverty, instead of prosperity, and happiness, which was intended by our creator, effected as we take the time to value, all we have been given.
 
Regards

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: Governor Jeb Bush 
Sent: Saturday, July 08, 2006 3:46 AM
Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, July 7, 2006

For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:

http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news

The text version of the e-newsletter is below.


RECORD NUMBER OF FLORIDIANS USING SAFETY BELTS

On Thursday I announced that a record number of Floridians are using safety
belts. The Preusser Research Group recently reported that 80.7 percent of
drivers and their front seat passengers are using safety belts on Florida
highways.  Overall, safety belt usage rates in Florida have climbed more
than 20 percent since 2000. A vast majority of Floridians are using safety
belts. Wearing a safety belt saves lives. It is the single most effective
way to prevent injuries and reduce fatalities in motor vehicle crashes. For
more information on Florida's 'Click It or Ticket' safety belt campaign,
please visit www.clickitfla.com.


CHRISTA CALAMAS APPOINTED SECRETARY OF THE FLORIDA AGENCY FOR HEALTH CARE
ADMINISTRATION

On Thursday I named Christa Calamas as Secretary of the Florida Agency for
Health Care Administration (AHCA). Calamas most recently served as the
General Counsel for AHCA.  The appointment is effective July 8.  Previously,
she served as Assistant General Counsel to Governor Bush from 2002 to 2005.
Calamas replaces Secretary Alan Levine who was recently selected as the new
CEO of the North Broward Hospital District. Christa's extensive experience
in health care policy continues to be a great asset to my administration. I
am confident Christa will continue the good work done by Secretary Levine as
Florida implements landmark Medicaid reform, leads the nation in public
reporting of hospital information and begins the process of creating
networks for electronic medical records. All three of these priorities will
fundamentally improve the way health care is delivered in our state. For
more information on Florida's consumer-driven health care initiatives,
please visit http://ahca.myflorida.com or www.floridacomparecare.gov 


POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD PRESENTED TO ALICIA CRABTREE

On Wednesday I recognized Alicia Crabtree of Melbourne as this week's Points
of Light Award recipient.  For over three years, Alicia has dedicated her
time to volunteer efforts at the Melbourne Children's Home Society, an
organization designed to prevent child abuse and neglect. I am proud to
recognize Alicia for the tremendous impact she has had on the lives of
others less fortunate. She has given selflessly of her time and resources
for the enhancement of others.  Alicia is to be commended for her
extraordinary commitment to the community and should serve as an example to
us all.  For more information, or to nominate, go to
www.VolunteerFloridaFoundation.org.

Congratulations!

To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
http://www.flgov.com/release/7975


GOVERNOR BUSH'S 2006 LEGISLATIVE INITIATIVES

Please visit www.govfloridaforum.com.

who are also mentioned in the article.

   1) Dehumidifiers pull (collect) water from the air.
   2) This water is electrolyzed by "hydrogen-boost" converters.
     available at:   Hydrogen-boost.com

   3) Hydrogen engines generate all the power we need.
     available at:   Hydrogenenginecenter.com

   Costs?   I don't know.
   The combination of these technologies would allow us to
pull power out of thin air.

come from a high output alternator, or several of them.

"onboard conversion" technology that would make in unnecessary to
have a hydrogen infrastructure.

hydrogen engine. No petroleum is necessary, no platinum , no
hydrogen infrastructure, no fuel cells.

-----Original Message-----
From: Adams, Nancy [mailto:Adams.Nancy@hsmv.state.fl.us] 
Sent: Thursday, July 06, 2006 4:30 PM
To: wlsm5607@bellsouth.net
Subject: RE: Why are you wasting my time? Drivers License issue

 

 

 Dear Mr. Hillard:

 

Executive Director Fred Dickinson received your email regarding your license renewal and asked us to respond.

 

Your record shows that you have a non-digital driver license.  This would be an older, laminated version of a Florida driver license, opposed to the one that looks like a credit card. You may go to your local driver license office to apply for a new driver license with a current photo.  Once your photo has been taken, it will be stored in our database and will allow you to use one of our convenient options the next time you need a duplicate or a renewal.

 

Appointments are not mandatory but will help reduce the wait time at the driver license office.  You may visit our website at www.hsmv.state.fl.us to make an appointment or call our appointment center at (850)922-9000. 

 

We are continually striving to make our services more convenient and user friendly.  We will address your concerns regarding our website and phone center to the appropriate area.

 

We hope this information will assist you.

 

Sincerely,

SANDRA C. LAMBERT, Director

Division of Driver Licenses

From:	Patrick O'Neill PhD <patrickoneillphd@cox.net>
Sent:	Monday, July 10, 2006 1:32 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Our Social Security

Dear Governor Bush,
You may want to forward this eMail that is circulating among US citizens.
Thanking you in advance for your immediate attention to this matter,
I remain...
Patrick W. O'Neill, PhD
 
Our Social Security


Many years ago in Seattle, two wonderful neighbors,
Elliott and Patty Roosevelt came to my home to swim on
a regular basis.  They were a great couple full of
laughter and stories that today I continue to marvel
at.  Both are now deceased, but their stories remain.
During the years of our friendship we had many, many
discussions about Elliott's parents (President Franklin D.
and Eleanor Roosevelt) and how his father and mother
never intended for the Social Security and Welfare
programs to turn out the way they are today.  Elliott
used to say that if his parents returned to earth and
saw what the politicians had done to their programs
they would have burned all of them in hell.

Here is a story I received today regarding the Social
Security Program and I immediately thought of
Elliott's comments.  I Hope you will read
this and think about it.   

_____________________________________________

Franklin Roosevelt, a Democrat, introduced the Social
Security (FICA) Program.  He  promised:

1.) That participation in the Program would be
completely voluntary,

2.) That the participants would only have to pay
1% of the first $1,400 of their annual
incomes into the Program,

3.) That the money the participants elected to put
into the Program would be deductible from
their income for tax purposes each year,

4.) That the money the participants put into the
independent "Trust Fund" rather than into the
General operating fund, and therefore, would
only be used to fund the Social Security
Retirement Program, and no other
Government program, and,

5.) That the annuity payments to the retirees
would never be taxed as income.


--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
---------------------

 
Since many of us have paid into FICA for years and are
now receiving a Social Security check every month --
and then finding that we are getting taxed on 85% of
the money we paid to the Federal government to "put
away" -- you may be interested in the following:

-------------------------------------------------------------

Q: Which Political Party took Social Security from the
independent "Trust Fund" and put it into the
General fund so that Congress could spend it?

A: It was Lyndon Johnson and the democratically
controlled House and Senate.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Q: Which Political Party eliminated the income tax
deduction for Social Security (FICA) withholding?

A: The Democratic Party.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Q: Which Political Party started taxing Social
Security annuities?

A: The Democratic Party, with Al Gore casting the
"tie-breaking" deciding vote as President of the
Senate, while he was Vice President of the US.

-------------------------------------------------------------------
AND MY FAVORITE:

Q: Which Political Party decided to start giving
annuity payments to immigrants ?

A: That's right!  Jimmy Carter and the Democratic Party.
Immigrants moved into this country, and at age 65,
began to receive Social Security payments! The
Democratic Party gave these payments to them,
even though they never paid a dime into it!

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Then, after doing all this lying and thieving and violating
of the original contract (FICA), the Democrats
turn around and tell you that the Republicans
want to take your Social Security away!

And the worst part about it is uninformed
citizens believe it!


==============================================


If enough people receive this, maybe a seed of
awareness will be planted and maybe changes will
evolve.  Maybe not, some Democrats are awfully
sure of what isn't so.

But it's worth a try.  How many people can
YOU send this to?

Actions speak louder than bumper stickers.    

Forward this E-mail to others so that they can
be informed of the truth.

Dear Governor Bush,
                   Just a quick note in response to an evening news report concerning a shortage in orange pickers. I agree with the President,bending or breaking the law is not the solution to this problem.  What may be the answer, is using those who broke the law or are now incarcerated in our minimal security prison system.  As you know, many prison inmates owe a dept to society that should be paid back.  What also may work is to offer these inmates at a reduced cost to the growers who must in turn provide additional security at the grooves with the monies they save by using our inmates.  The other problem I have with this report is how can their be a shortage with pickers with people still trying to collect welfare or unemployment?  I don't understand.  I know if I had to provide for my family, I would do what I had to do.  This may not be the most desirable job, but it may make those wanting to live off of the system become more motivated to better their situation.  I don't mean to  sound unsympathetic, but I don't believe allowing our oranges to rot on the tree is economically the answer either.

                                                                         Rick Myers- Tampa, Fl
From:	Marivett Gerena <marivett2003@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Sunday, July 9, 2006 9:16 PM
To:	Brantley, Shelly
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush; lee.tom.web@flsenate.gov
Subject:	A DESPERATE PARENT

My name is Marivett E. Gerena. I have a 13 year old daughter, Keyla Martinez, who has Prader Willi Syndrome. The most common characteristics of this syndrome are eating disorder, obesity, mental retardation, and behavior problems. She currently weights 177 pounds and measures 4’ 8”.
 
Keyla’s condition in the last 2 years has rapidly deteriorated. Her behavior has become the most overwhelm obstacle. She is compulsive, violent, and unpredictable to anyone near her at the time of crisis. These crisis can be at home, school, bus, church, stores, parks, libraries, restaurants, and etc. As parents we are in a very difficult situation because she is violent to her household members, students and teachers in her classroom, bus drivers, neighbors which make it very difficult for us to be a part of society. 
 
Keyla has a 8 year old brother, Angel Martinez, who has been psychologically affected by Keyla’s crisis. As a result of her attacking him, watching her constantly be restrained by the police, parents, teachers, and other officials, he has currently been diagnosed with ADHD. It is very difficult to give him a normal life since Keyla demands so much of our time. This has also affected her father’s health, he is been treated for Severe Depression and High Blood Pressure. This has left me to keep my household together, especially my marriage. This situation has caused my career to also be in jeopardy.
 
We have called Hillsborough County Sheriff to intervene during these crisis. We have been advised that the only options that they can offer to us is to have her arrested for domestic violence, for us to handle the situation or to call the Crisis Center. I have called the Crisis Center and was advised that being she is over 12 year old they would only admit Keyla, if she goes voluntarily. Keyla was sent to the Crisis Center at the age of 12 for backer acting by Hillsborough County School Officials. 
 
I am pleading for a Crisis Intervention for the second time. The system failed me the first time and that is why I am writing you. On Friday Keyla was dismissed from the Special Needs Summer Program at the YMCA. She attacked the Counselors and other children in her group. They called me at work and gave me minimum time to arrive before calling Officials. On the way home she attempted to jump out of the vehicle while I was still driving on a major road. This situation has gotten out of control. I want what is best for Keyla and my family. But due to the lack of services I am not able to do that. Also with school being out I have no professional setting or staff to care for Keyla while I work. My journey with Keyla has become over my head, where I can’t take care of her and give her a good quality of life.
 
We clearly need help. Please help me. 
 
Cordially,
 
Marivett E. Gerena
1313 Hatch Place
Valrico, Fl 33594

From: wgkozak

Subject: Stop The Unlawful Regulation Of Intarstate Transportation

Stop The Unlawful Restrictions Placed On Intrastate Motor Carriers & The Traveling Consumer!!
 
Fact: Most municipalities in the State of Florida that hold the major transportation hubs that numerous Counties are reliant upon extort monies and restrict intrastate motor carriers from entering to load their prearranged and/or chartered passengers for transportation back home!
 
Fact: Under the influence of political pandering taxi companies, the local municipalities create under color of law, monopolies servicing the major transportation hubs servicing interstate commerce! 
 
Fact: Cab Owners serve as lobbyist for politicos serving as commissioners on business entry level decision boards!
 
Fact: The economic regulatory restrictions placed on intrastate motor carriers are in violation of Federal and Florida Statutes!
 
Fact: Residents in the State of Florida reliant on nonpublic forms of transportation are restricted in travel choices, type of service provisions and geographical limitations due to the States failure to enforce its own laws! 
 
Fact: State Senators Lee, Crist, Sebesta and Fasano have been apprised of this situation numerous times over the past 3 years and have failed to take corrective action! 
 
Send a message to the Governor and the Florida Attorney General that the unlawful restrictions placed on the intrastate motor carrier and the traveling consumers must stop!

Fact: Residents in the State of Florida reliant on nonpublic forms of transportation are restricted in travel choices, type of service provisions and geographical limitations due to the States failure to enforce its own laws! 
 
Fact: State Senators Lee, Crist, Sebesta and Fasano have been apprised of this situation numerous times over the past 3 years and have failed to take corrective action! 
 
Send a message to the Governor and the Florida Attorney General that the unlawful restrictions placed on the intrastate motor carrier and the traveling consumers must stop!

Subject:	ANSLEY PARK IN VERO BEACH FLORIDA

TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN:
I AM WRITING IN REGARDS TO A SAD SITUATION THAT IS TAKING PLACE IN OUR NEIGHBORHOOD.  ANSLEY PARK IS SURROUNDED BY BEAUTIFUL CONSERVATION AREAS WITH OLD LIVE OAKS, SWAYING PINE TREES AND NATURAL FLORIDA PALM TREES.  WHEN THIS DEVELOPMENT WAS BEING SOLD, THOSE OF US WHO WISHED TO HAVE PRIVACY PURCHASED ON THE "CONSERVATION" SIDE OF THE STREET ON ANSLEY AVE.  WE WERE ALL TOLD THAT  "CONVERSATION" AREAS WERE PROTECTED IN FLORIDA AND COULD NEVER BE DISTURBED.  OBVIOUSLY THAT IS NOT THE CASE IN VERO BEACH, THIS IS A VERY SAD THOUGHT NOT ONLY FOR ALL OF US WHO VALUED OUR PRIVACY AS WELL AS THE NATURAL BEAUTY, SHADE NATURAL HABITAT AND SECURITY IT PROVIDED US ALL.  WE ALL WOKE UP FRIDAY JULY 7TH TO 3 BULLDOZERS ON 31ST AVE BEHIND OUR HOMES LITERALLY DESTROYING MOST OF THE "CONSERVATION AREA" FOR THE SAKE OF ASPHALT......ASPHALT THAT IS PAVING A ROAD MORE THAN TWICE THE SIZE OF THE EXISTING ROAD THAT HAS BEEN THERE SINCE THAT STREET WAS BUILT.  THERE HAVE NOT BEEN ANY PROBLEMS WITH CARS PASSING ON THE EXISTING SIZE OF THIS STREET AND IT HASN'T PREVENTED ALL THE DRAG RACING THAT GOES ON DAILY, OR THE WEEKLY TRASH PICKUP, OR EVEN THE SCHOOL BUSES FROM PICKING UP ALL THE KIDS.  NOW IT SEEMS THE CONSERVATION AREA IS SECONDARY TO ALL AROUND IT INCLUDING THE HABITAT THAT CALLS THIS HOME.  THE AMAZING PART OF THIS STORY IS THAT NOT ONE PERSON IN THE ANSLEY PARK DEVELOPMENT KNEW ANYTHING ABOUT THIS DESTRUCTION TO THE NATURAL HABITAT, BEAUTIFUL OLD OAKS AND ALL THE NESTS THAT FILL THE TREES.  IT'S AS IF IT WAS SET UP AS A HIT AND RUN EFFORT TO GET IN, BULLDOZE ALL THESE OLD TREES, BURN THE GROUND AND MOVE ON BEFORE ANYONE COULD BRING THIS TO THE ATTENTION TO SOMEONE WHO MIGHT JUST CARE WHAT IS HAPPENING TO OUR NATURAL AREAS THAT "SHOULD" BE PROTECTED.................WHERE WILL THIS END, VERO IS A CHARMING BEAUTIFUL OLD HIDDEN TREASURE AND THAT'S WHY WE MOVED HERE FROM PALM BEACH.  WATCHING ALL THE BIRDS FILL THE MANY TREES EVERY MORNING AND LISTENING TO ALL THE FROGS AT NIGHT IS A VERY THERAPEUTIC PART OF LIVING HERE.  STARTING AGAIN JULY 10TH THE BULLDOZERS WILL CONTINUE WHAT THEY SET OUT TO DESTROY, THE "PROTECTED" NATURAL PRESERVE THAT HAS PROTECTED CONSERVATION SIGNS POSTED ALL THROUGH OUR NEIGHBORHOOD.  JUST WHAT IS PROTECTED HERE.... OBVIOUSLY NOTHING.   OUR PEACEFUL SMALL NEIGHBORHOOD IS NOW LOOSING THE CHARM THAT DREW ALL OF US TO LOVE WHAT NATURE OFFERED.  NOW NATURE IS BEING DESTROYED AND NO ONE CAN STOP THE 10 TON MONSTERS FROM CONTINUING THEIR QUEST.  IS ANYONE LISTENING ???? 

signed  PAGE FRANZEL, 

A VERY CONCERNED VERO RESIDENT, WHO VALUES THE NATURAL CONSERVATION THAT IS QUICKLY VANISHING

you MUST REPLACE THE TREES YOU REMOVE WITH A LIKE TREE.  This does  
not mean a sapling but a tree of substantial size.  You have created  
a situation that NONE of Ansley Park was aware of, and was never

Indian River is not one of those areas.

be GREATLY appreciated if we did hear from you.
This is a VERY serious situation for Ansley Park, so we hope you take

happening and if it shouldn't be happening STOP the process immediately.

James L. Guglielrno

America Reforming Florida's Homestead Act 
3588 Ivy Drive 
Bethpage, New York 11714-3314 
 

Dear Mr. Guglielrno; 
 
Your letter dated June 7, 2006, to Governor Bush and various attachments were forwarded to this office for response because the Department of Revenue- is the state agency charged with the responsibility of providing information pertaining to the local property tax to Florida property owners. You refer to the letter you received from the governor's office which mentioned a 2006 bill that was passed in which the Legislature commissions the Department of Revenue to conduct an in-depth study of the property tax structure. You make several suggestions as to what you perceive the Department should do pertaining to the study. 
 
While your suggestions are of merit, please be advised that according to the bill, the Department of Revenue must conduct the study as specified in the legislation, which requires specific items to be included and mandates the timeframes for the Department's completion. The Department of Revenue is required to prepare a draft of the study by November 15, 2006, and to conclude the study by January 2,  2007
 
The Office of Economic and Demographic Research is required to prepare a report summarizing the study conducted by the Department of Revenue. The report prepared by the Office of Economic and Demographic Research is required to contain findings and policy options that may be available to the state. The bill also provides that the Office of Economic and Demographic Research may contract with state universities or nationally recognized property appraisal education and certification organization for the purpose of developing findings and policy options to be included in the report. 
 
The legislation found in section 3., of HB 7109 did pass both houses and was enrolled. However, the bill has not been presented to the governor for approval or veto at this time. You may wish to monitor the progress of the bill at: http:/_/www.leg,state.fl,us/Welcome/lndex,cfm 

This response is not a policy statement or interpretation of state law or rules, but is provided for your information and assistance since the Department of Revenue does not administer property tax. 
 
You may also wish to provide your comments to the Office of Economic and Demographic Research since that office is charged with the responsibility of providing policy options resulting from the study.
 
 Sincerely,
 

Jane Marshall 
Tax Law Specialist 
 
JM 21686/608460
 
 
James L. Guglielmo
President
America Reforming Florida’s Homestead Act
3588 Ivy Drive
Bethpage. NY 11714-3314
June 7, 2006
 
Dear Governor Bush:
 
Enclose is a packet with letters pertaining to our up-to-date stance, as to our organization’s on going  determination to undue Florida’s tax flaws. These letters where also E-mailed to you and others a few days ago. It is imperative that we also mail (via USPS) you a hard copy of this packet, for the purpose of assurance of receipt.
 
Your letter (May 12, 2006) mentions that the legislature commissioned the Florida Department of Revenue to conduct an in-dept study of the property tax structure.  In my dealing with Florida establishing of the newly created ombudsman, for over seeing condominium board’s deportment, Great friction developed by key Florida’s departments, as to whose jurisdiction this newly formed body falls under When it was obvious to any layperson, what department is to be held accountable for ombudsman’s operation. In view of my past involvement  and the outcome of ombudsman,  I foresee little will be achieved  in overhauling the property tax structure; without the following being employed, unless already  in place:
 
1.     The revenue department should submit schedule progress reports, on their property tax changes.
2.    Schedule meetings must be conducted with the department of revenue and key personnel, as to progress, recommendations and unforeseen problems confronting the revenue department.
3.    A schedule time of completing their property tax changes with their proposals. Sufficient time for the legislated body to study and intelligently act. 
4.    If need be, seek expert input from without the Florida legislative structure.

Dear Governor Bush: 
 
Our organization appreciates your letter mailed to me and is posted below, for others to read. 
 
In resolving the complexity of the numerous problems that the Florida Legislature struggled with this past session, I recommend that the many inequities of our current tax structure should be resolved “one frame at a time;” instead of confronting the entire aspect of this tax deformity, in one session. The first and simplest reformation and greatest gravity of all Florida’s tax deficiencies, because of federal Constitutional Civil rights violation…Caused by the excessive taxation imposed on seasonal (Snow Birds) visitors, who have no legal representation. 
 
In viewing the entire tax deficiency as a whole, two main obstacles are obscuring any progress in rectifying Florida‘s tax system, (the second is the simplest to rectify) and they are as follows: 
 
1. Law makers should approach with tenacity, the approving of Florida’s Constitution, to repeal prohibition against state personal income tax. With Florida leading the nation in job and economic boom, Floridians must be educated to this pliable means of taxation, as testified by other states. 
 
2. The “Golden Egg” hatched by Snow Birds is a difficult tax to resolve, that was enacted subjectively. In addition, viewed as a lucrative income for Florida’s treasury, which is in my point of view, a perpetual criminal act, condone by our legislators in Tallahassee. 
 
I have written letters in the past advocating intervention by states whose constituents,’ constitutional civil rights, are violated. Presently response has been nil. If no satisfaction is evident from said states, then intervention is mandatory by our federal government. 
 
Our doctrine dictates, that we will continue to pursue this subject matter, even when it appears dormant by our Florida legislators. It is vigorously engaged (because it is morally wrong) until we Snow Birds receive equal civil rights as enjoyed by our brethren Floridians. 
 
Sincerely, 
 
 
 
James L. Guglielmo
President
ARFHA
(516) 681-9881

STATE OF FLORIDA

Mr. James L. Gugliclrno 
Americans. Reforming Florida's Homestead Act

Hollywood. Florida 33021-7933 

 
 
Dear Mr. Guglieimo: 

 
Thank you for your letter to Governor Bush regarding property taxes and the need for a state personal income tax. Governor Bush has asked me to respond on his behalf. 

 
 
Governor Bush certainly appreciates your concerns regarding the increasingly unfair property tax burden on non-residents in Florida. This is but one of several inequities in our properly tax structure which have become more apparent in recent years. In fact. in its recently ended regular session, the Florida Legislature struggled with all of these issues, but could not find a comprehensive solution because of the complexity of the problem 
 
Consequently, the Legislature commissioned the Florida Department of Revenue to conduct an in-depth study of the property lax structure, with special emphasis on the unequal effects among various groups of taxpayers. 1 know that this sounds like they are trying to avoid the issue, but in all honesty- a thorough understanding of all the consequences of any changes in Florida's property tax system must come before concrete proposals are put forth. This is particularly important because the changes that are likely to be needed will require amendments to the Florida Constitution, which will, in turn. require voter approval. The voters would also have to approve a change in the Florida Constitution to repeal the prohibition against a state personal income tax. 

 
 
Governor Bush definitely recognizes the value that part-time residents bring to our state. That is one reason why he supports further study of the issue so we can understand the best solutions. even though he will be leaving office at the end of this year. 

 
Thank you again for contacting Governor Bush with your concerns. He always appreciates hearing from Florida taxpayers, whether they are permanent residents or seasonal visitors. 
.Sincerely.                     .,
 
Don Langston   
Policy Coordinator 
Finance and Economic Analysis 
DI/msv
 
 
 
James L. Guglielmo
President
America Reforming Florida’s Homestead Act
3588 Ivy Drive
Bethpage, NY 11714-3314
April 27, 2006 
 

Dear Governor Bush: 
 
Our organization has written to you in the past about this current Homestead Act, raising havoc with Florida’s current crop of Snow Birds. We call ourselves “crop of Snow Birds” because we coop in Florida (as per Mayo's article April 13, 2006 Sun-Sentinel) during the winter months, only to eventually be slaughtered (financially) by those with indifference and/or biased Temperament... our so-called Florida lawmakers. We snowbirds are very proud of our ancestors, as to how they structured our constitution… only sorely now, to see it slowly being erroneously interpreted/ ignored by those who deliberately or unknowing levy taxation with disregard toward their fellow Americans' rights, their constitutional rights being violated. If this is not bias practice by our legislators, than it is immaturity. 
 

I may sound emotional in this letter; it is just what kind of feedback I am receiving from my fellow Americans and Foreign friends. -I have been in many precarious situations during my careers, maintaining my composure; I was able to succeed in overcoming the crisis so confronted at the time. However, when confronted with indifference, it is a sorrowful situation that only individuals who have experienced such difficulties can appreciate what I am attempting to relate. Under such trying circumstances, people at times` through frustrations, resort to unorthodox means, to gain some degree of redress from an unjust stigma. At times, such means causes great hardship for all, before the cause is resolved in accordance to our statute. Our legislators can avoid .Such a predicament. 
 

Below is attached a letter I have received from my insurance company. That was waiting for me when I arrived at my "home base," I refer you to the high lighted Paragraph in the letter dated Jan.23, 2006. Now we snow birds must supplement the beleaguered state-run Citizen’s Property Insurance Corp… Implemented for water front properties.  Water front property that is unable to purchase private insurance. My condominium is located three miles west of I-95. I can only call it a “double whammy.” for Snow Birds.
 

How can our legislators execute their responsibilities with a clear conscious? There is something erratically wrong.  One recommendation: insert innovation when planning budgets and taxation. Digress` from this current criteria [in legislating] that is Florida's mod style. 
 

Refine the method employed to distinguish those destitute and those fortunate. One method to mandate... those required to prepare federal tax returns should be compelled to attach a copy (of their federal tax return) to their Florida property taxes when payment is due. Those fortunate Floridians should be required to pay their fair share of Florida property taxes.  To expedite the implementation of federal returns attached to Florida property tax payment, Federal Individual Income tax return data is available from Federal Internal Revenue Bureau. A branch of government, that is available to assists, coming under the heading of Mutual Assistance. 
 

In my estimation, this current system of taxation, by our current crop of legislators are abusing there inherent constitutional powers. Alternatively, lack the intelligence to see that they are straying, from the very fibers of our federal constitutional laws. This is a perfect example what develops, when subjectivity prevails. 
 

This Homestead Act is a form of coercion, compelling citizens to relinquish their freedom of choice in choosing their permanent residency.  
 

I must impress all that have received a copy of this letter and previous letters, ( E-mailed and/or conventional mailing,  pertaining to Homestead Act) who have vested authority granted under our Federal Constitution, are morally required to initiate through direct intervention and or coordination, the means necessary within their authorization, the assistance required to resolve these discriminatory practices. Refraining from involvement violates their elected office, commensurate with condoning such discriminatory laws.  Dispassionate display by our elected officials is the inception of the fall of These United States. This is what our organization believes. 
 

My apology… I attempted to high light the paragraph below, but it did not develop to my expectation. However, you can see clearly the 6.8 percent increases in insurance premiums. 
 

Please respond. 
 
Sincerely, 
 
James L. Guglielmo
President
ARFHA
(516) 681-9881 

 
 
 
 
 
News Columnist 
 
?Michael Mayo
Back to recent columns 
 
With property tax bills soaring, snowbirds might fly their Florida coops
Published April 13, 2006, SUN-SENTINEL
 
There's nothing more annoying than being scrunched into a middle seat on a long flight and overhearing the guy on the aisle brag about his cheap fare, hundreds less than yours. That's sort of how Ellen and Lawrence Klein of Hollywood feel when they get their property tax bill every year.
 
The Kleins are snowbirds who spend winters in Hollywood and the rest of the year in Queens. Because New York is their primary residence, they don't qualify for the $25,000 Florida homestead exemption or the Save Our Homes cap, which limits the rise in assessed value to 3 percent a year.
 
Last year, the tax bill for their one-bedroom, 800-square-foot condo was $1,724, an 18 percent increase over the previous year. Their next-door neighbors, full-time residents who bought into the Hillcrest East building seven years after they did, paid $161.
 
"It's outrageous," said Ellen Klein, 74. "And it's not fair."
 
After all, they're only here five months a year, which means they use less than half the city and county services that year-round residents do. Yet they pay more. Much more.
 
"We end up subsidizing everyone else," said Lawrence Klein, 78, a retired mechanic, U.S. Army veteran and an Auschwitz survivor.
 
The Kleins, who bought the unit for $33,000 in 1988 and paid $580 in property tax that year, live on a fixed income. After seeing their property tax bill double in the last three years, they don't know how much longer they can afford a winter retreat. They say their Florida property tax now exceeds the tax on their Kew Gardens house.
 
"If the taxes keep going up like this, we might be forced to sell," Lawrence Klein said Wednesday. "We'll be back next season, but after that I don't know."
 
Snowbirds are an easy mark, Florida politicians figure, because they do not vote here.
 
And it's no longer just property tax. To bail out the beleaguered state-run Citizen's Property Insurance Corp., legislators are considering special surcharges on policies covering vacation and second homes.
 
The rationale: Those who can afford second homes can afford the expenses that come with them.
 
But the Kleins and other seasonal residents say they're getting to the point where they can't.
 
"You have to cut back on things," Ellen Klein said. "We don't go to shows anymore, we haven't been to the movies all winter. We eat out less, try not to drive much. We used to play golf every week, now we play every other week."
 
As legislators mull certain property tax reforms -- "portability" for homesteaded residents who move, increased exemptions for first-time buyers and public servants such as teachers and police -- there's no concern or proposed relief for seasonal residents.
 
"It's like we're second-class citizens," Ellen Klein said.
 
"Excessive taxation without representation," said James Guglielmo, a winter resident since 1982 at Hillcrest East who has started a grassroots group to protest the tax disparity. His tax bill is nearing $2,000.
 
So why don't snowbirds such as Guglielmo, who returned to his Long Island home this week, and the Kleins simply declare Florida their primary residence? They say that would trigger other tax consequences if they don't first sell their New York homes. And they don't want to.
 
"My grandchildren are there," Ellen Klein said.
 
So now they find themselves squeezed, on the verge of quitting the winter lifestyle they love.
 
Broward Property Appraiser Lori Parrish says don't blame her for enforcing the law. Of 206,000 residential properties without homestead exemptions in Broward, she estimates 70,000 to 80,000 belong to seasonal residents. She said they all have a chance at getting equal treatment by filing for homestead status, but they choose not to.
 
"I feel for everyone, but it's just the way the system works," Parrish said. "My main concern is for the people who live here year-round who can't afford even one home."
 
Said Lawrence Klein: "Over the years we've spent a lot of money here. You get the feeling they're trying to chase us away."
 
Michael Mayo can be reached at mmayo@sun-sentinel.com or 954-356-4508.
 
WALL STREET JOURNAL
 
Tropical Storm
Florida Snowbirds
Challenge Fairness
Of Two-Tier Tax
No Shield From Rising Bills
For Seasonal Residents;
Who Pays for Growth? 
'For Sale' Sign in Longboat Key 
By RAFAEL GERENA-MORALES
 
May 22, 2006; Page A1
 
In late March, hundreds of Florida homeowners jammed the chambers of county commissioners in Fort Pierce, Fla., to protest rising property taxes. Ed McIntosh, a 75-year-old retiree, showed up with a foot-tall stack of complaints from homeowners, 623 letters in all.

He read a batch of them aloud, one tale after another of seasonal residents juggling rising insurance costs, hurricane-repair bills and escalating property taxes, which have more than doubled in five years in parts of the state.

 
Such protests have become commonplace in Florida as the state's snowbirds -- winter residents, who are mostly retirees from the Northeast, Midwest and Canada -- fight back against a tax system they believe is unfair and onerous. Mr. McIntosh, a retired Ford Motor Co. finance manager who lives in Beulah, Mich., spends four months a year along the Atlantic coast in Jensen Beach. He complains that seasonal residents are "being discriminated against...We're carrying the state on our backs."

All across the country, homeowners are complaining about runaway property taxes. In many places, sharp increases in home values are to blame. But Florida's snowbirds are angry about something else -- an unusual dual-bracket tax system. Florida allows municipalities to set the taxable value of properties at different levels for permanent and seasonal residents. There have been cases of snowbirds paying property taxes 10 times as high as those of permanent residents living nearby.

 
Records of the St. Lucie County Property Appraiser show, for example, that one permanent resident of Jensen Beach pays $271 a year in property taxes on a 408-square-foot mobile home built in 1984. Four houses away, a seasonal resident from Pennsylvania pays $3,007 for a 420-square-foot mobile home built in 1987, the records show. The two lots are nearly the same size, according to the records.

The disparities can be "extreme," says Ken Emens, a 59-year-old retiree from New Jersey who became a permanent Florida resident in November. "If anything, part-timers should get a discount because they demand less services," he says.

 
Not surprisingly, many full-time Florida residents, who are shielded by law from big 
property-tax hikes, don't see it that way. Kenneth Wilkinson, a property appraiser from Fort Myers who pushed for the two-tier system, says anyone who owns a second home in Florida should bear higher property taxes because "they created the problem" of rising real-estate values by bidding up prices and by increasing the need for local services.

 
At the heart of the debate: Who should pay for the state's rapid growth? Florida gains, on average, about 1,000 new residents a day, according to the state's economic and demographic research office. It is growing at the third-fastest clip in the nation, after Nevada and Arizona.

Senior citizens led prior growth spurts. This one includes many young families with children. Public-school enrollment has risen about 10% since 2000, leaving localities struggling to pay for additional classrooms and more teachers. County spending on public safety rose nearly 40% between the 2000 and 2004 fiscal years, according to the Florida Department of Financial Services. Transportation-infrastructure spending jumped 42% over the same period.

 
 
In Florida, one of a handful of states that doesn't tax personal income, such costs are mainly the responsibility of county governments. Increasingly, those counties are passing along the costs to the snowbirds, who don't vote.

 
Florida's seasonal residents "are getting slammed," says Dominic M. Calabro, president of Florida TaxWatch, a nonpartisan government watchdog group in Tallahassee. There has been "a tax shift" from permanent to seasonal residents, he says. "We're hearing from people from out of state who are getting hit with extraordinarily high taxes. They're mad as heck and not going to take it anymore."

Florida's two-tier system is rooted partly in a "homestead" exemption that dates back many years. The exemption currently provides permanent residents of the state with an automatic $25,000 reduction in the assessed value of their primary homes. In addition, an amendment to the state constitution that went into effect in 1995, called Save Our Homes, caps the annual increase in assessed property values and taxes at 3% or the rate of inflation, whichever is lower. That too applies only to the primary homes of permanent residents.

 
 
Anyone who owns a home in Florida can become a permanent resident, no matter how much time the homeowner spends in state. A homeowner needs only to submit an affidavit stating his Florida home is his permanent residence. But many snowbirds are unwilling, because switching permanent residence would mean giving up tax breaks or other benefits they get from their home state or nation.

 
For Florida's permanent residents, the property-tax savings have been substantial and are growing. Last year, 28% of the value of Florida's residential real estate, or $362.2 billion in value, was shielded from property taxes, according to Florida's Department of Revenue. That cut the average property-tax bill on the primary homes of state residents by $1,600, the state said.

Property owners who don't qualify as permanent residents, as well as Florida residents who own second homes or rental properties, have watched property-tax bills double over the past five years in many areas.

 
 
Florida isn't the only state to protect some residents from rising property taxes. Many other states limit increases for the elderly or poor. California's landmark Proposition 13 caps property-tax increases on all homes, regardless of the residency status of owners. As a result, when California homes change hands, taxes on them often jump sharply, which has created a disparity between the tax bills of new and longtime homeowners that has drawn criticism. In Florida, recent home buyers who are permanent residents often voice similar complaints, and are as critical of disparities in the state's tax system as are snowbirds.

 
Mr. Wilkinson, the elected real-estate appraiser of Florida's Lee County, calls himself the "proud father" of the Save Our Homes amendment. During the 1980s, property values in parts of Florida were rising at double-digit annual rates. Some residents, especially retirees, worried about being taxed out of their homes. After fielding hundreds of complaints about appraisals, Mr. Wilkinson launched a statewide campaign to cap increases.

 
He spent his weekends collecting signatures at music festivals and other events across the state. It took him four years to amass the more than 600,000 signatures necessary to put the issue on the state's ballot. Florida voters approved the amendment in 1992, and it took effect in 1995.

 
Few full-time Florida residents sympathize with the tax plight of seasonal residents, who are widely perceived to be rich Northerners who can afford to subsidize Florida's growing needs. "These are second homes for them," says Daryl Wilmoth, 57, a Boca Raton resident and retired boat captain in the marine-dredging industry. "If they're prosperous enough to afford two houses, then I think they're prosperous enough to pay the current property-tax rate on their homes." Florida residents who have lived in their homes for a long time deserve the lower tax bills, he says.

 
Florida's average part-time resident isn't as rich as many Floridians imagine. The average annual income of seasonal residents is about $63,000, compared with roughly $53,000 for permanent residents, according to the University of Florida's Bureau of Economic and Business Research. One in five seasonal residents lives in a mobile home, double the rate for full-time residents, bureau data shows.

"Most of the snowbirds are middle-class," says Lance deHaven-Smith, a Florida State University political-science professor. "They're factory workers, truck drivers, people who sold cars, people who worked all their lives. For them, Florida was a dream...The vast majority are cost sensitive."

 
 
Florida has been trying to attract seasonal residents since the early 1900s, when railroad tracks were laid from Jacksonville to Key West, providing easy access for out-of-staters. Various industrial titans became part-time residents, including Thomas Edison, who had a home built in Fort Myers. After World War II, people of more modest means began buying winter bungalows. In 1965, Social Security benefits were benchmarked to inflation and Medicare health benefits were added, boosting the income and financial security of many retirees. Florida became the retirement choice of the masses.

 
Florida now attracts an estimated 1.2 million part-time winter residents, according to the University of Florida's economic-research bureau. The influx represents about 6.3% of the state's peak winter population.

 
Mr. McIntosh, the retired Ford manager, expects to pay about $7,000 in property taxes on his two-bedroom, 850-square-foot home along the Atlantic coast north of Palm Beach. He bought it in November to replace one bought in 1995 and destroyed by a hurricane in 2004.
In January, angry about tax increases, Mr. McIntosh formed a group of seasonal residents to lobby for lower tax rates and for the extension of property-tax caps to seasonal residents. He has fired off hundreds of letters, spoken at meetings of property owners and condominium associations, and appeared on public-access cable television. He has written to a half-dozen Florida legislators and to Gov. Jeb Bush seeking support. Mr. McIntosh's appearance in March before commissioners of St. Lucie County -- with 300 supporters in tow -- was part of that campaign. A spokeswoman for the county commission says that commissioners have discussed reducing tax rates.

Gov. Bush has said the state's property tax caps have created "inequities" by placing a heavier tax burden on new home buyers, seasonal residents and business owners, and that possible solutions should be studied, his spokesman says.

 
 
Any change to the Save Our Homes amendment would require the approval of Florida voters, which many experts say is unlikely. During the legislative session that ended this month, Florida lawmakers proposed a half-dozen different property-tax relief bills, including one to extend tax caps to everyone. None were approved. The state legislature is expected to conduct a study of the state's property tax system next year.

Mr. McIntosh says he will press on. Other seasonal residents are considering leaving. In February, the Morrisey family put their two-bedroom cottage up for sale, in large part because of the rise in property taxes -- to $4,600 in 2005 from $1,800 in 2000. Tom Morrisey, a 55-year-old farmer and beekeeper, says that on his 20-acre farm in Orillia, Ontario, property taxes come to $800 a year. "It's sad," he says, to sell a home due to rising property taxes. The Morriseys have owned the 830-square foot property in Longboat Key, north of Sarasota on the Gulf Coast, for more than 35 years.

 
Another seasonal resident of Longboat Key, Norman Sommers, says he and his wife intend to visit Scottsdale, Ariz., in October to investigate relocating there. Mr. Sommers, 86, a Michigan resident, complains he's paying more than $10,000 a year in taxes on his two-bedroom condo. That's nearly double what permanent Florida residents are paying for similar units in his building, he says.

"I believe in supporting schools, but I don't feel I should pay more than people who live here all year round," he says. "There's only so much I'm willing to take."

 
 
Florida's courts haven't ruled on the legality of the Save Our Homes amendment, although the Florida Supreme Court has upheld the validity of the state's homestead exemption.
Pat Thacke, 61, a New Jersey resident with a two-bedroom condominium in Port St. Lucie, says she has called 25 Florida law firms looking for someone to handle a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of Florida's property-tax system. For 35 years, she and her husband have spent part of each year in Florida. This year they expect to pay more than $4,000 in property taxes, while a permanent Florida resident with an identical unit across the hall will likely pay about $750, she calculates.

So far, she has been unable to find a lawyer willing to handle a suit. "I feel like I'm being discriminated against," says Ms. Thacke, a retired hospital switchboard operator. "This is taxation without representation...The Florida snowbirds need another Boston Tea Party."

family.  The police report also states that he was
confrontational and provocatory against the Conner
family.  This behavior of Matthew's was supposed to
have taken place on the infamous day that both his
house and mine were assaulted by Molotov cocktails.

been accused of this behavior, but has not been
allowed to counter them, even though there are
eyewitnesses that can directly contradict all the
nonsensical accusations.   Matthew has been informed
that because of his behavior, as stated by this
"police report", he has been dropped from Crime Watch.

member happens to be one of the eyewitnesses of the
entire fiasco of that day.  There have been no phone

home where he has had to bring an "African-American"
governmental representative to task for using the "N"
word in his home.  This representative was telling an
anecdote and I assume did not realize the
inappropriateness of using that word, even under those
circumstances.  Matthew does not resort to low and
ugly behavior like that, even though that sort of
behavior has been very openly directed toward him time
and time again.

Subject:	Recent MsNBC Questions: A GoodWill Hunting Story?

  
Sunday, July 09, 2006


Recent MsNBC Questions: A GoodWill Hunting Story? 


A GoodWill Hunting Story:

A number of people have suggested thinking differently, ending bickering and/or fostering [global] cooperation?

Recently Officials at the University of Cambridge, where Stephen Hawking is a mathematics professor, confirmed that Hawking wrote a message but said he would have no further comment. Hawking's question: "In a world that is in chaos politically, socially and environmentally, how can the human race sustain another 100 years?"

Hawking's groundbreaking research on black holes and the origins of the universe has made him one of the best-known theoretical physicists of his generation. Author of the global best seller "A Brief History of Time," Hawking is known for proposing that space and time have no beginning and no end - [but human life always will].

Lately, he's been pondering about the fate of [the] human [race].

In a June 13 speech in Hong Kong, Hawking said the survival of the human race depends on its ability to find new homes elsewhere in the universe because there's an increasing risk that a disaster will destroy Earth.

He said that if humans can avoid killing themselves in the next 100 years, they should have space settlements that can continue without support from Earth.

Hawking is one of 10 celebrity questioners Yahoo solicited as part of its "Ask The Planet" campaign. The Sunnyvale, Calif., Internet company spent weeks trying to track 

Hawking down but got his participation within a day of reaching the correct assistant, said Patrick Crane, vice president of marketing for Yahoo Search. The question was submitted a few days before the Hong Kong speech and posted this past Wednesday.

Over the next week, Yahoo employees are expected to work with Hawking to sift through the answers and select one or several to highlight as best responses.

Yahoo Answers, like an offering from Google Inc. And one planned by Microsoft Corp., is among the services aimed at tapping the collective intelligence. It's based on the premise that humans as a group can do a better job at finding information than machines or any single person can.

Anyone can ask or answer a question, regardless of expertise, although Yahoo will eventually implement a rating system meant to elevate users with better reputations, based on their past [experience] in asking [meaningful questions] and getting [solid meaningful] answers [from those with the political will, finances and a global super power willing to help to make it happen].

Past celebrity participants include Donald Trump, Isaiah Washington, Al Gore and "Click & Clack," the hosts of NPR's "Car Talk." U2 lead singer Bono closed the celebrity series Friday by asking, "What can we do to make poverty and the destruction of family unity history?"

Subject:	Welcome to the Governor's Ex-Offender Taskforce

  


Welcome to the Governor's Ex-Offender Taskforce - ARE NOT non-custodial Mom's and Dad's in need of the Same Protections in our Society Today? 


THE LAND OF THE SECOND CHANCE

One State recently announced a NEW program - Florida is committed to the ideal of America being the land of second chances, as expressed by the President of the United States who declared: "When the gates of the prison open, the path ahead should lead to a better life."

There are currently 86,000 inmates in Florida's prisons, of which over 26,000 are expected to be released within the coming year.

Successful reentry and reintegration in one's community is a matter of critical import to the public's safety.

Without successful re-entry into one's community, recidivism is likely to occur, to the great detriment to the public safety, Florida's communities, families, taxpayers, and individual ex-offenders.

There is hereby created the Governor's Ex-Offender Task Force formed to help improve the effectiveness of the State of Florida in facilitating the re-entry of ex-offenders into their communities so as to reduce the incidence of recidivism.

Governors' Charge to the Task Force:

1. Identify barriers to successful reentry - legal, policy, structural, organizational, and practical barriers to successful reentry.
2. Recommend reforms that will eliminate barriers to successful reentry
3. Recommend implementation strategies.
4. Recommend measures to assess the effectiveness of the reforms.

THE NEXT TASK FORCE MEETING:

Monday, June 26 at the Quorum Hotel in Tampa, FL from 9:00 am to 5:00 PM

The Ex-offender Re-entry Summit sponsored by the US Attorney's Office and Abe Brown Ministries on June 27-28

From:	Julie Ann Waid <julieann@waidwrites.com>
Sent:	Sunday, July 9, 2006 12:24 PM
To:	energy@dep.state.fl.us
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Proposed Energy Plan

Dear Florida DEP & Governor Bush:
 
I think the proposed energy plan is an excellent first step.  Investing in alternative energy and conservation efforts is not just an investment in dollars, it's an investment in our future and the future of our children.
 
We have reached a "now or never" point when it comes to our dependance on fossil fuel and what it means to the continuing deterioration of our planet--the only one we've got!  Critics say we may be saving dollars and jobs now by not investing in alternative fuel technologies and conservation efforts, but the price our planet and our children will pay in the very-near future will fundamentally eclipse any "dollar savings" we get by not investing in alternative energy sources.  They will pay with their lives, and as a Floridian, an American, and a resident of this planet---this scenario scares me to death. 
 
I'm not anyone special--just an ordinary taxpayer with an eleven-week-old nephew I love more than life itself, and I want nothing more than for him to inherit a safe, clean world.  He doesn't deserve the road we've put him on, but WE HAVE THE POWER TO STOP IT!  All we have to do... is do it. 
 
I applaud Governor Bush for this very important Act and I hope its implementation is swift and results of its efforts even swifter.  Please, if we don't make the effort to save our children and their world---who's going to?
 
Sincerely,
Julie Ann Waid
Coconut Creek, FL 
julieann@waidwrites.com

President Bush has a new body language, he throws his arms out wide and shrugs his shoulders and gets a perplexed look; he shows us he is extremely anxious, everything he does is wrong and he is called a liar and a reprobate. It is the look of a man who has no clue, whose faith in his wisdom has been sorely tested by bad experience; yet, he persists in the same old failed policies with the same old failed advisers. It’s hard being the President of the United States. It’s impossible, you can’t please any of the people any of the time. It is especially lousy when the “Best and Brightest,” the supposed elite thinkers of America, are no better than the rabble. Just look at the ranting of Paul Krugman (and Krugman has some good ideas) when it comes to Bush, it’s nasty and personal and has nothing to do with ideas or disagreements on issues.

 

President Bush represents America. Most of his policies are what we wanted. We wanted lower taxes; we wanted the war on terrorism and we relished the thought of easy victory in Iraq. We as a nation are just as perplexed as Bush our minds have not caught up with our problems and we are in a time warp fighting new battles with old and tired solutions, solutions that should find their place in the nearest land fill, a land fill fortified to keep the contamination from eroding into the rivers of our minds. It is too late, our minds are a reservoir for the inane, a cesspool of putrefied garbage. And we, in our effete dash of splendor, adorn the adulterated truth by pronouncing our incompetence with a French flair “Garrr...bage.”
