Fiscal Year 2006-2007 Final Budget
 
GOVERNOR BUSH SIGNS FISCALLY RESPONSIBLE BUDGET WITH RECORD INCREASES IN FUNDING FOR EDUCATION 
 
TALLAHASSEE – Joined by Lt. Governor Toni Jennings, Governor Jeb Bush today signed a $73.9 billion budget for fiscal year 2006-2007, building on the conservative fiscal management policies that have spurred economic growth and increased revenues for state government. The budget funds state priorities, including record increases in funding for education, while cutting taxes by $298 million and setting aside $6.4 billion in reserves.
 
“I want to thank the members of the Florida Legislature – especially President Tom Lee and Speaker Allan Bense – for their leadership and hard work,” said Governor Bush. “This budget funds the priorities of the State of Florida. It highlights the importance of providing a quality education to each and every child – especially those facing challenges in learning.”
 
This budget represents Florida’s conservative approach to government. Spending taxpayers’ hard-earned money demands responsibility and accountability. During the last eight years, the state has combined significant reform with increased funding to yield the best results for Floridians.
 
CONTINUING FLORIDA’S RISING STUDENT ACHIVEMENT
 
A quality education gives a child the best opportunity to succeed in life. The single most important thing the state can do to grow Florida’s economy for the future is to provide a quality education to each and every child.
 
Funding for education is the centerpiece of this year’s budget. This year, the state is providing $32.6 billion for education, an increase of $3.9 billion or 13.5 percent. 
 
Increased funding does not work without reform. Seven years ago, Florida embarked on a sweeping overhaul of the state’s education system – a transformation that is still just beginning. Governor Bush’s education reforms have been based on high standards and expectations, clear measurement and accountability and rewards and consequences for results. Funding is important, but maintaining focus on results will ensure Florida’s schools and students continue to make progress.
 
Voluntary Pre-kindergarten Program
 
The state is providing $390.6 million, or an average of $2,560 per child, so more than 144,000 four-year-olds can participate in high-quality education programs that prepare children to read and succeed in school. 
 
K-12 Public Schools
 
The state is providing $18.8 billion, an increase of $1.8 billion or 10.76 percent, to fund public schools from kindergarten through high school. This increase results in funding of $7,004 per student, an increase of $542 or nearly 9 percent. 
 
· $2.2 billion, an increase of $644 million or nearly 43 percent, is provided to implement the class-size constitutional amendment. An additional $1.1 billion is also being provided for school construction to reduce class size. Since 2003, Florida has spent $7 billion to meet its obligations under the constitution to reduce class sizes
 
Reading
 
Reading is fundamental to the success of a child’s entire education. The state is providing $111.8 million, an increase of $22.8 million or more than 25 percent, for reading initiatives. The money will be used for intervention, instruction and teacher training to ensure the value of reading is institutionalized in Florida’s primary education system.
 
The state is also providing $18.5 million, an increase of $8.5 million or 85 percent, to expand reading initiatives launched under Just Read Florida! Funding will expand training for principals and teachers in all grades and for the parents of struggling readers in elementary and middle schools.
 
Teachers
 
This year, the state is launching a statewide bonus plan for teachers. The state is providing $147.5 million for the STAR (Special Teachers are Rewarded) Performance Play Plan. Under the program, 25 percent of the state’s highest performing teachers are eligible for a bonus of at least 5 percent of their salary.
 
Higher Education
 
The budget provides $1.66 billion, an increase of $116.4 million or 7.5 percent, for community colleges and $3.5 billion, an increase of $366.5 million or 11.8 percent, for universities. The university budget includes $103 million for new programs created in substantive legislation, including:
· $20 million for the World Class Scholars Program 
· $30 million for the Centers of Excellence 
· $45 million for the Research and Economic Development Investment Program 
 
Need based financial aid
 
For young people pursuing their dream of a college education, the state is also providing $120.5 million in need-based financial aid, an increase of $21.7 million or 21.9 percent. 
 
Workforce Education
 
The budget provides $17.5 million for the Ready to Work Initiative to provide the necessary training and industry certifications for skilled workers and craftsmen. An additional $12 million is provided to continue training up to 11,000 workers for Florida’s construction industry. 
 
The budget also provides $34.5 million for SUCCEED Florida, which funds career academies and programs for nursing and allied health, teaching and manufacturing and automotive technology.
 
The results of these education reforms, combined with funding increases, are extraordinary. 
 
· Today, more of Florida’s students than ever are reading on their own.
· 75 percent of Florida’s third graders, including 61 percent of African-American and 70 percent of Hispanic children, are reading at or above grade level, compared to only 48 percent in 1999.
· According to the 2005 National Assessment of Educational Progress, Florida again surpassed the national average in fourth-grade reading and, for the first time, bettered the national average in fourth-grade mathematics. 
· According to the national norm reference test, Florida students are outperforming their counterparts in every grade.
· More students, including an increasing number of minority students, are taking college entrance exams. More than 93,500 – 65 percent – of Florida’s 2005 high school graduates took the SAT and 58,000 of these students took the ACT.
· Florida’s high school graduation rate is up and Florida’s dropout rate is down.

Sincerely,
 
Mr. Chuck Schroeder
7496 18th Street North
St. Petersburg, FL. 33702
 
From:	Chester Lee McWhorter <alarictgoth@gowebco.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 3:39 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; Neil Cavuto
Cc:	Cristy Loftis; Christy LeMire
Subject:	The Emancipation Prorclamation (A Farce)

THE GENERALLY MISUNDERSTOOD EMANCIPATION PROCLAMATION

The Gray Book, by the Sons Of Confederate Veterans, General Hqs, Box 5164, Southern Station, Hattiesburg, Mississippi, C. S. A. 

There is no document so little read or so misunderstood as the Emancipation Proclamation—

there is no subject so entirely misstated as Lincoln’s connection with, and attitude toward, freeing the negro.

Lincoln, who never freed a slave, is called "The Emancipator", while The Emancipation Proclamation, a war measure of the sternest description, holding within its possibilities an untold measure of woe for the South, is almost universally hailed as a great "humanitarian" document!

To those who wish to know the truth, attention is directed to these several points especially–the document is self-styled "a war measure; it not only did not free a single slave (this was done long afterward by Congressional action and the 13th amendment) but it expressly and particularly continued to hold in bondage the only slaves it could have freed, viz., those in country held by Federal armies and under the jurisdiction of the United States government; intended as a war measure to demoralize the South and destroy the morale of Southern armies is a pointed hint at servile insurrection in paragraph third from the last in the proclamation of January 1st , 1863.

Attention is also called to Lincoln’s attitude toward freeing the negro, as clearly expressed by him in a letter to Horace Greeley, just prior to issuing the proclamation.

This letter, inserted below, is copied faithfully from the files of the New York Tribune now in the Congressional Library. It most abundantly speaks for itself. In it Lincoln makes use of expressions which entirely dispose of any claim that he was waging war to free the slaves and which confound those who so persistently misrepresent the causes of the war between the states.

"My paramount object," he says, "in this struggle is to save the Union, and is not, either to save or destroy slavery. If I could save the Union without freeing any slave I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves, I would do it. What I do about slavery and the colored race I do because I believe it helps to save the Union"

This letter and the terms and restrictions of the Proclamation itself show beyond any doubt the entirely war-like purpose of the proclamation and the entire absence of any humanitarian element either in Lincoln’s purposes in promulgating it or in the provisions of the instrument itself.

Lincoln’s Letter to Greeley (from Vol 22 New York Tribune, August 25, 1862, page 4, column 3, on file in Congressional Library) with a few preliminary and non-essential sentences omitted.

Executive Mansion, Washington,

August 22, 1862.

"Hon. Horace Greeley:

Dear Sir:

I would save the Union. I would save it the shortest way under the constitution. The sooner the National authority can be restored, the nearer the Union will be "the Union it was." If there be those who would not save the Union unless they could at the same time save slavery, I do not agree with them. My paramount (object to) those who would not save the Union unless they could at the same time destroy slavery, I do not agree with them. My paramount object in this struggle is to save the Union, and is not either to save or destroy slavery. If I could save the Union without freeing slaves, I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone, I would also do that. What I do about slavery and the colored race, I do because I believe it helps to save this Union; and what I forebear, I forebear because I do not believe it would help to save the Union. I have here stated my purpose according to my view of official duty and I intend no modification of my oft expressed personal wish that all men, everywhere, could be free.

	Yours,

	A. Lincoln."

Here follows the preliminary proclamation of Sept. 22, 1862, and then afterward the "Emancipation Proclamation" itself, exempting from its provisions all those in territory held by Federal arms and under jurisdiction of the U. S. government.

By the President of the United States of America.

A PROCLAMATION.

I,. Abraham Lincoln, President of The United States of America, and Commander-in-Chief af (sic) the Army and Navy thereof, do hereby proclaim and declare that hereafter, as heretofore, the war will be prosecuted for the object of practically restoring the constitutional relation between the United States and each of the States and the people thereof in which States that relation is or may be suspended or distributed.

That it is my purpose, upon the next meeting of Congress, to again recommend the adoption of a practical measure tendering pecuniary aid to the free acceptance or rejection of all slave States, so called, the people whereof may not then be in rebellion against the United States, and which States may then have voluntarily adopted, or thereafter may voluntarily adopt, immediate or gradual abolishment of slavery within their respective limits; and that the effort to colonize persons of African descent with their consent upon this continent or elsewhere, with the previously obtained consent of the governments existing there, will be continued.

That on the 1st day of January, A. D. 1863 all persons held as slaves within any State or designated part of a State the people whereof shall then be in rebellion against the United States shall be then, thenceforward, and forever free; and the executive government of the United States, including the military and naval authority thereof, will recognize the freedom of such persons and will do no act or acts to repress such persons, or any act or acts they may make for their actual freedom.

That the Executive will on the 1st day of January aforesaid, by proclamation, designate the States, if any, in which the people thereof, respectively, shall then be in rebellion against the United States; and the fact that any State or the people thereof shall on that day be in good faith represented in the Congress of the United States by members chosen thereto at elections wherein a majority of the qualified voters of such State shall have participated shall, in the absence of strong countervailing testimony, be deemed conclusive evidence that such State and the people thereof are not then in rebellion against the United States.

That attention is hereby called to an act of Congress entitled "An act to make an additional article of war," approved March 13, 1862, and which act is in the words and figure following: "Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, That hereafter the following shall be promulgated as an additional article of war for the government of the Army of the United States, and shall be obeyed and observed as such:

Art–– All officers or persons in the military or naval service of the United States are prohibited from employing any of the forces under their respective commands for the purpose of returning fugitives from service or labor who may have escapes from any persons to whom such service or labor is claimed to be due, and any officer who should be found guilty by a court-martial of violating this article shall be dismissed from the service.

Sec. 2. And be it further enacted, That this act shall take effect from and after its passage." Also the ninth and tenth sections of an act entitled "An act to suppress insurrection, to punish treason and rebellion, to seize and confiscate the property of rebels, and for other purposes," approved July 17, 1862, and which sections are in the words and figures following:

Sec. 9. And be it further enacted that all slaves of persons who shall hereafter be engaged in rebellion against the Government of the United States, or who shall in any way give aid or comfort thereto, escaping from such persons and taking refuge within the lines of the army, and all slaves captured from such persons or deserted by them and coming under the control of the Government of the United States, and all slaves of such persons found on (or) being within any place occupied by rebel forces and afterwards occupied by the forces of the United States, shall be deemed captives of war and shall be forever free of their servitude and not again held as slaves.

Sec. 10. And be it further enacted, that no slave escaping into any State, Territory, or the District of Columbia from any other State shall be delivered up or in any way impeded or hindered of his liberty except for crime or some offense against the laws, unless the person claiming said fugitive shall first make oath that the person to whom the labor or service of such fugitive is alleged to be due is his lawful owner and has not borne arms against the United States in the present rebellion nor in any way given aid and comfort thereto; and no person engaged in the military or naval service of the United States shall, under any pretense whatever, assume to decide on the validity of the claim of any person to the service or labor of any such person to the claimant on pain of being dismissed from the service." And I do hereby enjoin upon and order all persons engaged in the military and naval service of the United States to observe, obey, and enforce within their respective spheres of the act and sections above recited.

And the Executive will in due time recommend that all citizens of the United States who shall have remained loyal thereto throughout the rebellion shall, upon the restoration of the constitutional relation between the United States and their respective States and people, if that relation shall have been suspended or disturbed, be compensated for all losses by acts of the United States, including the loss of slaves.

In witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and caused the seal of the United States to be affixed.

Done at the City of Washington, this 22d day of September, A. D. 1862 and of the Independence of the United States the eighty-seventh.

                                                                                                                                                                                                            Abraham Lincoln

(Seal)

By The President:

William H. Seward, Secretary of State.

Taken from"A Compilation of the Messages and Papers of the Presidents 1789 - 1897, published by authority of Congress by James D. Richardson, a Representative from the State Of Tennessee, Volume VI, Page 96.

(This is the one that really flew to the outside world and was published)

By the President of the United States of America.

A PROCLAMATION.

Whereas on the 22d day of September, A. D.1862, a proclamation was issued by the President of the United States, containing, among other things, the following, to wit:

"That on the 1st day of January, A. D. 1863, all persons held as slaves within any State or designated part of a State the people whereof shall then be in rebellion against the United States shall be then, thenceforward, and forever free; and the executive government of the United States, including the military and naval authority thereof, will recognize and maintain the freedom of such persons and will do no act or acts to repress such persons, or any of them, in any efforts they may make for their actual freedom.

That the Executive will on the 1st day of January aforesaid, by proclamation, designated the States and parts of States, if any, in which the people thereof, respectively, shall be in rebellion against the United States; and the fact that any State or the people thereof shall on that day be in good faith represented in the Congress of the United States by members chosen thereto at elections wherein a majority of the qualified voters of such States shall have participated shall, in the absence of strong countervailing testimony, be deemed conclusive evidence that such State and the people thereof are not in rebellion against the United States."

Now, therefore, I, Abraham Lincoln, President of the United States, by virtue of the power in me vested as the Commander-in-Chief of the Army and Navy of the United States in time of actual armed rebellion against the authority and Government of the United States, and as a fit and necessary war measure for suppressing said rebellion, do, on this 1st day of January, A. D.1863, and in accordance with my purpose so to do, publicly proclaimed for the full period of one hundred days from the day first above mentioned, order and designate as the States and parts of States wherein the people thereof, respectively, are this day in rebellion against the United States the following, to wit: Arkansas, Texas, Louisiana (except the parishes of St. Bernard, Plaquemines, Jefferson, St. John, St. James, Ascension, Assumption, Terrebonne, St. Mary, St. Martin, and Orleans, including the city of New Orleans), Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia (except the forty-eight counties designated as West Virginia, and also the counties of Berkeley, Accomac, Northampton, Elizabeth City, York, Princess Anne, and Norfolk, including the cities of Norfolk and Portsmouth), and which excepted parts are for the present left precisely as if this proclamation were not issued.

And by virtue of the power and for the purpose aforesaid, I do order and declare that all persons held as slaves within said designated States and parts of States are now and henceforward shall be free, and that the executive government of the United States, including the military and naval authorities thereof, will recognize and maintain the freedom of said persons.

And I hereby enjoin upon the people so declared to be free to abstain from all violence, unless in necessary self-defense; and I recommend to them that in all cases when allowed they labor faithfully for reasonable wages

And I further declare and make known that such persons of suitable condition will be received into the armed service of the United States to garrison forts, positions, stations, and other places and to man vessels of all sorts in said service.

And upon this act, sincerely believed to be an act of justice, warranted by the Constitution upon military necessity, I invoke the considerate judgment of mankind and the gracious favor of Almighty God.

In witness whereof I have hereunto set my hand and caused the seal of the United States to be affixed. (Seal) Done at the city of Washington, on this 1st day of January, A. D. 1863, and of the Independence of the United States of America the eighty-seventh.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Abraham Lincoln    

By the President:

William H. Seward, Secretary of State

Taken from "A Compilation of the Messages and Papers of the Presidents 1789 - 1897, published by authority of Congress by James D. Richardson, a Representative from the State of Tennessee, Volume VI, Page 157."

From:	Margaret Dargaignon <mabeldoyle@knology.net>
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 5:00 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	making ends meet

Dear Gov. Bush:
 
     My husband and I came here with our son in 1979.  We were
trying to escape high taxes and high insurance rates.  We bought
the whole picture of it being less expensive to live here.
 
    Our home in East Islip, New York was beautiful and in a nice area
and a great school district.  The taxes and insurance were going up,
so we decided to leave our other family and friends and come where
we could make a living and save for our future.
 
      This year we paid a bit more than $10,000 to replace our windows
with ones that would meet the hurricane code.   Our insurance doubled.
 
       I am on oxygen 24 hrs a day and can no longer work as a nurse.
My Pharmacy just let me know that I'd reached my limit on part D.
and must pay the full price on my meds.
Thank God that my husband is in pretty good health.  Even at 75 yrs.
 
        Groceries and gas are going up.   I am sure there are many others
in our positions and some a lot worse.  When I first went on oxygen and 
couldn't work, I volunteered to help the poor.   I saw how they lived...
pretty much the way I had as a child growing up.
 
      I do not want to go back to living like that.
 
    What are you doing for us?
 
Margaret Dargaignon
1512 Price Circle W.
Clearwater, Fl., 33764

> 5/26/06
> I just called and emailed requesting the governor veto 2 new state bills 
> that will accelerate development in Florida - including on barrier islands 
> like Amelia Island that are in a coastal hazard area.   This is being done 
> by having one of the new bills redefine what a Coastal High Hazard Area 
> is.
>
> Ironically while telling all of Amelia Island they must get off the island 
> for every Category 1 Hurricane --in the same bill the state government has 
> declared most of Amelia Island is no longer a Coastal High Hazard Area. 
> Therefore, development is no longer capped at the current Comprehensive 
> plan level by the state.
>
> It is so risky we all have to all get off the island for every hurricane - 
> and simultaneously the state eliminates the development cap.    Does that 
> make any sense - to anyone other than developers?
> See the 1000 Friends of Florida email below and website: 
> http://www.1000friendsofflorida.org/
> You may want to pass this email on to your groups.

> Phil Scanlan

> ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> From: 1000 Friends of Florida
> To: gourdsandboards@hotmail.com
> Sent: Wednesday, May 17, 2006 2:23 PM
> Subject: Please Ask Gov. Bush to Veto Two Damaging Bills
> 1000 Friends Calls on Gov. Bush to Veto Bills Related to Coastal 
> Redevelopment and Agricultural Economic Development
>
> 1000 Friends of Florida, the state's nonprofit growth management watchdog, 
> is calling on Gov. Bush to veto two bills passed by the 2006 Legislature. 
> HB 1359, "Hazard Mitigation for Coastal Redevelopment," makes it easier to 
> develop coastal lands in Florida, particularly in the relatively 
> undeveloped Panhandle. HB 1015, also known as the "Agricultural Economic 
> Development Act," promotes sprawling development in rural, agricultural 
> lands. 1000 Friends Executive Director Charles Pattison notes that both of 
> these bills benefit major developers while harming the taxpayers of 
> Florida.
>
> Your Help Is Needed!
>
> Please Call Gov. Bush at 850-488-4441 (e-mail jeb.bush@myflorida.com) and 
> ask him to veto HB 1359 because it promotes fiscally irresponsible coastal 
> development.
>
> Please also ask Gov. Bush to veto HB 1015 because, in his words, it 
> encourages farmers to "cash out," encourages "the premature conversion of 
> agricultural lands to development," and does not look at growth management 
> comprehensively.
>
> More Information:
>
> Coastal Redevelopment--"The Coastal Redevelopment bill could jeopardize 
> the lives of Floridians and cost taxpayers millions if not billions of 
> dollars when the next major storm hits," says Pattison. Previously, it was 
> fairly difficult to increase the density of allowed development in coastal 
> or "High Hazard" areas, as they are known in emergency management lingo. 
> But under the new law, a developer can get around that requirement by 
> showing that people are able to evacuate the high hazard area within 12 to 
> 16 hours.
>
> Because much of the Panhandle remains relatively undeveloped, this will 
> not be much of a deterrent to new development in North Florida for a 
> number of years to come. "When that next big storm hits, the people of 
> Florida will be left holding the bag," Pattison notes. "Taxpayers will be 
> called on to subsidize the insurance payouts on damaged condos and pay for 
> repairs to the roads, bridges, and other infrastructure that supports all 
> that new development."
>
> "The scenario for much of the rest of the Florida is even more 
> frightening," Pattison explains. Developers in the more densely developed 
> southern parts of the state may not be able to meet the 12- to 16-hour 
> evacuation requirement. However, the new bill is a "developer's dream." 
> Developers can pay the local government an unspecified amount for the 
> right to develop.
>
> Making matters worse, the money does not have to be allocated to road 
> improvements, shelters, or other measures to help with hurricane 
> evacuation-it can go toward anything that the local government decides is 
> "appropriate mitigation." More developed parts of the state are hit by a 
> double whammy with this new legislation, according to Pattison, with the 
> potential loss of lives because people are unable to evacuate to safety, 
> and the costs to taxpayers of rebuilding.
>
> In light of the events of the last two years, Floridians have no excuse 
> for allowing accelerated development in coastal high hazard areas, 
> Pattison explains. He points to headlines of the last few days alone-State 
> Farm calling for a 71.5 percent increase in insurance rates, Allstate 
> announcing it will drop the policies of close to 200,000 customers, the 
> governor signing an insurance bill that will require taxpayers to fork out 
> $1 billion over the next 10 years to cover insurance deficits from recent 
> storms, and a hike in utility bills in South Florida to cover the costs of 
> recent storm damage to utility infrastructure. "If HB 1359 is signed by 
> Gov. Bush, taxpayers need to be prepared to pay higher taxes to subsidize 
> the insurance and rebuilding when all this new development is damaged by 
> the inevitable storms," says Pattison.
>
> Agricultural Economic Development--1000 Friends is also calling for a veto 
> of HB 1015, says Pattison. This controversial legislation allows the 
> conversion of "agricultural enclaves" to urban uses. An agricultural 
> enclave is defined as an agricultural parcel under single ownership that 
> is surrounded on at least 75 percent of its perimeter by existing or 
> designated industrial, commercial, or residential uses.
>
> Pattison points out that similar legislation failed in 2005, and in 2004 
> Governor Bush vetoed a comparable bill. In his veto message, Bush noted 
> that the 2004 legislation could provide an incentive for farmers to "cash 
> out," and encourage "the premature conversion of agricultural lands to 
> development." He also explained that the bill did not look at growth 
> management comprehensively.
>
> "We could not have put it better ourselves," Pattison notes. 1000 Friends 
> is particularly concerned that this bill overrides state rules limiting 
> urban sprawl, and preempts the ability of local governments to decide 
> whether land should be agricultural or urban in use.
>
> "It is also deeply disturbing that this bill was intended primarily to 
> benefit special interests," says Pattison. "By providing a 'safety net' 
> for a few major developers, the legislature has opened up thousands of 
> acres of agricultural lands across the state for premature, sprawling 
> development," explains Pattison.
>
> Pattison asks citizens across the state to call Gov. Bush at 850-488-4441 
> to urge him to veto these developer-friendly bills. "Ask him to put the 
> interests of Florida's taxpayers first."
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
> 1000 Friends of Florida, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization founded in 
> 1986, serves as the state's growth management watchdog. To find out more, 
> visit www.1000friendsofflorida.org.
>
>
>
>
>
>

> Version: 7.1.394 / Virus Database: 268.8.3/360 - Release Date: 6/9/2006

From: Governor Jeb Bush 
To: Suzana Megles 
Sent: Thursday, July 06, 2006 10:40 AM
Subject: RE: down listing the Manatee


Dear Friend,

 

Thank you for sharing your concerns about the new science-based process for classifying Florida’s imperiled species.  Governor Bush appreciates your sharing your views and opinions about this important issue and asked me to respond on his behalf.

 

The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC) is using sound science to determine the appropriate classifications for manatees, bald eagles, gopher tortoises and Panama City crayfish.  Regardless of their final determination, the Commission will develop management plans to ensure continued protection and sustainability of these species.  Management plans typically take a year to draft and the process includes public participation.

 

The goal of the Commission is for all imperiled species populations to recover.  As the bald eagle population has recovered substantially, it is appropriate for the species to be removed from the list.  Because the manatee is no longer in imminent danger of extinction, it will be reclassified as threatened.  However, it is important to note that a threatened species by definition still faces a very high risk of extinction.  Even though the species has recovered substantially, the marine mammal will continue to be protected under the new process.

 

The State of Florida and the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission are committed to the recovery of our imperiled species.  For more information about the reclassification process, please visit www.myfwc.com.

 

Thank you again for writing and for sharing your concerns with Governor Bush.

 

 

Sincerely, 

 

Shahlaine KhunKhun

Office of Citizens’ Services

From:	Pricher Barbara <barbara.pricher@baycare.org>
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 3:11 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Cost of living in Florida prohibitive for Registered Nurses

Dear Governor Bush,
I am the manager of a large Intensive Care Unit in Tampa. Recently, I have
become alarmed with the number of Registered Nurses
that I hear talking about moving out of Florida due to exorbitant cost of
housing in the state. Just today, I have heard that another insurance
company is requesting an increase of 71%. If this goes through, as all the
rest have so far, I fear that this will further impact the decision of those
nurses already vacillating over moving out of our state. As a profession
that is already in crisis due to the aging population and nursing shortage,
this profession cannot afford to have a mass exodus from this state. Or
should I put it another way, this state cannot afford to have a mass exodus
of these essential service personnel.  Although the Florida Legislature
passed an affordable housing bill this year, this is just a start. In order
to keep up with the cost of living, nurse's salaries would need to increase
exponentially,  which in turn would increase the cost of healthcare which is
already out of control. This has to stop somewhere. Please say "no" to
further demands of the insurance industry. We have been a lucrative market
for these companies for years. It is now time for these very companies to
show some compassion and help us develop an affordable solution. Thank you
for your time.
Sincerely,
Barbara J. Pricher, RN, BSN
Manager
Intensive Care Unit
sSt. Joseph's Hospital

From:	Bevis, Buddy <bevisb@doacs.state.fl.us>
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 1:44 PM
To:	jborew@bellsouth.net; Governor Jeb Bush
Cc:	Bronson, Charles H.; Rhodes, Terry
Subject:	RE: south Carolina

Good Afternoon Mr. Borew,
 
I am with the Division of Licensing, Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services.  We are responsible for the Concealed Weapons program for the State of Florida.
 
It appears you are changing your state of residence to South Carolina.  While there are requirements concerning your driver's license, the move to South Carolina should not effect the status of your Florida Concealed Weapons permit.
 
Unless things have changes recently, South Carolina will not honor your Florida permit, whether you are a resident of Florida or a South Carolina resident.  You will need a south carolina permit if you are a resident of South Carolina.
 
However, I would recommend you keep your Florida CW permit because Florida has reciprocity with 29 other states.  Your South Carolina license is only recognized by 9 other states.  You can change your address and get a duplicate Florida license for only $15 should you want a replacement license with your South Carolina address.
 
I must also say, two states of the twenty nine, Michigan and New Hampshire, will honor a Florida permit, but only if you are a Florida resident.  So, if your residence is South Carolina, Michigan will not honor your Florida license.  New Hampshire does not have reciprocity with South Carolina, therefore your South Carolina permit is not good in that state.
 
You have already spent the money in Florida, I would recommend keeping it, but change your address for $15.
 
I have placed a link to our web site, and a link to South Carolina's web site for your convenience concerning information on each of our programs.
 
Florida
http://licgweb.doacs.state.fl.us/news/concealed_carry.html
 
South Carolina
http://www.sled.state.sc.us/sled/default.asp?Category=sccwp&Service=menu
 
I hope this helps,
Buddy Bevis
 
 
 
 
MICHIGAN and NEW HAMPSHIRE will honor the Florida license ONLY IF the license holder is a legal resident of Florida

From:	Roxanne Nadolsky <iroxnow@aol.com>
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 11:41 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Safeguard State Sovereignty in Global Trade Talks

Dear Governor,
I am writing to express my concern about the threat that services negotiations at the World Trade Organization (WTO) pose to state sovereignty. This week, federal trade negotiators are in Geneva talking about how to expand the WTO’s General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS).

Governors in other states have begun to weigh on these talks by requesting that the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) exempt their states from the proposed expansion of this agreement.  

I respectfully urge you to notify USTR Robert Portman that: 1) Our state does not agree to be bound by any new service sector commitments in ongoing WTO GATS negotiations (such as higher education); and 2) Our state does not support the development of new GATS rules that would create new grounds for the challenge of nondiscriminatory state laws in the service sector. 

Thank you for your consideration of this timely and important issue.

Sincerely,

Roxanne Nadolsky
14964 Wildflower Lane
Delray Beach, FL 33446

NAVARRE BEACH RESTORATION STILL ON HOLD 

The US Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) has shut down the Navarre Beach Restoration Project until at least late October. I received this information during a phone call last evening from Peter Ravella of Coastal Technology, Santa Rosa County’s consultant on the beach restoration project. 

The sand dredging operation on Navarre Beach had been suspended since a juvenile loggerhead turtle was killed early Saturday morning July 1. The Corps conducted a risk assessment of the project and its two dredges, the R.N. Weeks and B.E. Lindholm earlier this week before halting the project. 

The dead turtle discovered Saturday was the third one killed by a dredge since Weeks Marine the contractor started the project on March 17. 

Coastal Technology sent a letter of reconsideration yesterday (Wednesday) to the Corps as an appeal. It is my understanding that Coastal Technology is basing their appeal on some of the following: 

• To modify the Corps’s dredging permit until October 1. 

• To Allow Weeks Marine to resume dredging for 15 days to fill in the 
remaining 1,400 feet of beach and extend the 14 foot high dune system the entire length of the project. 

• To complete the beach restoration project, because only 6 loggerhead turtles have been killed by dredging in 2006 in the entire Gulf of Mexico from Key West, FL to Brownsville, TX. That the Gulf of Mexico is allowed to kill by dredging 40 loggerhead turtles, and that the entire Gulf of Mexico has not exceeded the limit required by the Corps and the National Marine Fisheries Service. 

In my opinion the appeal letter is a good faith effort on the part of Coastal Technology and Santa Rosa County. I think the chances of reversing the appeal to the Corps are slim to none. However, I think we have an excellent chance in getting the stop order reversed by winning the battle of public opinion. The Corps has to answer to Congress. I will be organizing today a letter and e-mail blitz to send to our US Representatives, Senators, President Bush, Governor Bush and the Director of the US Corps of Engineers. 

I will post on this forum later today a suggested letter to send to the above mentioned public officials along with corresponding mailing addresses and e-mail addresses. I’m very sorry about the killing of 3 turtles at Navarre Beach, but leaving a 1,400 foot gap in the middle of our 3.6 mile beach during hurricane season could have disastrous results in millions of dollars of property damage if we are hit by a hurricane or tropical storm. This uncompleted 1,400 gap would cause major flooding to the east and west of the entire 3.6 miles of beach. 

The shrimp industry is allowed to kill about 3,500 turtles annually with their trawlers in the waters of the Gulf of Mexico. And our beach restoration has been stopped because of 3 turtles killed in the dredging operation. I don’t understand the reasoning here. 

“We the People” can convince our representatives in Congress to do the right thing and use a little common sense and give us 14 more days to complete the last 1,400 feet of our beach. Let’s Roll!

Corrupt Prison Officials Confess

The nation's third-largest prison system has been plagued by scandal and
corruption for years and now its top official, a governor appointee, has
finally admitted that he took thousands of dollars in bribes from a
state contractor over two years.

A wide-ranging investigation into rampant criminal activity among prison
system employees found enough evidence to force James Crosby to resign
as Florida's Secretary of the Department of Corrections earlier this
year, though he has maintained his innocence until this week. Crosby
pleaded guilty to a federal charge of accepting kickbacks from a
subcontractor and seven other prison employees have been charged in
state court with theft and another with accepting bribes.

Crosby's plea agreement will allow him to escape arrest, indictment, a
hefty fine and even prison time (he could have faced 10 years in federal
prison). 
Apparently it pays to have friends in high places, like the governor's
mansion. When Florida Governor Jeb Bush announced Crosby's appointment
with great fanfare in 2002, he said that he was "honored to have Jimmy
join my leadership team ... and confident he will serve the citizens of
Florida well."

As Secretary of the Department of Corrections, Crosby was in charge of
more than 26,000 employees that operate 128 prisons and 151 probation
and parole offices statewide. Bush had no choice but to ask for his
friend's resignation earlier this year amid mounting evidence of
criminal wrongdoing. In the final months of Crosby's tenure, the
department of corrections was scandal-plagued with arrests of
drug-abusing prison guards, accusations of sexual assault and the
bribery matter.

A report by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement concluded that
Crosby tried to shut down an investigation into criminal activity among
many employees in the prison system. One Florida newspaper wrote that
Crosby's administration was under federal and state scrutiny for
nepotism, cronyism, steroid use, alleged misuse of inmate labor and
state property, and employee clubs and vendors operating with little
oversight while handling large amounts of cash.

http://www.corruptionchronicles.com/2006/07/corrupt_prison_officials_con
fe.html

July 5, 2006

Here Are the Facts on the Cross Issue

ACLU and activist judge put on ice over Mt. Soledad cross by Supreme Court

Dear kate,

 In our latest AFA Action Alert, we asked you to take action by encouraging the U.S. Senate to pass legislation protecting the crosses in all federal cemeteries and use Article Three, Section Two to remove jurisdiction from federal judges. 

There has been some confusion regarding our Action Alert. Many have been led to believe by outdated material and websites that the ACLU's efforts are nothing more than a rumor or hoax. 

I have said, and maintain, that the ACLU is behind the effort to remove this cross. 

Late last Friday, according to CBS News, Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy intervened in a 17-year battle over a large cross on city property in San Diego, allowing the 29-foot structure to remain until its supporters complete a legal challenge. 

U.S. District Judge Gordon Thompson had ordered the city to remove the structure by Aug. 1 or face a fine of $5,000 a day. Thompson ruled the cross unconstitutional in 1991, but the case has remained in courts and become an issue of public policy. 

I urge you to research the facts for yourself. Please take time to view these sources regarding the ACLU and the activist judge who wants the cross removed. 

Judge orders San Diego cross removed. Gives city 90 days in case brought by ACLU-backed atheist
http://www.wnd.com/news/article.asp?ARTICLE_ID=50038 

Supreme Court Saves San Diego Cross. Ruling Stays Order That Would Have Forced City To Remove It
http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/07/03/national/main1774069.shtml 

It is only logical that if the cross is removed from the Mt. Soledad Memorial, then the next move by the ACLU would be to remove crosses from all memorials and cemeteries. 



Take Action

If you haven't already, would you please take time to contact your Senators and ask them to pass legislation protecting the crosses (indeed, all religious symbols) in all federal cemeteries and memorials? If the ACLU wins this battle, you can be sure they will pursue removing crosses from national cemeteries everywhere. 

Please take action to protect our right to have crosses above the graves of those who have given their lives to protect our religious freedom. 

	

Click Here to Email Your Senators Now!

Or, copy and past this link to your browser - http://capwiz.com/afanet/issues/alert/?alertid=8890016&type=ML

If you think our efforts are worthy, would you please support us with a small gift? Thank you for caring enough to get involved. 

Sincerely,

 

Donald E. Wildmon, Founder and Chairman
American Family Association

SENATE RACE


Fast fundraising targets incumbent Villalobos


State Senate candidate Frank Bolaños is quickly catching up to incumbent Alex Villalobos in campaign donations.


BY BETH REINHARD


breinhard@MiamiHerald.com


Jeb Bush loyalists have helped Miami-Dade School Board Member Frank Bolaños round up more than $200,000 in three weeks to try to topple state Sen. Alex Villalobos, who crossed the governor on two key votes earlier this year.

Bolaños' rapid haul is a stunning amount to raise against an incumbent who, until recently, was the Senate's Republican majority leader and its future president. But then came this spring's legislative session.

Villalobos forfeited his leadership post after he helped defeat a Bush-backed proposal to water down the constitutional amendment limiting class sizes. He also opposed a proposal the governor hoped would help revive private school vouchers for students of struggling public schools. The Florida Supreme Court has declared vouchers unconstitutional.

The Villalobos-Bolaños race is becoming one of the roughest races on the Sept 5. ballot, sparking clashes on Spanish-language radio and exposing rifts in the Miami-Dade Republican political establishment. The governor has said he may get involved in the Miami-Dade Senate race personally, though it's unclear whether he's done anything to date.

In response to Bolaños' fundraising announcement Wednesday, Villalobos said he had raised about $80,000 during the past three months. He already had collected nearly $225,000, which had seemed like a comfortable lead.

Florida candidates don't have to report their contributions and expenses for the past three months until Monday, but some candidates jump the gun when they have good news.

''I'm encouraged and humbled by the remarkable response we've gotten from voters in our district,'' Bolaños said in a written statement. ``Our fundraising efforts have been surpassed only by the words of support I've heard as I walked the district, sharing my ideas with neighbors and local business leaders.''

Bolaños did not disclose a list of his donors but did list the members of his finance committee. Many are longtime fundraisers for the governor and President George W. Bush who don't live in the western Miami-Dade Senate district.

They include former Florida Republican Party Chairman Al Cardenas, Fort Lauderdale lobbyist Justin Sayfie, developer Sergio Pino, Fort Lauderdale cardiologist Zachariah Zachariah and Jason Unger, a Tallahassee lobbyist married to the governor's former campaign manager.

Asked why he was supporting Bolaños, Zachariah responded: ``He's the guy running against Villalobos, right? I think the guy has done a good job on the School Board and he seems like a good candidate.''

Zachariah added: ``I believe in good government and I don't care what part of the state a candidate comes from. We need men and women of good moral character.''

Seven state legislators and senators recently held a press conference to display their support for Villalobos and decry the infighting among Miami-Dade legislators. The senator also is receiving support from members of the PTA and teachers' union.

''That's worth more to me than a big fundraiser,'' Villalobos said.

From:	Hurricanesupply@aol.com
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 7:54 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	RE: Emergency Alert

 
Dear Sirs,
 
Please take the time to visit our site for unique and essential emergency supplies.
We sell a product in Florida called Ezy Flare. This is a battery operated emergency flare that helps alert emergency officials as well as surrounding neighbors when a person is in need of help due to hurricanes or storms. When phone lines are down, this devise is an alternative to communicate to the outside world from their home. On many occasions street signs are knocked down making it difficult for Emergency officials to find the residents home. Ezy Flares pulsating bright LED lights make it easier for them to find their home simply by placing this unit in their window or front porch.  Ezy Flare is even designed to stand up or lay flat with it's built in rubber pads and is water resistant. This can be seen by air or land up to 8,000 feet.
Ezy Flare can be placed on roof tops as well. Also, our new commercial flare can be seen in the day.
 
Sincerely,
Ms. Susan Haskins
 
 
                                        
 
Je'vay International Inc.
1412 South Riverside Drive
Edgewater, Fl 32132
USA

----- Original Message ----- 
Subject: AMERICA




  Subject: AMERICA

 

This is an editorial written by an 
American citizen, published in a 
Tampa, FL Newspaper. He did quite a job; didn't he? Read on, please! 

IMMIGRANTS,…………… NOT AMERICANS,  MUST ADAPT.


I am tired of this nation worrying about whether we 
are offending some individual or their culture. Since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 
we have experienced a surge 
in patriotism by the majority 
of Americans. However...... the dust from the attacks had 
barely settled when the "politically correct! " crowd began complaining about 
the possibility that our patriotism was offending others. 

I am not against immigration, nor do I hold a grudge against anyone who is seeking a better life by coming to ! America 
Our population is almost entirely made up of descendants of immigrants. 
However, there 
are a few things that those 
who have recently come to 
our country, and apparently some born here, need to understand. 
This idea of America being a 
multicultural community 
has served only to dilute our sovereignty and our national identity. As Americans...... 
we have our own culture, our 
own society, our own language and our own lifestyle. This culture has been developed over centuries of struggles, trials, and victories by millions of men and women who have sought freedom. 


We speak ENGLISH , not Spanish, Portuguese, Arabic, Chinese, Japanese, Russian, or any other language. 
Therefore, if you wish to become part of our society, learn the language! 

"In God We Trust" is our national motto. This is not some Christian, right wing, political slogan.. We adopted this motto because Christian men and women.......on Christian principles............. 
founded this nation..... and this is clearly documented. 
It is certainly appropriate to display it 
on the walls of our schools. 
If God offends you, then I suggest you consider another part of the world as 
your new home.........because 
God is part of our culture. 

If Stars and Stripes offend you, or 
you don't like Uncle Sam, then you 
should seriously consider a move 
to another part of this planet. 
We 
are happy with our culture and have 
no desire to change, and we really 
don't care how you did things where 
you came from. 
This is 
OUR COUNTRY, 
our land, and our lifestyle. 
Our First Amendment gives every citizen the 
right to express his opinion and we 
will allow you every opportunity to do so! 
But once you are done complaining....... whining...... and griping....... about our flag....... 
our pledge...... our national motto........or our 
way of life....I highly encourage you to 
take advantage of one other Great American Freedom....... 

THE RIGHT TO LEAVE. 


It is Time for America to Speak up 
If you agree -- pass this along; 
if you don't agree -- delete it - You are in the WRONG Country! 

AMEN 

 


  _____

From:	jeb.bush@myflorida.com
Sent:	Thursday, July 6, 2006 6:08 AM
Subject:	FL prison official Crosby pleads guilty

And of course Jebbie, John Ellis "FIB!" Bush, pardons his good buddy rather 
than risk him spilling the beans about what other crimes Jebbie and his felon 
family (drug dealer, stalker, B&E, grand theft) have been covering up....

Corrupt Prison Officials Confess

The nation's third-largest prison system has been plagued by scandal and 
corruption for years and now its top official, a governor appointee, has 
finally admitted that he took thousands of dollars in bribes from a state 
contractor over two years.

A wide-ranging investigation into rampant criminal activity among prison 
system employees found enough evidence to force James Crosby to resign as 
Florida's Secretary of the Department of Corrections earlier this year, 
though he has maintained his innocence until this week. Crosby pleaded guilty 
to a federal charge of accepting kickbacks from a subcontractor and seven 
other prison employees have been charged in state court with theft and 
another with accepting bribes.

Crosby's plea agreement will allow him to escape arrest, indictment, a hefty 
fine and even prison time (he could have faced 10 years in federal prison). 
Apparently it pays to have friends in high places, like the governor's 
mansion. When Florida Governor Jeb Bush announced Crosby's appointment with 
great fanfare in 2002, he said that he was "honored to have Jimmy join my 
leadership team ... and confident he will serve the citizens of Florida 
well."

As Secretary of the Department of Corrections, Crosby was in charge of more 
than 26,000 employees that operate 128 prisons and 151 probation and parole 
offices statewide. Bush had no choice but to ask for his friend's resignation 
earlier this year amid mounting evidence of criminal wrongdoing. In the final 
months of Crosby's tenure, the department of corrections was scandal-plagued 
with arrests of drug-abusing prison guards, accusations of sexual assault and 
the bribery matter.

A report by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement concluded that Crosby 
tried to shut down an investigation into criminal activity among many 
employees in the prison system. One Florida newspaper wrote that Crosby's 
administration was under federal and state scrutiny for nepotism, cronyism, 
steroid use, alleged misuse of inmate labor and state property, and employee 
clubs and vendors operating with little oversight while handling large 
amounts of cash.

http://www.corruptionchronicles.com/2006/07/corrupt_prison_officials_confe.html

It’s been a long day and a trying time with MVE/Insight software, based out of Miami, FL.

 

When I purchased the software 6 months ago the sell came with high “implied” outstanding customer support, compatibility with billing services as yours, etc. I have had a horrible experience and received an attitude that it is something “We” are doing wrong. 

 

At this point I’m considering legal action against Insight for the incompetence and the shifting of that to the customer. I’ve lost count of the hours, updates, and remote access sessions Vipul has had to implement, all with an attitude that we’re screwing up our system; never once claiming it may be a “software issue.”

 

In December of 2004 I purchased the Network Edition for $2250, which included a three year special for customer support.

 

I received an invoice today Dated December 26th, 2005, with a “revised” three year support and updates charge of $747.00, stating that I owe them another $500.00.

 

I need someone on your end that has adept experience with MVE/Insight in relation to interfacing our two systems, and possibly some advice on another software company.

 

Sincerely,

 

 

Joe

 

 

www.ctvisioncenter.com

 

I’m insulted. I’ve been in the business for twenty years, come from blue-collar roots, and have had experiences with Vipul, an owner of a company, who is irritable, short-tempered, impatient, and condescending.

 

If you check my credentials, the area we are located in, only a fool would have such a short-sighted paradigm. The household per capita income in this area is second only to the Greenwich area of CT, which is located near NY, NY. 

 

Please feel free to forward this to your senior management.

 

From what I’ve experienced from EDI to this point is nothing but true professionalism, from the first person I’ve spoken to.

 

I hope the file you received shows some improvement. I went through every claim myself, and toughed it out, since asking MVE for “support” is relative. 

 

Looking forward to hearing from you, and please take a look at our website before calling us. I’ll be in after 10:00 tomorrow; it’s our long day.

 

Take care!

Dear Mr. Newman

How is it that two governments run by two brothers, who happen to be
ideological allies can be of two completely different minds? The one is
fighting a war in Iraq and Afghanistan for freedom and the other one has
created a dictatorship in our Florida school system. I can prove every

Florida.

legislation that made it possible for Dr. Clinton Wright Superintendent
of the Lake Wales Charter School to dismissed 20 teachers and 7
paraprofessional in an anti democratic manner without given an
explanation. If a teacher questions a charter schools decision you are
out of the gate. An opinion poll by the local newspaper The Ledger shows
that 77% of Lake Wales consider it a wrongful dismissal. See Charter
attachment sign across from Sears on Highway 27 in Lake Wales. 

Dr. Wright dismissed me for a difference of opinion. How close can you
get to a dictatorship? My civil rights have been violated by the Polk
County School Board for not following due process. The Polk County school
System is violating (school board regulation 60X53-8, 004 (C). Also
violation  447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant
to section 447,503(20). 

Principal D’Angelo has been dismissed as a principle of the Kathleen High
School by the Polk County School Board for exploring the idea of
converting the high school into a charter school, dismissal confirmed by
a local judge. 

The University of Southern Florida approved Professor All-Arian private
fund raising campaign for political reasons. Professor All-Arian had the
power to fail students when not donating to his fund raising campaign and
visa furze. Allowing private fund raising in a public school has become a
serious educational problem. 
 
Polk County School Board has created an anti democratic school system for
political gain and our local politicians and our county justice system
are following in the same track. Local Florida attorneys are not willing
to look into a “Florida Home Rule“ problem. Governor Jeb Bush claims in
writing that he is powerless to look into that matter and our local
Florida Senators and Representatives do not seem to care.  

Every American Citizen has the right to receive a hearing in a conflict.
I received a letter from Manuel Zurita Director of the EEOC in Tampa. The
EEOC is refusing to give me a hearing or an explanation on Charge No. 152
2005 00756 and telling me that a new lawsuit would be time barred, why?
The EEOC is by their action failing their mission to promote educational
excellence throughout the nation.   

According to Glenda Hood, Florida’s Secretary of State: Florida is an
"employment at-will" state. An employer can terminate an employee for any
reason, at any time, without advance notification so long as there is no
violation of federal or state law, (11.242, Chapter 11). Completely
ignored by the Polk County school system. 

I donated my time to train minorities and women to pass a mechanics test.
On August 17, 2005, School Board Attorney Deming Cowles wrote to me that
the school “can dismiss you for you’ re [sic] ethnic background....’ no
explanation needed “. Can't you see that this has been eating me alive? I
am presently tutoring a colored lady to prepare for her electrical
journeyman exam. My family is telling me that I am nothing else but a
fool because of the treatment I received by the Polk County School
System. 

May 15, 2002, is the day that President Bush signed into law the Federal
(No FEAR) Act to increase federal agency accountability against
Discrimination and Retaliation. The Polk County School Board is ignoring
those laws,

Friday, May 5th, 2006, the day that the Florida Legislature gave final
approval to House Bill 1123, the "Government Accountability Act." The
Polk County School Board has been ignoring your laws. We are entitled to
an explanation by our Senators and Representatives in the State of
Florida in who is holding the school boards accountable. 

Sincerely yours,

John Meyer
404 Whitman Rd.
Winter Haven Fl. 33884

                 President George W.                         Letters To Leaders 
                                 
                                 
                                All messages are published with permission of the sender. The general topic of this message is Immigration: 
                                 
                                 
                                Subject:
                                Bush deceives on border

                                To:
                                President George Bush

                                July 5, 2006

                                Bush deceives on border
                                Posted: June 27, 2006
                                1:00 a.m. Eastern

                                Many of President Bush's supporters continue to write to me saying I am not being fair to him on the border issue. 
                                With White House press secretary Tony Snow attacking WND by name for its "splashy" stories on the border, it's no wonder. 
                                But here are some facts - many of which may be deemed "inconvenient" by the White House, and, if Tony Snow or President Bush himself would like to address them, they are more than welcome. 
                                Until recently, Bush's rhetoric and actions on the border and illegal immigration meshed. Essentially, he told the American people they were too lazy to work, and the country needed cheap labor from Mexico. This was his rationalization for five or six years of border-security neglect. 
                                Now, however, Bush is sounding a different tune. Last month, in outlining his "comprehensive immigration reform plan," he said: "First, the United States must secure its borders. This is a basic responsibility of a sovereign nation. It is also an urgent requirement of our national security." 
                                There's just one problem. He's not sincerely working toward that goal. Even if the president's current border security proposals are implemented, the U.S. will still not have secure borders because neither his plan nor the Senate bill he supports includes enough Border Patrol agents, enough fencing, enough equipment and new technology to secure the border. 
                                Earlier this month, Bush made reference to "doubling the size of the Border Patrol during my administration." 
                                There's just one problem. Not only has the Border Patrol not been doubled during his administration, the White House has fought against significant increases in its budget every year since 2001. Actually, the Border Patrol was growing faster during the Clinton administration - before Sept. 11, 2001 - than it has since 9-11. The Clinton administration increased the Border Patrol from 4,026 in 1993 to 9,078 when they left office in 2001, an increase of 5,052 agents or 125 percent. Bush has increased the manpower from 9,078 to the 11,800 we have today, an increase of 2,722 agents or 30 percent. 
                                Just last year, four full years after 9-11, the White House's 2006 budget included funds for only 210 new Border Patrol agents, not the 2,000 new agents authorized by Congress in the Intelligence Reform Act of 2004. He still has not adopted the congressional plan to add 2,000 new agents per year for five years. 
                                To sell his neglect of the border and the immigration laws of the land, Bush has purposely redefined the word "amnesty." He did this once again earlier this month: "Amnesty is: OK, everybody who is here, you're a citizen. That's amnesty." 
                                As I have explained before, "amnesty" has never meant a grant of "automatic citizenship." Amnesty is, instead, any plan that allows people who entered the country illegally to profit from that lawbreaking. 
                                Once again, earlier this month, Bush reiterated the defamatory statement that illegal aliens are sneaking across the border to "do work Americans aren't doing." 
                                There's just one problem. Of 473 job categories studied by the Center for Immigration Studies for the year 2004, only four - plasters and stucco masons, dressmakers and sewers, agricultural graders and sorters, and miscellaneous personal appearance workers - had a majority of immigrant workers, and only 23 out of 473 job categories (less than 5 percent) had 33 percent or more. More to the point, every single kind of work done by illegal aliens in this country is also performed by Americans. 
                                One of the reasons some jobs are increasingly being taken over by illegals is because they will accept jobs for lower pay. When a construction worker loses a $15 an hour job to an illegal worker who will do it for $8.50, that is not an example of a poor work ethic by Americans. 
                                Bush also recently told Americans: "Since 2001, we have apprehended and sent back 6 million people trying to get in the country." 
                                There's just one problem. Since 2001, the U.S. government apprehended 6 million people out of at least 18 million who tried to get into our country, but those 6 million were not sent home. Mexican nationals apprehended are merely put back through the gate to try again the next night or the next week. 
                                Bush also said just last month: "We need to hold employers to account for the workers they hire." 
                                There's just one problem. During the eight years of the Clinton administration, 5,587 employers were fined for violating the laws against employing illegal workers, an average of 698 per year. During the first four years of the Bush administration, a total of 218 fines were issued - less than 55 per year. In 2004 only four fines were issued. 
                                Again, last month, Bush claimed: "We have ended the policy of catch-and-release." 
                                There's just one problem. Six months after announcing this policy change, thousands of non-Mexicans are still being released for lack of detention space. Worse yet, some of them are from Middle Eastern countries. 
                                Again, just last month, Bush claimed about his amnesty program: "Every worker who applies for the [guest worker] program would be required to pass a criminal background check." 
                                There's just one problem. The U.S. government does not have the capability of doing this. The U.S. can only check criminal records within the U.S, not crimes illegal aliens may have committed in their home countries. Mexico does not even have a centralized database of criminal warrants. Tens of thousands of child molesters, car thieves and violent criminals who entered our country illegally would be eligible for a legal work permit under both the president's plan and the Senate bill passed May 25. 
                                Bush has also stated that under his plan "temporary workers" will go home when their employment term is up: "We've got to have a comprehensive approach that includes a temporary worker plan that says you can come and do a job . and then once you finish that time, you go home." 
                                There's just one problem. There is no requirement in Bush's plan or the Senate bill that "temporary" guest workers actually go home after three or six years when their temporary work permit ends. They can then apply for permanent resident alien status (a "green card") at any time and gain eventual citizenship. 
                                That's the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth about the border and the illegal alien invasion. What do you have to say about that, Tony? 


                                Dundee , IL

From:	DeAna Mullins <deana_mullins@yahoo.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 10:19 PM
To:	nancygrace@cnn.com; larryking@cnn.com; loudobbs@cnn.com; itcouldhappentoyou@foxnews.com; brianandthejudge@foxnews.com; friends@foxnews.com; speakout@foxnews.com; ontherecord@foxnews.com; dateline@nbc.com; nightly@nbc.com; today@nbc.com; 2020@nbc.com; rusch@eibnet.com; mayor@ocfl.net; district1@ofcl.net; district2@ofcl.net; district3@ofcl.net; district4@ofcl.net; district5@ofcl.net; district6@ofcl.net; campaign@charliecrist.com; speaker@myflorida.com; Siplin, Gary; Constantine, Lee; Posey, Bill; comments@whitehouse.gov; Governor Jeb Bush; greta.vansusteren@foxnews.com; charlie.crist@myflorida.com; cfo@fldfs.com; geraldo@geraldoatlarge.com; lee.tom.web@flsenate.gov; Smith, Rod; Webster, Dan
Subject:	[*] Devastated and Desparate in Apopka, FL

Email Number 3 for most of you!!
July 5, 2006
 
To Whom It May Concern,
 
How can this keep on and how can so many people say there is nothing they can do?  
 
Myself and a number of other families get scammed by a FELON because the STATE and FINANCIAL INSTIUTIONS were asleep at the wheel and all we get told is “so sorry.”  This is ridiculous and I am ASHAMED to be a Floridian – yes, one of those rare individuals who was actually born and raised here.  I am ashamed of my state.
 
I still pay monthly payments on worthless property when the financial institution should have done their homework and never allowed this FELON to have access to money that I’d have to make payments on.
 
I have  personally paid nearly $5,000 in legal fees to try to resolve the lien (that we don’t think are legal but that doesn’t stop the crooked attorney to move forward and for me to have to defend myself) and break a contract with a FELON who has stolen $200,000.
 
Where is the pain for the FELON?  Yes, he sits in jail because we stuck the FBI on him because the State Probation Officer was obviously asleep at the wheel.  He still calls me from jail – how many calls are they allowed in a day?
 
Where is the pain for the FINANCIAL INSTITUTION?  They are still receiving monthly payments for useless land that they provided a FELON our money.  I’d love someone other than me to ask the following questions:
 
1)      Why did your bank employee refer to him as a Preferred Builder?
2)      Why did your bank employee tell me he was a good builder then stumbled when I asked name one thing that he has built?
3)      Why did they provide him millions without doing at least a credit check?
Assume a FELON who has spent a number of years in jail he would have poor credit.
4)      Why  an officer of the bank shut a door in my face when I asked about the                      loan they were getting ready to provide him – prior to the FBI coming in to ask questions?
5)      What they think about the Felon’s probation office being in the lobby of the bank?
6)      What type of guidelines do they have to safe guard their clients?
7)      Why was the appraisal that was done provided by someone the FELON chose and not a bank appraiser?
8)      Why did they provide more than what the land appraised for?  It shouldn’t have mattered what we signed – then why have an appraisal.
9)      Why didn’t they catch his name change when they were establishing him as one of their developers?
10)    Why the loan officer would not accept my calls when we were trying to get this loan and I had questions?
11) Why they provided him a mortgage on his million dollar plus headquarters?
 
I accept some responsibility for this decision – but why am I living this HELL and becoming more and more FINANCIALLY devastated.  There are laws and professional guidelines that should have protected me.
 
There is something someone can do and we are determined to find them.  We are so disappointed in our government, the laws and especially our elected officials.
 
Let’s recap who all I’ve contacted in the last couple of months:
 
The White House – form letter
 
Senator Nelson- office personnel called so sorry but can’t help
 
Congressman Fenney  - office personnel called so sorry but can’t help
 
State Senator Brummer – office personnel made call for us, sorry can’t really help and he is losing his seat at the end of this term.  Later I found out, he is however running for County Commissioner and someone came by my house asking if they could put up a sign – I don’t think so.
 
Orange County Mayor – no response at all
 
County Commissioners (contacted all) – no response at all
 
Governor Jeb Bush - office personnel called so sorry but can’t help
 
Lt. Governor Toni Jennings- no response at all
 
Attorney General Charlie Crist – after second email office personnel met with us, sorry 
not much we can do to help.
 
Florida Department of Business and Regulations – provided information on funds, sorry you don’t fit the small scope in which the law provides for, so sorry.
 
Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services – sent complaint form, so sorry can’t do much else
 
Numerous Individuals at City of Apopka – sorry can’t help, most never responded back to us.
 
Federal Bureau of Investigations – spent hours with them and they investigated and got the FELON on laundering money for a drug dealer.
 
 
 
If at my job I made these types of errors I’d be fired – why is NO ONE ACCOUNTABLE.  I am (there are about 50 others) now out over $200,000 for property that would probably appraise today at $35,000 – but don’t forget the $153,000 illegal lien that is currently placed on the property.
 
 
 
.
 
There has to be SOMEONE out there that can CHAMPION our cause.  I don’t want something unrealistic – I just want out of this nightmare.  Here is what I would like to see happen:
 
1)      The bank to let me sign over my property and they forgive the loan of approximately $125,000.  They have errors and omissions insurance they will become whole – believe me they have a ton of errors.
2)      For the State Real Estate Relief Fund to repay me the real estate fees that were paid to Felon’s wife approximately $12,000.
3)      For the State Contractor Relief Fund to repay me my deposit of approximately $42,000.
 
I would still be out approximately $30,000 cash and that is fine with me because I own some of this responsibility too.  I did my homework as best I could with the information I was provided and got burned badly, but many others were asleep at the wheel or looked the other way and are not being burned at all.
 
PLEASE HELP!!!!
 
Please contact us and at least hear our story!!!
 
 
Sincerely,
 
DeAna Mullins-Gudino
1747 Sweetwater West Circle
Apopka, FL  32712
407-814-0592 evening
407-691-9895 daytime

Subject:	[*] Crosby pleads guilty to accepting kickbacks

This St. Petersburg Times (http://www.sptimes.com) story has been sent to you from: tonytke@yahoo.com

Pardon these guys!!! They belong to"The Rangers" fund raiser club!!!

Crosby pleads guilty to accepting kickbacks
By LUCY MORGAN
Published July 5, 2006

http://www.sptimes.com/2006/07/05/State/Crosby_pleads_guilty_.shtml

null

Former Corrections Chief James V. Crosby Jr. has admitted taking more than $130,000 in kickbacks between October 2003 and February of 2006 when he was forced to resign.<br /><br />In a plea agreement reached with federal prosecutors Wednesday, Crosby admitted corruptly accepting the money and agreed to cooperate in a continuing investigation of others in an effort to get a reduced prison sentence.<br /><br />Allen Clark, former director of prisons in North Florida and a close Crosby associate, entered a similar agreement with prosecutors. Both men have agreed to forfeit assets acquired with the kickbacks they received.<br /><br />Clark resigned on August 30, 2005, as state and federal investigators began looking at his conduct.<br /><br />The kickbacks were allegedly paid by Edward L. Dugger and an associate in return for a subcontract obtained for prison canteen sales handled by Keefe Commissary Network.<br /><br />Dugger is described as &quot;&quot;the conspirator&#39;&#39; in documents filed in federal court Wednesday. He did not return a telephone call from a <em>Times</em> reporter.<br /><br />Crosby worked his way up through the state prison system after going to work in 1975 and was named Secretary of the Department of Corrections in 2003 by Gov. Jeb Bush.<br /><br />At the governor&#39;s urging, Crosby joined many other state officials in pursuit of private contracts to replace canteens previously run by prison inmates. He hired Keefe in 2003 under a contract that has since been criticized by state auditors. &nbsp;&nbsp;¬© Copyright 2002-2006, St. Petersburg Times
From:	JSKALET@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 9:24 PM
To:	Detert, Nancy
Cc:	Aronberg, Dave; Bennett, Michael (LEG); frederick.brummer@myfloridahouse.gov; Governor Jeb Bush; Carlton, Lisa; Clarke, Donna; Brett@tg2006.com; Lt.
