Subject:	Re: LETTER TO THE EDITOR

Dear Nancy,  it means a lot to me that you would take the time to read my comments regarding the homestead exemption,  have interest in those comments and take the time to send me your thoughts.  I know that fraud is a problem in virtually all areas of public assistance, municipal and state services and the collection of revenues to provide for them.   Property tax revenue is such a significant and essential part of that equation that I think collection and fair assessment of it is extremely important as I know you do.  One thing that I believe the  68  county appraisers really need out of Tallahassee is a clear definition of what constitutes  “in good faith occupy the property as a permanent residence”  as written in the statute,  this is pretty vague and as a result,  the appraisers vary a lot on what questions they ask to determine it. I think they need “teeth”  in order for their determination to hold up against aggressive claimants.  What amount of rental disqualifies the owner,  home much of the year do they need to live there,  can they have a residence exemption in another state,  can family live there, do both spouses have to live there, etc.?   I believe that most statutes,  once created and passed by the legislature,  need an interpretation,  usually done by the state attorney general’s office.  When I asked that office to define for me what criteria determined if an owner was using the property as a permanent resident,  their spokesman told me to get an attorney in private practice to advise me.  If that’s what the appraisers are getting,  no wonder they are trying to figure out how to enforce it and no wonder it varies so much from one County to another.  I have attached a link to the Lee County Fraud suspicion form if you would like to pass it on to Mr. Todora. Lee Cty-fraud report  (click on homestead fraud report at top of page) I don’t think it would be well received from me.   Best regards to you and thank you again for your willingness to communicate on this.  Please call on me if I can ever be of help to you or any of your efforts.   Just so you know a little more about who you are talking too,   I am not a Florida voter yet.  I live and work in Denver, CO and own a small condominium on Siesta Key and I am a Condominium Association Board member there and a member of the Siesta Key Association.  I am a CPA by background and when I retire I will spend a lot more time in your beautiful area.  I have a genuine interest in the fiscal health of Florida of the Sarasota community.

 

John  (800) 321 9592

 
In a message dated 7/5/2006 12:08:46 P.M. Mountain Daylight Time, Nancy.Detert@myfloridahouse.gov writes:


Dear Mr. Skalet;
 
Thank you for your e-mail regarding Homestead Exemptions.  You point to something that is needed-more enforcement of existing laws by the property appraisers office.  Naturally, they do not have enough staff to check the veracity of each exemption. However, we would all benefit by increasing their staff so as to cut down on fraud.  We see the same problem in other areas such as health insurance, workers comp., etc.  It would pay to have enough people to enforce current laws.  As a law maker, I support more money to hire more inspectors.  The idea of a website for reporting is a good one.  We all know which neighbors are part time and which are full time.
 
Thank you for your suggestion.
 
Sincerely,
 
Rep. Nancy Detert-Venice

Subject: LETTER TO THE EDITOR




XT DIS   THE NEXT DISASTER!        HURRICANE OR THE HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION?

 

As I read the Sarasota papers it seems ironic to me that the very office of the County that is saddled with the task of policing the Homestead Exemption now seems to be advertising for new applicants.   I suppose that it is important to notify “would be, legitimate, entitled, Homesteaders to the benefits of the Homestead Exemption and the corresponding “Save our Homes” Amendment but it seems to me that a far bigger issue for the Sarasota County Appraisers office is to do some policing and reduce the wide spread abuse of the Exemption by claimants who do not “in good faith make it his or her permanent home”.   The Sarasota county,  Homestead claimants must make application, asserting that they truly are a permanent Florida Resident, evidenced by things like tax returns, drivers license, voter registration, auto registration,  and current employment.  Other counties  require various documents like exemption withdrawals from other state’s of residence and statements from the owner(s) that they have not rented their property during the past 2 years.   In the Sarasota application they must also state their date of occupancy of the specific property and whether or not they got an exemption last year.  They do not need to state that they do not intend to rent their property but they do need to state that “they qualify under the statute for the Exemption and that they own and occupy the subject property.”  What the statute actually says is that the applicant must be a permanent Florida Resident and that they “in good faith occupy the property as their permanent residence.”  It also states that  “rental of an entire dwelling previously claimed to be a Homestead for tax purposes shall constitute the abandonment of said dwelling as a Homestead”,  however,  if the property is occupied by the claimant on January 1st but is later rented during that year they do not abandon the Homestead “ so long as this provision is not used for two consecutive years”   What that tells me is that a legitimate exemption claimant can rent a property after January 1st of the Exemption year but they can not do it two years in a row without sacrificing the Exemption.   I believe that it is this provision that is being totally ignored by the appraiser’s office.  The appraiser’s responsibility in the statute is to “examine each claim” and determine “accordance with law (the statute), marking the same approved and making the proper deductions on the tax books”   You might say, “what’s the big deal?”   The big deal is that millions of dollars of tax burden, county, schools, fire, hospital, water and emergency services is being transferred over to the part time resident owners when illegitimate claimants are getting a huge reduction on their tax bill.  The biggest reductions are coming from the “Save our Homes” amendment which limits annual increases on Homesteaded properties to only 3% or the CPI.  As the tax burden shifts to the honest taxpayer,  fewer and fewer properties make sense as investments or rentals,  reducing the number of properties available to house tourists who bring our County huge sales tax revenues and our businesses most of their sales revenue  The least expensive beach area properties now have a property tax burden over $4,000 a year,  20% over last year and they have total occupancy levels averaging about 20% of available days. What this means is that the owners will claim the exemption and not rent, try to sell their property, or claim the exemption and still rent.  It is the Homesteading claimant who is periodically renting their unit each year where I believe there is widespread fraud and the appraiser’s office needs to get enforcement engaged.  It is my opinion that this abuse of the rental prohibition in the statute, that calls for abandonment of the exemption on  properties rented for any amount of time in any two consecutive years,  is unchecked.  I believe this could be enforced easily in that every management company or renting condominium association files an individual taxpayer 1099 tax form with the Federal Government and the Florida Department of Revenue for each owners collected rental revenue each year.  They also collect, report and submit to the County Treasurer the sales tax collected on the rental income of the owner.  This record could simply be checked against the list of owners claiming the Homestead Exemption, identifying the tax evaders.   A few misdemeanor convictions, collection of taxes in arrears with interest and $5000 fines would drastically reduce the abuse..   Many beach area owners are now saving in excess of $10,000 a year by utilizing  the Homestead Exemption. I did my own little research study and found that about 18% of the roughly 500,  million dollar plus units at the Posh Siesta Key “Gulf and Bay Resort”  were paying property taxes as a permanent resident,  paying around $4,000 in taxes while their neighbors were paying around $14,000.  Give me a break!,  nowhere near 18% of owners of  beachfront properties like Gulf and Bay  “in good faith occupy the property as their permanent residence”.  Granted,  the legislature or the State Attorney General do need to more specifically define what “in good faith occupy the property” means.   If owners don’t need to lie on the Sarasota application that they “use the property as their permanent residence” and “that they don’t rent their properties”, they will continue to steal from the rest of us!   In defense of the Sarasota County Appraiser’s office,  it appears that there is no current staff available to enforce compliance with the Florida Statutes regarding the Homestead Exemption.  The Lee County appraiser has initiated a web-site anonymous fraud suspicion report for his constituents to assist the efforts of his office in eliminating this fraud.   I suggest to the Sarasota County appraiser’s office that they first obtain the supporting detail from the management companies collecting the rental taxes and compare it to the list of Homestead Exemption owners!  Recent articles in the Herald and other Florida newspapers have been focused on alleged frauds and abuses being owners of Homesteaded properties in more than one Florida county.  I think the multiple Florida property issue is dwarfed by the partial year Florida residents  who are claiming the exemption and don’t meet the criteria,  leaving the burden to the rest of us who are honest.

 

John T. Skalet

Siesta Key Property Owner

contacted me at my home in Fort Mill, SC on February 10th, 2004.  I was 
eventually arrested in my home State.

State Law Enforcement Officials and Public Safety.  I perceived his use of 
your title as an act of intimidation towards these representative of South 
Carolina and in an effort to cover up the mistakes made by Officer Annello,

in the first place.

farmers.

deposit the sum of US$18M (Eighteen Million United State Dollars) with one of
the Financial Institution, as if he knew the looming danger in ZIMBABWE. We
were married for twelve years and God blessed us with two children.

Institution. Recently, my Doctor told me that I might

individual, group or a charity organisation that will
utilize this money the way I am going to instruct
herein while half of the money shall be kept for the
betterment of my children. I want an individual, or
Charity Organisation that will use this fund for
orphanages, widows, and helping land mine victims
worldwide.

are Trouble Makers and I don't want my husband's
efforts to be used for trivialities I do not want a
situation where my husband's sweat will be used in
material pursuits. This is why I am taking this
decision.

Governor Bush has received your e-mail and has asked me to respond on his behalf.
 


As you may know, Florida has very few laws governing employer/employee relations.  The Florida Legislature is responsible for debating and creating new laws, so you may want to contact your legislators to make them aware of your views.  

 

I wish you success in your future professional experiences.  If you have not consulted an attorney, you may want to consider doing so.  I am concerned about your problem, and am sorry that the law does not provide me the power to assist you further.

> From: "Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
> Date: 2006/07/02 Sun PM 03:29:27 EDT
> To: "Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
> Subject: Governor Jeb Bush's IN THE NEWS... Friday, June 30, 2006
> 
> For those E-Newsletter recipients who have Adobe Acrobat reader, Governor
> Bush's e-newsletter is available in .PDF format by clicking here:
> 
> http://www.flgov.com/in_the_news
> 
> The text version of the e-newsletter is below.
> 
> 
> BILL CREATING NEW COMMISSION FOR CHARTER SCHOOLS SIGNED INTO LAW
> 
> On Monday, I signed House Bill 135, which creates a state-level charter
> school authorizer - the Florida Schools of Excellence Commission. This
> independent statewide commission will directly sponsor charter schools and
> authorize municipalities, state universities, community colleges and
> additional entities to co-sponsor charter schools in Florida, expanding
> educational opportunities for students.  Florida's charter schools offer a
> valuable public school option for students.  This legislation opens the door
> for the expansion of more high quality charter schools in Florida, and the
> newly created Commission will ensure that these schools are held accountable
> for serving student needs.  To learn more about charter schools in Florida,
> visit the Office of Independent Education and Parental Choice Office website
> at www.floridaschoolchoice.org. 
>  
> 
> BILLS TO BENEFIT FLORIDA VETERANS AND ACTIVE DUTY MILITARY TROOPS SIGNED
> INTO LAW
> 
> On Monday, I signed into law a series of bills that will provide additional
> benefits to Florida's veterans and active duty military troops. Since 1999,
> the Florida Legislature and I have worked diligently to establish Florida as
> a military and veteran-friendly state.  In 2005, an interim study conducted
> by the U.S. House Military and Veterans' Affairs Committee ranked Florida
> highest overall in providing benefits to veterans.  On behalf of all
> Floridians, I thank our soldiers and veterans for their extraordinary
> dedication and service to our country.  Their selfless dedication to our
> country commands not only our respect and admiration, but also our
> willingness to provide them and their families with assistance to improve
> their quality of life.  For more information on benefits and assistance for
> veterans, please visit www.floridavets.org.
>  
> 
> RURAL INFRASTRUCTURE GRANT OF MORE THAN $235,000 AWARDED TO FLAGLER COUNTY
> 
> On Tuesday, I awarded Flagler County a Rural Infrastructure Fund Grant
> totaling $236,813 to assist in the retention of Sea Ray Boats, Inc., a
> manufacturer of high quality pleasure yachts.   The grant will be used for
> roadway, sidewalks and drainage improvements that will help retain 644
> full-time jobs within Flagler County. These 644 jobs contribute more than
> $21 million to the local economy in annual payroll dollars.  We are proud to
> support Flagler County's efforts to retain an area manufacturer that
> provides more than 51 percent of the county's manufacturing jobs.  The
> infrastructure improvements will ease traffic flow for company employees,
> vendors and residents in nearby neighborhoods.  Florida's Rural
> Infrastructure Fund is a key component of our rural economic development
> efforts.  For more information on Florida's economic development
> initiatives, please visit www.myflorida.com.
> 
> 
> JIM MCDONOUGH NAMED SECRETARY OF THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS
> 
> On Thursday, I named Colonel (Ret.) Jim McDonough as Secretary of the
> Florida Department of Corrections. McDonough has recently served as the
> interim Secretary of the Department. The appointment is effective
> immediately. Previously, McDonough served as Director of the Florida Office
> of Drug Control from 1999 to 2006. Prior to his work in the Governor's
> Office, he was Director of Strategy for the Office of National Drug Control
> Policy, the White House agency leading the nation's efforts to reduce drug
> abuse, from 1996-1999.  During the past seven years, Colonel McDonough has
> proven to be a strong and principled leader, dedicated to serving the State
> of Florida.  I am confident he will continue leading the Department of
> Corrections with integrity.   For more information on the Department of
> Corrections, please visit www.myflorida.com or www.dc.state.fl.us.
> 
> 
> GOVERNOR BUSH PRESENTS POINTS OF LIGHT AWARD TO LAWRENCE RICE
> 
> Congratulations!
> 
> To read more about this week's winners, please click here: 
> http://www.flgov.com/release/7953
>

From:	Dyuti Mahendru <funkemunke08@gmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 4:02 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Re: Manatees

Thank you for the response.

--Ms.Dyuti Mahendru


On 7/5/06, Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@myflorida.com > wrote:

Dear Mr. Mahendru,

 

Thank you for sharing your concerns about the new science-based process for classifying Florida's imperiled species.  Governor Bush appreciates your sharing your views and opinions about this important issue and asked me to respond on his behalf.

 

The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC) is using sound science to determine the appropriate classifications for manatees, bald eagles, gopher tortoises and Panama City crayfish.  Regardless of their final determination, the Commission will develop management plans to ensure continued protection and sustainability of these species.  Management plans typically take a year to draft and the process includes public participation.

 

The goal of the Commission is for all imperiled species populations to recover.  As the bald eagle population has recovered substantially, it is appropriate for the species to be removed from the list.  Because the manatee is no longer in imminent danger of extinction, it will be reclassified as threatened.  However, it is important to note that a threatened species by definition still faces a very high risk of extinction.  Even though the species has recovered substantially, the marine mammal will continue to be protected under the new process.

 

The State of Florida and the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission are committed to the recovery of our imperiled species.  For more information about the reclassification process, please visit www.myfwc.com. 

 

Thank you again for writing and for sharing your concerns with Governor Bush.

 

 

Sincerely, 

 

Shahlaine KhunKhun

Office of Citizens' Services

Dear Mr. Jeb Bush,
 
Hello, my name is Dyuti Mahendru.  I was made aware that there is a debate on the subject of whether or not to down list the manatees from "endangered" to "threatened".  In my opinion, I believe that you should not down list the manatees.  This will result in further danger for the manatees.  It is imperative that everyone is made aware of the severity of this subject.  By keeping the manatee's label as "endangered" there will be greater awareness.  Please do not down list the manatees.  If the state of Florida does not take action now, the manatees will be gone tomorrow and there will be no way to bring them back.  Please help these poor manatees, as the death rate of the manatees is increasing exponentially. 
 
Thank you for your patience,
 
Dyuti Mahendru

From: "Jan Bergemann" <janberg@att.net>
To: "Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
CC: "DBPR Secretary Simone Marstiller" <Simone.Marstiller@dbpr.state.fl.us>
Subject: ASSOCIATION BILLS VETOED! NOW WHAT??
Date: Wed, 5 Jul 2006 12:18:09 -0400
MIME-Version: 1.0
Received: from mtiwmhc11.worldnet.att.net ([204.127.131.115]) by bay0-mc12-f12.bay0.hotmail.com with Microsoft SMTPSVC(6.0.3790.2444); Wed, 5 Jul 2006 09:23:03 -0700
Received: from bergj (79.orlando-09rh15-16rt.fl.dial-access.att.net[12.78.66.79]) by worldnet.att.net (mtiwmhc11) with SMTP id <20060705161818111004b60le>; Wed, 5 Jul 2006 16:20:47 +0000



CCFJ, Inc, Dispatch -- Please Distribute Widely! 
July 5, 2006
 

Dear Governor Jeb Bush, Dear Secretary Simone Marstiller, Dear Legislators, Friends and Members,
 
After both major association bills have been vetoed, it is really time to find solutions for all the open problems, not just trying to find band-aids for the many pending issues. 
We have here in Florida not only a total property insurance disaster, but as well serious problems for owners in mandatory associations -- condos and homeowners' associations alike!
In his veto messages the Governor already stated that reforms are really necessary.
Please read the Governor's suggestions in his veto messages at:
http://www.ccfj.net/PB06HB391-SB1556veto.html
 
It is time that we create the necessary reforms -- in insurance and association law -- trying to avoid that many families -- and especially retirees -- are being priced out of their homes.
It is time that we will see a comprehensive bill that will try to remedy the many problems owners are facing on a daily basis. We need statutes with teeth -- meaning easy enforcement of our laws and regulations -- and education and accountability of the people in charge.
 
The only people with a vested interest in this matter are the owners, not the service providers or anybody else.
These new laws should protect the property rights of the owners, not the income of the service providers!

A comprehensive association bill will be ready for the next legislative session!
 
Warm Regards,

Jan Bergemann, President
Cyber Citizens For Justice, Inc.
http://www.ccfj.net/
 
IN ALLIANCE WITH: 
League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC) 
Property Owners Association in the Villages (POA) 
Service Employees International Union (SEIU) Local 11  
Fair Housing Center of the Greater Palm Beaches (FHCGPB) 



  _____  

Get the new Windows Live Messenger! 
From:	WriteDel2000@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 3:18 PM
To:	wishfer@att.net; Governor Jeb Bush; janberg@att.net
Cc:	Marstiller, Simone
Subject:	Re: Indeed, Now What?

Robert!

  Del Revels 
From:	Robert Janauskas <wishfer@att.net>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 3:57 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; Jan Bergemann
Cc:	Marstiller, Simone
Subject:	Indeed, Now What?

Dear Secretary Simone Martstiller, et al
 
Obviously, while it IS important to bring the 'Sunshine State' out into the sunshine we must walk before we run to the nearest subdivision and/or condominium. 
 
It's been said; '..be careful what you ask for...you just might get it!' 
 
Therefore, Full Disclosure NOT Caveat Emptor must be the 'Buy Words' during real estate transactions in Florida. 
 
Passing and enacting more laws without adequate protection of prospective purchasers and current residents will NOT stem the tide of discontent in communities with mandatory homeowners associations. 
 
It's important to understand, there isn't an agency in Florida that requires a developer, owner and/or seller to provide a copy of the CC&R's prior to contract for sale. 
 
Therefore, the primary criteria for meaningful reform of HOAs is the full disclosure of the Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions (CC&R's) prior to contract for sale. All else will fail if this important stipulation isn't enacted!  
 
To date: 
 
*The DBPR has been reluctant to insist upon this disclosure. 
*Realtors are unwilling to provide the CC&R's
*Industry partisans simply say, "...provide, if requested..." 
 
Secondly, a developer must not be allowed to hide the yearly financial disclosure of receipts and expenditures from residents into a for profit corporation unaccessible by residents.
 
All funds collected must be deposited in the mandatory homeowners association account and disbursed for the benefit of the community and its members.
 
Developers must not be allowed to issue a yearly financial report of the HOA which reads: "Nothing collected, nothing spent!"  
 
This is a SHAM! 
 
Full disclosure and a yearly financial report of receipts and expenditures by the HOA before and after transition of control will enhance peace, harmony and tranquility in communities. 
 
Purchasers simply want a copy of the governing documents before contract for sale and to know how THEIR money is being spent while the developer is in control of the HOA.
 
The mandate of Governor Jeb Bush seems clear but it won't be easily attained if competing forces aren't seated at the same table to brainstorm meaningful HOA reform. 
 
It just won't happen!  
 
With all due respect, I wish you the best and look forward to learning how, by your own initiative, you'll insist that the Governor's mandate shall be accomplished. 
Sincerely, 
Robert E. Janauskas 
5395 SW 81st Street
Ocala, FL 34476 

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Jan Bergemann 
To: Governor Jeb Bush 
Cc: DBPR Secretary Simone Marstiller 
Sent: Wednesday, July 05, 2006 11:18 AM
Subject: ASSOCIATION BILLS VETOED! NOW WHAT??


CCFJ, Inc, Dispatch -- Please Distribute Widely! 
July 5, 2006
 

Dear Governor Jeb Bush, Dear Secretary Simone Marstiller, Dear Legislators, Friends and Members,
 
After both major association bills have been vetoed, it is really time to find solutions for all the open problems, not just trying to find band-aids for the many pending issues. 
We have here in Florida not only a total property insurance disaster, but as well serious problems for owners in mandatory associations -- condos and homeowners' associations alike!
In his veto messages the Governor already stated that reforms are really necessary.
Please read the Governor's suggestions in his veto messages at:
http://www.ccfj.net/PB06HB391-SB1556veto.html
 
It is time that we create the necessary reforms -- in insurance and association law -- trying to avoid that many families -- and especially retirees -- are being priced out of their homes.
It is time that we will see a comprehensive bill that will try to remedy the many problems owners are facing on a daily basis. We need statutes with teeth -- meaning easy enforcement of our laws and regulations -- and education and accountability of the people in charge.
 
The only people with a vested interest in this matter are the owners, not the service providers or anybody else.
These new laws should protect the property rights of the owners, not the income of the service providers!

A comprehensive association bill will be ready for the next legislative session!
 
Warm Regards,

Jan Bergemann, President
Cyber Citizens For Justice, Inc.
http://www.ccfj.net/
 
IN ALLIANCE WITH: 
League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC) 
Property Owners Association in the Villages (POA) 
Service Employees International Union (SEIU) Local 11  
Fair Housing Center of the Greater Palm Beaches (FHCGPB) 

From:	Lee <leegullett@hotmail.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 2:36 PM
To:	McDonough, Jim
Cc:	Jen Girgen; Linda S Vaughn; Governor Jeb Bush; Monica David; Beth Atchison; Linda Brooks; Tony V Harper
Subject:	Cost of Probation

Dear Mr. McDonough,
As you are a busy man I will make this short.
During our March 20th meeting I told you I was picking up "my" prisoner the next day.  We have found that transition back into family and community has been the roughest part of this entire experience.  
I am preparing a letter telling you of some of the difficulties that probationers face upon release; difficulties not even hinted at during their classes.  But that is for another time.
 
My reason for writing today is the financial burden placed upon a probationer and his/her family.  I have just budgeted what we must pay for the month of July and I would like to give you an idea of what is put on the backs of these people and their families.  I will use my fiancé as an example.
July 3rd
    Drug Test $20.00
    Alcohol Test $20.00
    Substance Abuse Meeting $20.00
July 5th
    Monthly payment to P&P $100.00
July 10th
    Substance Abuse Meeting $20.00
July 17th 
    Substance Abuse Meeting $20.00
July 18th
    Drug Test $50.00
July 24th
    Substance Abuse Meeting $20.00
July 31st
    Substance Abuse Meeting $20.00
 
There will be a Substance Abuse Meeting Counseling session (as yet unscheduled) for $50.00
This does not include any drug or alcohol tests (as $20.00 each) that P&P may spring on him.
This also does not include lost wages and/or gas.
 
This totals $340.00 (plus extras) that must be paid to P&P every month.  
 
These are payments that MUST be paid due to DOC's zero tolerance policy.  
Jim's crimes had nothing to do with drugs or alcohol but he must still attend meetings.  Jim has back problems and brought the prescriptions into the P&P office, as well as the Substance Abuse Evaluation ($65.00) but he must still be tested for drugs he has prescriptions for.  While in prison Jim ran both AA and NA meetings because of his passion to stop this type of abuse. But all this means nothing.  DOC mandates that probationers attend these meetings and be subjected and pay for drug & alcohol testing and meetings (a probationer could go to AA or NA for free).
 
Mr. McDonough, this is breaking the backs of those newly released and their families.  If the inmate/probationer's crime did not involve drugs or alcohol, why must they be subjected to this additional financial burden?  It is difficult enough to get started again after release.  
For a felon to find a job is quite difficult.  
For a felon to find a place to live is almost impossible (even public housing excludes felons).  
A newly released inmate/probationer must procure food, clothing and any other type of commodity that is necessary to live in the "free world" and find transportation to a job.  Most are lucky to find employment at minimum wage.  How are they to live with this additional, (and in many cases unnecessary) burden placed upon them.  If they can't pay then the family must.
 
You have done so much to alleviate financial burdens placed on family's, and for that I truly thank you, but I would ask that you look into P&P policies, mandated by DOC, that continue to drain a family financially when the prisoner is released.  These continuous tests and meetings are setting these people up for failure and, as a result, a ride back to prison.  For the well-to-do, these fee's mean nothing but for the majority of probationers these fees mean the difference between food and prison .. housing and prison (they are violated if they don't have housing) ... transportation to a job and prison (they are violated if they can't secure employment).
 
The Governor has a task force looking into things like this.  The Legislature is currently looking into things like this.  The hard fact is that looking is not doing!  You, Mr. McDonough, are a doer!  
 
Our county jails are filled to overflowing with probationers that have technical violations, such as not paying their P&P fees.  They stay in a sentencing limbo in a county jail awaiting a bed to open up in a prison so they can "start the clock" again; so they can be released to P&P again; so they can violate again.
 
Please, look at this problem. Can these DOC mandated "conditions of release" be looked at and maybe be tailored to the individual and the crime they committed rather then be simply rubber stamped for all?
 
Thank you for your time, sir and thank you for doing so much to make the Florida Prison System so much better for all involved.
 
Sincerely,
Lee Gullett
Proud member of the Florida LOLITS
From:	Hyson, Jeff <Jeff.Hyson@fluke.com>
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 2:26 PM
To:	fhp@hsmv.state.fl.us
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Traffic Law Enforcement

To whom it may concern : 

While driving near my home on June 14, 2006 I was issued a citation by Officer Burnett (Badge # 1968) for running a red light at the intersection of Aloma Ave. and Tuskawilla Road.  I was in a right turn only lane that is poorly marked to indicate a stop.  I tapped the brakes, checked for traffic from the other direction and then continued through the turn.  Officer Burnett was waiting there and signaled for me and one other driver to pull over.  I gave my drivers license and registration as requested.  I was fined $180.50 and points were assigned to my license.  During the time I waited for Officer Burnett to come back to my car, at least 20 other drivers also committed the same offense.

I am not complaining - I will pay my fine as I did commit a traffic offense.  The thing that really bothered me was I drove by the same intersection this morning and Trooper Burnett was camped out in the same spot.  My daughter recently started at the University of Florida and I have spent a bit of time on the turnpike and I-75 in the last few weeks.  While driving at the speed limit, I am amazed at how many drivers are exceeding the posted limits by 20 MPH or more.  I am also amazed at how few state troopers are out on patrol on these major highways.  Shouldn't our state troopers be spending more time out on our highways and leave the local traffic enforcement to the county & city agencies?  I find it hard to believe that having a trooper assigned to one intersection writing citations is making much of a contribution to the safety of our roads, which I thought was the mission of the Florida Highway Patrol.  

Your comments or explanation would be appreciated. 

Jeff Hyson 
2898 Oak Bluff Way      
Oviedo, FL 32765 

407-977-9416

-----Original Message-----
From: Governor Jeb Bush <Jeb.Bush@MyFlorida.com>
To: FelixFusco@aol.com
Sent: Wed, 5 Jul 2006 10:52:19 -0400
Subject: RE: Save the Manatees


Dear Friends,
 
Thank you for sharing your concerns about the new science-based process for classifying Florida’s imperiled species.  Governor Bush appreciates your sharing your views and opinions about this important issue and asked me to respond on his behalf.
 
The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC) is using sound science to determine the appropriate classifications for manatees, bald eagles, gopher tortoises and Panama City crayfish.  Regardless of their final determination, the Commission will develop management plans to ensure continued protection and sustainability of these species.  Management plans typically take a year to draft and the process includes public participation.
 
The goal of the Commission is for all imperiled species populations to recover.  As the bald eagle population has recovered substantially, it is appropriate for the species to be removed from the list.  Because the manatee is no longer in imminent danger of extinction, it will be reclassified as threatened.  However, it is important to note that a threatened species by definition still faces a very high risk of extinction.  Even though the species has recovered substantially, the marine mammal will continue to be protected under the new process.
 
The State of Florida and the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission are committed to the recovery of our imperiled species.  For more information about the reclassification process, please visit www.myfwc.com.
 
Thank you again for writing and for sharing your concerns with Governor Bush.
 
 
Sincerely, 
 
Shahlaine KhunKhun
Office of Citizens’ Services

the observer
Play By The Rules
The Coconut Grove Playhouse is dark, in more ways than one. It closed in 
April after "Sonia Flew," a play which saw its opening night thanks to a last 
minute effort by actress Lucy Arnaz, who successfully begged this community to 
give over $100,000 and threw in some $50,000 of her own as well. In a matter of 
days this charismatic woman managed to do what the Playhouse board of directors 
had not – raise money to keep the Playhouse alive and open, even if only for 
a few days.
When she hit the fundraising streets, Arnaz was unaware that employees would 
be left unpaid – not just salaries, but also expenses their supervisors had 
asked them to incur on behalf of the theater. Otherwise, I bet she would have 
done right by those employees who for years, even decades, devoted their lives 
to the theater they loved.
Luck willing, some of those prestigious members of the board of directors 
might become embarrassed enough to dig into their corporate pockets and pay the 
employees what is due them. And that means unpaid wages, expenses and 
severance. You do not pull the plug, without warning, on employees of five, 10 or 20 
years without giving them something to live on for a while. It is, after all, 
not their fault that the board allowed such gross mismanagement on its watch.
Otherwise, they could allocate the funds the Playhouse still receives every 
month from the Miami Parking Authority's lease of the parking lot adjacent to 
the theater. That would be $200,000 per year, divided by 12 months – you do the 
math. Where is that money going?
Surely it's a matter or priorities, and the Playhouse board doesn't view the 
employees that they left high and dry as one of them.
Then again, it's rather hard to imagine that they felt the need to finally 
cry uncle when they were in debt over $4 million dollars, and not sooner. It is 
so incomprehensible, it boggles the mind.
Where were those folks for the last few years? Were they planning the next 
gala? Or just lamely endorsing all decisions made by the board's executive 
committee, while remaining clueless?
As money was being handled or mishandled, and millions in debt grew and 
multiplied like bunny rabbits in spring, the Playhouse board was run by bankers and 
certified public accountants – folks one would assume understand a balance 
sheet.
But, we're told, this is all Arnold Mittelman's fault – the man who took out 
the improperly collateralized bank loan to pay salaries, including his own. 
The man who was not user friendly to the community, promising them so much and 
delivering so little. The man who fought hard to impede the hiring of a 
business manager – a brilliant idea sparked by then-State Rep. Manny Prieguez' 
decision in 2001 to block a $500,000 yearly state appropriation, citing the need for 
better accountability in operations and in the use of public and donor funds.
Alas, much to the board's chagrin, the disastrous predicament of the Coconut 
Grove Playhouse is not Mittelman's fault. He was an employee, with a contract 
negotiated by the executive committee (the full board was not allowed to 
participate in its last negotiation), whose actions were approved or condoned by 
the board – read: the employer, the boss.
That's where the buck stops.
With news of the millions in debt hitting the street, a "closed" sign on the 
theater doors, and some board members attesting that it was only days before 
that they discovered the extent of the financial ruin, the shameless board's 
reaction was not to fire Mittelman, but rather ask him if he would pretty please 
consider quitting.
Mittelman, of course, quit several weeks later when he was good and ready, 
because no one had the guts to fire him.
By the time you're $4 million in the hole, you're taking a whole lot of 
people down with you: employees, vendors large and small, loyal subscribers who 
pre-paid for a season they will not see, and an entire community.
And that's not right.
It's time to clean house, starting with the board of directors.
Regaining the trust of the community is not going to happen until changes are 
made in the governance of the Playhouse that suggest to future donors and 
supporters that their money will be well managed.
It is not going to happen until the theater is run with accountability and 
transparency, with a board in place that understands the fiduciary 
responsibility to its public grantors, private donors and the community at large. A board 
capable of overseeing policy, resource allocation, budget creation and 
adherence, internal controls, planning and execution of the core values of the 
organization and its business plan.
So Ladies and Gentlemen of the board – please do us all a favor and resign.
The Playhouse deserves a committed and competent professional to manage the 
reconstruction and transition. I'm certain the city and the county could help 
identify that individual.
Then hit the streets, pound the pavement and raise some money to bring back 
our beloved institution – you're some of Miami's finest, and you can make it 
happen.
And never again join a board where you accept being left in the dark. 
Willingly or not.
Pretty please?

Another article from th Miami Monthly which is another reason why you must 
act fast!

'No' To Home Depot
Zoning Board sides with Grovites
When the City of Miami Zoning Board got its chance to speak on the proposed 
Home Depot at 2999 SW 32nd Ave., it delivered a firm no.
The Zoning Board was set to hear an appeal of the Class II building permit 
issued by the Planning Department in April. Grove First, the group leading the 
opposition of Home Depot, filed the appeal as a last recourse before filing a 
lawsuit against the city for what they call "improper issuance of a Class II 
permit."
Most observers expected the appeal to be denied by the Zoning Department. In 
siding with residents, Zoning Board members indicated that being a "bad 
neighbor" was Home Depot's downfall. Many board members commented on the poor 
conditions that currently exist at the SW 8th Street store. "Eighth Street is my 
community," said board member Charles Garavaglia. "I go there about once a week 
and it's a total disaster."
Don Harrison, a Home Depot public relations manager, confirmed that the 
company does plan to appeal.
District 2 Seat Filled
Deputy city manager takes over for Winton 
Newly appointed City Commissioner Linda Haskins hit the ground running after 
she was named caretaker of Johnny Winton's seat. After meeting individually 
with staff and sitting in on a commission meeting, she set about scheduling a 
series of public and private meetings.
The sole nominee to take the reigns of District 2 while Winton faces legal 
charges for an incident at the airport in which he allegedly attacked police in 
a drunken rage, Haskins gave up a city job with an annual pay of $170,500. She 
will keep the post until Winton is cleared of the charges or until the 
November elections.
Haskins wouldn't rule out running for the office – and would likely face 
several opponents – but whoever wins that race could be forced to give it all up 
if Winton is acquitted. His trial is slated to begin Oct. 7. Haskins has no 
guarantee that she will get her city job back if Winton is able to reclaim his 
seat.
Monty Python

Ever the good sport, Monty Trainer hammed it up with Metro Zoo's 
Communications Director and Goodwill Ambassador Ron Magill, and an albino Burmese python 
at a recent Chamber of Commerce Event. 




Progress For Playhouse?
Lawsuit and little movement on audit say otherwise 
Ruling that the Coconut Grove Playhouse is subject to Florida's public 
records law, a judge has ordered the Playhouse to turn over financial records to the 
Miami Herald. Since February the newspaper has sought former artistic 
director Arnold Mittelman's employment contract and documents pertaining to theater 
finances.
Board members have said they were bound by a confidentiality clause on 
Mittelman's contract that could expose them to legal action if they disclosed the 
details.
Meanwhile, the state is seeking repayment of a $125,000 grant that was 
improperly used to pay employees, but continues to work with the board to salvage 
the remainder of the $500,000 grant; and Miami Parking Authority is moving ahead 
with preliminary plans for a mixed used retail space/parking garage on the 
lot adjacent to the Playhouse.
Meanwhile, the state is seeking repayment of a $125,000 grant that was 
improperly used to pay employees, but continues to work with the board to salvage 
the remainder of the $500,000 grant; and Miami Parking Authority is moving ahead 
with preliminary plans for a mixed used retail space/parking garage on the 
lot adjacent to the Playhouse. 


Thank you for your time, I look forward to hearing from you soon.


Felice Dubin

Importance:	High

Dear Sir:

 

My name is Esther Arias and for the past 10 yrs, I have been dealing with FEMA in connection with a wrong identity file connected to my social security number.  I have sent documentation proving that I am not the person they are looking for.  I have been dealing for the past 10 years with Mr. Joseph Cabrera, (800) 816-1122, and also Ms.  Margie Burroughs and or Ms. Muhammed (888) 826-3127, they all agreed that this is a wrong identity case, but nothing is being done about it. In 1999 when I last spoke to Mr. Cabrera, I asked him for something in writing stating that it was the wrong identity he explained again, as he did in 1996 that FEMA does not send any correspondence to that effect, I explained to him that I didn’t want this to go farther, since I was also a government employee and I didn’t want any problems, I’m a 20 year employee of the City of Miami,  he reassured me that everything was taken care off and I would not received any more letters from FEMA.  Well not FEMA but now in 2006  I received a notice form the IRS, stating that they were correcting my Tax returns from 1994, because they had received a notice of cancellation of Debt from FEMA which now that increased my 1994 income from which I now have to pay an additional amount of $274..  Again I called Mr. Cabrera who kept telling me that it was not his fault that he did his job, he requested my file from storage (as he explained to me)(this took about 3 weeks) the reason for this was that his new supervisor wanted to look at the file, I again waited patiently. Last week Tuesday, Mr. Cabrera calls me telling me to call the IRS and that everything was taken care off, that I could call them (IRS) and tell them to make the necessary corrections to my account because they had already spoken to them, of course that did not made any sense to me and I explained my concerns to him but any ways I called the IRS (800)829-8310, the lady I talked to was very helpful and gave me her employee badge number # 28-06758 she told me to called Mr. Cabrera back and ask for a corrected 1099 to be mailed to me and then mail that to the IRS.

Mr. Cabrera again told me he did his job and that eventually I would receive something from them.

  

Well this week end I received a cancellation of Debt and it doesn’t even shows an amount.  Mr. Paulison, I’m asking your help in solving this problem once and for all, I have never received any loans from FEMA, my last name was not even Arias back then, and why do I received a cancellation of debt, when I never had any dealings with FEMA to owe them anything.  All I want is a corrected 1099 sent to the IRS and a copy for me to keep with my records and that my name be cleared.

 

I have all pertinent documentation from past years correspondences relating to this, I can’t get any help from Mr. Cabrera not even a letter of apology, and really I think a have been very patient considering this has been going  on for more than 10 years.

 

Please let me know if you need additional information from.  Thanking you in advance for your help.

 

Esther Arias

Doral, FL 33172

Jan Bergemann <janberg@att.net> wrote: 

From: "Jan Bergemann" <janberg@att.net>
To: "Governor Jeb Bush" <jeb.bush@myflorida.com>
CC: "DBPR Secretary Simone Marstiller" <Simone.Marstiller@dbpr.state.fl.us>
Subject: ASSOCIATION BILLS VETOED! NOW WHAT??
Date: Wed, 5 Jul 2006 12:18:09 -0400



CCFJ, Inc, Dispatch -- Please Distribute Widely! 
July 5, 2006
 

Dear Governor Jeb Bush, Dear Secretary Simone Marstiller, Dear Legislators, Friends and Members,
 
After both major association bills have been vetoed, it is really time to find solutions for all the open problems, not just trying to find band-aids for the many pending issues. 
We have here in Florida not only a total property insurance disaster, but as well serious problems for owners in mandatory associations -- condos and homeowners' associations alike!
In his veto messages the Governor already stated that reforms are really necessary.
Please read the Governor's suggestions in his veto messages at:
http://www.ccfj.net/PB06HB391-SB1556veto.html
 
It is time that we create the necessary reforms -- in insurance and association law -- trying to avoid that many families -- and especially retirees -- are being priced out of their homes.
It is time that we will see a comprehensive bill that will try to remedy the many problems owners are facing on a daily basis. We need statutes with teeth -- meaning easy enforcement of our laws and regulations -- and education and accountability of the people in charge.
 
The only people with a vested interest in this matter are the owners, not the service providers or anybody else.
These new laws should protect the property rights of the owners, not the income of the service providers!

A comprehensive association bill will be ready for the next legislative session!
 
Warm Regards,

Jan Bergemann, President
Cyber Citizens For Justice, Inc.
http://www.ccfj.net/
 
IN ALLIANCE WITH: 
League of United Latin American Citizens (LULAC) 
Property Owners Association in the Villages (POA) 
Service Employees International Union (SEIU) Local 11  
Fair Housing Center of the Greater Palm Beaches (FHCGPB)

Dear Governor Bush:

I am writing in regards to some information I was recently informed of 
regarding making Spanish the "official language of Florida."  I was 
shocked and outraged at this and pray that it is just a rumor.  It is 
ridiculous that tax payer money is wasted now to make every official form 
available in Spanish.  I took my niece to the DMV to get a book to study 
for her license.  The only books available were the ones in Spanish!!!  It 
appears that all of a sudden no one matters except the Spanish people.  
There are still white people in this country! There are still German, 
Italian, Asian, French, etc. that have come here LEGALLY, learn  and USE 
the ENGLISH language and don't expect to be catered to. We still vote and 
shop and contribute to this country.  Stop slapping us in the face as if 
we don't matter all of a sudden.

Keep English as our official language AND if you are not going to offer 
all the other foreign languages in our government form, eliminate the 
Spanish versions!  

Sincerely,


Mrs. Kim Muchmore

From: lkent [mailto:lkent7@cox.net] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 05, 2006 10:19 AM
To: mike_whitehead@co.escambia.fl.us; jeb.bush@myflorida.com; Darryl.Boudreau@dep.state.fl.us; mary.jean.yon@dep.state.fl.us; Murzin, Dave
Cc: Saufley Field
Subject: Re: Happy July 4th -- The Dump is on Fire Again


Mr. Murzin
 
Thank you for your prompt response.  
 
My thinking is if Mr. Vinet was not breaking all the laws, if he was covering the trash weekly with dirt, if he had stopped putting trash in the dump when it exceeded the height limit, if he even once was in compliance with the county or DEP regulations, we would not have had the fire last night.  But no, let's go after the citizens of this county and put them in jail as we must abide by the laws.  Please, let's not hold Mr. Vinet responsible for anything.  He is just a poor man trying to have a business, at the cost, if I may remind you, of the health and welfare of the citizens of Pensacola.
 
So tell me, if lightening had started the fire, would we be holding God legally liable because Mr. Vinet is not required to work within the confines of the law.  Please do not insult me by saying he is.  I have read the correspondence from the DEP dated June 6, 2006 and I know he has been receiving warning letters since December of 2004.  He seems to be outside the law, does whatever he so chooses.  Makes many, many of the citizens who live around here wonder who he has in his pocket.  
 
So my suggestion as a course of action -- CLOSE THAT DUMP AND GET IT IN COMPLIANCE BY BRINGING THE HEIGHT DOWN AND COVERING WITH DIRT, STOP ALLOWING MORE TRASH TO BE BROUGHT IN.  DO SOMETHING BESIDES JUST TALK!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  
 
Or better yet, let's trade houses.  I'm sure you wouldn't mind sitting on your front porch in the evening and looking at a mountain over 120 feet tall of trash.
 
Thank you for your time.
 
Kris Hinson

----- Original Message ----- 
From: Murzin, Dave 
To: lkent7@cox.net ; mary.jean.yon@dep.state.fl.us ; Darryl.Boudreau@dep.state.fl.us ; jeb.bush@myflorida.com ; mike_whitehead@co.escambia.fl.us 
Sent: Wednesday, July 05, 2006 6:05 AM
Subject: Re: Happy July 4th -- The Dump is on Fire Again


Kristine, thanks for your email.  As I understand the situation right now, the landfill caught fire from the top.  The fire department has confirmed this and several witnesses have said that fireworks were being shot in the direction of the landfill, despite a burn ban, including fireworks, being in place.  The current thinking is that fireworks from your neighbors started the fire.  I am sure that the fire department and I hope the police department will investigate.   If your neighbors started the fire, because they were shooting fireworks in that direction, what would you suggest as a course of action?  They may very well be legally liable.  Dave

-----Original Message-----
From: lkent <lkent7@cox.net>

It is now 11:15 pm and I just now feel safe to go to bed.  The Saufley Field Dump caught on fire again, and this time it was a good one.  The air was filled with hot ambers and I was a bit concerned about my house. 

When is someone going to step up to the plate and do something about this dump.  I do not understand how you can allow this man to continue bringing in trash when we keep being told by DEP and the county commissioners that he is in violation of so many items.  What is it going to take for someone to do something -- someone's house burns down -- God forbid, someone gets hurt above and beyond the current health issues. 

The bulldozers will be working all night to put the fire out, so I am told.  Why is it so hard for me to believe it will be done properly?  Maybe all the other lies make it hard to accept this one.

A very concerned and tired voter!!!!!

L. Kristine Hinson

Sent: Wednesday, July 05, 2006 9:23 AM
To: Alan Williams; barry.j.webster@accenture.com; bjordan@championchevy.com; bmayco@aol.com; bbinzer@leoncountyfl.gov; brant@oldfirstchurch.org; bstreit@aol.com; Carol Bracy; colledge@ccbg.com; dan_simmons@bkitech.com; david.ramsay@suntrust.com; dharvey@wcso.org; doug.darling@FLDFS.com; elaine@volunteerflorida.org; governorbush@myflorida.com; gthornton@foleylaw.com; jacksonm@mail.leon.k12.fl.us; jennifer@tallahassee4u.com; Jesse Mckenzie; karen.walker@hklaw.com; Kay Stephenson; Kent Perez; kimberly.moore@wfplus.org; lawtonl@municode.com; Lee Hinkle; lisa.weimern@hcahealthcare.com; liza.mcfadden@vfffund.org; ljennings@tallbud.com; Lynna Sands; mark.obryant@tmh.org; marlonb@gadsdengov.net; Melissa Garner; mike.fields@bankofamerica.com; msvalentine163@earthlink.net; pdorsey@tallahassee.com; Rachel Goodson; Ray Bellamy; rsolomon@garnet.acns.fsu.edu; Shari Hill; sharon.roush@hcahealthcare.com; stransou@tallbud.com; tallahassee.seale@worldnet.att.net; tsperry@joe.com; vincel@leoncountyfl.gov; vwilliams@cricpa.com; WakullaSO@WCSO.org
Subject: Rewards to staff



2005-2006 is going to turn out to be a very strong year for UWBB financially.  The purpose of this memo is to tell you that I plan to reward the staff with year-end bonuses.  But it has been our practice for me to give you a heads-up on this in the past.  Since you have always agreed with my judgement on this, I don't believe I need to ask for a vote...but I would like for you to raise a red flag if you see an issue with it, in which case we will re-visit.  I would like to give about $30,000 in bonuses.  Our total personnel expense line is about $1 million, so this is not extravagant.  Last year, we gave $21,500.

This was a banner year for UWBB's work on a variety of fronts--most quantifiable, an 8% increase in campaign.  We were able to increase the dollars to neighboring counties, move both BEST and Whole Child Leon along, plow more money into agencies, and sharply reduce our uncollectible (we expect to collect about $150,000 more than we budgeted to collect).  Bottom line is that, while the board authorized deficit spending to the tune of $87,500 (the staff development plan) plus $50,000 (local hurricane relief), we will actually run a surplus of about $100,000 even if I pay these bonuses.

 All this was done in a year that we froze salaries from the previous year.  So these bonuses are larger than I would ordinarily pay.  The staff swallowed hard at no salary increases and delivered in a major way.  That summarizes this plan.  I have run this by Treasurer Bill Colledge before sending to you, and he is in support.  Feedback appreciated from you.  Ken

Kenneth S. Armstrong, Ph.D.
President
Visit us online at www.uwbb.org
office  850-414-0853
cell  850-545-4843
fax  850-414-0852
ken@uwbb.org
307 East 7th Avenue 
Tallahassee, FL 32303

From: Albania Ruiz <alingz24@yahoo.com>

<sandra.dilger@fldoe.org>; Falcon, Mayra B.
Sent: Tue Jul 04 19:20:47 2006
Subject: Eugenia B. Tomas Elementary School-Emergency

July 04, 2006
 
 
 
To whom it may concern:
 
     There is a very good elementary school by the name of Eugenia B.
Thomas Elementary located in the city of Doral, Florida (in Miami-Dade
county).  This school could be the best school in this area, but since
it is extremely crowded, it's turning into the worst.  I don't think it
is healthy for the kids to be in small classrooms with 43 classmates and
two teachers.  It gets to the point where they can't even go to the
bathroom because it is very difficult for the teacher to handle that
situation every five minutes.  I think that the teachers in this school
are heroes, because academically, it is impossible to teach comfortably
to so many kids.  The teachers are refusing to recommend kids for the
gifted programs because they don't have time to do all the paperwork.
Also, the gifted teacher has 40 kids in the classroom.  I don't
understand how they are building a middle school, turning the school
into a K-8 center when they can use that space to reduce the number of
kids per classroom.  There a quite a few middle schools in the area.  In
the previous years, this school was CAP and they were sending the kids
to other elementary schools in the area.  The school principal doesn't
want to do it anymore, for unknown reasons.  This city is growing every
day- there are almost 2,000 new houses to be occupied and of course, the
kids are going to attend Eugenia B. Thomas.  This year, a decision needs
to be made by somebody in a position of power.  There is a lot of
pressure the kids taking the FCAT during the third grade and they can't
learn comfortably in such crowded conditions.  Because of this
situation, they don't even have enough food for the kids.  The kids that
have lunch at 1:00, when they get to the cafeteria, there is not enough
food.  There are only leftovers from the earlier lunch periods.  They
have to swallow the food as fast as they can because more kids are
coming after them.  Do you think this is a healthy environment, with the
stress and hunger?  Is there any way the school can be provided with
portable trailers to be used as classrooms?  This is an emergency
situation that needs to be solved as soon as possible.  Can they apply
the law that says that 25 kids per classroom and per teacher is the
maximum?  It is unbelievable that in the United States of America this
situation is real.  Something must be done. 
 
 
 
 
 
From a concerned mother.

Subject:	Rewards to staff
Attachments:	uwbb-color-email-signature.jpg

2005-2006 is going to turn out to be a very strong year for UWBB financially.  The purpose of this memo is to tell you that I plan to reward the staff with year-end bonuses.  But it has been our practice for me to give you a heads-up on this in the past.  Since you have always agreed with my judgement on this, I don't believe I need to ask for a vote...but I would like for you to raise a red flag if you see an issue with it, in which case we will re-visit.  I would like to give about $30,000 in bonuses.  Our total personnel expense line is about $1 million, so this is not extravagant.  Last year, we gave $21,500.

This was a banner year for UWBB's work on a variety of fronts--most quantifiable, an 8% increase in campaign.  We were able to increase the dollars to neighboring counties, move both BEST and Whole Child Leon along, plow more money into agencies, and sharply reduce our uncollectible (we expect to collect about $150,000 more than we budgeted to collect).  Bottom line is that, while the board authorized deficit spending to the tune of $87,500 (the staff development plan) plus $50,000 (local hurricane relief), we will actually run a surplus of about $100,000 even if I pay these bonuses.

 All this was done in a year that we froze salaries from the previous year.  So these bonuses are larger than I would ordinarily pay.  The staff swallowed hard at no salary increases and delivered in a major way.  That summarizes this plan.  I have run this by Treasurer Bill Colledge before sending to you, and he is in support.  Feedback appreciated from you.  Ken

Kenneth S. Armstrong, Ph.D.

From:	tonytke@yahoo.com
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 8:15 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] Wounded Marine on a new mission

This St. Petersburg Times (http://www.sptimes.com) story has been sent to you from: tonytke@yahoo.com

Another life distroyed by "Bush Inc."

Wounded Marine on a new mission
By By ANDREA CHANG
Published July 5, 2006

http://www.sptimes.com/2006/07/04/4starcithernpasmana/Wounded_Marine_on_a_n.shtml

null

Times Staff Writer


ST. PETERSBURG - Cpl. Michael Jernigan and four other Marines were on a security patrol south of Baghdad two years ago when a roadside bomb tore through their Humvee. The blast killed one Marine and injured several others.


Jernigan, 27, a 1997 St. Petersburg High graduate, was the most severely injured survivor. He lost both eyes, his right hand and left knee were mangled, an artery in his left leg was torn open, and his forehead was shattered.


Jernigan's story, spread by the media and daily e-mails written by his mother, Tracey Willis, prompted thousands of e-mails, cards and well wishes to pour in from around the world.


Word of his injuries and recovery reached Bobby Newman, a board member of Southeastern Guide Dogs in Palmetto, who offered to pair Jernigan with a guide dog. Then Newman had a bigger idea.


"A light went on in my head, and I said, 'Hey, why don't we offer all the soldiers who have been blinded in the war on terror in Iraq and Afghanistan - why don't we offer them all a guide dog?' " recalled Newman, 55.


And so Paws for Patriots was born. The program provides free guide dogs to veterans of Iraq or Afghanistan, including those, such as amputees, who aren't blind but could use a service dog.


"I never thought I would be in a position to inspire others to do bigger and better things," Jernigan said. "It gives you an idea of a better way to live your life."


Paws for Patriots is running radio and television ads featuring Jernigan and retired Gen. Tommy Franks. Program representatives also visit military hospitals to promote the program.


In January, Jernigan received the first Paws for Patriots guide dog: a goldador (a mix of golden and Labrador retrievers) named Kera. The pair worked together for two months, but Jernigan had to return her after she led him into traffic.


"We had a great time; it just wasn't that great of a match," Jernigan said.


The program has identified about 30 veterans blinded in Iraq or Afghanistan. Three are receiving guide dogs, and at least six other veterans have requested service dogs, Newman said.


"We think it's a great way to give back to our country," Newman said.


Jernigan's family is contributing, too. Last month, Willis, 53, and Bob Campbell, Jernigan's stepdad, received a 9-week-old yellow Labrador puppy from Southeastern Guide Dogs that they will train for up to 24 months.


Jernigan paid $1,750 for the right to name the puppy Ted - in honor of Jernigan's grandfather, who was the first of three generations of Marines.


If Ted is accepted as a guide dog, he could be paired with Jernigan, though the odds are small.


"That would be phenomenal," Willis said through tears. "The idea that Mike would have spent that amount of money to name a dog after my dad that someday could be his guide dog is unbelievable to me."


Jernigan is making steady progress after undergoing major surgery 30 times in 12 months. He has regained partial use of his right hand but might have additional surgery to improve its function. In December 2004, he was fitted for a prosthetic right eye.


He actually has five prosthetic eyes that he rotates in use. Three are what he calls "normal" eyes - in baby blue, emerald green and aquamarine. Then there's a red eye with a Marine Corps emblem in the center. Finally, his "bling-bling" eye: navy blue with a carat's worth of diamonds embedded in the pupil.


"All the ladies love that one," he said.


His eye is also a hit with kids, who ask him, "Can you pop your eye out?"


Jernigan is always happy to oblige, pulling his lower eyelid down until the prosthetic eye slides out.


"I usually get a lot of oohs and ahhs," he said.


Despite his progress, not everything has gone smoothly.


In August, he and his wife, Bekah, decided to divorce. They were high school sweethearts who married in 2003, and his wife was by his side through much of the initial stages of his recovery and treatment.


Jernigan plans to enroll at St. Petersburg College in August and hopes to one day teach high school.


"I've got plans for the future, which is a good thing," he said. "I don't plan on sitting down and becoming a General Hospital addict with some bonbons."


Although Jernigan acknowledged the past couple of years have at times been tumultuous, he said now that his bad days are few and far between. And he knows to keep it all in perspective.


"No matter how bad it gets, it could always be worse," he said. "Yeah, I lost my eyes, but I could have lost my legs, too. Now I can walk but I can't see where I'm walking."


¬© Copyright 2002-2006, St. Petersburg Times

Dear Penne: 
  
Thank you for contacting me with your thoughts regarding the Child Protective Services' practice of removing children from their mothers even if they are breastfeeding. I have discussed your concerns with my staff and am grateful for your input. 
  
I firmly believe that any allegations of child abuse must be thoroughly and swiftly investigated. As a mother and grandmother, I am horrified by instances of child abuse. I appreciate such insight and true concern on this critical issue. Hearing your views is imperative so that I can best serve as your voice in Washington . If you would like more information on issues, or would like to share your thoughts with me via e-mail, you may visit my website at www.house.gov/brown-waite . Please do not hesitate to contact me again should you have further concerns on federal legislation or programs. 
  
Throughout my tenure in public service, I have always kept an open door and an open dialogue with my constituents. As the 109th Congress addresses the many challenges facing our nation, I hope you will continue to share your thoughts and views with me. Accordingly, I encourage you to visit my website at http://brown-waite.house.gov to email me and find useful information about our 5th Congressional District. 
It is my honor and privilege to serve the people of Florida 's 5th Congressional District and my offices and staff are here to provide you with any assistance you may need. 
 
Sincerely,
Ginny Brown-Waite
Member of Congress
Dear Ginny,
It’s wonderful to hear from you and learn that you have taken under consideration the concerns over DCF/CPS policies regarding removal of breastfeeding children from their mothers.  Your encouragement to continue the dialogue is most appreciated.  As a fellow mother and grandmother of nursing babes in arms, I share your repulsion at instances of bona fide child abuse in which criminal charges have been duly processed and proven beyond a shadow of a doubt.  I can imagine this would be a rare case with a mother dedicated enough to put her life on hold and breastfeed her child for a period of six months or more, as recommended by the DOHHS, AAP, WHO, and others. 
In fact, I understand that a vast majority of abuse and neglect allegations are discovered to be wholly unfounded, but only after the children have been removed from the home and the family traumatized unnecessarily due to lack of a proper and thorough investigation in accordance with procedure.  The special needs of a breastfeeding child are not specifically addressed in the state CPS policy manual, as far as I know, even though this type of nourishment is regarded as vital by its parent Department of Health and Human Services, as well as the above-mentioned organizations.
I am equally horrified at the reports coming in of the abuses being perpetrated upon innocent families by the government agencies designed to serve their communities.  As you may be aware, protecting the mother/child breastfeeding relationship is only one of the Constitutional rights frequently violated in the name of “child protection,” both here and around the nation.  With over thirteen hundred children missing in the Florida state system alone, and reports of FBI investigations confirming CPS involvement in baby trafficking, as well as overseas slave trade, in the House Ways and Means Committee meetings on Reform – there is definite cause for concern.  We would like to know what efforts are being made to investigate the possibility of this type of corruption within our own state agencies.
We have followed your work as our District Representative for a while now, Ginny, and are pleased to have an opportunity to get to know you better and learn more about this issue.  Looking forward to hearing from you again.
Yours truly,
Penne Ard and Family
Cc:  President George W. Bush
Governor Jeb Bush
Senator Mel Martinez, FL
Senator Tom Harkin, IA

Subject:	Next years Fire season

Dear Sir

I hope this E-Mail finds you well Happy Fourth of July. I am writing you 
with possible solutions for next years fire season. The dry weather that 
results in the fires in north and Central florida can be curtailed by 
salvaging the old and damaged oil rigs and placing them strategically in the 
Atlantic and the Gulf of Mexico where they can be used to create steam 
clouds both purifing the air and also condensation that will be carried over 
the peninsula at a given time when rain is needed. These towers can slao be 
used to bring cooler water from the ocean depth to the subsurface to be 
carried around the peninsula by the Gulf Stream avoiding the possibility 
that adverse conditions would cause damaging storms. A computer model 
simulation run on the Navy's Super Computer along with proper management by 
existing Army Corp. Engineers as well as State agencies can insure optimal 
use of our largest resource water, both on land in lakes and offshore.

In passing I wrote you regarding the loose gradient around Miami 
International airport Possible solutions include taking top portion of Metro 
rail and placing in the ground at an elevation suitable for use by FEC. Also 
a drainage canal leading to adjoining lakes much like the diversion channels 
built in Los Angeles but on a smaller scale. By using already existing 
methods, we can stream line the approval process and use are second most 
valuable resource lime and stone to build the track base that would be set 
into a tamped trench to avoid it sinkng further into the ground after 
installation.

I recently wrote Mr. Bill Gates and E-mail congratulating him on his 
retirement. I also recommended that he secure his servers and data bases in 
old abandoned mines that are still viable due to the density of the 
surrounding geology. I also recommended that he build Tilt-up concrete 
buildings approx. 15' high on barges that can be sunk offshore in 30' of 
water where Coral can be introduced on the exterior surface when nutured 
properly this will enclose the structure which will be made air tight from 
within. Pile-ons driven into the sea bed placed properly will prevent any 
further settling of structure. I felt this was necessary in case a Solar 
Flare burned off our atmosphere. With oxygen generators and other survival 
gear provided by Navy Surplus or Knowledge base would be secured.

I hope I have been helpful although I did not mention the state of Florida I 
would like very much for our Great State to play a major role in being able 
to implement such ideas and goals Nationwide much like are bridge building 
techniques we use World Wide.

Thank you

Noel Hernandez Jr

Dear Mr. Stone,
                       First of all, thank you for the response back. I can't even begin to tell you how much I appreciate the opportunity of communication with those of you who are entrusted with our Public Safety.
   We are the murder capital of Florida and that's just for starters. Recently in the Florida Times Union it was announced that Jacksonville will hold the League of Cities annual conference Aug.10-12 at the Hyatt Regency formerly Adams Mark.
   One of the keynote speakers will be James Lee Witt the former Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency. WOW! I wonder what his opinion would be to the April 22, 2005 old Fuller Warren Bridge study ordered by our Mayor John Peyton.
   Mike, with all do respect your answer and response back deserves a lot more than what you wrote. Governor Bush needs to intervene immediately. Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff needs to be briefed. R. David Paulison our new Director of FEMA needs to intervene and respond. Our new acting Director for Region IV Mary Lynn Miller needs to be immediately brought into the loop. Mr. Craig Fugate at the very least needs to send someone to Jacksonville to do their own site inspection then have a meeting with Mayor Peyton and ask the Mayor "What are you Thinking?"
   Mike on Friday June 30,2006 I attended the opening of Club Paris at the Landing in Downtown Jacksonville. I didn't have a VIP pass but felt a civic obligation to be there as Joe Q. Public
    I positioned myself adjacent to the upstairs escalator. When I took a break I'd walk a few hundred feet open the swinging doors and would look across the river and would see the old Fuller Warren Bridge. An FDOT structure that is next to a hospital, can be used for ambulatory service. A brand new helipad and an existing structure that can hold 6000 people. What a comforting and reassuring thought for Public Safety.
    Back inside where it was hot. People were starting to arrive. I saw Terry Lorrince our Executive Director for Downtown Vision, Congresswoman Corrine Brown, Mayor John Peyton and his wife, Neptune Beach Mayor Dick Brown was with his wife former city council president Elaine Brown.
   But the real action wasn't on the dance floor it was on the escalator. People coming up the escalator had no where to go when they got to the top. The faces of women in high heels and toe rings as they are ascending to the party are smiles until they suddenly realize they are trapped and they are jumping and pushing to avoid getting caught in the continuing motion of the escalator. It was gut wrenching to watch. The escalator was finally shut off in the name of Public Safety. I had seen enough. Well, maybe not.
    I walk outside one more time look across the river to the old Fuller Warren Bridge and I'm just thinking to myself somebody outside of Jacksonville Florida. Please help.
 
                                                                                    Sincerely,
                                                                                    John Nooney

Dear Mr. Fugate, 
                       My name is John Nooney and I'm a resident of Jacksonville Florida. The city that played host for Super Bowl XXXIX. I'm emailing you today at the conclusion of the annual meeting taking place at the State Emergency Operations Center in Tallahassee and hoping that this email could become part of your 10am agenda and that part of the program called Questions for Craig. 
  From what I just read from the website the DEM annual meetings are designed to give county emergency managers an overview on the state operation and programs as well as an opportunity to meet individually with you and DEM staff. I can't make it personally today but do look forward to the opportunity of meeting you in person in the future. 
  Craig, my question I feel can not only be applied in Florida or the other 7 states in Region IV according to the FEMA website which include Ga, Al, Ky, Ms, NC, SC, and Tn. but can be applied to any state in the country as it relates to the use of existing DOT (Department of Transportation) structures for Public Safety. 
   Specifically in Jacksonville a situation currently presents itself.  The old Fuller Warren Bridge which is the I95 corridor through the city of Jacksonville that also happens to be adjacent to a hospital with a new helipad. This DOT structure also connects to the 310 miles of the St. Johns River an American Heritage River that connects to 11 other counties. 
  I haven't had an opportunity to speak with my area 3 coordinator yet and share with him or you the April 22,2005 old Fuller Warren Bridge study. But my question is 
    Are State Emergency Management  Partners seriously looking at existing DOT structures in renovated urban core areas as it relates to Public Safety? 
    Thank you for an opportunity to participate and looking forward to hearing from you.
