Think about the next election
From:	JSKALET@aol.com
Sent:	Wednesday, July 5, 2006 1:03 AM
To:	editor.letters@heraldtribune.com
Cc:	b.ardren@verizon.net; liz.babiarz@heraldtribune.com; lburke@longboatobserver.com; dcalabroe@floridataxwatch.org; michael.connelly@heraldtribune.com; tdukes@longboatobserver.com; eric.ernst@heraldtribune.com; larry.evans@heraldtribune.com; julia.glick@heraldtribune.com; ajohnson@jcpgroup.com; WKealing@aol.com; neal.peirce@heraldtribune.com; michael.scarcella@heraldtribune.com; maurice.tamman@heraldtribune.com; rthomston@sarasotaobserver.com; thomas.tryon@heraldtribune.com; jturcotte@floridataxwatch.org; lbwalsh@longboatobserver.com; mwalsh@longboatobserver.com; cathy.zollo@heraldtribune.com; Aronberg, Dave; Bennett, Michael (LEG); frederick.brummer@myfloridahouse.gov; Governor Jeb Bush; Carlton, Lisa; Clarke, Donna; Detert, Nancy; Brett@tg2006.com; Lt. Governor Toni Jennings; info@sarasotataxcollector.com; thomas.gallagher@myflorida.com; Galvano, Bill; Grant, Michael; luisguinart@sarasotaproperty.org; manateepoa@co.manatee.fl.us; jeffrey.kottkamp@myfloridahouse.org; Kreegel, Paige; jley@scgov.net; pmercier@scgov.net; Miller, Lesley; dmills@scgov.net; npatters@scgov.net; Peterman, Frank; Reagan, Ron; clkinfo@scgov.net; jseward@scgov.net; sstaub@scgov.net; appraiser@sarasotaproperty.org; exemptions@leepa.org
Subject:	LETTER TO THE EDITOR

XT DIS   THE NEXT DISASTER!        HURRICANE OR THE HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION?

 

As I read the Sarasota papers it seems ironic to me that the very office of the County that is saddled with the task of policing the Homestead Exemption now seems to be advertising for new applicants.   I suppose that it is important to notify “would be, legitimate, entitled, Homesteaders to the benefits of the Homestead Exemption and the corresponding “Save our Homes” Amendment but it seems to me that a far bigger issue for the Sarasota County Appraisers office is to do some policing and reduce the wide spread abuse of the Exemption by claimants who do not “in good faith make it his or her permanent home”.   The Sarasota county,  Homestead claimants must make application, asserting that they truly are a permanent Florida Resident, evidenced by things like tax returns, drivers license, voter registration, auto registration,  and current employment.  Other counties  require various documents like exemption withdrawals from other state’s of residence and statements from the owner(s) that they have not rented their property during the past 2 years.   In the Sarasota application they must also state their date of occupancy of the specific property and whether or not they got an exemption last year.  They do not need to state that they do not intend to rent their property but they do need to state that “they qualify under the statute for the Exemption and that they own and occupy the subject property.”  What the statute actually says is that the applicant must be a permanent Florida Resident and that they “in good faith occupy the property as their permanent residence.”  It also states that  “rental of an entire dwelling previously claimed to be a Homestead for tax purposes shall constitute the abandonment of said dwelling as a Homestead”,  however,  if the property is occupied by the claimant on January 1st but is later rented during that year they do not abandon the Homestead “ so long as this provision is not used for two consecutive years”   What that tells me is that a legitimate exemption claimant can rent a property after January 1st of the Exemption year but they can not do it two years in a row without sacrificing the Exemption.   I believe that it is this provision that is being totally ignored by the appraiser’s office.  The appraiser’s responsibility in the statute is to “examine each claim” and determine “accordance with law (the statute), marking the same approved and making the proper deductions on the tax books”   You might say, “what’s the big deal?”   The big deal is that millions of dollars of tax burden, county, schools, fire, hospital, water and emergency services is being transferred over to the part time resident owners when illegitimate claimants are getting a huge reduction on their tax bill.  The biggest reductions are coming from the “Save our Homes” amendment which limits annual increases on Homesteaded properties to only 3% or the CPI.  As the tax burden shifts to the honest taxpayer,  fewer and fewer properties make sense as investments or rentals,  reducing the number of properties available to house tourists who bring our County huge sales tax revenues and our businesses most of their sales revenue  The least expensive beach area properties now have a property tax burden over $4,000 a year,  20% over last year and they have total occupancy levels averaging about 20% of available days. What this means is that the owners will claim the exemption and not rent, try to sell their property, or claim the exemption and still rent.  It is the Homesteading claimant who is periodically renting their unit each year where I believe there is widespread fraud and the appraiser’s office needs to get enforcement engaged.  It is my opinion that this abuse of the rental prohibition in the statute, that calls for abandonment of the exemption on  properties rented for any amount of time in any two consecutive years,  is unchecked.  I believe this could be enforced easily in that every management company or renting condominium association files an individual taxpayer 1099 tax form with the Federal Government and the Florida Department of Revenue for each owners collected rental revenue each year.  They also collect, report and submit to the County Treasurer the sales tax collected on the rental income of the owner.  This record could simply be checked against the list of owners claiming the Homestead Exemption, identifying the tax evaders.   A few misdemeanor convictions, collection of taxes in arrears with interest and $5000 fines would drastically reduce the abuse..   Many beach area owners are now saving in excess of $10,000 a year by utilizing  the Homestead Exemption. I did my own little research study and found that about 18% of the roughly 500,  million dollar plus units at the Posh Siesta Key “Gulf and Bay Resort”  were paying property taxes as a permanent resident,  paying around $4,000 in taxes while their neighbors were paying around $14,000.  Give me a break!,  nowhere near 18% of owners of  beachfront properties like Gulf and Bay  “in good faith occupy the property as their permanent residence”.  Granted,  the legislature or the State Attorney General do need to more specifically define what “in good faith occupy the property” means.   If owners don’t need to lie on the Sarasota application that they “use the property as their permanent residence” and “that they don’t rent their properties”, they will continue to steal from the rest of us!   In defense of the Sarasota County Appraiser’s office,  it appears that there is no current staff available to enforce compliance with the Florida Statutes regarding the Homestead Exemption.  The Lee County appraiser has initiated a web-site anonymous fraud suspicion report for his constituents to assist the efforts of his office in eliminating this fraud.   I suggest to the Sarasota County appraiser’s office that they first obtain the supporting detail from the management companies collecting the rental taxes and compare it to the list of Homestead Exemption owners!  Recent articles in the Herald and other Florida newspapers have been focused on alleged frauds and abuses being owners of Homesteaded properties in more than one Florida county.  I think the multiple Florida property issue is dwarfed by the partial year Florida residents  who are claiming the exemption and don’t meet the criteria,  leaving the burden to the rest of us who are honest.

 

John T. Skalet

Siesta Key Property Owner

Dear Governor Bush:

Dear Mr. Bush,

     I think that a law like that being passed would be more an example of 
"stifling" religious freedom, rather than encouraging it.  Wouldn't you 
agree? When a poll was taken regarding the elimination of the words; "In 
God We Trust" on our money, the results were pretty clear as to the 
"popularity" of that idea.  86% voted against the proposal, while 14% were 
in favor of the removal.  This country is based on that particular 
freedom. The Protestant Church was founded by people living in the 
"Colonies", who didn't want to be forced to follow Catholicism. Saying 
that we should hide our religious "Icons" would be an infringement on our 
very basic principles. Thanks for your time.

Sincerely,

From:	rarlcb@aol.com
Sent:	Tuesday, July 4, 2006 8:45 PM
To:	king.james.web@flsenate.gov
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush; bdccd5@co.st-johns.fl.us; dave.darty@sjcpa.us; sjcpa@sjcpa.us
Subject:	TIMESHARE TAX  vs. REAL PROPERTY TAX  = INEQUITY

                                                                                                    Barbara Ravoli 
                                                                                                    The St. Augustine Beach & Tennis Resort
                                                                                                    3960 A1A So., Unit #709
                                                                                                    St. Augustine, Fl. 32080
                                                                                                    July 4, 2006
     Senator Jim King, jr.
     kingjames.web@flsenate.gov
 
     Dear Senator, 
 
     I live here at the Resort.  In this complex we have 121 units.  Of these 121 units, there are 53 timeshares and 68 wholly-owned.  They are interwoven, one attached to the other attached to the other. They were all built at the same time, with the same layouts.
 
     According to the St. Johns County Property Appraiser website (sjcpa@sjcpa.us ) the timeshare units market values are $ 50,000 - $60,000, depending on their layout.  Their market value has not changed since they were built in 1980. The exact same units , if wholly-owned, have been given a current market value of $225,000- $230,000.  Thus, they are assessed accordingly and the timeshare units are paying approximately one-fourth the tax that the wholly-owned units are paying ($1,000  vs. $4,000).  Their $1,000 tax is shared among 50 owners, unlike the wholly-owned units where 1 owner is responsible for a  $4,000 tax payment.  This is not the only complex in which timeshares have never been re-assessed for many years.   I, myself have come across an oceanfront complex of 48  timeshare units, on the county website that were built in 1984.  They are currently valued at $50,000 and $100,000.  I fully realize that timeshares may not have increased in value as much as real property (even though they  truly are real property they are not taxed as such under the current law), but this does not mean that their value has not increased at all in 25 years.
  
     Dave Darty, of the property appraisers office, informed me that because they are timeshares, there are no sales records to go by, and he needs "solid, verifiable evidence to support revaluation". He also advised me by email, that he had sent a letter to timeshare managers requesting this info, but it was voluntary on their part as to a reply.   If wholly-owned units are evaluated by the latest sales prices, why aren't the timeshare management companies required by law to report their "individual week" sales to the property appraiser?  Mr. Darty said that he had sent a letter to timeshare managers requesting this info, but it was voluntary on their part as to a reply.  Are these figures available from the timeshare regulatory agency?  Shouldn't they be sent to the county property appraisers' office on a regular basis?  If the availability of these figures is purely voluntary, shouldn't the law be changed to make their reporting mandatory?  After all, this is the computer age and fulfilling this requirement is easily practicable.
 
     Being that timeshares are regulated by State law, every county in the State must face the same dilemma as St. Johns when it comes to their revaluation.  Something is very wrong here.  Clearly the law must be corrected. 
 
     Why should every property owner in the state subsidize timeshares by paying a disproportionately higher amount in taxes?   We homeowners are being penalized by this failure of communication, seemingly due to an unfair law. 
  
    Since Florida, at times, has been called "the timeshare capital" of the U.S., a change in this law, I am sure, would greatly lessen the tax burden on all homeowners in the State, as well as increase State, County and Local government coffers. 
 
    I personally would appreciate it if this issue were brought to the attention of the other legislators for consideration.  I am also sure that a large majority of Floridians would agree with me .
 
 
                                                        Respectfully, 
 
                                                        Barbara Ravoli

From: Jorge E. Calvo [mailto:jecalvo@bellsouth.net] 
Sent: Monday, July 03, 2006 10:27 AM
To: 'ajbarrera@dadeschools.net'
Cc: TFiedler@herald.com
Subject: "Vamos a Cuba" controversy
Importance: High

 

Mr. Agustin J. Barrera

Chairman

Miami Dade School Board

 

Dear Mr. Barrera:

 

You have decided, despite legal advice to the contrary, to ban the book “Vamos a Cuba” for reasons that I am totally in agreement with. Unfortunately, in the U.S., as you know, anything that “smells” against the Freedom of Speech, as defined 200 years ago, is taken to a wacky extreme used by the news media and libertine people with total disregard of facts or  the sensitivity of a community.

 

First, I hope you have done your homework in preparing for this fight that you have chosen and not risk our community’s reputation as it happened with the Elian Gonzalez’s experience, from which we are still paying the price as a “radical community” that wants a system like the one in Cuba. Unfortunately, to understand our perspective, you have to have Cuban roots just like you have to be a Jew to fully understand the Holocaust, a black person to understand racism, etc … The ban of these types of  books has nothing to do with the dislikes or differences with Fidel Castro or Adolf Hitler.

 

Second, I believe we need to address the truly erroneous statements in the book i.e. “In Cuba the 26th of July is celebrated as a carnival”, etc… as the reasons for the ban or have it moved perhaps to the “fiction” section of the library for adults.

 

Third, we should require for the education of our children that books not only should be “Factual” but “Balanced”. Why should we accept in our schools, books that present smiling children at the Dachau camp, Darfur or Cuba, that provide an image of an incorrect state of life without a required factual balance ?. Sure, children smile everywhere, but if they are taken to Gas chambers, Starve to death or condemn to a life of slavery and without human rights, we, as a society, have the obligation of presenting to our children, that side as well. These types of books belong somewhere else where a mature mind can put into proper perspective.

 

Fourth, our constitutional right to free speech is a wonderful right that needs to be preserved at all cost, but hopefully your stand would help bring our definition of “Freedom of Speech” to the 21st Century and remind people that the other side of “Rights” is “Obligations”.

 

Fifth, someone needs to explain to Mr. Ingram of the School Board and Mr. Pitts of the Miami Herald, that the Cuban community, just like any other community, including the black community, have some criminal elements that use violence to express themselves, but as a community, it has an impeccable record for its law abiding citizens. And if they need proof, they should move to Los Angeles, New Orleans, Detroit, etc…

 

Finally, be prepared and good luck in your colossal fight !!!!!!

 

Respectfully submitted,

 

Jorge Calvo

Miami, Florida

Subject:	Critical information on our Solar Energy Program. Please get to the President.

The US is currently making critical mistakes in our Solar Energy Program.

We took time out on the 4th of July to send out these emails. Please make sure you can take some time out to read this letter and  reply when you can. Your State and our Country is wasting lots of money and even more importantly limiting the pollution savings that we could be getting if we approached Solar Energy production in the manner described below. This will take Federal implementation across State lines to truly reach its full potential. If you could forward this to the President it may have a better chance of getting to him, and then on to The Department of Energy, and The Department of Environment. This letter is important enough that we would like to make sure you have received it. Please reply back that you have gotten it.

 

From the “New Freedom Project” and the research by Sensible Ventures, LLC.

 

Dear Mr. Bush                           July 4th, 2006

 

My name is Kevin Burk and I have been helping some engineers and computer programmers with groundbreaking research in many different industries. We have developed powerful imaging applications, a Seeing Aid, and many solutions for energy conservation and public safety. Our engineers understanding of psychics, electronics along with some of my research had us stumble across some profound flaws in our current solar energy program and the million solar home projects.

 

The following is a letter that must get to the intended party. If you are reading this on behalf of that intended party make sure you understand what it is we are proposing and get this in the hands of that person. Each day that goes by is another day that we all should have been heading down a different path in renewable energy production.

 

A team of researchers at Sensible Ventures has come across findings from years of research in the study of (time and space), and the exploration of the 4D planet. There will be much more work and studies needed to move forward but by combining our computer expertise, Internet application development, 40 years of engineering background by our founder, and some creative vision we have been able to design a much more efficient Solar Energy Program. 

 

 Some of the very Governors, Senators, and Congressmen that have gotten this letter have implemented some noble incentive programs for their citizens. Some of the energy and conservation advocates we are sending this letter to were the driving force for such programs and the advancements of technology and efficiencies in Photovoltaic cells. There are already millions that are seeking to do the right thing and install solar panels on their homes and office buildings to produce electricity in a clean manner.  We are not sure whether more people are doing this to reduce their future energy cost or to reduce pollution. We are also not sure if Federal and State governments have set up incentive programs to look like they are doing the right thing, to reduce our dependency on foreign oil, or to create jobs for their citizens.

 

The problem is, and it’s a big one, we need to rethink our current programs and in many cases put a halt to residential implementations of high costing, low power generating inefficient units. We need to look at this renewable energy problem as a Nation. That means allow State and Federal subsidies to continue for placing a Vermont residences election to do the right thing and protect the planet by putting his solar panel in one of 4 western States. Yes we know projects are under way with concentrated power plants but for the American citizen to feel like he is doing his or her part the $15,000 he was going to spend on a unit at his home should be converted to a co located solar panel or section of one of the parabolic mirrors at a much lower cost to deploy. We have our own solar invention that may improve upon any existing cost per kilowatt in existence today. The installation cost of a concentrated plant would be greatly reduced and the annual power return could increase by a factor as high as 4. Yes that’s 4 fold and that’s what we are missing out on each day we continue in the direction we are going. We could save 4 times more reduced burning of coal or natural gas. We could return up to 4 times the investment to each citizen for decades to come. That kind of improvement and the National approach or “movement” toward reducing our dependency on other forms of energy production will possibly tax our system with people in high rises, in New York, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Alaska, and all over understanding our 4D Logic and joining the ranks of the green pioneers and increasing our private investment into Solar Energy 100 fold. That influx of participants is a good problem to have and we will leave that to all of you to work out. Speaking about those Solar Pioneers it is our opinion that any previous incentive they got from the Government should not come into play if they want to do a “Solar Transfer” and do their part again. They didn’t throw their money away the first time; they could have just done it the more “Sensible Way”. This is a National Program potentially a global solution bigger than we will be able to handle ourselves. Everyone on our email list is going to have to work together to work it out. We agree with the President that its time American Ingenuity and our Industrial might shines again. No pun intended.

 

 

Here is the first draft of our letter that was just sent out by snail mail. It’s the Internet age so our 2nd letter has been combined with the first and will give you all you need to get the ball rolling.

 


Like the letter Leo Szilard prompted Albert Einstein to write to President Roosevelt in August of 1939 this document seeks to reach the President on matters of great importance in the current technologies and discoveries coming from a small group of engineers and visionaries. Unlike the attempt from Einstein that took years to move forward it is our hope that the New Freedom Project or Manhattan 2 as we call it can begin to make positive effects on health, public safety, security, and energy conservation. To that goal we release findings from our energy division on an innovative solution that could have profound effects on renewable energy sources.  


 


Sensible Ventures, LLC   (UTC 10:28:44.424, 05-29-06)


Inventive solutions in health, public safety, and energy conservation.

 

This is one of many groundbreaking technologies and discoveries being made by the inventors and engineers from Sensible Ventures working on the “New Freedom Project”. To learn more visit www.NewFreedomProject.com, www.Manhattan2.com, or www.SensibleVentures.com 

 

 

 

 


Solar Transfer       Co-located Power    


 

 

 

Years of research and a vision of the way things should be has brought Sensible Ventures and its engineers to the profound understanding of the inefficiencies of current renewable energy source power generation. Likely to forever change the direction of residential solar power generation our invention and copyrighted material will reshape the dynamics of Solar energy creation. Our business model and Solar Transfer process coupled with strategic energy production locations near heavy energy consuming cities will create the load or consumer base that can generate the ROI for customers in poor solar producing regions. If you or your company is intending to do the right thing and deploy low pollution renewable energy sources think twice before you make your decision on where to place the units. This ingenious concept of a multi state or multi country investment sharing by consumers across the nation allows someone in Pennsylvania who has a low solar energy factor in his region but still wants to take advantage of Federal tax incentives and State and Local subsidies for the reduction of fossil fuels to deploy his investment and contribution to the environment out in one of our nations high solar power producing zones. The advantages of such a system will be laid out below but basically rather than charging up expensive chemically polluting batteries with an inefficient solar panel the smarter choice would be to deploy a co-located solar panel or concentrated solar farm in the Nevada desert. This will generate peak power 1,000’s of miles away from your home with a lower total investment to you. With Federal understanding of the “brilliant” design you will still get the tax right off and still be making an indirect positive approach to reducing dependency on fossil fuels and lowering greenhouse gases. The only con or negative we can come up with is that your neighbors wont know you are doing the right thing and saving us all some of the effects of pollution. Our remedy for this is to have you put up a small wooden sign in your front yard or decal in your window that you can stick in the ground that will read “SolarTransfer.com” This will help us get the word out and show your dedication to the planet earth and a higher return on your energy investment. It is possible in addition to current Federal incentives the President and Congress will enact a form of energy bond that is a tax free investment into research and technology that can take financial donations and convert them to tax free purchases of sections of solar panels or mirrors.

 

Pros:

Centralized panels or concentrated solar technologies in high solar power generation zone

Lower transportation cost and truck pollution by building panels onsite.

A national sense of pride with donations to the environment and technology innovation

Elimination of chemical conversion loss because of not needing battery back ups for local units.

Lower pollution because the power goes directly to the grid and doesn’t use batteries.

Easier maintenance in dry environment.

More efficient localized cleaning and security.

Ability to deploy the highest efficiencies because of consistent light levels.

Greatly reduced installation cost.

No aftermarket cable runs. Piping or brackets needed.

No large panels on your roof collecting snow in the winter.

Electronic funds transfer of credits with no paper cost. What we call Solar Transfer credits.

Reduced energy cost ($billions!) for all because of lowered dependencies on fossil fuels!

Improved geopolitical climate because of regional power centers and less dependency on foreign oil

Lower pollution for every customer that buys a panel or mirror. The more that join up the less energy  Las Vegas or Los Angeles needs to burn or produce from fossil fuels.

West coast pollution which typically moves across the country would be lowered.

Shared revenue across all states in the program, spreading the savings across the country.

Millions more solar cells will be needed creating new markets and new jobs.

 

High-rises full of New York residents or Chicago consumers can join in and make a difference.

The influx of private dollars along with continued Federal incentives will pay for advance solar technologies and improved efficiencies.

 

Cons:

You may have to put a sign up to let your neighbors know your doing the right thing.

Residential solar power installers will have less work.

 

 

 

Spreadsheets of investment cost and the improved ROI using our system available upon request.

 

 

Straight talk.

Unfortunately a lot of people early into renewable energy production took the wrong path. We will need to find a way to compensate them for their pioneering spirit but going forward when you understand our logic there should almost never be an electricity generating solar panel placed in the north or in heavily cloudy regions. The money you would put into such a system would effectively be constantly losing value compared to our solution. This is no small task and energy companies, States, and the Federal Governments will certainly need to be involved. It sounds backwards but if you are in Rhode Island and you are researching getting a solar panel installed on your roof or in your backyard to reduce your energy cost and help the environment you would be much better off buying that panel or section of mirrors and placing your unit in New Mexico or Arizona. The reason this works is because you took the $6000 or more it would cost to deploy a local collector, battery, electrical lines, and venting etc and bought $6000 worth of high efficient PV cells or mirror space in the Arizona desert. Your $6000 pays you back in credits from the Phoenix region for reducing their cost to generate power with 40-50% efficient cells in a region that has twice as much sun power as your backyard. This would result in a 2-3 times more productive, lucrative power generation than if you would have spent the $6000 for a bulky collector in your backyard. The Federal government still gives you the tax credit even though your unit in not at your house and it would be foolish for them not to do so because the logic our engineers have come up with proves the inefficiencies of our current programs and that is the straight talk. We could have kept this technology secret longer but sometimes doing the right thing may require trusting your customers and government to stay loyal and embrace your technology. The millions or billions our system will save the world will surely financially reward all our investors and engineers that have put so much into this and other products and at the same time help the environment. We are willing to negotiate immediate licensing contracts with power companies, solar manufactures and with the help of Government Grants will see to it that our invention and business model continues to evolve to be the most efficient system possible. SolarTransfer.com , CoLocated Power.com the future is now and with the help from our local Congressmen and assistance from the President and Congress this model will be on the fast track to Nationwide implementation.

From:	Larry Lander <llander@tampabay.rr.com>
Sent:	Tuesday, July 4, 2006 12:30 PM
To:	President George Bush
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush; charlie.justive@myfloridahouse.gov; evertrice@myfloridahouse.gov; frankfarkas@myfloridahouse.gov; jones.dennis.web@flsenate.gov; Berfield, Kim; Waters, Leslie; Miller, Lesley; Sebesta, Jim; Howard Troxler
Subject:	Education USA

A REMINDER FOR THE 'SO-CALLED' EDUCATORS AND THOSE THAT CONTROL THE 
FUNDING...

1895 Eighth Grade Final Exam



Remember when our grandparents, great-grandparents, and such stated that 
they only had an 8th grade education?

This is the eighth-grade final exam from 1895 in Salina, KS, USA. It was 
taken from the original document on file at the Smokey Valley 
Genealogical Society and Library in Salina, KS, and reprinted by the 
Salina Journal.


8th GRADE FINAL EXAM


Grammar (Time, one hour)
1. Give nine rules for the use of Capital Letters.
2. Name the Parts of Speech and define those that have no Modifications.
3. Define Verse, Stanza and Paragraph.
4. What are the Principal Parts of a verb. Give Principal Parts of. lie, 
lay and run
5. Define Case, Illustrate each Case.
6. What is Punctuation? Give rules for principal marks of Punctuation.
7. Write a composition of about 150 words and show therein that you 
understand the practical use of the rules of grammar.


Arithmetic (Time, 1.25 hours)
1. Name and define the Fundamental Rules of Arithmetic.
2. A wagon box is 2 ft deep, 10 feet long, and 3 ft. wide. How many 
bushels of wheat will it hold?
3. If a load of wheat weighs 3942 lbs., what is it worth at 
50cts/bushel, deducting 1050lbs. for tare?
4. District No. 33 has a valuation of $35,000. What is the necessary 
levy to carry on a school seven months at $50 per month, and have $104 
for incidentals?
5. Find cost of 6720 lbs. coal at $6.00 per ton.
6. Find the interest of $512.60 for 8 months and 18 days at 7 percent.
7. What is the cost of 40 boards 12 inches wide and 16 ft. long at $20 
per meter?
8. Find bank discount on $300 for 90 days (no grace) at 10 percent.
9. What is the cost of a square farm at $15 per acre, the distance 
around which is 640 rods?
10. Write a Bank Check, a Promissory Note, and a Receipt.


U. S. History (Time, 45 minutes)
1. Give the epochs into which U. S. History is divided.
2. Give an account of the discovery of ?America by Columbus.
3. Relate the causes and results of the Revolutionary War.
4. Show the territorial growth of the United States.
5. Tell what you can of the history of Kansas.
6. Describe three of the most prominent battles of the Rebellion.
7. Who were the following: Morse, Whitney, Fulton, Bell , Lincoln, 
?Penn, and Howe?
8. Name events connected with the following dates: 1607, 1620, 1800, 
?1849, 1865.


Orthography (Time, one hour)
1. What is meant by the following: Alphabet, phonetic, orthography, 
etymology, syllabication?
2. What are elementary sounds? How classified?
3. What are the following, and give examples of each: Trigraph, sub 
vocals, diphthong, cognate letters, linguals?
4. Give four substitutes for caret 'u'.
5. Give two rules for spelling words with final 'e.' Name two exceptions 
under each rule.
6. Give two uses of silent letters in spelling. Illustrate each.
7. Define the following prefixes and use in connection with a word: ?bi, 
dis, mis, pre, semi, post, non, inter, mono, sup
8. Mark diacritically and divide into syllables the following, and name 
the sign that indicates the sound: card, ball, mercy, sir, odd, cell, 
rise, blood, fare, last.
9. Use the following correctly in sentences: cite, si te, sight, fane,
fain, feign, vane, vain, vein, raze, raise, rays.
10. Write 10 words frequently mispronounced and indicate pronunciation 
by use of diacritical marks and by syllabication.


Geography (Time, one hour)
1. What is climate? Upon what does climate depend?
2. How do you account for the extremes of climate in Kansas?
3. Of what use are rivers? Of what use is the ocean?
4. Describe the mountains of North America.
5. Name and describe the following: Monrovia, Odessa, Denver, Manitoba, 
Hecla, Yukon, St. Helena, Juan Fernandez, Aspinwall &Orinoco.
6. Name and locate the principal trade centers of the U.S.
7. Name all the republic s of Europe and give the capital of each.
8. Why is the Atlantic Coast colder than the Pacific in the same latitude?
9. Describe the process by which the water of the ocean returns to the 
sources of rivers.
10. Describe the movements of the earth. Give the inclination of the earth.



Also notice that the exam took five hours to complete.
Gives the saying "she/he only had an 8th grade education" a whole new 
meaning, doesn't it?

What happened to us? ??

Dear Governor Bush: 

 

During a Business Trip through Florida just north of Daytona Beach, the is a billboard that says “Women are the Center of the Home” picturing a woman sitting inside the house in a chair. As women are the highest percentages of small business owners in the country (including my self) and many conferences are in Florida this billboard needs to come down or be redone as not to offend women or send the messages to people that women belong in the home only.  After all, is that not one of the things we are suppose to be doing in IRAQ and Afghanistan,  is to protect women’s right to be educated, vote, work and even own their own businesses without feeling intimated or threatened; the same should be true in the U.S.  Please have this billboard removed and any like it and replaced with positive messages about women.  Please let me know your action on this matter, thank you.  Crystal Basler

From:	Hilmon Sorey <hilmon7@comcast.net>

Subject:	Thank you

Governor Bush,

 

It has been a pleasure to serve as president of the Florida Black Business Investment Board for the past 4 ½ years.  I appreciate the opportunity to have served in your administration and as a member of your staff.  Florida has benefited from your leadership. Hilmon Sorey

Lynne Warrick, VP of Community Relations, FEFFynb

Subject:	[*] SUPPORTING H.R 503 End Horse Slaughtering in America

 
 
 Good morning .
 
I am  very strongly opposed to horse slaughter and I do hope that you support H.R 503. Slaughter is "not" Humane euthanasia as horses suffer on the way to and during slaughtering. 
 - Passage of the American Horse Slaughter Prevention Act will reduce animal suffering—hence its wide support throughout the equestrian and veterinary world, as well as the humane community.  
Americans overwhelmingly support an end to horse slaughter for human consumption (polls from Kentucky, Virginia, Texas and Utah show that 82, 74, 72 and 69 percent respectively of those questioned oppose the practice). In California, a 1998 ballot initiative (Prop. 6) banning horse slaughter for human consumption passed with 60 percent of the vote.
 
 Last year, three foreign-owned slaughter plants cruelly slaughtered more than 90,000 horses for human consumption in Europe and Asia. Tens of thousands more of America's horses were exported from the U.S. and slaughtered in other countries.
 
Please this has to end!!  
 
Sincerely,
 
Vicki C.Thomas

From:	Mark Vander Lugt <mavl7@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Monday, July 3, 2006 11:58 PM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Concerned citizen of Florida and the U.S.A.

Recently I sent a letter detailing many of the problems of Florida,
including the ridiculous hikes in impact fees. Please look into the
following link that substantiates what I, and many other Floridians are now
saying. It is an article posted on the St. Petersburg Times:

http://www.sptimes.com/2005/06/19/Business/Price_tag_escalates_o.shtml

Wages are WAY too low. Affordable housing is not the only solution - wages
MUST be brought up to a respectable level. Housing is too costly. The
insurance debacle with Citizens is outrageous. Law enforcement MUST get a
handle on red light runners and tailgaters. Lives are being lost because of
the epidemic recklessness on the roads.

People will stop moving here - the word is getting out that Florida is NOT
affordable. The middle class is getting bled to death.

I started a business here, and now find that I work 12 hours a day to make
ends meet and pay all of Florida's licensing fees, occupational taxes,
corporate taxes, etc. As a result, I am taking my business, education and
job skills to a state where I can earn a decent living, own a decent house,
in a decent neighborhood, away from all the rednecks and all the non-English
speaking immigrants.

Whoever says, "We need illegal immigrants because it's good for the economy"
is completely missing the boat. Illegals get free medical aid, at the
expense of legal taxpayers. It costs this country billions of dollars in so
many ways. Some examples are reprogramming bank ATM's for English AND
Spanish. Printing Voters ballots in both English AND Spanish. (If one is to
vote in this country, they should speak, read and write English so as to be
able to stay current with events and make informed choices. Otherwise, the
illegals tend to vote for what is best for them, not what is best for the
country. In a democracy where the majority rules, it is imperative to be
careful about who becomes the majority.) And when hard-working, tax-paying
Americans like myself struggle because of the low wages in Florida, I have
less money to spend on products and services and that is NOT good for the
economy.

Those who say, "Illegals do the jobs that Americans are unwilling to do" are
flat out wrong. That statement is in-and-of-itself extremely offensive to
hard-working Americans who are having their jobs taken away and their
standard of living brought down by businesses that use illegals at $8 per
hour. The truth is that Americans are not willing to work for $8 per hour to
do work that clearly deserves higher pay. Those who say, "Illegals do the
jobs that Americans are unwilling to do" are often Latinos in favor of
what's good for Latinos, not what is good for the country, or, they are
lobbyists for the businesses looking to cut Americans out of the workforce
in favor of hiring cheap, illegals. And again, that is NOT good for the
long-term economic health of this nation.


Mark Vander Lugt
21072 Evanston Ave.
Port Charlotte, FL 33952

MAVL7@earthlink.net

Re:  Admitted Drug Use by Ft. Lauderdale Attorney Norm Kent

 

Dear Mr. Satz:

 

Ft. Lauderdale Attorney Norm Kent has recently admitted, in two separate replies to a Request for Admissions, that he has consumed marijuana, without a medical prescription, since July 1, 2004, in a Broward Circuit Court case now before Circuit Court Judge Jeffrey Streitfeld, Case #CACE06006282.

 

Mr. Kent is a national director of NORML.  It is interesting to note that NORML complains in a study available on at http://www.njweedman.com/racist_laws.html on the Internet that African Americans are arrested for marijuana possession and sale in disproportionate numbers compared with  whites.  For example, the study shows that in Broward County, the ratio of black to white marijuana sale arrests has been by a whopping and disturbing ratio of 20:1!  Looks like race-based law enforcement (racial profiling) to me, and it does to others. 

 

I have a suggestion that will help ameliorate this racist imbalance.  Investigate  Mr. Kent for what he has admitted, in a court case, he does, and then bust him if you find he is doing what he says he does.  Mr. Kent is very visible in his marijuana use advocacy, and he is very white.  I believe any failure to do just that raises questions about the racial impartiality of your office.  I intend to make a very big deal about that if I need to.

 

Regards, Jack Thompson

From: Fraud Update 
To: bulldog01@bellsouth.net 
Sent: Monday, July 03, 2006 2:12 PM
Subject: Your query to FraudUpdate.com

Mr. Ruff,
 

You posted your query related to Medicaid on FraudUpdate.com, which is operated by Florida State University and the St. Thomas University School of Law, but hopefully we can point you in the right direction.

 

The Florida Attorney General's Office has an internet intake form at this URL:

 

http://myfloridalegal.com/Contact.nsf/Contact?OpenForm&Section=Economic_Crimes

 

However, we believe that office would caution you that any information provided on that form could be a public record and, thus, might utlimately available to the target of an investigation.  Therefore, you might wish to consult the AG's office first by telephone.

 

The following link contains information about the AG's Medicaid hotline.

 

http://myfloridalegal.com/pages.nsf/4492d797dc0bd92f85256cb80055fb97/ebc480598bbf32d885256cc6005b54d1!OpenDocument

written a new book, titled America, Wake Up!, which is designed to educate 
the average American on who can help prevent crime and terrorist attacks. 
America seems to think the police can prevent, however, this research 
shows that the police can not prevent because the before factor is not 
present. (PRWEB) July 16, 2005 -- The bombings in London on July 7 have 
brought back the memories of fear felt on September 11, 2001. Over 50 
victims were killed, and over 700 injured in the calculated acts of 
terror. Nobody knows for sure when terrorists will strike, and billions of 
dollars are being poured into homeland security to try and prevent these 
events from happening. It is an overwhelming task, due to the endless 
avenues terrorists can take to spread destruction. This new book homeland 
security could endorse and supply a grant, so every American could have a 
copy. James R. White, Jr., and Anthony S. Petti are public safety and 
security consultants who have combined 35 years of experience and research 
and written a new book, titled America, Wake Up!, which is designed to 
educate the average American on how they can help prevent crime and 
terrorist attacks.

Both Mr. White and Mr. Petti have worked in security positions in 
hospitals, shopping malls, schools, and large complexes during their 
careers, and have determined that many people have the wrong concept about 
who, and what can prevent a crime, and terrorist attack. In their book 
they describe how many people think that public police officers can 
prevent a crime or act of terror, when police are actually often not on 
the scene of a crime until after the event has occurred. They explain how 
the answer lies with placing more emphasis on having a strong security 
staff in place at all of these public facilities, and having a public that 
respects the professionalism and authority of these officers.

Terrorism is a topic that affects each and every one of us. America, Wake 
Up! is a valuable tool that will help you come to understand the 
challenges that we face in fighting terrorism, even general crime, and 
show you the respect that security personnel deserve in our battle. 
America, Wake Up! is published by American Book Publishing and is 
available at stores near you, and at a discount online at the Publisher 
Direct Bookstore&#8217;s website at http://www.irg-security.us Plus! Check 
out the http://www.irg-safety.us  Or go to the American Book Publishing of 
Utah USA at http://www.american-book.com    

 

What are you waiting for?  We don&#8217;t need more 
&#8220;body-bags&#8221; to know America is going to be hit again. 

 

Our research dates back to 1968. We know that the entity that can prevent 
crime and terrorist attacks on US soil does not, have the tools they need 
to do their job! We have the proof! It&#8217;s in our new book!

 

I just hope nobody in your loving family become the next

Subject:	Two brothers

Dear Governor Bush,

How is it that two governments run by two brothers, who happen to be
ideological allies can be of two completely different minds? The one is
fighting a war in Iraq and Afghanistan and the other one has created a
dictatorship in our Florida school system.  I can prove every statement I
made in this E-mail, because you are a representative for the people you
own an explanation to our students and those who teach in the State of
Florida. 

The Jeb Bush administrations Home Rule has become a bad piece of
legislation that made it possible for Dr. Clinton Wright Superintendent
of the Lake Wales Charter School to dismissed 20 teachers and 7
paraprofessional in an anti democratic manner without given an
explanation. If a teacher explores a charter schools decision you are out
of the gate, why? An opinion poll by the local newspaper The Ledger shows
that 77% of Lake Wales consider it a wrongful dismissal. See Charter
attachment or sign across from Sears on Highway 27. 

Dr. Wright dismissed me for a difference of opinion. How close can you
get to a dictatorship? 

Principal D’Angelo has been dismissed as a principle of the Kathleen High
school by the Polk County School Board for exploring the idea of
converting the high school into a charter school by a local judge! 

The University of Southern Florida approved Professor All-Arian private
fund raising campaign for political reasons. Professor All-Arian had the
power to fail students when not donating to his fund raising campaign and
visa furze. Allowing private fund raising in a public school has become a
serious educational problem. 

I have been dismissed from teaching an adult electrical class for a
difference of opinion or not donating to a private fund raising campaign,
why? The motivator of the campaign did not feel the need to donate
himself.  The campaign has been performed in an illegal matter (school
board regulation 60X53-8, 004 (C)) however approved by the Polk County
School Board for political reason. I have not only been discriminated
against but also harassed, humiliated for all school employees and
students to see. When I came back from summer vacation I found all my
study material placed in boxes in the hallway. The hard drive had been
take out of the school computer with my prepared lessons to start the
second semester. This is a violation of 447,501 (1) (a) and (b) of
Florida Status (2004)’1, Pursuant to section 447,503(20). My civil rights
have been violated by the Polk County School Board for not following due
process, see harassment attachment.

No body should have to accept this type of abuse in a Florida Public
School System regardless of the “Florida Home Rule“. I constantly
received pledge forms in my school mailbox including one illegally placed
in my home mailbox. I kept on teaching under those absurd circumstances
for 6 month. It ended with a dismissal for a difference of opinion in the
middle of a semester.

The Florida Home Rule could be a good law, however in Polk County it has
become an open door policy for misuse of rank. I have prove that the Polk
County School Board has created an anti democratic school system for
political gain and our local politicians and our county justice system
are following in the same track. Local Florida attorneys are not willing
to look into a “Florida Home Rule“ problem nor do our Local Senators and
Representatives willing to give representation, why? Governor Jeb Bush
claims in writing that he is powerless to look into that matter, why?

Every American Citizen has the right to receive a hearing in a conflict.
I received a letter from Manuel Zurita Director of the EEOC in Tampa. The
EEOC is refusing to give me a hearing or an explanation on Charge No. 152
2005 00756 and telling me that a new lawsuit would be time barred, why?
The EEOC is by their action failing their mission to promote educational
excellence throughout the nation!   

According to Glenda Hood, Florida’s Secretary of State: Florida is an
"employment at-will" state. An employer can terminate an employee for any
reason, at any time, without advance notification so long as there is no
violation of federal or state law, (11.242, Chapter 11). Completely
ignored by the Polk County school system, why? 

On March 12, 2002, Mr. Bob Butterworth one of Florida Attorney Generals
made a statement that Florida would possess zero tolerance for
discrimination.  

I donated my time to train minorities and women to pass a mechanics test.
On August 17, 2005, School Board Attorney Deming Cowles wrote to me that
the school “can dismiss you for you’ re [sic] ethnic background....’ no
explanation needed “. Can't you see that this has been eating me alive? 

May 15, 2002, is the day that President Bush signed into law the Federal
(No FEAR) Act to increase federal agency accountability against
Discrimination and Retaliation. The Polk County School Board is ignoring
those laws,

Friday, May 5th, 2006, the day that the Florida Legislature gave final
approval to House Bill 1123, the "Government Accountability Act." The
Polk County School Board has been ignoring your laws, why? We should be
entitled to an explanation by our Senators and Representatives in the
State of Florida. 

Sincerely yours,
John Meyer
404 Whitman Rd.
Winter Haven Fl. 33884

At that point Debra's mom (Joanne Ingersoll) had her prints taken as a person who could watch children in our absence. In early June we were told that once again Debra's fingerprints had not been received. I contacted Nancy Higgins and she told me that she was never told to resend them by Connie. We attempted to contact the Tavares office today to have Debra fingerprinted, but no one was able to answer their phones. From:	Feuchs@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, July 3, 2006 1:34 PM
To:	wjrodgers@tampatrib.com
Cc:	Hasner, Adam; rfedrizzi@usgbc.org; alexandra_clough@pbpost.com; Bense, Allan; aronber.dave.web@flsenate.gov; baaronso@co.palm-beach.fl.us; byoung@seattletimes.com; chancellor@flbog.org; Scholz, Diane; dweil@floridabiz.com; afins@sun-sentinel.com; herelle@miamidade.gov; holly_duquette@fpl.com; info@100ideas.org; info@cleanenergy.org; info@nanosolar.com; Governor Jeb Bush; kathy_schmitt@fpl.com; klein.ron.web@flsenate.gov; Edgar, Lisa; LKeever@Floridatrend.com; mayor@miamidade.gov; pfairey@fsec.ucf.edu; rbenash@eflorida.com; skarle@usgbc.org; southflorida@bizjournals.com; steve.auger@floridahousing.org; tballing@psc.state.fl.us; tfiedler@herald.com
Subject:	Your article: The Sunshine State's Potential for Power
Attachments:	Solar Bldg..jpg; Trio- NYC.doc

Will Rodgers, Tampa Tribune
 
Florida is 30 years behind California in the issue of energy conservation and exploiting renewable energy. Californians use about the same energy per capita in 1976, as they do today. In Florida, we use 50% more. California has a mandate to supply 20% of its energy from renewables by 2020 and offers $3 billion in solar rebates to meet that objective. California will require that developers building 25 units and more MUST offer solar technology. I requested the Florida PSC to make public this disparity. They declined.
 
In Florida, the Sunshine State, solar is not being exploited as in other states. Instead, the 2006 Florida Energy Act makes it easier for utilities to build new coal burning power plants (the world's largest polluters) with Floridians having to pay for their construction. If instead, the billions that will be spent on these new polluting plants were spent to subsidize the assembly of solar "Mini-Power Stations" integral with new construction, building owners could "sell" energy to the state's energy companies, and get a check in the mail instead of a bill. This is happening today, but needs to become common. Such a  program could be implemented, if it weren't for Florida politics.
 
Florida's $1.1 billion for new school construction could integrate PV technology and save taxpayers tens of millions in future energy costs. All new public construction could specify likewise. The State's spending of $516  million for affordable housing could require solar, and Five Energy Star building envelopes, and appliances, to be integrated into new construction. There's no political will to do so and the non-profit housing groups I contacted, have no interest either.
 
As it stands, the administrator of Florida's affordable housing money, Steve Auger, has no intent to change its policy. The Florida Dept. of Education is not open  to discussion in this subject. The Governor's Office is not responsive to such alternatives, and the Florida Dept of Energy, ditto. 
 
As your article states, Germany and Japan are  ahead of the U.S. in PV production and incentives. In Japan, manufactured housing suppliers have PV technology as a standard component. With 100 year mortgages available, it's foolish not to include solar. In Europe, 100 year mortgages are not uncommon.  In the USA, typical wood frame residential construction is not engineered to last 100 years, but concrete and steel construction will.
 
Your article states that it's a sellers market for PV manufacturers. They can not produce sufficient volumes to meet demand, and making several billionaires in a few short years. I read that Honda will be in the PV business soon as well, and China became a world player in just three years. Florida does not have a single PV producer in the state. The Germans chose MA and CA as production sites. The Japanese selected TN. Enterprise Florida has no one to talk to in this area! 
 
Commodity pricing is not that far off for PV technology, making it competitive with fossil fuel generated electricity. The pollution problem should be a factor in Florida, but, thanks to the $50 million that Florida lobbyists were paid in the 1st three months of 2006, this is not likely to happen. We have answers to many issues, if politics were a curable affliction. 30 years ago a hand held solar calculator cost well over $100. Now dollar stores sell them!
 
I am hoping that NY will surface as a collaborator in the exhibit of a demonstration house in NYC that sells energy (see attachment). The solar air conditioner described in the attachments would be ideal for Florida. It operates for hours upon a blackout, and can power LED lighting. Florida has several fabricators  of Five Star Energy building envelopes, but no one in State government seems to want to see them succeed. 
 
I suggest you contribute a follow up story to your earlier article, and also send this piece to your colleagues in this subject across the state. Maybe something will happen as result. Florida claims to be the "Innovation Hub of the Americas". This is not the case in energy conservation and exploiting solar, etc. Policy changes are necessary. You could help. Good luck. 
 
Feedback is welcomed.
 
Walter Feuchs
P.O. Box 2715
Palm Beach, FL 33480
tel. 561.602.9198
fax 561.447.6804

From:	PDunn13445@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, July 3, 2006 1:06 PM
To:	ruthb@mho.com; jblack1133@yahoo.com; donald.bross@gmail.com; dabrooks@nytimes.com; cdejesus@cinci.rr.com; openforum@denverpost.com; gdunnia@webiowaplus.net; editor@latimes.com; letters@csmonitor.com; Governor Jeb Bush; letters@latimes.com; letters@nytimes.com; president@whitehouse.gov; editors@rockymountainnews.com; toni-charlie@earthlink.net; letters@washpost.com
Subject:	Will votes be counted accurately in the November elections?

I was reading the following article yesterday and it dawned on me that the same rules apply to the 2000 and 2004 elections. Americans are worried about decorum, even if we have the good hunch that elections were just stolen, and just don't want to believe that this could happen in our country. The Greeks would take to the streets, and justice would be done even if the powers to be didn't want justice or real vote tallies. 
 
If Floridians had taken to the streets in 2000 and Ohioans in 2004, or if actions would have been taken by the proper authorities to insure valid vote counting instead of obfuscation, I would have today more faith in our electoral process. We have elections coming up later this year, and I have little faith that they will not be manipulated. Worse, I do not see movement on governmental levels to make sure this cannot happen. Instead I see what could be a movement towards creating conditions ripe for stealing elections. For instance, we have electronic voting machines made by private companies with proprietary software. If this doesn't strike you as odd, then you live on another planet? Why, perhaps like the article below concludes, we are like an American woman on a subway, more concerned about decorum than striking out at a molester as a Greek woman would do if violated. I see the polite Democrats rolling over and playing dead while ruthless Republicans run over the top of them. Is this year another repeat? I see nothing to make me think differerently.
 
This morning I read about the "crisis" in Mexico where two Presidential candidates have declared victory. I think these Presidential candidates took good lessons from Gore and Kerry, that you need to stand your ground and not allow decorum/politeness to allow the other party to steel the election. I see a healthy reaction, not a "crisis". So what do we intend to do about elections this year. I am curious to see how this exercise in denial unfold. Mark Dunn; Golden CO and Zacatecas, Mexico fax 1-815-377-1635 or email
 
  

  _____  

July 1, 2006
Op-Ed Contributor

Moving Violations 

By DEBORAH TANNEN

Washington

RECENTLY, the New York City police arrested 13 men, saying they had groped or flashed women on the subway. Reading the press reports that followed, in which many women told of similar assaults, I was reminded of one of the first academic papers I published — an analysis of how Greek women talked about just such experiences.

I was also reminded of my own experience on the New York subway.

I was 15 and in my first year at Hunter College High School. Taking my usual route to school, I was riding a crowded express train to Manhattan from Cortelyou Road in Brooklyn. At the center of a crush of people holding onto a pole, I became aware — I thought — that my leather purse, which was hanging from my arm, had gotten jammed between my legs. I moved my arm to dislodge it and discovered, to my horror, that the purse moved, but the pressure remained. I stood frozen in fear. When the train pulled into the Prospect Park station, the pressure finally disappeared, and I saw a man in a suit look back at me as he stepped onto the platform.

That was the last time I took an express train to school. Instead I added a half-hour to my commute in order to catch the local, get a seat and keep it all the way to Manhattan. And forever after, I got a queasy feeling when the doors opened at the Prospect Park station. I think I expected that man to get back on.

This memory eventually receded, like the man through the subway doors. But it resurfaced 15 years later when, as a member of a team investigating how people talk about personal experiences, I asked New Yorkers if they'd had any memorable experiences on the subway. Indeed they had. And most of the stories I heard from women were about being groped, flashed, rubbed against or otherwise molested by men.

Around the same time, I spent eight months doing research in Athens, so I decided to record Greek women recounting narratives I could compare to the New Yorkers'. Since most of the subway stories were actually molesting stories, I asked Greek women if they'd ever been molested. 

The experiences the Greek women described were similar to those I'd heard from Americans. But there was a difference. Most of the American women — like those recently interviewed in the New York news media — told me they had felt humiliated and helpless and had done or said nothing. Of the 25 stories Greek women told me, only eight concluded with the speaker doing nothing. In the others, she said she had yelled, struck back or both.

One Greek woman told of walking to school with a friend when they were 12 years old, and encountering a man who exposed himself. Their reaction? "We grabbed some rocks and started aiming at his head. ... How we didn't kill him I don't know. We started to scream out loud." Another said: "I have given smacks. I have given a punch to a sailor. I have given kicks."

She went on to say that when she traveled she kept a rock in her pocket for protection, and she described how she used it on a repulsive man who had been dogging her and a friend on vacation in Venice. 

Though my research focused on how the women talked (the Greek women were vivid story-tellers, using the present tense and setting dramatic scenes with dialogues and details), I can't help pondering the differing actions the two groups of women described. Surely some general cultural patterns are at play. 

For one thing, most Greeks, like their Mediterranean neighbors, place value on expressiveness, whereas American culture is influenced by the Northern European and British emphasis on public decorum. That's why Americans often mistake animated Greek conversation for argument. Another cultural difference is how readily strangers get involved in others' interactions. I once saw two men arguing on an Athens street; when one raised his hand to strike, he was immediately restrained by a passer-by.

This incident may help explain another Greek woman's account of a strange man who followed her and then approached with unwanted advances. She told me: "I yelled and I gave him a strong smack. He had become so enraged that he jumped at me and he wanted to hit me," but a man who happened to be standing close by "intervened and cursed him and he left." Would she have risked enraging a stranger if she were less confident that another stranger would leap to her aid?

Whatever the reasons for them, the different ways of responding to public molestation led to different emotional reactions. Though many of the Greek women reported feeling anger and fear, they didn't talk about feeling helpless, as many American women did, and as I recall feeling when it happened to me. Equally dreadful was the sense of isolation: though you're in a crowd, something is happening only to you, and no one else knows. 

Speaking out dispels that isolation, as well as the sense of shame that it reflects and reinforces. Knowing that she had acted allowed at least one of my Greek storytellers to transform a potentially traumatic experience into bonding through shared laughter. The rock-wielder said that after the Venetian pest had fled, her friend "was dying of laughter, rolling on the floor," and then "the laughter grabbed me too" and they were both "laughing about how we had thrown him out willy-nilly." 

Deborah Tannen is a professor of linguistics at Georgetown University and the author, most recently, of "You're Wearing That? Understanding Mothers and Daughters in Conversation."

http://www.sun-sentinel.com/news/local/southflorida/sfl-73teendrivers,0,2641472.story?coll=sfla-home-headlines 


Limits on teen drivers may reduce deaths 


Johns Hopkins study shows fewer deaths in states that restrict 16-year-olds
  
 
 
By Dennis O'Brien
Baltimore Sun

July 3, 2006, 10:06 AM EDT



A comprehensive, federally funded study of highway fatalities and laws that govern 16-year-old drivers confirmed today what past research has suggested: Strict driving rules for teenagers can save lives.

In a report released this morning, researchers at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health analyzed the number of fatal crashes caused by 16-year-old drivers in 41 states and the District of Columbia.

It found far fewer deaths in Maryland and other states that have tough restrictions on 16-year-olds. Nationwide, they range from a ban on driving after midnight to requiring at least 30 hours of adult driving supervision before a teenager can take a driver's test.

"There are huge advantages to making sure that kids are trained as well as possible," said Susan P. Baker, a professor and injury prevention specialist at Bloomberg who led the study.

The report, sponsored by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, focused on fatalities in the District of Columbia and the 41 states that had some type of graduated driver licensing program by the end of 2004, Baker said. Four other states have enacted restrictions since then, the agency says.

The researchers found that states with at least a few restrictions on young drivers had 11 percent fewer fatal crashes caused by 16-year-olds between 1994 and 2004 compared with states that had no restrictions.

But 19 states - including Maryland - place at least five restrictions on 16-year-old drivers, and those states together reported 20 percent fewer fatalities, Baker said.

"Maryland is one of the states with more comprehensive laws," she said.

Maryland began a graduated driver licensing program in 1999. Under the system, a 16-year-old driver is given a provisional license and earns full driving privileges only after 18 months of trouble-free driving.

Nationwide, there are about 1,000 fatal crashes each year involving 16-year-old drivers, so a 20 percent reduction translates into about 200 lives a year, Baker said.

There was no single restriction that stood out in reducing deaths. "The thing is, all of these restrictions are important," Baker said.

Officials at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which shared costs for the $264,000 study with Hopkins, said the findings add support for teen driving restrictions.

"I think it will help any state legislators looking at teenage driving laws, and any parents with a teenager who wants to start driving. Parents may want to say, 'Even if it's not the law of my state, it can be the law in my house when my children turn 16,'" said Nicole Nason, the NHTSA's administrator.

The AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety reached similar conclusions in a smaller study of graduated driver licensing programs released June 22.

The foundation found that a state with night-time driving and passenger restrictions (Oregon) had 20 percent fewer crashes involving 16 year olds than a Canadian province (Ontario) that didn't have the restrictions.

Although restrictions play a major role, the lead author of the AAA report said getting parents involved is also important. "They should get out on the road and practice with their children under a diversity of conditions," said Daniel R. Mayhew, senior vice president of the Traffic Injury Research Foundation.

The Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration uses its Web site to encourage parents to spend time teaching their children to drive, said John T. Kuo, the MVA's administrator.

"Parents spend hours and hours teaching their kids how to play baseball or how to play football or basketball. They should do the same thing when they want to learn how to drive," he said.

Traffic safety advocates say the studies support their arguments about the benefits of teen driving restrictions. "None of these studies come as a surprise. This was what we said would happen when we passed these laws," said state Del. William A. Bronrott, a Montgomery County Democrat and supporter of teen driving restrictions.

Several attempts over the years to beef up restrictions on teenage drivers drew little attention or support in the General Assembly until a series of teenage highway fatalities in 2004 and early in 2005, Bronrott said.

The fatalities prompted legislators, with the backing of Gov. Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., to enact a package of restrictions that took effect in October.

"In previous years, I think a lot of it was just a case of things getting lost in the press of other business," Bronrott said.

Before a new driver can take the licensing test, the state requires a learner's permit for at least six months, 36 hours of driver's education and 60 hours of supervised driving practice with a qualified adult (someone 21 or older who has been a licensed driver for at least three years).

For the first five months under a provisional license, drivers younger than 18 are prohibited from carrying nonfamily teenage passengers without an adult in the car. Drivers younger than 18 are also banned from using cell phones while operating a vehicle except to make an emergency 911 call.

-- dennis.obrien@baltsun.com 
Copyright © 2006, South Florida Sun-Sentinel

I am critically concerned about the health and welfare of one of the supporters of our organization, and am disturbed by the lack of action by the Department of Children and Families to provide assistance to her in any manner.

She was divorced in January of 2006 and has since worked to improve herself. She enrolled, after a decades absence, in college taking a full course load this summer at St Petersburg College. She has initiated her own business, which in its first six months has blossomed. All this while raising two children and maintaining her home. She has done this without the assistance that is designed and was created in part to help individuals like her. That is not acceptable.

 

Her income does not yet afford her the ability to secure private health insurance for herself or her children. She is an insulin dependent diabetic and also was on medication for anxiety and other conditions. She has been without medication since January of 2006 and has had to deal with her medical conditions the best she can.

She has each time done her best to provide proof of income, reciepts etc and even court documents for her divorce and child support. The latter being governmental record documents easily available to government agenices, but not as easily available via public record for private citizens. She utilized commercially available public records databases and provided an address to the worker and was advised it was no longer a good address and she needed to obtain a valid one.

 

This a ludicrous and unfair burden to put upon a single mother working to improve her income capabilities while raising her two children.

 

Ms. Jennifer Lynn-Mahoney Quarles should be the poster child for the current philosophy regarding welfare as an interim measure while an individual improves themselves and takes themselves off the welfare roles by that improvement.

 

Ms. Quarles is enrolled full time as a student, works her own business and derives only that income and the amount she recieves in child support-information she has painstakingly and repeatedly provided to DCF. Her income is well below the standards by which Medicaid is provided.  

 

The failure of DCF to provide services to her for the last six months is extremely disturbing since it could have negatively impacted the health and welfare of Ms. Quarles as she has been without neccessary insulin and other medications for that time. He ability to perservere and manage her diabeties, anxiety and other ailements is a testament to the resiliance of the human spirit but should not be relied upon as a exuse by DCF for ineffective delivery of service.

 

I have emailed various individuals at DCF regarding Ms. Quarles predicament and recieved no response. I am emailing one last time in the hopes that this will be addressed with her in an equitable and fair manner.

 

This matter needs swift resolution for Ms. Quarles as its been too long that she has been without medication or medical coverage based on her needs. She is precisely, I believe, the kind of individual for which this program was designed and should be adequately and humanely addressed.

 

I hope you take this into account and resolve this matter with her so that further activity on my part is not neccessary.

Subject:	Please Help the Police

Dear Governor,

 

I retired and moved to Pensacola FL about three years ago hoping for a peaceful and quiet retirement.  I am trying to survive on a very limited income, Social Security, and so far, I am making it work.  One of the many obstacles along the way has been harassing phone calls from the Police.  I get calls averaging every month or two from the Police begging for money.  I can’t afford to contribute, and I have asked each time to be removed from their “sucker list” to no avail.  I am on the National Do Not Call List, but they ignore that also.  If you get a phone call and the caller identifies himself as the “Police”, it is intimidating, and then, if he begs you for money, under those conditions it is not a charitable request, it is closer to extortion.  What the person getting the call thinks is "This is the Police, give us your money!"  After nearly three years of this, I consider it harassment.

 

Would you please do what you can to increase the pay of the Police so that they do not have to resort to intimidating and harassing senior citizens by continually begging for money?

 

Thank you for your help,

 

Donald Sima

 

Pensacola

From:	aimfl@aol.com
Sent:	Monday, July 3, 2006 10:12 AM
To:	hemmenn@ahca.myflorida.com
Cc:	Arnold, Thomas; Governor Jeb Bush

Greetings:
 
I am critically concerned about the health and welfare of one of the supporters of our organization, and am disturbed by the lack of action by the Department of Children and Families to provide assistance to her in any manner.
 
Ms. Jennifer Lynn Mahoney-Quarles is a divorced single mother of two children. She was the victim of spousal abuse and her young son the victim of physical abuse. 
 
She was divorced in January of 2006 and has since worked to improve herself. She enrolled, after a decades absence, in college taking a full course load this summer at St Petersburg College. She has initiated her own business, which in its first six months has blossomed. All this while raising two children and maintaining her home. She has done this without the assistance that is designed and was created in part to help individuals like her. That is not acceptable.
 
Her income does not yet afford her the ability to secure private health insurance for herself or her children. She is an insulin dependent diabetic and also was on medication for anxiety and other conditions. She has been without medication since January of 2006 and has had to deal with her medical conditions the best she can.
 
Her medicaid application 1236646592 has been repeatedly put on hold with various additional requirements being put upon Ms. Quarles and requests being made of her. She has each time done her best to provide proof of income, reciepts etc and even court documents for her divorce and child support. The latter being governmental record documents easily available to government agenices, but not as easily available via public record for private citizens. Nonetheless she has acquired them and provided them as requested.
 
The latest request, has asked her to hunt down the father of her daughter, a man she hasn't seen or spoken to in over a decade. She utilized commercially available public records databases and provided an address to the worker and was advised it was no longer a good address and she needed to obtain a valid one.
 
This a ludicrous and unfair burden to put upon a single mother working to improve her income capabilities while raising her two children.
 
Ms. Jennifer Lynn-Mahoney Quarles should be the poster child for the current philosophy regarding welfare as an interim measure while an individual improves themselves and takes themselves off the welfare roles by that improvement.
 
Ms. Quarles is enrolled full time as a student, works her own business and derives only that income and the amount she recieves in child support-information she has painstakingly and repeatedly provided to DCF. Her income is well below the standards by which Medicaid is provided.  
 
The failure of DCF to provide services to her for the last six months is extremely disturbing since it could have negatively impacted the health and welfare of Ms. Quarles as she has been without neccessary insulin and other medications for that time. He ability to perservere and manage her diabeties, anxiety and other ailements is a testament to the resiliance of the human spirit but should not be relied upon as a exuse by DCF for ineffective delivery of service.
 
I have emailed various individuals at DCF regarding Ms. Quarles predicament and recieved no response. I am emailing one last time in the hopes that this will be addressed with her in an equitable and fair manner.
 
This matter needs swift resolution for Ms. Quarles as its been too long that she has been without medication or medical coverage based on her needs. She is precisely, I believe, the kind of individual for which this program was designed and should be adequately and humanely addressed.
 
I hope you take this into account and resolve this matter with her so that further activity on my part is not neccessary.
 
 
Thanks,
 
 
Sheridan Murphy
State Executive Director
American Indian Movement of Florida
