READ BELOW:
Governor's Nonprofit Foundation Has Paid Pollster, Former Campaign Finance 
Chief
    By Dara Kam
    The Palm Beach Post

    Thursday 29 June 2006

    Tallahassee - Gov. Jeb Bush has used his recently revived nonprofit 
foundation to pay a former campaign finance director and two former 
campaign aides.

    Although Bush has said his Foundation for Florida's Future is not a 
way of keeping his political machine intact after he leaves office early 
next year, recent disclosures on the foundation's Web site show that it 
paid:

    * Nearly $99,000 to Ann Herberger, Bush's campaign finance director 
during two campaign and a longtime political fund-raiser for his family.

    * Nearly $70,000 to Neil Newhouse of Washington-based GOP Public 
Opinion Strategies group for polling last October.

    * $48,000 for "management services" to a lobbying and public-affairs 
firm whose staff includes Mandy Clark and Mandy Fletcher. Both worked on 
Bush's reelection campaign and on his brother's presidential reelection 
campaign.

    * $23,500 for "legal services" from the Washington law and lobbying 
firm Patton Boggs.

    * $20,000 in February to GOP political strategist Adam Goodman's The 
Victory Group Inc.

    The foundation has spent about $320,000 of the $1.9 million it has 
raised since Bush revived it in the fall, according to its Web site. Those 
contributions have come from friends, former colleagues and campaign 
contributors, and even the prime minister of Haiti.

    Bush also has tapped three "Rangers" - fund-raisers who brought in at 
least $200,000 for President Bush's 2004 campaign - to sit on the 
foundation's board: Zach Zachariah, a Fort Lauderdale cardiologist; Tom 
Petway, a Jacksonville businessman; and Sergio Pino, a Miami developer.

    In Washington on Wednesday, Bush said the foundation's expenditures 
are within the law and that Herberger's salary comes from donations.

    "It's all pretty transparent, complying with the new law," Bush said. 
"Ann Herberger gets money when she raises money. It's kind of how she 
makes a living."

    But when asked about the subject of the $70,000 poll, Bush said, "I'm 
not going to tell you."

    Bush had said he resurrected the foundation to campaign for a 
constitutional amendment to allow the state to pay for private- and 
religious-school tuition for children in failing schools, but lawmakers 
failed to pass a joint resolution that would have put such a question on 
the ballot in November.

    Although Bush has said he will not seek public office in 2008, 
political strategists say the foundation will keep him from fading out of 
sight.

    "The first time Michael Jordan retired, I bet he didn't quit working 
out. I bet he didn't quit playing basketball. You never know when you want 
to play again. And you want to be in shape if you think, 'I want to play a 
few seasons,'" said GOP strategist Mac Stipanovich.


Sincerely,


Joseph Daraio
(561) 965-9178

From:	bob hall <boball3@earthlink.net>
Sent:	Saturday, July 1, 2006 1:10 PM
To:	Castille, Colleen
Cc:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	Water Conservation Needed in Atlanta

                                                                                July 1, 2006
 
 
Colleen Castille
Secretary, Department of Environmental Protection
Commonwealth Blvd.
Tallahassee, FL 
 
Dear Colleen,
 
I have been retired from DEP for two years, but have often wondered why Georgia, and specifically Atlanta, have not been required to implement good water conservation and reuse practices, as we now have in many areas of Florida (I spent my last 10 years in DEP reviewing comprehensive plans for local governments in Florida).  
 
While visiting Atlanta within the last 10 years I have noticed some rather cavalier water use practices in the city.
At one motel near Lenox square a few years back, the pressure from the shower almost knocked me down, which led me to believe that flow restrictors had not been required in the motel plumbing.  It made me wonder about all the other motels, hotels, businesses and homes in the city that is still growing strong.  
 
More recently at one of the newer hotels, the J.W. Marriott near Lenox Square, I had to let the water run for almost five minutes to get hot water for a shower on the eighth floor (my shower took less time than it took to get hot water).  I suggested to the deskclerk upon checkout that water heaters near the sources of use would save a lot of water for the hotel (and for the City of Atlanta that uses the Lake Lanier reservoir).  
 
With such free use of the valuable water resource, it occurred to me that Atlanta has probably not implemented reuse policies that would provide graywater for irrigation of the palatial lawns or public parks in the city, or in the remaining water recharge areas surrounding the city.  And, from my rudimentary observations it is doubtful that there are policies that require plumbing code improvements, or that restrict flows using updated plumbing devices.  It is therefore recommended that before Florida enters into further negotiations on the use of water from the Lake Lanier reservoir, that Georgia, and specifically the ever-expanding city of Atlanta, demonstrate that they have implemented the most current water conservation policies that are similar to those being used in Florida (South Florida would be a poor example of reuse policies, since they are probably still at no more than 6% reuse).  
 
If the states are truly compromising on the water use issue, then it seems that Atlanta needs to do its part by implementing some realistic and workable water conservation policies, similar to those being used by Florida.
 
Sincerely,
 
Robert W. Hall
Retired DEP Planner       
cc:  Editor, Atlanta Constitution
 
p.s.  I would have copied Anthony De Luise who has been mentioned repeatedly as the DEP contact, but I could not find his name or email address in the Myflorida directory.

Subject:	Reporter Rosenberg thrill over Supreme Court decision to protect terrorists

Prisoner grateful to Allah and U.S. courts
Osama bin Laden's driver praised Allah upon learning that the Supreme Court had sided with him against President Bush over military trials at U.S. prisons at Guantánamo.
BY CAROL ROSENBERG
crosenberg@MiamiHerald.com


GUANTANAMO BAY NAVY BASE, Cuba -- Osama bin Laden's stunned ex-driver praised Allah three times in Arabic upon learning of his U.S. Supreme Court victory that shut down President Bush's war court, his U.S. military attorney said Friday.

Moreover, Navy Lt. Cmdr. Charles Swift said Salim Hamdan's defense team would arrive at this remote base in southeast Cuba on the Fourth of July to brief the Yemeni with a fourth-grade education on their plan to seek ''a fair trial'' for him.

Hamdan, 36, sounded stunned, said Swift, as he got the first word about the Supreme Court decision Thursday in a 20-minute phone call between Washington and Camp Delta, the Pentagon's sprawling prison camp complex overlooking the Caribbean.

''Alhumdullah, Alhumdullah, Alhumdullah,'' he told his lawyers -- Arabic for ``Praise be to God.''

Four people were on the line -- Hamdan; Swift; a Pentagon-approved defense Arabic translator; and Georgetown Law professor Neal Katyal, Swift's civilian counsel who argued the case at the high court.

''It was moving. There was no whooping and hollering,'' Swift said in an interview Friday with The Miami Herald.

Swift said he could ethically describe the telephone conversation in detail because U.S. military intelligence agents monitored the conversation, meaning attorney-client privilege was breached.

''I could hear in his voice that he was ultimately stunned. He was as caught by surprise by the decision as anyone,'' said Swift, a 19-year career Navy officer, recalling earlier conversations in which Hamdan's legal team laid out his Supreme Court challenge.

Swift said Hamdan had long found it inconceivable that he could win.

'He would say, `He's the president of the United States, and it's the Supreme Court.' ''

`IN YEMEN'

''In Yemen, the president goes to the Supreme Court,'' said Swift. ``You think he loses?''

In the 5-3 ruling, the Supreme Court found that President Bush exceeded his powers with the administration's formula for Military Commissions, which opened in August 2004 and before which 10 Guantánamo captives were charged as al Qaeda co-conspirators.

The first detainee in the dock was Hamdan, a wiry Yemeni who has been held here for four-plus years and admits to working for bin Laden as a driver on his farm in Kandahar, Afghanistan.

But Hamdan argues he did it as a job, earning $200 a month. He claims he never hurt anyone and never conspired with al Qaeda to attack American targets.

Swift said there was no air of celebration in the conversation -- the first ever by telephone between Hamdan and his legal team, which plans to travel here Tuesday from Jacksonville Naval Air Station.

`A FAIR TRIAL'

Rather, he said, there was an air of ''gratitude'' that the ``Supreme Court said whether it was a military or a civilian trial, he'd get a fair trial -- that he'd have the right to be at the trial, he'd see the evidence, and he'd have all the protections.''

U.S. military officials here would only confirm that the call took place -- but would not address how arrangements were made: for example, whether a telephone was brought to Hamdan's cell or who on the Navy base arranged, approved or monitored the call.

''Mr. Hamdan was notified of the Supreme Court's decision today by his attorney via telephone,'' Navy Cmdr. Robert Durand, director of public affairs at the prison camps, said Thursday.

Only a few of the 450 captives here have been permitted telephone calls.

The Saudi father of a U.S. aeronautical university graduate spent an hour chatting with his son from Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, earlier this year to persuade him not to boycott his first Military Commissions hearing.

Army Maj. Wade Faulkner, another military defense attorney, has so far failed to line up a call for his Algerian client, Sufyian Barhoumi, to speak to his mother following the December death of his father, an attorney in Algiers.

From:	Gayle <bestasiesta@comcast.net>
Sent:	Saturday, July 1, 2006 11:33 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	[*] motorcycle noise and helmets

Dear Governor Bush,
 
Please read the following editorial I have sent to local newspapers. Thanks so much for considering.
 
As to the recent editorials about motorcycle helmets.

 

I agree with yesterday’s editorial on the burden placed on taxpayers because of the extinct helmet law. I can’t imagine what FL lawmakers were thinking when they eliminated the helmet law in the first place. I agree it is amazing they would put this burden on the taxpayers. I would like to suggest that there is an even heavier burden the state has placed on our individual shoulders. The likelihood of running into or being run into by a motorcycle is increasing as there are more and more of these machines on our highways. If you or a family member happens to be involved in an accident where a helmet less motorcyclist is killed due to head injuries, think of the burden that places on you, your fault or not!  I don’t want to, nor should anyone have to, live with the horror and burden for the rest of my life of being at an accident scene where there was a death that could have been prevented if a helmet were worn. 

 

While lawmakers and police are listening, I have another request. While I enjoy riding myself, I do not appreciate the few riders who feel they must be seen and ‘heard’ by everyone a mile away. Please, provide adequate funding to our police departments to enforce the law regarding loud, obnoxious noise coming from this vehicle’s altered engines. I understand tampering with these engines to make them as loud as possible is “cool” to the rider. Most of us do not agree. This obnoxious behavior by a few riders is yet another burden placed on society. Noise pollution such as this causes stress and other health related problems. This is a fact. That is why laws were made and are on the books in FL to prevent this, but these laws are ignored by our police. It is time to enforce the law where all noise altered vehicles are concerned. If we can outlaw loud music coming from cars, why can’t we enforce longer standing laws regarding the much louder motor noise pollution? Why should a few riders be able to place so many burdens on all the rest of Floridians? Legislators have 3 burdens on society that they can remove by reinstituting the helmet law and enforcing and strengthening the motor noise laws. E-mail Gov Bush and your state legislators today and urge them to do so. 

 

Gayle Wardner

8630 Midnight Pass Rd

Sarasota, FL 34242

504 3926

President Bush,

	First off I voted for you twice, and I fully support just about every
thing your administration stands for and has done. However with regard
to Palestine. The US is making crucial mistakes that could effect our
positions in Iraq and Afghanistan. Here are the points summed up.

Palestinians form a democracy, and elect into power a group that the US
does not like. When the US cuts of support and denounces the Hamas
government. That sent the WRONG message to Iraqis, Afghanis, and even
Iran saw it hypocritical. Not to mention the rest of the Arab world.

Hamas is expected to rein in terror. 90% of Hamas's funds go to
non-militant civil services. Including now running the government.
However without outside aid, paychecks to police officers and etc, civil
servants where none existent. How can Hamas rein terrorist, without the
funds, personal, resources or etc, that any other country would need to
fight the same battle.

Furthermore, for many months now, Israel has not only killed innocent
Palestinians. Without any sort of reprisal or condemnation from the
international community or the US. Per all official records not a single
Israeli has been killed, or even seriously injured by the crude quassam
rockets. So from the start of this year to date, Palestinians have a
much higher civilian death toll.

Beyond the civilian deaths. Israel has recently, just a few days prior
to the Israeli soldier being kidnapped. Conducted secret commando
operations into Palestine to arrest suspected and claimed militants.

How did the Palestinians in Israeli jails get there? When is their trial
dates? What are they charged with? We have less than 1000 combatants in
jail in Cuba. Yet Israel has around 10,000 Palestinians in Jail. With a
considerable number of women and children in jail.

That the US blindly looks at the loss of one soldier on one side is not
going to win the US support in the Arab world. It will only turn more
Arabs against the US. Furthermore Israel has obviously gone way beyond
trying to recover the soldier. On the verge of regime change, and if
they succeed. There will be no government, and who will be left to fight
terrorism in Palestine?

Taking out a US insured Palestinian power plant is totally unjustified.
Yet the US sits by, and allows Israel to do such destruction effecting
hundreds of thousands of Palestinians. Much less one that the US
ultimately will have to pay for. Our economy will have to absorb the
expense with an increase in insurance premiums.

Israel needs to be condemned. The US needs to stop blocking UN actions
that the Arab states are trying to take. For the US to butt it's nose
in, defend Israel or turn a blind eye to their blatant violation of just
about every international law that exists. Going against that of all
other Arabs states is very arrogant.

Much less the Geneva convention. Israel's capture/abduction/arresting,
of Palestinians, and what happens to them afterward. Is 100% a violation
of the Geneva Accords. Not to mention them going after infrastructure,
and now arresting government officials.

This is totally unacceptable. If the US does not react soon, protests
will not only be taking place in the middle east. But here in the US as
well. Those protests will grow in numbers rapidly.

Not to mention what happens now with Palestine will set the playing
field for all future middle eastern events.

The US could amaze every Arab, by condemning Israel's actions. Providing
neutral support to both Israel and Palestine. Give the Palestinians a
fair shot at peace, and controlling their own destinies, on their own
land.

The US could send a clear signal to all other Arabs, and really effect
the avg opinion of the US. By doing what we preach, and supporting human
rights. Condemning state sponsored terrorism. Because hundreds of
thousands of Palestinians are being terrorized now by Israel. Prompted
by the actions of a few radicals, but not limited to effecting just
them. Israel's actions are terrorizing everyone living in the Gaza
strip. 1.4 million people, that is real fear. Much less a few weeks ago
with innocents being killed.

That little girls who's family were shelled on a beach. How do you think
she feels. Terrorized I assure you. Or the children at home with their
pregnant mother, when a missile flies through the wall and kills the
mother, injuring children and other family present in their home.

Or we can continue to support Israel till eventually the reveal the
liability they really are to the US. By dragging us into more wars and
major conflict, the likes of which have never been seen.

Finally Mr. President, you are a religious man. I ask you to pick up
your bible and learn about the Temple Mount. The Jewish people will one
day attempt to rebuild the Temple Mount. Destroying a holy Muslim masque
first. If the US does not change it's relations with Israel but the time
they move on rebuilding the Temple Mount.

Christians, and the US will have to make a choice. Support Jewish people
in a holy war with Muslims. Or finally change our relations with Israel.

Please do not let this escalate.

Mr. President, regardless of your legacy in Iraq or Afghanistan, you
could add you your legacy that you were the first president in 50 years
to finally end and resolve the Israeli-Palestinians conflict. By
bringing true peace and democracy to the middle east, which will spread.

Create a Palestinian state, an every Arab will rejoice.

I also advise someone on your staff to go back and listen to archives of
Henry Kissinger. In his recently released tape recordings. There is one
where he, as a Jewish American, clearly states that the US support of
Israel is unjustified, logically, strategically, natural resource wise,
politically, diplomatically, or etc. Israel is nothing to the US, but a
liability. One we need to reduce, minimize, or be done with. 

Future generations of Americans will not sit idly by and turn a blind
eye to Israel's actions in the Arab world. And not just against
Palestinians. Is the US paying any attention to what the Israeli's are

---------------------------------- 

SOCIAL SECURITY: 
(This is worth reading. It is short and to the point.) 

Perhaps we are asking the wrong questions during election years.

Our Senators and Congresswomen do not pay into Social Security and, of 
course, they do not collect from it. 

You see, Social Security benefits were not suitable for   persons of their 
rare elevation in society .  They felt the  should have a special plan for 
themselves. So, many years ago they voted in their " own" benefit plan. 

In more recent years, no congressperson has felt the need to change it. 
After all, it is a great plan. 

For all practical purposes their plan works like this: 

When they retire, they continue to draw the same pay until they die. 

Except it may increase  from time to time for cost of living adjustments.. 

For example, Senator Byrd and Congressman White and their wives may expect 
to draw $7,800,000.00 (that's Seven Million, Eight-Hundred Thousand 
Dollars), with their wives drawing $275, 000.00 during the last years of 
their lives.

This is calculated on an average life span for each of those two 
Dignitaries. 

Younger Dignitaries  Who retire at an early age, will receive much more 
during the rest of their lives. 

Their cost for this excellent plan is $0.00 . NADA...ZILCH.... 

This little perk they voted for themselves is free to them. You and I pick 
up the tab for this plan . The funds for this fine retirement plan come 
directly from the General Funds; 

" OUR TAX DOLLARS AT WORK "! 

From our own Social Security Plan, which you and I pay (or have paid) 
into,     every payday until we retire (which amount is matched by our 
employer)- we can expect to get an average of $1,000 per month after 
retirement. 

Or, in other words, we would have to collect our average of $1,000 monthly 
benefits for 68 years and one (1) month to equal "Senator" Bill Bradley's 
benefits! 


Social Security could be very good if only one small change were made. 

That change would be to: 


Jerk the Golden Fleece Retirement Plan from under the Senators and 
Congressmen Put them into the Social Security plan with the rest of us 

then sit back..... 

and see how fast they would fix it! 

If enough people receive this, maybe a seed of awareness will be planted 
and maybe good changes will evolve. 

How many people CAN you send this to?


Better yet.. 


How many people WILL you send this to ?


Thank You for your time....Kathryn M. Campbell

  


  

 

 



Sincerely,


Kathryn Campbell
863-452-5359

The governor and mayor should be sacked, yeah verily put on criminal charges of contempt for public safety, and in fact, I would say banishe from the kingdom, so that they never ever are allowed to do that again, when it is indeed their thorough responsibility to do what they are paid to do, in government.
 
And where were your fellow states, with all their strong men and help machines?  You USA ians, have everything, from tanks to planes, to cars, motor cycles, private jets, and golf courses for single individuals such as Mr Trump and his ilk, but noone of yous, turned up to help each other.

Madam:

This past week, three residents on our street have suffered serious
damage to our vehicles from a person or persons speeding through Henry
Avenue between 1:00 and 4:00 AM honking their horn and squealing tires.

violence in retaliation for our efforts to slow down speeding traffic.

that the desperate concerns that I express on behalf of a great many
residents, have simply been handed off back to the local officials in my
city that have failed to respond for a very long time.  

I did not chose to escalate our plea to your level for any reason than
nothing so far here in Tampa has worked!!  Residents continue to gather
in large numbers to ask the City for new traffic engineering in pace
with the growth of our area.  The offending drivers who use Henry Ave as
a cut-through know we have no traffic device, we have far too much
traffic traveling far too fast on our residential street.

Please help me get relief.  We are being threatened and cursed at in
front of our own houses.  Why should this be tolerated?  Will it take
one caring elected official or does someone have to be killed by this
unnecessary traffic and its accompanying hostility?


Cindy Peden

From:	john norton <johnnorton@boardermail.com>
Sent:	Saturday, July 1, 2006 4:38 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush
Subject:	S.3496 Working American Competitiveness Act

Sir,
On June 23, 2006, U.S. Senator Jim DeMint introduced tax legislation called: “Working American Competitiveness Act”.  This somewhat obscure piece of tax legislation only concerns US expatriates earning income abroad.  This Act will replace Section 911 exclusions (which include an $82,400 Foreign Earned Income Exclusion and limited Housing Exclusion) with a total exclusion of federal income taxes for US expatriates on foreign earned income.  This has been hailed by Prosperitas as “good tax policy” and the Heritage Foundation as a means to “boost America’s position in the global economy.” These conclusions are based on surveys of firms that have large numbers of expatriates working abroad; as these firms often must reimburse expatriates for US taxes paid there is a definite self-interest in promoting the passage of this Act.  In reality, it’s bad tax policy, and will provide no boost to America, global or otherwise.
There is an increasing trend to define office not as a desk in a particular place but as a lap-top plugged into an internet connection.  This allows people to run business, and salaried employees to work, wherever internet is available.  What this Act will do is allow any US taxpayer (US Citizen and Resident Alien) to plug the lap-top into any socket located abroad and declare residency in that country.  Once the taxpayer establishes Bona Fide Residency abroad, defined by principle place of work, than he or she can make as many visits or stay as long as wanted in the United States and not pay a penny of taxes, providing that the taxpayer declares that no ‘business’ was conducted in the US.  The taxpayer could be paid from American sources, into an American bank, even have the family continue to live in America, and still not pay any tax on the earned income.  A dream opportunity to avoid US taxes.
This is an example based on 2005 tax figures using standard deduction and exemption: A single taxpayer earning $500,000 of wages or business income, with a private income of $100,000, living in the US would pay federal income taxes of $188,720.  The same taxpayer residing officially abroad, after the passage of this Act, would pay federal income tax of $20,218 – a saving of $168,502.  Varying from state to state in addition to this substantial saving there might be additional savings, and considerable additional savings, by not having to pay state and local income taxes.
The passage of this tax act would be a powerful incentive for high wage earners and businessmen and women to establish Bona Fide Residence abroad, and would certainly cause a considerable dip in tax revenue.  The only economies that would receive a ‘boost’ are tax havens abroad that would readily welcome these ‘tax’ expatriates.  Far from achieving ‘a level playing field’ the passage of the Working American Competitiveness Act could very well have the distinction of being the largest legal tax avoidance scheme ever approved by Congress.
Yours Sincerely,
John Norton
Innsbruck, Austria
johnnorton@boardermail.com


--

From:	Robert Perkis <robertp@icdus.com>
Sent:	Saturday, July 1, 2006 1:23 AM
To:	Governor Jeb Bush; comments@whitehouse.gov; jriley@legalaid.org
Subject:	[*] Florida's manufactured home owners in a vulnerable state

Florida's manufactured home owners in a vulnerable state 
   
The Associated Press 
By ANDREA FANTA 
June 30, 2006 It's just unbelievable what they're putting these people
through Leo Plenski isn't sleeping well.

The 62-year-old Pinellas County retiree has lived in the same 180-acre
mobile home park for 15 years. Recently he received a six-month
eviction notice _ his park closes in November to make way for a new
condo village.

'You got elderly people here that are really stressed out to the
gills,' he said. 'We have heart attacks here on a daily basis. Where
are you going to put these people? They're elderly, they're veterans,
they're on Social Security. I don't know what we're going to do with
them.'

Plenski is one of thousands of mobile home residents statewide who
could eventually find themselves with no place to move as parks close
because their owners can make more money selling to developers.
Combine that with hurricanes and rising insurance costs, and the
pressures on mobile home residents to find another type of housing are
immense.

'We're looking at tomorrow's homeless,' said Jami Ross, a housing
advocate with the nonprofit 1000 Friends of Florida organization. 'I
feel like we're looking at a part of history. Decades from now, the
mobile home lifestyle will have disappeared.'

One problem, housing experts say, is that information about mobile
home owners is scarce _ one researcher called it Florida's
'informational black hole.'

For example, neither state agencies nor nonprofit organizations
serving mobile home owners can even pinpoint how many manufactured
home residents live in Florida. Estimates run anywhere from nearly
532,000 to 1.2 million mobile home units. Census data from 2000 shows
that 10 percent of Floridians live in manufactured housing _ that
would put the number at about 1 million.

Housing experts mostly rely on anecdotal evidence to paint a picture
of Florida's manufactured home dwellers.

Some are snowbirds, retirees who come to Florida and sink considerable
savings into their mobile homes. Many are working poor and disabled
Floridians who can't afford to live anywhere else. Others are elderly
Floridians who live on a fixed income.

These residents face three major pressures, they say.

The first is hurricanes. Last year's storms, most notably Hurricane
Wilma, destroyed nearly 2,000 mobile homes across the state. Residents
living on fixed incomes can't afford to make repairs.

New building codes enacted in 1994 after Hurricane Andrew ensure that
today's mobile homes can withstand 100 mph winds. But nearly 858,000
manufactured home units, or 74 percent of Florida's manufactured
homes, were built pre-Andrew.

The second is insurance, which is becoming impossible to find and very
expensive, said Anthony Pinzone, who's lived on a 211-acre mobile home
park in Sarasota County for the past decade. He and his wife had to
look for another insurer when their former company pulled out of the
Florida market.

'I couldn't find any,' he said. 'It's very expensive and extremely
difficult to find. I was forced to go into Citizens,' the state's
insurer of last resort. His premiums doubled; he now pays about $600 a
year.

The third is park closings. Since 2003, nearly 70 mobile home parks
have closed, according to Florida's department of business regulation.
There are about 5,825 parks.

Those last-standing parks are going to disappear quickly if things
don't change, said Travis Moore, a lobbyist for the Alliance of Park
Residents. As the rush to find undeveloped land in Florida continues,
mobile home parks will become the last frontier.

If mobile home owners have to move, they can get up to $3,000 in
relocation assistance from the state. But not all manufactured housing
is mobile, so some evicted residents who may have paid upward of
$100,000 for stationary manufactured housing lose their investment,
Moore said.

Even if they can afford to move, there's nowhere left to go, said Dave
Bruns, Florida's AARP spokesman.

'Where are they going to go?' he said. 'People are not building more
mobile home parks.'

This is especially hard for elderly residents, Bruns said. Census data
shows about 15 percent of households headed by someone 75 years or
older live in manufactured housing. And, according to AARP, one in
five Floridians 65 years or older lives on a $960 monthly Social
Security payment. After they pay for housing, health care and
groceries, they can't afford to move, Bruns said.

Plus, they suffer psychologically, said Don Hazelton, a retired
attorney and past president of the Florida Federation of Manufactured
Home Owners.

'What they lose is people who can drive, people who'll get their
groceries for them, their medicine for them,' he said. 'They're going
to lose that camaraderie, and I think that's what bothers them the
most.'

Housing experts offers several solutions for protecting manufactured
home living in Florida.

_ Stop the blame game. 'Who's to blame?' Hazelton said. Not the
developer who's doing his job, not the city that wants to attract new
investment and not the mobile park owner who's tired and wants to
sell.

'It's the economics of the day,' he said. 'You can call the developers
greedy, you can call the park owners greedy _ that's not greed, that's
a simple business deal.' Some developers even pay displaced mobile
home owners to help them move. Don't get angry, Hazelton said _ get
creative about statewide solutions.

_ Retrofit homes. This will help bring insurance costs down, said
Nancy Stewart, a lobbyist for the Federation of Manufactured Home
Owners. She helped pass a bill this spring to provide $7.5 million for
manufactured home owners to retrofit their anchors, windows, roofs,
doors and attachments.

_ Allow flexible insurance payments. Part of this bill will also allow
some manufactured home owners to pay their insurance premiums in
installments, making it easier to cope with these costs, Stewart said.

_ Tighten rules surrounding park sales. Moore wants to modify existing
law to require park owners to notify residents every time they get an
offer for their land _ right now, they only have to disclose offers
they solicit. This will give residents more time to form a homeowners
association, match the offer and buy the park themselves, Moore said.

_ Build better cities. In the long-term, building more
transportation-friendly communities with multifamily housing for
seniors will help elderly residents transition into new living
arrangements, Bruns said.

In the meantime, Plenski will look for another home and hope he and
his neighbors have good luck, he said. For them, solutions can't come
too soon.

'It's just unbelievable what they're putting these people through,' he
said. 'There's gotta be a solution.'

End advance

Copyright 2006 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This
material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed. 

Hosted by: Topix.net Publisher Platform (beta)

BobP

|Flag for Review 7 min ago 
What a load of hog wash. Park owners invite people to lease their
land. Often they sell people the home, finance the home, require
expensive additions that tie the home to the land like patio,
driveway, carport or garage, Florida room, etc. When all is paid off
they sell the park to a developer after promising they would never
sell to anyone but another park owner. 

Developers know exactly what they are doing. They are stealing
people's homes. Their only excuse, "If we didn't do it someone else
would." didn't work at Nuremberg and is just as disingenous today.

City attorney's work with developer lawyers to create false legal
opinions as to what twenty year old mobile home law (s723.083) really
means while ignoring the Florida Attorney General's opinion right in
front of them, giving city commissioners plausible denyability when
voting against the well being of their citizens for the supposed good
of the city. It is disgusting watching Florida laws written to protect
mobile home owners trashed by cities and courts so developers can make
more money.

The only honest solution would be to offer low interest no down
payment government loans for mobile home owners to buy their parks or
build low income housing for the express purpose of guaranteeing
housing to people from closing mobile home parks at the rent they were
paying and for local government workers who also can't find housing
like teachers, police, firemen, etc. 

We need to do something or people who bought and paid for housing will
have it stolen due to state ineptitude and Florida citizens will be
responsible for the crime.
